HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Sounds of Summer: W.N.B.A. to Take Center Court

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The behemoth is racing Gary Cavalli's way, dribbling a two-toned basketball. The co-founder and chief executive of the American Basketball League awaits Saturday afternoon's start of the Women's National Basketball Association, which insists that it has come to coexist with the A.B.L., not to bury it.
"In print they say they want both leagues to succeed, and I'll take that at face value," Cavalli said. "I don't want them to bomb. If they do, people will say that even with the N.B.A.'s support, women's basketball can't succeed." 
 By being first, the A.B.L. capitalized on the United States women's team's gold medal victory in the Summer Olympics in Atlanta; the W.N.B.A., in turn, is benefiting from the continued attention on the sport provided by the A.B.L.
"The fact that women's basketball has been in the news for most of the last 10 months is only good for us," said Val Ackerman, the W.N.B.A. president.
Now, by trying to execute a 10-week summer schedule, one that may extend in future seasons, the W.N.B.A. is trying to rewrite the basketball equation. The league wants to shift players from traditional schedules and lure fans, old and new, into arenas during the summer. If the W.N.B.A. succeeds, Commissioner David Stern's Mother Ship will have created a year-round presence.
Despite major differences, the leagues share one common element: all teams are centrally owned and the players are signed and paid by the leagues. There are no team owners, a structure designed to control marketing and costs.
The same single-entity structure of Major League Soccer, which is two years old, was challenged in a Federal lawsuit filed last February by 10 players who charged that the league violated antitrust laws by holding down salaries.
So far, A.B.L. salaries are higher than the W.N.B.A.'s, but the latter offers the promise that some of its players can augment their paychecks by appearing in advertising from its blue-chip sponsors.
The idea of extending the National Basketball Association's reach into the summer -- the W.N.B.A. will start eight days after the N.B.A. finals end -- has been kicked around the league for a decade, but the economic moment had not arrived.
That changed because of several factors: the N.B.A.'s marketing alliance with USA Basketball; the success of the women's national team from 1995 to 1996; the popularity of the college game; the embrace of the sport by Reebok and Nike, which created a shoe named for Sheryl Swoopes, and the Olympic victory.
"By calling it the W.N.B.A., we are putting our brand into play, and at risk at some level," said Rick Welts, the president of N.B.A. Properties and the chief marketer of the women's league.
Now unleashed, the W.N.B.A. comes to the sport nurtured as no new league has ever been, armed with the privileges of the pampered child of the marketing-mad N.B.A.: some of its sponsors, eight of its arenas, and its employees.
Also, General Motors, Lee Jeans, Sears Roebuck, Nike, Reebok, American Express, and Coca-Cola are fortifying its debut.
NBC, ESPN and the Lifetime Network will show 33 games; games will be carried to 150 nations; league ads ran during the N.B.A. playoffs and a Reebok spot starring the New York Liberty's Rebecca Lobo ran during Game 6 of the finals.
Reebok is sponsoring both leagues. "By supporting both, we show that Reebok stands for women's basketball," said Kathy O'Connell, group director of the apparel company's women's sports marketing.
Champion designed the players' uniforms; advertising inserts appeared in Glamour and Self magazines; player profiles ran in major publications; the league mantra, "We Got Next," is catching on with young girls; season previews have run on NBC and ESPN, and Lifetime is eager to make broad use of the W.N.B.A. as the flagship of its fledgling sports division.
Then there is the official ball: orange and off-white, smaller than the N.B.A. and A.B.L. version, but sure to call attention to itself on television.
Ackerman and Welts have no doubts that the June-August season -- avoiding competition for television exposure and advertisers with college and pro basketball and football, and the National Hockey League -- was the only viable strategy.
"When you take into account how deep into the summer the N.B.A. season runs and you look at everything that happens with camps, clinics and summer leagues, summertime and basketball really go together," Ackerman said.
It is also easier to book arena time during the summer, and to use N.B.A. team personnel.
"It's a wonderful time to redefine the best time to play basketball," said Nancy Lieberman-Cline, 38, the doyenne of women's basketball, and a guard for the W.N.B.A.'s Phoenix Mercury. An Olympic silver medalist in 1976, she played in the old Women's Basketball League.
The A.B.L. counters that an October-to-March schedule is more suitable, especially in the eight (now nine, with expansion to Long Beach, Calif.) college basketball-oriented markets that host its teams.
"I wanted to play a regular basketball season," said Jennifer Azzi, a 1996 gold medalist now with the A.B.L.'s San Jose Lasers, "not at a time where you start from the bottom up."
Cavalli said: "We believe women's basketball deserves to have a legitimate season in terms of length and when it's played. It should be the main event, not a subsidiary stuck in the summer for convenience and marketing reasons."
A.B.L. players are barred from playing in European leagues or elsewhere, while the W.N.B.A.'s players are free to play anywhere, even in the A.B.L. The two leagues have similar views of their talent levels: Each believes it has the best players. The A.B.L. boasts it has 7 of the 12 members of the 1996 Summer Olympic team, but the W.N.B.A. crows about having 3 of the 5 starters. The A.B.L. signed college stars like Kate Starbird and Kara Wolters, who will play for the New England Blizzard, and be coached by K. C. Jones, an N.B.A. lifer; the W.N.B.A. has Lobo, Lisa Leslie, Ruthie Bolton-Holifield and Swoopes, and a crop of European players like Yelena Baranova of Russia.
"It's great to have an option but I chose the W.N.B.A. because it's the credible one for the long term," said Pam McGee of the Sacramento Monarchs.
Both leagues have modest attendance goals. The A.B.L. projected a 3,000 average a game last year, and got 3,500, with a 4,200 average last February. It hopes for greater attendance this season, and added a team in Long Beach. But the league lost about $5 million on its partners' $4 million investment.
Cavalli admitted that he must improve the A.B.L.'s sponsor roster and that being carried on SportsChannel's network of regional sports services is inadequate.
"We're spending all our time working on it," he said.
The league is also trying to raise capital by selling investors team-operating agreements -- not franchises -- for up to $3 million to raise capital.
The W.N.B.A. is hoping to average 4,000 fans a game. Each arena will be draped to create sites with no more than 10,647 seats. Optimism abounds, not only from exhibition-game attendance, which was as high as 9,677 in Phoenix, but from the juggernaut of marketing and hype orchestrated by the N.B.A.
"I have no doubt we will see the W.N.B.A. at 50," Lieberman-Cline said.
Azzi is almost as confident about the A.B.L. and likes its more shoestring appeal. "A lot of people thought we wouldn't make it, but we surprised a lot of people, basically with no marketing money," she said.
Still, the suggestion that the W.N.B.A. will swallow the A.B.L. lingers.
"People question our motivation," Welts said. "That's blatantly unfair. Our motivation is this is the right time. We're as transparent as we can get. That's why we're doing this."

(Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-16
 
Turkish Leader Resigns After Military Pressure
Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, the first head of an Islamic party to lead Turkey, yielded to pressure from the military and resigned after nearly a year in power. President Suleyman Demirel did not indicate who he would name as Mr. Erbakan's successor. A1 

Pol Pot Is Said to Surrender
Pol Pot, the leader of the Khmer Rouge, surrendered to former comrades who turned against him, according to a clandestine radio broadcast. It was not clear whether he would be turned over to the Government or the international community and be put on trial for the killings of more than a million Cambodians during his reign of terror from 1975 to 1979. A1
 
Man Charged in C.I.A. Killings
Mir Aimal Kansi, who was seized Sunday by F.B.I. agents in a hotel in Afghanistan, appeared in a courthouse in Fairfax, Va., and was charged with the murder of two C.I.A. agents. Mr. Kansi, who fled the United States four years ago but was eventually captured by a coalition of C.I.A. and F.B.I. agents, Pakistani spies and Afghan warriors, said he did not have money to pay for a lawyer but understood the charges against him. A3
 
Deported Saudi Pleads Guilty
Hani Abdel Rahim Hussein al-Sayegh, a Saudi dissident suspected of having a minor role in the bombing that killed 19 Americans in Dhahran last year, has agreed to plead guilty to charges that he tried to kill Americans in an earlier plot that was never carried out. Mr. Sayegh has said that he would cooperate with United States officials in the investigation of the blast. A3
 
Israeli Cabinet Member Resigns
Finance Minister Dan Meridor quit the Israeli Government in a dispute over exchange rates, angrily asserting that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had deliberately raised the issue to force him out. Mr. Meridor is the second Likud politician to quit the Cabinet. A7
 
Oxford Accepts Huge Gift
Reversing an earlier vote, Oxford University academics have voted overwhelmingly to accept the $32 million gift of Wafic Said, a Saudi billionaire. The gift will be used to build a new business school. The dons had voted against the plans last November because of concerns over the proposed location for the school and questions about the background of the donor, who used his contacts with the Saudi royal family to help Britain win a $1.7 billion arms contract in 1988. (AP)
 
Guerrillas Arrested in Colombia
Five leftist guerrillas were arrested in Colombia in raids carried out after an explosion that killed 8 policemen and injured more than 10 others, authorities said. The National Police said the suspects were known members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, a pro-Cuban group founded in 1964. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A10-14
 
Broad Changes Proposed In Structure of Medicare
The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved sweeping legislation that would modernize Medicare, increase Medicare charges for affluent elderly people, provide new money for health coverage of uninsured children and restore welfare benefits for more than a half-million legal immigrants. A1
 
Disney Boycott Proposed
The Southern Baptist Convention called for a boycott of Walt Disney to protest what it said was the company's accommodation of gay issues and portrayal of violence in its entertainment products. Gay rights and civil liberties groups called the measure an attack on homosexuals and free speech that would fail, while Disney said it was dedicated to providing family entertainment. A10
 
Benefit From Hormone Use
Hormone replacement after menopause can significantly reduce a woman's risk of death as long as she continues it, a study has found. In the first decade of hormone use, the chance of dying was 37 percent lower among women in the study who were using hormones than among women who never took them, primarily because of fewer deaths from heart disease among hormone users. A1
 
Congress Criticizes C.I.A.
The C.I.A. and the rest of the nation's intelligence services do not have "the analytic depth, breadth and expertise to monitor political, military and economic developments worldwide," the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence said. The committee, whose chairman is a former C.I.A. officer, said the services had a largely inexperienced work force that was unfamiliar with the countries they analyzed. A13
 
Tax Compromise Offered
Representative Bill Archer, the chief Republican tax writer in the House, dropped a provision from his tax-cutting bill that has drawn heavy criticism from Democrats, saying he hoped the Clinton Administration would offer a compromise in return and help avert partisan warfare over the legislation. A13
 
Speaker Outlines Program
Speaker Newt Gingrich sketched out a 10-point program to promote racial healing and black achievement in the first clear-cut Republican response to President Clinton's recent speech on race relations. Mr. Gingrich said his program relied more on specific steps and less on theory, talk and affirmative action. A12
 
Charges in Drug Case
Two wealthy San Francisco interior decorators, who lived in an expensive house with a view of the Golden Gate Bridge, owed their success to the Cali drug cartel in Colombia, Federal prosecutors charged. They said the two men had financed a lavish life style by laundering more than $30 million for the Cali cartel by converting narcotics money into artwork and furniture. A10
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-9
 
Judge Orders Family Courts To Remain Open to Public
New York State's Family Courts, which handle some of the system's most private and wrenching cases, from custody fights to crimes committed by children, should routinely be open to the public and news organizations, the state's Chief Judge said. Judges will still have the discretion to close cases under the new rules, but only for compelling and specific reasons, like insuring the privacy of a child who was the victim of sexual abuse. A1
 
One Times Square Sold
One Times Square, the skinny tower that is an international landmark and home to the New Year's Eve ball drop for nearly a century, is being sold to German investors for four times the price paid by Lehman Brothers a little more than two years ago. The building is vacant and, aside from a possible theme restaurant in its base, is likely to remain mostly empty, serving as little more than a gigantic billboard. A1
 
Helmsley to Sell Holdings
Leona Helmsley said she intended to sell most or perhaps all of her hotels, office buildings, apartment houses and other properties, valued at close to $5 billion. Mrs. Helmsley's decision comes amid a bitter falling out with business associates of her deceased husband, Harry Helmsley, who accumulated the real estate holdings over five decades of investing in which he was widely regarded as one of the shrewdest deal makers in the industry. B1
 
EDITORIAL A22-23
 
Editorials: Outlawing Islam; the endangered bookshop; Mr. Clinton's F.E.C. fold; good early returns for interleague play.
 
Columns: Frank Rich, Thomas L. Friedman.
 
SPORTS B13-20
 
Yankees Take Series
Tino Martinez broke an 0-for-21 slump to hit a game-winning single in the 10th inning, giving the Yankees a 3-2 win over the Mets and the decisive third game of the first Subway Series in 40 years. B13
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-20
 
AT&T Merger Opposed
The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is expected to declare that merging the AT&T Corporation with a Bell telephone company would be "unthinkable" under antitrust laws. AT&T has been discussing a $50 billion merger with SBC Communications, the largest of the nation's six regional Bell companies, according to executives familiar with the talks D1

Broadway Record to Fall
"Cats" is poised to pass "A Chorus Line" as the longest-running show in Broadway history, with 6,138 performances. The musical, which opened at the Winter Garden theater on Oct. 7, 1982, has been an audience favorite, seen by more than 8 million people in New York. A1

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 579 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Stocks Fall, Dragging Market Lower
Technology stocks plunged after Seagate Technology and Gateway 2000 again said they expected earnings growth to slow and because of news that Intel planned to cut prices on its Pentium computer chips.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 10.68 points, to 1,432.43. The Dow industrials were also pulled lower, losing 42.07 points to close at 7,718.71. [Page D8.] 

Fed Sees Some Weakness
All 12 districts monitored by the Federal Reserve showed economic expansion in May and early June, but "pockets of weakness" have emerged, the Fed said in its survey known as the beige book. [D4.]
 
Bond prices rose as investors saw the Fed's survey as further reducing the chances of an interest-rate increase. The yield on the 30-year Treasury fell to 6.68 percent from 6.71. [D18.]
 
Lockheed Gets Ally in Fighter Bid
British Aerospace joined Lockheed Martin in its competition with Boeing to build the United States military's next-generation fighter aircraft, for which Lockheed Martin has developed an early proposal (above). [D4.]
 
Westinghouse Shifts Breakup Plan
In a big change in its plan to break up into two companies, Westinghouse said that its Thermo-King refrigerated transport business would join the media concern to be formed, not the industrial group. [D4.]
 
Gold Price Defies Expectations
The world economy is set to grow at its fastest pace in almost a decade and currency markets are jittery. So gold, that age-old hedge against inflation and uncertainty, must be rising, right? Not a chance. Its price has dropped 6.8 percent this year. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Boycott of Disney Is Sought
The Southern Baptist Convention called for a boycott of Disney, saying that the creators of Mickey Mouse and an animated Snow White had gone astray, profiting from a liberated Ellen and offering health benefits to employees' homosexual partners. [A18.]
 
Helmsley to Sell Real Estate
Leona Helmsley said that she intended to sell most or perhaps all of the real estate empire, valued at close to $5 billion, that was built by her now deceased husband, Harry B. Helmsley. [B1.]
 
Big Profit Seen for Lehman
Lehman Brothers, which paid $27.5 million for One Times Square two years ago, is selling the building for about $110 million, people familiar with the negotiations say. [A1.]
 
South African Miner Plans Spinoff
The South African mining company Gencor said it would spin off its base metals, minerals and coal units and acquire control of an Australian nickel refiner, QNI. [D20.]
 
Contender for Accounting Board
With the Financial Accounting Standards Board chairman's term about to expire, the choice of a replacement is up in the air. Robert K. Elliott, a partner at KPMG Peat Marwick, is said to be the leading candidate. [D2.]
 
Shareholders Discuss Digital
Digital Equipment shareholders held a rump session in Manhattan to examine the prospects of the troubled computer maker, but it was unclear what concerted action, if any, the group would take. [C4.]
 
Compuserve Loss Widens
Compuserve said that its quarterly loss deepened as the number of subscribers in the United States fell sharply. [D20.]
 
S.E.C. in Court on Its Rules
The S.E.C. obtained an order against a British Virgin Islands mutual fund in an effort to clarify a rule on selling stock overseas without registering it in this country. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Pataki Assails 'Vile Remarks' On Black City University Trustee

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 18

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and his aides today assailed a Democratic lawmaker who questioned the qualifications of the black educator he nominated for the City University of New York's board of trustees and claimed the Governor's choice amounted to racial pandering.
The administration's criticisms focused on comments made by Emanuel R. Gold, a Democratic Senator from Queens. During a vote on Tuesday to confirm the nominee, Kenneth E. Cook, Mr. Gold strongly suggested that the Governor nominated Mr. Cook solely because of his race, not his qualifications. The nomination of Mr. Cook, a retired junior high school teacher, was ultimately approved by the Republican-dominated Senate. 
 Mr. Gold made it clear that he and other members of the Democratic minority in the State Senate wanted the board to have more black representation. But speaking on the Senate floor before the vote, he added that "it is an insult to the Afro-American community to say we'll put somebody on the board that has a dark face regardless of intellect and that ought to shut up the community."
The Pataki administration went on the offensive today, distributing transcripts of Mr. Gold's comments to reporters and quickly arranging a news conference that was attended by about two dozen black, female and disabled members of the administration. Ranging from high-ranking officials to low-level bureaucrats, they denounced the Senator.
"We take it personally," said Randy Daniels, a senior vice president for economic revitalization at the Empire State Development Corporation who is black. "We understand what attacks on the intelligence of black people historically have meant in this country."
At a news conference later in the day, Mr. Gold refused to apologize and stressed that he meant no offense. He was flanked by seven black Democratic senators who defended him, saying he had merely echoed their concerns. Mr. Gold and his colleagues said they were deeply troubled that Mr. Cook was unable to answer the most basic questions about City University during confirmation hearings, such as how many students and campuses are in the system. "We were talking about his qualifications," said Alton R. Waldon Jr., a black Senator from Queens.
The administration released a letter that Mr. Pataki sent to Mr. Gold. "I was shocked and appalled by your vile remarks on the Senate floor," he wrote. "You have set a new low for public discourse in the State Legislature."

HEADLINE: Let a Wiser Writer Amend His Epitaph;
Errata and Incongruities At Isaac Bashevis Singer's Grave

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
What writer has not suffered the indignity of a typo? But for Isaac Bashevis Singer, this particular typo was the ultimate indignity: It was on his gravestone.
To some of his friends it was a cruel insult, a mistake set in stone. Others saw it as a comic absurdity, one that would have certainly been appreciated by Singer himself. His widow, like an antic Singer character afloat in her own world, was willing to let it pass. 
 But yesterday, nearly six years after the death of the Yiddish writer who won the 1978 Nobel Prize for Literature, a monument engraver finally corrected Singer's honorific. Singer at last is a "Nobel" laureate, and no longer a "Noble" one, as his stone has proclaimed since 1992.
The correction brought to an end not only the unintended pun but also a saga of love and abandonment that was, in essence, Singer's longest and last short story.
"Isaac would have enjoyed the irony," said Eve Friedman, the co-author with Singer of the play "Teibele and Her Demon." "But there was something kind of sad about it. Isaac in that stone was the butt of a joke."
The typo was one of several unfortunate leitmotifs in the tale surrounding Singer's final resting place. Another was his son's anger over the site of his father's grave: why did the author of "Gimpel the Fool," who wrote such farcical stories about the ambiguities of sex and death, end up buried in suburban New Jersey, in a tree-bordered but casually kept grave site within view of an encroaching subdivision? Yet another was the family's incredulity that Singer, described by his son as a "Jewish Casanova," was laid to rest three gravestones away from the man, Walter Wassermann, from whom he stole his second wife. That woman, Alma Singer, who died in 1996, now lies next to Singer, but within feet of Mr. Wassermann -- a woman buried between her first and second husbands.
If this were a Singer short story ("The Reencounter" comes to mind), Walter and Isaac would continue to glare at each other in death, through the yew bushes. "They hardly got along in life, so it's kind of ironic that they're neighbors in death," said Alma Singer's grandson, Stephen R. Dujack, who, like the rest of the family, first noticed the proximity of the graves at what he called Singer's 1991 "funeral from hell."
(When the Singer limousine was departing the Beth-El cemetery in Paramus, N.J., it was stopped at the gate for nonpayment of the plot. Mr. Dujack offered his credit card, but Beth-El did not take Visa; Mrs. Singer had to write out a check for $3,026 on the spot.)
The typo was discovered a year later, in the summer of 1992, at the unveiling of the gravestone in Beth-El before family and friends. Roger Straus, a founder of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, Singer's publisher, was horrified, and immediately pulled Mrs. Singer aside. "I said 'This is awful, what are we going to do?' " he recalled. Mrs. Singer responded, he said, that "Noble" was "an acceptable alternative."
At that, Mr. Straus said, "I thought it was time to go for lunch."
The story really begins in a Catskills resort. The then-Alma Wassermann, a stylish, self-absorbed, 30-year-old refugee born in Germany, was married to Walter Wassermann, a wealthy businessman. They had two young children. The family had recently fled Nazi Germany and settled in Washington Heights in Upper Manhattan. In the summer of 1937, they took their first American vacation at a farm in Mountaindale, N.Y. Nearby was Green Fields, a colony of Jewish writers, where Singer, 33, the son of a Warsaw rabbi and himself a recent immigrant, was staying.
Mrs. Wassermann and Singer became friends, and went for long walks with her children. The relationship continued in the city, in clandestine meetings at the New York Public Library, and grew into a romance. By 1940, Mrs. Wassermann had left her husband, who had grown withdrawn and morose, as well as Inge, 10, and Klaus, 6, to marry Singer. The newlyweds settled in Brooklyn. Inge and Klaus remained in Washington Heights, to be raised by their father and housekeepers.
"I just felt that I had to spend the rest of my life with him and therefore I had to give up my marriage and my children," Alma Singer later told Janet Hadda, the author of "Isaac Bashevis Singer: A Life," a new biography. Mrs. Singer called it "a very difficult and, really, a very terrible decision to make."
Alma's daughter, Inge, never forgave her -- a mother-daughter chasm that is a large part of the story behind Singer's grave. Inge grew up, married Raymond Dujack, now an economist, and settled in the small New Jersey town of Emerson.
In 1964 Inge's father, Mr. Wassermann, died. Inge, who had always loved the nearby Beth-El Cemetery, bought four plots near a tree, and buried her father in one. In 1990, Inge died of cancer at 60 and was buried in front of her father. Her mother, who by this time had been married for half a century to Singer, had not come to see her daughter during her illness. Inge was instead cared for by her friend and next-door neighbor, Leah Feingold.
The following year, Singer was dead. Mrs. Singer, searching for a suitable plot, called Mrs. Feingold, knowing she had been her daughter's friend and knowing that Mrs. Feingold lived close to Beth-El. Would Mrs. Feingold, she asked, select a nice plot for Isaac? And one where there would be room someday for her, too?
"She said she wanted it as close to Inge as possible," Mrs. Feingold said. "She had a lot of guilt about her daughter. A lot of guilt."
So Mrs. Feingold found the grave for the Nobel laureate, which was just three stones away from Walter Wassermann, Alma's ex-husband. "Alma didn't care about that," Mrs. Feingold said.
A miserable time was had by all at the funeral. Israel Zamir, Singer's son from a common-law marriage in Poland, could not fit in the single, crowded limousine and had to beg a ride to his father's burial. In his book, "Journey to My Father," Mr. Zamir wrote that the "Godforsaken place would attract no one," but that if Singer had been buried in Israel, the grave would have been the destination of pilgrimages.
At the unveiling the following year, the family found the "Noble" typo -- and two others on the smaller footstone marking Singer's grave. There, Nobel was spelled wrong, and worse, at least in Mrs. Singer's view, the "h" had been dropped from her husband's middle name.
Mrs. Singer complained to Shastone Memorial Corp. in Great Neck, N.Y., the company that had made the stones. Shastone retorted that Mrs. Singer had specified both the "Noble" and "Basevis" spelling in her original instructions , and produced documents showing her signed approval of blueprints of the stones, with all three mistakes.
"We told her the spelling of Nobel was incorrect," said Arnold Haskel, who was then the owner of Shastone. "She said, 'Do it as I gave it to you.' "
After much mutual fingerpointing, Shastone replaced the footstone with a corrected one in June 1993, at a cost of $430 to the Singer family. (The original is now just inside the door in Shastone's Great Neck showroom, in a place of honor.) "Noble" on the big stone stayed as it was.
Over the years, the mistake gnawed at the family. In 1996, after Alma died, Susan Dujack, Alma's granddaughter and an heir to the estate, called a lawyer. Soon Shastone said they could make the change -- for $625, which Israel Zamir would pay for -- but not without the approval of the two other heirs, Steven Dujack, Alma's grandson, and Klaus Wassermann, Inge's brother. Mr. Wassermann quickly said yes, but Mr. Dujack balked.
"Alma had chosen not to change it," Mr. Dujack said. "Why should I interfere with history? It had happened."
Mr. Dujack then spoke to Ms. Friedman, who reasoned with him. "Isaac," she told him, "would never want his dignity punctured to make a point about humanity."
That settled it. Yesterday in Beth-El, under an overcast sky, a monument engraver, Reed Frankel, knelt near the scruffy crabgrass that edges Singer's grave, and carefully drilled away the past. "I don't want to make a correction," said Mr. Frankel. "I want to make it look like it wasn't a correction. "
Would Singer be amused or annoyed by the fuss? A clue may lie in "The Reencounter."
"Of all my disenchantments," a dead character says, "immortality is the greatest."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Embroidery Industry Loan

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK

 BODY:
Last fall, the state announced a nine-point plan to gird Hudson County's $300-million-a-year embroidery industry against cheaper oversees competitors. Yesterday, the State Economic Development Authority announced the first low-cost loan under the plan.
The $2.1 million privately financed loan will allow Carolace Embroidery of Ridgefield to expand its West New York operation, said Nicole Esposito, a spokeswoman for the agency. 
 The expansion will create 17 new jobs in order to fill a large order from a retailer, Fabri-Centers of America, Ms. Esposito said. The county's embroidery industry, which employs 4,000 people, accounts for 70 percent of the domestic market, but sales have dropped 20 percent in the last 15 years.

HEADLINE: Diverse Strategies Offered As Response to President

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich, in a speech to the Orphan Foundation of America, outlined 10 steps tonight to improve race relations in the United States. They are excerpted from his prepared text.
1. LEARNING -- Create better opportunities for all children to learn by breaking the stranglehold of the teachers' unions and giving urban parents the financial opportunity to choose the public, private, or parochial school that's best for their children. 
 2. SMALL BUSINESS -- Set a goal of tripling the number of minority-owned small businesses by bringing successful small-business leaders together to identify -- and then eliminate -- the government-imposed barriers to entrepreneurship.
3. URBAN RENEWAL -- Create 100 Renewal Communities in impoverished areas through targeted, pro-growth tax benefits, regulatory relief, low-income scholarships, savings accounts, brownfields clean-up, and home-ownership opportunities.
4. CIVIL RIGHTS -- Clear the existing backlog of discrimination cases at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission by enforcing existing civil rights laws, rather than trying to create new ones by regulatory decree.
5. EQUAL OPPORTUNITY -- Make America a country with equal opportunity for all and special privilege for none by treating all individuals as equals before the law and doing away with quotas, preferences and set-asides in Government contracts, hiring, and university admissions.
6. RACIAL CLASSIFICATION -- Break down rigid classifications. A first step could be to add a "multiracial" category to the census and other government forms to begin to phase out the outdated, divisive, and rigid classification of Americans as "blacks" or "whites" or other single races. Ultimately, our goal is to have one classification -- American.
7. HOME OWNERSHIP -- Ease the path toward home ownership by giving local communities and housing authorities the flexibility and authority to more effectively and efficiently house low-income Americans. We must also expand faith-based charities such as Habitat for Humanity, which grow families as well as build homes.
8. VIOLENT CRIME -- Make our cities safe and secure places to live and work through community policing, tougher sentences for violent criminals, and innovative anti-crime programs. Dramatically expand the community-based anti-drug coalition efforts and create a victory plan for the war on drugs.
9. ECONOMIC GROWTH -- Expand economic opportunities for all Americans by promoting continued economic growth with low inflation and rising take-home pay, through tax cuts, tax simplifications, litigation reform, less regulation and overhaul of the burden of government on small business. All in all, for welfare-to-work to be successful, work needs to be available.
10. WELFARE REFORM -- Take the next step in welfare reform by fostering and promoting innovative local job training, welfare-to-work, and entry-level employment programs to move welfare recipients into the work force.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Trade Gap Below Forecasts Helps Dollar Rise Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday on news of a narrower-than-expected trade deficit in April but fell in most other foreign exchange dealings as the mark and pound rallied.
The Commerce Department's report showing an $8.36 billion shortfall in trade was less than the $10 billion widely forecast, and the gap with Japan widened only marginally. 
 Traders bought dollars on the assumption that the deficit would not emerge as a contentious issue at a meeting of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations, which begins today in Denver.
There had been fears that a major deterioration in the United States trade imbalance might make Washington take steps to push the dollar lower, which would raise the price of Japanese imports and help narrow the shortfall.
"There's less chance now of official rhetoric between U.S. and Japan officials using the dollar as a tool," said Robert Gilmartin, a dollar-yen trader at the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 114.30 yen on the trade data before settling in New York at 113.98 yen, up from 113.65 yen Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.7237 marks, down from 1.7333. The pound cost $1.6488, up from $1.6388 and the highest level in a month.
The dollar initially rallied against the yen and mark on the trade data, but traders said the Japanese currency's broad weakness also helped create the basis for a rally in the mark against the yen. As the German currency kept climbing against the yen that set off more mark buying for yen and helped indirectly weaken the dollar against the mark.
"What we really had was a case of the mark strengthening, not the dollar weakening," said Jan Alvarez, senior foreign exchange trader at the Corestates Bank in Philadelphia.
The pound's surge largely reflected a consumer spending boom in Britain, raising the probability of further interest-rate increases by the Bank of England to suppress demand and reduce inflationary pressure. The broadest measure of Britain's money supply rose sharply in May to an annual expansion rate of 11.1 percent, well above the 9 percent maximum in the central bank's target range.

HEADLINE: France's Premier Says Shaky Finances Put a Brake on Jobs Plan

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 19

 BODY:
France's Prime Minister told Parliament today that the country's precarious finances would force him to move cautiously on the job-creation programs he promised during the election campaign last month.
Making his first policy speech in Parliament and asking for a vote of confidence from his leftist coalition majority, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, a Socialist, reaffirmed the intention of France to join the common European currency when it begins in 1999. He said nothing, however, about whether the country would meet the strict limits on budget deficits set for the currency. 
 "The first indications given to me lead me to think that public finances are in a serious state," he said.
Newspapers here reported today that the budget deficit by the end of this year might be as high as 3.8 percent of France's gross domestic product. That would be well above the 3 percent ceiling called for in the European Union Treaty that established the currency project.
Foreign diplomats who heard the speech today said they feared that Mr. Jospin's proposals would set back France even further in its efforts to satisfy criteria for the common currency.
During his campaign, Mr. Jospin said that his first priority would be doing something about the 12.8 percent unemployment rate, not tightening budgetary screws to suit European central bankers. Today he again promised to put jobs first, but told legislators that he would report back to them on the new Government's budget plans only after a more thorough review of the state of the country's finances.
Another campaign pledge, reducing the workweek to 35 hours, from 39, would also take time, he said -- possibly even five years, the term of the new legislature.
As an immediate small step to stimulate economic demand in France, Mr. Jospin announced today that the Government would raise the minimum wage by 4 percent on July 1 to the equivalent of $6.76 an hour.
Mr. Jospin also said that he would call a national jobs conference in September and that the first of the 700,000 jobs for young people he promised during his campaign would be created then.
He promised to raise French Government spending on culture to 1 percent of the budget, and said that the policy of his conservative predecessor as Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, of not hiring replacements for all retiring Government workers, a deficit-cutting measure criticized by public service unions, would be halted immediately.
He even announced that 35,000 people would be hired to help the police patrol the streets and improve public safety, as great a concern in French cities as it is in the United States.
In one major break with French tradition, Mr. Jospin proposed limiting family allowances, payments from public funds to people rich and poor depending on how many children they have. Under his proposal, allowances would go only to families with an income below $50,000 a year, provoking cries of protest in the chamber from opposition conservatives.
Mr. Jospin also said he would not reverse a conservative decision last year to end the French military draft.
But in a major break with conservative policy, he said the new Government would undo changes in French immigration laws that made it difficult for children of foreign immigrants born on French soil to claim citizenship.

HEADLINE: Europeans Have Long Agreed to Disagree

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire ("Waiting for Euro," column, June 18) ridicules the decision-making process of the European Union by citing the contradictory pronouncements of the participants in the Amsterdam summit meeting. 
 Nobody knows whether the euro, the common currency, will come or not, whether it will be strong or weak, whether it will be beneficial or not. However, the habit of putting contradictory positions into agreements is as old as the European Union itself.
The Common Market treaty, which came into force in 1957, stipulated free international trade and the protection of agriculture at the same time, two mutually incompatible aims. The European Union has nevertheless lived with this contradiction for 40 years and has become so successful that it has grown from 6 to 15 members, with a waiting list for more countries to be admitted.
The Common Market was forced together by the threat of the Soviet Union and by the economic preponderance of the United States. Now, as the European Union, it will be condemned to success by global competition.
 
PHIL-HEINER RANDERMANN
Southampton, N.Y., June 18, 1997
 
The writer was in charge of European Community trade policy in West Germany's Foreign Office from 1979 to 1987.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise Unexpected 8,000

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The number of Americans applying for state unemployment insurance rose a surprising 8,000 in the week ending last Saturday to a seasonally adjusted level of 347,000, the Labor Department said today.
The increase in claims was the opposite of analysts' expectations for an 8,000 decline and reflected a continuing moderation in the nation's labor markets. Though employment growth remains robust in the second quarter, economists say it has lost some forward momentum from earlier in the year. 
 Jobless claims, which rose an unrevised 1,000 in the previous week, now stand at the highest level since the May 3 week. The four-week moving average -- a closely watched barometer of labor market conditions -- is also at the highest level since early May. It rose 6,250 in the latest week to 335,5000.

HEADLINE: Nation's Trade Deficit Rose 7.8% in April

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

 BODY:
The nation's foreign trade deficit rose 7.8 percent in April, calling new attention to trade tensions with Japan and China as President Clinton and other world leaders gathered yesterday for a summit meeting in Denver.
The Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit in goods and services increased to $8.4 billion in April from a revised $7.8 billion in March. Economists said the biggest surprise was that American exports kept growing at a record pace in April, keeping the deficit from swelling more. 
 But the latest numbers also showed that America's trade balances with Japan and China "just keep deteriorating," said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at First Union Corporation.
President Clinton was expected to bring up the trade frictions with the Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, and other leaders in discussions this weekend.
The tensions with Japan over trade had eased in 1995 and the first half of 1996, but they have returned in recent months as the Japanese have started pouring out exports again, bolstered by a weaker yen, to rev up their economy.
America's deficit with Japan, the difference in the value of imports and exports, increased 5.1 percent in April to $4.8 billion, the highest monthly total since last October, the Commerce Department said.
That also was America's highest deficit with any country, with China following not far behind. The United States' trade gap with China jumped 33.3 percent in April to $3.5 billion from $2.6 billion in March.
In fact, Japan and China have alternated recently at the top of the list of countries that have a surplus in trade with the United States, and in April about 60 percent of the total deficit in goods and services came from trade with those two countries.
"That really brings the whole problem into focus," Mr. Naroff said. "Yeah, we have a trade deficit. But we basically have a trade deficit with two countries."
The rise in the deficit with Japan has led to renewed calls from Washington that it open its markets further to American goods and services. The sharp increase in the deficit with China is likely to give ammunition to some in Congress who oppose renewing its status as a most-favored trading partner.
While Americans bought $51.5 billion of Chinese goods last year, they sold just $12 billion worth of products to China, meaning there was a $39.5 billion deficit. Some analysts believe this deficit could top $50 billion in 1997.
Still, economists said there was some good news in yesterday's Commerce Department report. In most other parts of the world, American exports "are back in force," said Michael P. Niemira, a vice president and senior economist at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York. He said that reflected a strength in American manufacturing and "basically a pretty good picture for the economy."
Total exports of goods and services had surged in March to a record $78.2 billion, and some analysts thought that might cap several years worth of growth. But exports edged up even more in April, by two-tenths of 1 percent, to $78.4 billion.
That offset some of an expected nine-tenths of 1 percent rise in imports, which climbed to $86.7 billion as Americans bought more computer parts, toys, apparel and pharmaceuticals from overseas. Declining oil prices, the lowest in a year, also helped restrain the increase in the value of imports even as the volume of oil imports jumped by 6.8 percent.
Still, Mr. Niemira cautioned that the growth in exports could slow soon. He said his bank's surveys of trade executives showed that they had been expecting only gradual gains, and not the sharp pickup that occurred in March and April.
One other improvement in April came in North American trade, the Commerce Department report showed. While the United States continued to run deficits with Canada and Mexico, both narrowed, buoyed by strong export sales.
The deficit with Canada declined by 26.3 percent, to $970 million, the lowest in two years. The gap with Mexico dropped by 5 percent, to $1.4 billion.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department also announced that the overall current account deficit, which includes trade in goods and services as well as flows of investment capital, totaled $148.2 billion in 1996. That was down from an earlier estimate of $165.1 billion. But it was also the second-largest gap ever, after $168.1 billion in 1987.
The department also said that by this measure, the broadest way to account for foreign trade, the deficit totaled $41 billion in the first quarter of 1997. That compared with a revised total of $36.9 billion in the fourth quarter of 1996.

HEADLINE: Willard Hurst, 86, Legal Scholar And Pioneer in History of Law

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
J. Willard Hurst, professor emeritus of the University of Wisconsin Law School and internationally recognized as the dean of American legal historians, died on Wednesday at his home in Madison, Wis. He was 86.
The cause was cancer of the larynx, said his wife, Frances. 
 In linking law and social history in his studies, Professor Hurst broke with a school of thought in which law was regarded as a self-contained society and the law library as its laboratory. How the law actually affected people or how legal institutions evolved was ignored in favor of the study of appellate decisions, according to that thought.
In 1937, after clerking at the Supreme Court, he joined the Wisconsin law school faculty and was urged to create a program in law and society, to examine the cross-pollination between Wisconsin's legal system and economy. In the 20-year study that laid the base for his seminal work, "Law and Economic Growth," published in 1964, Professor Hurst focused on the state's lumber industry.
His work illuminated the underlying social and economic forces involved in the exploitation of the state's forests and determined how the industry both used and shaped laws of property, contracts, banking, transportation, accident compensation and other relationships.
"Willard Hurst is renowned in this country and abroad as the founder of the field of legal history," said Shirley Abrahamson, the Chief Justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court and a former student.
James Willard Hurst was born in Rockford, Ill. He received a bachelor's degree in 1932 from Williams College and a law degree in 1935 from Harvard University, where he graduated at the top of his class and edited The Harvard Law Review.
He then became a research fellow for Felix Frankfurter, a professor at Harvard at the time and later Justice of the Supreme Court, and in 1936 became a clerk for Justice Louis D. Brandeis.
In 1967, Professor Hurst received a master's degree from Cambridge University, where he was the Pitt Professor of American History and Institutions and fellow of Trinity Hall in 1967-68. He was also a visiting professor at Northwestern University, Stanford University, the University of Utah and the University of Florida. He retired in 1980.
Besides contributing to law reviews and other publications, Professor Hurst wrote over a dozen books, among them "The Law Makers" (1950), "Law and the Conditions of Freedom" (1956), "Law and Social Process in U.S. History" (1960), "Justice Holmes on Legal History" (1964) and "A Legal History of Money in the United States" (1973).
He is survived by his wife, the former Frances Wilson; a son, Thomas Robert, a professor of law at the University of Florida; a daughter, Dr. Deborah Hurst of Berkeley, Calif., and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Price of 30-Year Bond Edges Up as Yield Stays at 6.68%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities bounced around yesterday in choppy trading before finishing slightly higher. The market fell early in the day on fears that signs of strength in the economy would lead to inflation, but it later recovered.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 3/32 , to 99 11/32 , keeping the yield at 6.68 percent, unchanged from Wednesday. 
 Among the reports that alarmed investors early was one from the Philadelphia branch of the Federal Reserve. The bank's manufacturing survey, one of the earliest indicators of the economy's state in June, suggested a pickup in business activity, with its index rising to 25.2 points from 1.6 in May.
But counteracting the effects of that number was a report showing that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose somewhat unexpectedly in the latest week, by 8,000, to 347,000. Together with some other recent numbers, that suggested a possible moderation in the labor market, which had been gaining strength.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the economic statistics released this week solidified the case for no change in interest rates when the Fed's Open Market Committee meets in early July.
"Without question, it would be difficult for the Fed to tighten pre-emptively while inflation is still declining and aggregate demand shows signs of slackening," Mr. Fine said. He pointed to other recent reports -- including one showing weakness in housing starts during May and one showing strength in industrial production last month -- as painting an unclear picture.
Further readings on the economy will be provided by a smattering of statistics next week as the F.O.M.C. meeting approaches.
Some analysts said they thought the bond market was at or near the top of its current range. But Mr. Fine saw positive signs for the future.
For example, he pointed to the widening of the United States trade deficit, reported yesterday, which added further evidence that the gap for the year will be bigger than the Federal budget deficit. That implies that foreign buyers, whose purchases of Treasury bonds are included in the trade balance, have been active buyers in the market and will continue to bolster it, he said.
At the Treasury's auction of $13 billion in new one-year bills yesterday, the average rate at auction was 5.35 percent, down from 5.55 percent last month and the lowest since 5.34 percent on Jan. 30. Next week, the Treasury will auction new two- and five-year notes. In when-issued trading ahead of those sales, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.01 percent, and the five year at a price to yield 6.28 percent.
With rates the lowest in months, debt issuance is up. The Philippine central bank yesterday priced $500 million in bonds through Salomon Brothers. It is the first international bond sale by the Philippines. Two months ago it tried unsuccessfully to sell a larger amount, $1.25 billion, but borrowing rates are now lower, making it less costly for the Philippines to come to market.
Taking advantage of declining rates, the central bank sold $400 million of 30-year bonds at a price to yield 8.609 percent, or 184.9-hundredths of a percentage point more than a 30-year United States Treasury bond. It also sold $100 million of a 100-year bond at a price to yield 8.735 percent, or 197.5-hundredths more than a long United States Treasury bond.

HEADLINE: Stocks Regain Steam as Dow Jumps 58.35

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market roared back to life yesterday, sending all the major indexes back into record territory.
After suffering through a technology selloff on Wednesday, investors surged back into the market and went on a late afternoon buying spree. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average overcame a slow start to gain 58.35 points and close at 7,777.06, just five points off its record high.
And the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 14.71 points, or 1 percent, to close at a record 1,447.14.
Early in the day, there were some renewed concerns about inflation after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said that factory production in its region had risen for the sixth consecutive month in June.
But investors, increasingly confident about an economy that is strong but not yet inflationary, were not discouraged for long.
"We're a very resilient market," said Larry Wachtel, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "There's so much money coming in that even when stocks break, there's a tendency to buy them back. And in the final analysis, a bull market doesn't stop cold in its tracks."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, with more than 537 million shares trading hands. And winners outnumbered losers by better than 2 to 1.
Since mid-April, the market has been soothed by good news about inflation and falling interest rates. As a result, stock prices have surged, with investors pouring billions of dollars into stock mutual funds.
And unlike July 1996, when technology stocks suffered huge losses after several companies warned of slowing earnings, this year the sector has been able to bounce back strongly from similar warnings.
Yesterday, the Morgan Stanley high tech index rose 5.48 points, or 1.1 percent, to 436.16. A day earlier, the market had slumped on news that Seagate Technology, among others, was forecasting slower growth.
Among the technology issues gaining yesterday were Cisco Systems, up 2 points, to 69, and Tellabs Inc., up 3 7/8, to 56 7/8. Shares of Tellabs, which makes voice and data transport and network systems, are up 51 percent this year.
The market also benefited from strong tobacco shares, which rose on expectations that there could be a settlement regarding health-related lawsuits. Some investors believe that could relieve the industry of some of the uncertainty surrounding future profits.
RJR Nabisco, whose subsidiary produces Camel cigarettes, rose 1 3/8, to 35 7/8. Philip Morris, the nation's leading cigarette maker, rose 1 1/2, to 47 1/2, a 52-week high.
But the day's best performers were drug stocks. The American Stock Exchange pharmaceuticals index soared nearly 3 percent yesterday, well ahead of the market, to 476.53.
Merck, a Dow component stock, rose 3 3/8, to 99 3/4. Pfizer was up 4 1/8, to 112 1/2. And Warner-Lambert surged 6 7/8, to 112 3/4. The Dow was led by Procter & Gamble, which rose 3 3/8, to 142 1/8.
William Paternotte, a market analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, said that investors continued to favor blue chips over smaller company stocks, largely because the multinational companies have had superior earnings performance this year.
"Those stocks are already highly valued compared to the rest of the market," he said. "But money keeps pouring into them."

HEADLINE: Golden Arches Are Victorious, But Bloodied, in a British Court

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 19

 BODY:
McDonald's has had more than its fair share of grief lately: hamburger sales are down, hackers are spreading nasty tales through the Internet, and the company's 55-cent burger campaign in its native United States fell flat.
Today the company had some good news. After the longest trial in British history, a judge in a libel case ruled that McDonald's does not destroy the world's rain forests, discriminate against employees or poison its customers. 
 But the $96,000 judgment the judge issued, after the company had spent millions in legal fees to defend its reputation, was a decidedly Pyrrhic victory.
After two and a half years of testimony, the judge agreed with the claim of two anti-McDonald's activists that the company is cruel to animals, that it exploited children in its advertising and that its low wages in Britain tended to depress salaries in the fast-food industry.
The case, which came to be known as the McLibel trial, was undoubtedly something of a nadir in the hamburger chain's public relations history.
The defendants, Helen Steel and Dave Morris, were respectively a part-time bartender and an unemployed ex-mailman, and the sight of the multi-billion dollar corporation hauling them into court provoked innumerable stories about Goliath taking on David.
Ms. Steel and Mr. Morris were sued for libel after they helped distribute a detailed pamphlet attacking McDonald's some eight years ago.
In summarizing his exhaustive decision, which filled three hefty volumes, Justice Rodger Bell said that while some of the defendants' assertions -- touching on everything from the sorry living conditions of the company's future Chicken McNuggets to the fat and salt content of a Big Mac and fries -- were true, the preponderance were, in fact, false.
Accordingly, he said, Mr. Morris and Ms. Steel had harmed the reputation of the McDonald's chain and were liable for the damages.
McDonald's said today that it was "broadly satisfied" with the judgment.
"For the sake of our employees and our customers, we wanted to show these serious allegations to be false, and I am pleased that we have done so," said Paul Preston, chairman and chief executive of McDonald's in Britain.
But Michael Mansfield, a lawyer who has been advising Ms. Steel and Mr. Morris, called the result "a major victory" for the defendants, who are known in the anti-McDonald's movement as the McLibel 2.
"They have dared to tread where no others have dared to tread, where those with resources have not dared to go, to raise issues that matter to us all," Mr. Mansfield said, speaking of Mr. Morris and Ms. Steel at a raucous news conference attended by many people waving signs saying things like "We will not be silenced."
The case dates to the late 1980's, when Ms. Steel joined London Greenpeace, an informal group that campaigns for a range of social issues and is not connected to the international Greenpeace organization. In 1989 and 1990, London Greenpeace distributed the pamphlet in question, "What's Wrong with McDonald's," which made seven broad charges against the company.
McDonald's, which is well-known for being fiercely protective of its reputation, was decidedly displeased and sued five members of the groupfor libel. Three said they were sorry and would not do it again; Mr. Morris and Ms. Steel decided to fight on.
The trial began in June 1994, with McDonald's represented by a top-drawer lawyer in wig and gown, and Mr. Morris and Ms. Steel representing themselves, in jeans and sweat shirts.
Under British law, the burden of proof is on the defendants to show that their statements are true. This meant that Mr. Morris and Ms. Steel had to call experts in nutrition, in deforestation and in employment practices, among other things, in an effort to prove the veracity of even the most far-reaching generalizations in their pamphlet.
With no legal experience and no free time, the defendants held strategy meetings on the subway each day and turned to a motley group of vegetarians, environmentalists, libertarians and animal-rights campaigners around the world for both moral and substantive support.
An anti-McDonald's site was set up on the World Wide Web, so that an expanded version of the pamphlet that so upset McDonald's became available to anyone with a computer and a modem.
By the end of the case, the court had heard from 180 witnesses, sat for 313 days over two and a half years and generated 60,000 pages of transcripts and other documents.
At a news conference, Mr. Preston said that McDonald's had "no intention of bankrupting" Mr. Morris or Ms. Steel by demanding the $96,000 if the two could not afford to pay it. And, when asked whether he thought McDonald's reputation had been hurt by the case and the attendant publicity, Mr. Preston said he did not.
"I think our reputation is valuable," he said, "and it is something you must be willing to stand up and protect."

HEADLINE: In Denver for Economic Talks, Clinton Calls for Freer Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: LITTLETON, Colo., June 19

 BODY:
On the eve of an economic summit meeting of eight nations in Denver, President Clinton chided critics of his free-trade policies in a speech in this suburb today and called on Congress to give him greater flexibility in negotiating trade agreements with Latin American countries like Argentina, Brazil and Chile.
He also urged Congress not to revoke China's trading privileges with the United States, in a vote on its so-called most favored nation status that is scheduled for next week. 
 Basking in the strength of the United States economy, Mr. Clinton ticked off a series of rosy economic indicators that he said demonstrated the virtue of his policies. He swatted aside criticism of free trade, which is heard from such influential members of his own party as the House minority leader, Representative Richard Gephardt of Missouri.
"Protectionism is simply not an option because globalization is irreversible," Mr. Clinton said. "If we try to close up our economy, we will only hurt ourselves."
He added: "It seems to me difficult to imagine that this is even a serious debate now."
Mr. Clinton arrived in Denver today to serve as host for the "Summit of the Eight," the international conference known as the Group of Seven before Russia this year was admitted to all but one of the meetings.
In a bid for support for his China trade policy, Mr. Clinton sent a letter today to Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, in which he pledged to increase broadcasts into China by the Voice of America and Radio Free Asia. He said that he would seek to have the broadcasts extended to 24 hours a day, and diversified to include more dialects to reach more Chinese.
Tonight, another influential conservative, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said tonight that he would support retaining China's trade status.
"We must recognize free trade as a basic human right," Mr. Armey said in a speech at Johns Hopkins University's School for Advanced International Studies in Washington. He said he would like to oppose China's trading privilege to express his "deep repugnance" for Beijing, but that trade relations offer "the best prospect for liberating" the Chinese.
Mr. Clinton hailed Denver today as an avatar of American economic transformation, calling it a city that "once drew its wealth from mine shafts and factories and the land," but was now "thriving on telecommunications, aerospace, banking, computer software, and the magnificence of its environment."
To underscore his point, Mr. Clinton spoke before a crowd of hundreds seated in a baking parking lot outside the National Digital Television Center, which beams movies and other programs to satellites for cable systems around the country. Behind him stood a a thicket of satellite dishes, tilted skyward and ranging in size from that of a large pizza to 30 feet. To the west, the jagged Rockies gleamed white in the sun.
Mr. Clinton made a pitch for so-called "fast track authority," saying it would allow him to "go and negotiate a trade agreement with Chile or with Argentina or with Brazil." Congress would then have to vote for or against the treaty, but would be unable to amend it. Latin American nations have said they would refuse to negotiate if Congress had the power to reopen agreements after the Administration finished talking.
"We have nothing to fear from these countries," Mr. Clinton continued. "They are our partners in democracy. They are our partners in opportunity."
On the subject of trading disputes with another major partner, Mr. Clinton said today that the Administration had made progress in long-running negotiations over how Japan would deregulate important sectors of its economy, including telecommunications and medical equipment.
Today the two nations agreed to would meet more frequently on how the Japanese would deregulate those specific areas of their market. Mr. Clinton's aides said that American officials would have an advisory role in the Japanese deregulation. But before meeting with Mr. Clinton here this afternoon, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan rejected that view, saying the Americans would have no "advisory role."
"We have no intention of being supervised," he said. But Administration officials said later that during his meeting with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Hashimoto said he would welcome American advice.
Dan Tarullo, the Assistant to the President for International Economics, said that during the meeting Mr. Clinton "voiced quite specific concerns" about the rising American trade deficit with Japan.
While he repeatedly touted the American economy as the world's leader today, President Clinton acknowledged that in some ways, the United States lagged behind.
"To be fair, a lot of countries have more generous benefits for child care than we do," he said. "They cover all their children with health care, and we're going to cover half of those without insurance in this budget agreement. And I won't rest until we finish the job."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Whoever Came to Bat, Interleague Play Proved a Big Hit

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Stan Javier hit three home runs against American League pitchers after not having hit a home run all season against National League pitchers. Rickey Henderson and Tony Phillips each hit a home run playing designated hitter in one of the first games involving the N.L. and the d.h. In a game in which A.L. pitchers had to hit, Matt Stairs batted for a pitcher in the seventh inning, got a hit, stayed in the game and stroked two more hits.
But the long anticipated batting game of "can you top this" between Barry Bonds and Ken Griffey Jr. was a dud. 
 Three sellout crowds saw the Yankees play a scintillating series against the Mets. Chicago fans belatedly woke up, filled the stands twice and were equally enthralled watching the White Sox and the Cubs. The Pittsburgh Pirates experienced a 115 percent increase in their average attendance. But the Minnesota Twins and the San Diego Padres fell embarrassingly flat in their quest for economic and esthetic riches.
Major League Baseball's first attempt at interleague play did not deliver 100 percent of what it promised, but is 98 percent so bad?
It even enabled history to be made. In the Wednesday night game between the Anaheim Angels and the Dodgers in Los Angeles, two Japanese pitchers were in a game at the same time for the first time in a major league game in the United States. Hideo Nomo had started for the Dodgers and was still in the game when Shigetoshi Hasegawa relieved for the Angels in the sixth inning.
The only real blight on the interleague landscape cropped up in Milwaukee, where Bud Selig, owner of the Brewers and acting commissioner, tried to imitate Nolan Ryan but flung the ceremonial first ball somewhere in the direction of Green Bay instead of home plate.
"When I was 15 or 16," Selig said by telephone from Milwaukee yesterday, "I knew if I was going to have a career in baseball, it wasn't going to be on the field."
The Brewers, however, overcame Selig's foray into fantasy land, swept the St. Louis Cardinals and drew nearly double the average number of fans for each game as they had attracted for those mundane intraleague games.
Of all of the figures that emerged from the first round of interleague games, the most dramatic was attendance. The 84 games drew 2,933,407, an average of 34,922 that was 35 percent over the average of 25,851 for all previous games.
The Seattle Mariners drew the most fans, 208,387 for four games, while the Yankees had the highest average, 56,240, for their three games with the Mets.
"This is good for the game and good for New York especially," said Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' general manager, who was delighted with the experience despite his team's two losses. "Look at the crowds, look at the enthusiasm. Baseball in New York was hit harder by the strike than just about any other city. People here love their baseball. A lot of people felt betrayed. They want to come back to baseball. They want to love the game. This series certainly hasn't hurt that."
Chicago fans were slow in embracing the all-city series at Comiskey Park. One theory was that the fans resented the White Sox attempt to shove a multigame ticket package at them. In the end, though, they could not stay away and filled Comiskey for the last two games.
Most stunning, though, was the reception interleague play received in Pittsburgh, where 108,536 turned out for three games with the Kansas City Royals. A common explanation was that the fans went to see two former Pirates, Jay Bell and Jeff King. But countering that view was the one that said the fans didn't go to Three Rivers Stadium to see Bell and King when they were there as Pirates.
Only two teams, the Twins and the Padres, drew crowds that averaged fewer fans than the pre-interleague attendance.
Speaking of the Twins' average of 15,530 for their series with the Pirates, Terry Ryan, the team's general manager, said: "I'm going to attribute that to a lot of the uncertainty of the future of this club in this market. It's not who we played, it's not interleague play. I don't know if we had brought the Cubs or the Cardinals here it would have been any different. I thought we'd be in the 20's, but it didn't happen. People don't know if we're going to be here or not. People are thinking we're a lame duck franchise."
But when the Twins played in Houston, Ryan added, "There was a different energy to our club. Our players enjoyed it."
Two players, Bonds and Griffey, were unable to produce the fireworks expected when the Giants played the Seattle Mariners twice in San Francisco. They each got one hit in each game and did not hit a home run or drive in a run between them.
A Bonds teammate, on the other other hand, produced enough for both of them. Javier had not hit a homer in 129 at-bats this season and only two in 403 at-bats this season and last, but he hit three in 21 times at bat in six interleague games.
On the first day of the interleague schedule, Henderson, the d.h., for San Diego, and Phillips, the d.h. for Anaheim, each hit a home run. Last Tuesday, with the Athletics playing in San Diego and their pitchers hitting, Stairs batted for Dane Johnson in the seventh inning and singled. He remained in the game as the right fielder and added two singles in the nine-inning game.
The hottest hitter in the week-long span of games was Rusty Greer of Texas, who batted .591. Mike Piazza of Los Angeles took advantage of the d.h. rule to rest his weary catcher's body for a couple of games, found his bat rejuvenated and hit .542. King drove in the most runs, 12, and tied Eric Karros, Piazza's teammate, for most homers with four. Mike Stanton, the Yankees' reliever, emerged with the most victories, two.
American League teams won 48 games, the National 36. More games were played at A.L. parks, but A.L. teams prevailed in N.L. parks, too, winning 20 of 38 games. The outcome of East and West Division games was close, 16-14 for the A.L. East and 13-11 for the A.L. West, but the A.L. Central clobbered its N.L. brethern, 19-11.
A.L. designated hitters outhit their N.L. counterparts, .253 to .238, and N.L. pitchers outhit the neophyte A.L. pitchers, .169 to .108.
Omar Olivares of Detroit had the most productive game among A.L. hitting pitchers, rapping a triple and a single against Montreal. But he lost that game. When he pitched against Florida, he didn't bat because the game was in Detroit, and he won.
Probably the greatest indignity suffered because of the N.L.'s use of the d.h. was the 1-0 decision Jimmy Key and the Baltimore Orioles lost to the Expos. The run was a home run by Sherman Obando, the Expos' designated hitter. The outcome also made the Orioles a series loser at home for the first time this season.
Win or lose, it seemed, players enjoyed the experience.
"I know there are some valid arguments against interleague play," David Cone said, "but as a player you have to love facing the best players in the other league, the best players in baseball. It was tremendously exciting to be able to go to Miami and face Gary Sheffield. To be able to face Todd Hundley or John Olerud again, is such a unique opportunity."
Don Baylor, the Colorado manager, said he saw a lot baseballs going back and forth. "Guys were signing balls for each other," he said. "It's good where guys admire guys who play in the other league and never get a chance to see them play."
