HEADLINE: U.S., Lauding Its Economy, Finds No Summit Followers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 19

 BODY:
It may not be polite to gloat about your good fortune in front of your guests. Nonetheless, as President Clinton and his economic team prepare to open the annual summit meeting of major industrial nations, which starts here on Friday, they just cannot resist.
"We host our partners at a time when America's economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world," Mr. Clinton said today. He boasted of "a new American approach" to managing the economy, a strategy that he maintained "enabled us to move earlier and more strongly than most other nations into the new global economy." 
 Others in his Administration are using even stronger language. The Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, described the United States the other day as "the world's only economic superpower" -- a proclamation that grates on Japanese ears -- and "the world's most flexible and dynamic economy." He suggested that other nations "have things to learn from us."
Perhaps so, but the lessons of the American boom of the 1990's are not exactly resonating around the globe. While the leaders arriving here this afternoon may envy the recent performance of the United States economy, few of them are rushing to emulate all the elements of Mr. Clinton's "American approach," which he spelled out in a speech today. [Page A10.]
In fact, the unstated message from the Denver summit meeting may be quite the opposite: The French already made their views quite clear in elections this month, rejecting the deficit cutting, the corporate downsizing and the thinning of social safety nets that were all key elements of the rebound Mr. Clinton is touting here.
Now all of Europe is debating whether it can tolerate the kind of austerity and corporate bloodletting that the world's financial markets increasingly demand around the world -- and that they richly rewarded here.
"Just a few months ago the consensus among the world's leaders seemed to be that there was a right way to guide your economy, and it looked like the American way," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International and a veteran of the delicate pirouettes that countries perform at these meetings to create the illusion of common strategy.
"The consensus that we thought was universal among leaders turns out not to be shared by voters," Mr. Hormats said. "We are coming to the limits of the political acceptance of these approaches."
Mr. Clinton alluded to that quandary this afternoon, declaring: "Now, all the countries in the world face the same choices we do. They're having to decide, can they reduce their deficit and still invest in their people, can they target people programs, can they maintain a social safety net."
Clearly Mr. Clinton intends to use this meeting to push them along. He announced a mini-program with Japan to send American experts to advise Tokyo on deregulating key segments of its economy -- though Japanese officials bridled today at suggestions that they needed American advisers.
The President also argued today that other nations had to break out of what he called "old thinking" about the trade-offs between deficit reduction and spending on worker retraining and other social investments.
But the fact is that none of the leaders of those nations -- with the possible exception of Tony Blair, the new British Prime Minister -- seem eager to sit still for such lectures.
While the jobless rate in the United States shrank to 4.8 percent last month, unemployment in Germany is over 11 percent, and it is over 12 percent in France and Italy. Russia's economy, whose condition is always impossible to measure accurately, appears to have actually shrunk in the last six months. And the economic policy makers in all those countries point out that precisely the factors that make the United States economy so dynamic -- the globalization of businesses, rapid-fire technological innovation, brutal cost cutting -- are the same forces that create enormous insecurity in the workforces accustomed to stability.
"I think there is a sense around the world that the steps that worked in America do not easily translate into other cultures," said Park Ungsuh, the president of the Samsung Economic Research Institute, which is owned by the South Korean electronics giant.
Dr. Park, who is a frequent economic adviser to President Kim Young Sam, noted that as South Korea has struggled with its own competitive woes in recent years, it may have looked to the United States but not adopted many of its solutions wholesale.
"South Koreans would not stand for that kind of economic instability," he said.
Or as one senior European Union official said recently, "It's a bit arrogant of the Americans to assume that what works in Illinois will work in Frankfurt."
Clearly there is plenty for Mr. Clinton to celebrate: the lowest unemployment in a quarter-century, the best inflation numbers in almost as long. That alone changes the dynamics of this meeting.
Summit conferences were rarely happy events for Washington in the late 1980's and early 90's. The Japanese usually delivered a stock lecture about the evils of large budget deficits, which they said pushed up interest rates and dragged down America's trading partners. "When I first came to Washington, what you'd hear at summit meetings is that we were yesterday's economy," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin noted the other day.
During the review of American economic conditions that is part of every summit meeting, Mr. Rubin plans to make the point that this year the Federal budget deficit may drop to 1 percent of gross domestic product. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan will be arriving with one of the largest deficits: nearly 7 percent of the country's G.D.P., what Japan's Government spokesman called the other day "a record budget deficit" that seems likely to force a 10 percent reduction in the country's foreign aid budget, among other cuts.
So will the United States be dusting off some of the old lectures it received so often at past meetings?
"I'm tempted," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers said the other day, "very, very tempted."
Perhaps the most interesting encounters will be between Mr. Clinton and the leaders of the European Union, whose leaders have spent the week in Amsterdam trying to patch up differences with the French that are making their single currency project look more fragile than ever.
The new French Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, a Socialist, came to office pledging to create 350,000 state-financed jobs, to cut the workweek to 35 hours from 39 without a commensurate loss of pay, and to resist the sale of state-owned companies, which would presumably shrink once they were privatized.
All of those run counter to the American model of cutting deficits to free up capital for entrepreneurship, venture capital and new technology. To paper over the differences with France, the European Union on Monday came up with some vague wording about job creation.
Even Germany, the economic disciplinarian of Europe, attempted a bookkeeping gimmick -- revaluing its gold supplies -- to keep from making painful budget cuts needed to meet the requirements of joining the European Monetary Union. That failed, and now Germany's embattled Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, is facing such a political crisis at home that he is taking the rare step of not showing up at the Denver meeting.
None of this will break out into the open, of course. The economic communique was precooked weeks ago, stuffed with the usual bland pronouncements that create the illusion of unanimity.
Mr. Rubin has made it clear several times this week that the United States plans to stay out of Europe's debate over the euro.
But in the private meetings that take place on the fringes of the summit talks, there will probably be some subtle reminders that the markets would punish countries that waver from the deficit-cutting path. Hardly a week passes without seeing Mr. Rubin make the point that the markets surged in the United States in response to "a deficit-reduction plan that investors came to view as very serious."
The question looming over this conference is whether the retreat from Mr. Rubin's prescriptions is a fundamental change, or just a temporary setback.
"There are people in every country, our own included, who want to turn their backs on reality," Mr. Rubin said. "But we're talking here about fundamental pressures, fundamental movements that no country can insulate itself from.
"The real lesson is that if you don't have the fiscal discipline you need, you pay a price. That message may take a long while for people to understand."

HEADLINE: Whitman and Legislators Plan $16.8 Billion Budget

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 19

 BODY:
After three years of cutting taxes and reining in government spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Republican legislative leaders agreed today on a $16.8 billion election-year budget that increases spending for public schools, state colleges, child protection workers and municipalities struggling to pay for school construction projects.
In contrast to last year's budget, which included cuts at almost every state agency, the new budget would increase spending by more than a half-billion dollars. The total is $260 million more than the proposed budget that Governor Whitman unveiled in January, in which she included additional money for more than a dozen modest initiatives attractive to Democratic and swing voters, like increasing the number of openings for children in state-subsidized day care. 
 The boom on Wall Street and a thriving state economy are largely responsible for making the new spending possible. The state expects at least $600 million more than anticipated in January from tax revenues pouring into the state's coffers. The Whitman administration was also able to win legislative approval earlier this month for its pension borrowing proposal, which allows the state to skip this year's $590 million scheduled pension payment.
Once the plan to borrow $2.75 billion for the pension system was passed, there was little wrangling during the budget negotiations between the Governor's staff and the Republican-controlled Legislature. The budget for the new fiscal year, starting July 1, is expected to be signed into law next week, while the New York State budget is more than two months overdue.
Under the agreement, the new New Jersey budget meets the State Supreme Court's order last month that the state spend $246 million more to end the disparity between the state's poorest and richest school districts. This is in addition to the $286 million increase in school spending that was included in the Governor's proposed budget in January.
The extra tax revenues and the pension borrowing also helped provide more money than Governor Whitman had originally budgeted for state colleges, school construction and the troubled State Division of Youth and Family Services.
To keep down threatened college tuition increases, the new budget includes $29 million more for community colleges and state colleges and universities. The Legislature added $25 million to help school districts pay off their loans on construction projects and $18 million to hire 175 workers to improve the monitoring of cases involving allegations of child abuse and neglect.
State lawmakers predicted earlier this week that the new budget would reach $17 billion. But Republican leaders and Governor Whitman rejected several other spending proposals, including a $55 million plan to provide new child-care tax credits to about 150,000 middle-class families, out of concern that they would jeopardize their standing as fiscal conservatives with voters.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (92%); NEW YORK, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Affordable Apartments Open Way for Financing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 33-story mixed-income apartment tower rising on a plot running from 42d to 43d Street between 10th and 11th Avenues underscores both the city's hearty rental market and continued developer interest in the so-called "80-20" method of tax-exempt financing, in which some apartments are leased to low-income tenants.
When completed by year's end, the building, whose entrance will be at 530 West 43d Street, will have 375 studio to two-bedroom apartments. It will also have 3,700 square feet of ground-level retail space fronting 42d Street. 
 Eighty percent of the rentals, averaging 400 to 950 square feet, will be leased at market rates. The remaining 20 percent will be made available to tenants whose annual income is $14,000 to $24,500, depending on family size. The $55 million project is being developed by the Gotham Organization, which is based in Manhattan. It owns the building through a subsidiary in partnership with the housing arm of Sun America, the Los Angeles insurer. It marks Gotham's return to building market-rate housing after a seven-year absence.
Gotham bought the vacant midblock site, which extends from 43d Street through to 42d Street and was once the location of a piano factory, in 1994 from a subsidiary of Chemical Bank. Gotham paid $2.5 million, which David L. Picket, its executive vice president, said "makes the economics of the project work." But he said his company waited until financing opened up to build it.
In return for keeping 20 percent of the rentals affordable to low-income tenants, the city or state issues tax-exempt bonds to provide permanent financing to builders, who are also eligible for a 20-year property-tax abatement from the city.
The program remains a primary financing vehicle, indicating the reliance of new construction on public benefits.
"The market is stronger and hotter and financing has loosened up to an extent," said Alan H. Wiener, chairman of American Property Financing, a lending and real estate consulting firm in Manhattan. "But the reliance on this program has not abated because on large sites in areas that have not seen development in a number of years lenders won't go in without the abatement and tax-exempting financing."
Gotham's project received $55 million in bond financing from the city's Housing Development Corporation. The developer also secured a letter of credit from Fleet Bank and Dime Savings Bank -- a requirement of the program to protect bond holders against default. Gotham and Sun also financed $18 million internally. This is the third mixed-income rental Gotham has built in Manhattan.
With the economy and housing market strengthening and with the 42nd Street redevelopment taking place, it is also a good time to build, Mr. Picket said.
Those factors, along with the availability of development sites, has helped restart the area's revival, which began in the last decade but was halted by the recession. Seven residential projects, many conceived during the mid-80's building boom but never built and now rekindled by new owners, are under way or planned in the area. The projects could produce a total of 3,200 apartments, many of them mixed-income rentals, according to data from Community Board 4, which guides the neighborhood's growth.
"There is no question the Clinton area is being developed," said JoAnn Macy, chairwoman of Community Board 4. "What we've always been interested in is controlled growth and encouraging housing for a mix of incomes, ages and professions, which Clinton has always had."
Despite the competition "there are no signs demand for rentals is not there," Mr. Picket said.
Rents continue to rise, said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage firm in Manhattan. In a preliminary midyear market survey, her firm estimates that average rents for all sizes of apartments on the Upper East and West Sides rose by 6.64 percent since the end of 1996. For example, the average rent for two-bedroom apartments in 24-hour doorman buildings in the two neighborhoods is $3,738.
"This rise is being reflected throughout the Manhattan rental market," Ms. Packes said.
Gotham's building, designed by the Manhattan firm of Schuman Lichenstein Claman & Efron, will have a masonry facade with a granite and limestone base. Stephen Alton Architects is designing the common areas in the building where the apartments will have floor-to-ceiling windows. Planned amenities include a health club, children's play area and a sun deck.
Monthly rents for the market-rate apartments have not been set. But Mr. Picket said they would be competitive to those in the area, which Feathered Nest put at $1,350 for studios to $2,800 for two-bedroom apartments. Rents for the low-income units will be about $303 to $496. Leasing will begin in December, Mr. Picket said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The building going up at 530 West 43d Street will have 375 apartments, 20 percent of which will be set aside for low-income tenants. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Trade Deficit Grows, But Exports Stay Strong
The trade deficit rose 7.8 percent in April, calling new attention to tensions with Japan and China as world leaders gathered for a summit meeting in Denver, left. 
 But economists said they were surprised by a continuing surge in exports, which kept the deficit from swelling more. [Page D4.]
 
Indeed, President Clinton focused on the importance of exports in a speech, chiding critics of his free-trade policies and asking Congress to give him more flexibility in trade negotiations with Latin America. [A10.]
 
In preparing for the meeting, the President and his economic team have been unable to resist gloating about America's good fortune. But few other countries are rushing to emulate the United States' approach. [A1.]
 
Murdoch in Sports Investment
Fox Sports Net, a joint venture of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and Liberty Media, is expected to invest $850 million for 40 percent of Rainbow Programming, a holding company controlled by Cablevision Systems that owns the New York Knicks and Rangers and a number of cable channels. [B12.]
 
SBC to Take Big Charges
SBC Communications said that it would take charges of up to $2.3 billion in 1997 in connection with its purchase of Pacific Telesis as the company pares its operations. [D3.]

Unisys Chief to Depart
Unisys said James A. Unruh, its chairman and chief executive since 1990, would step down, paving the way for new management at the struggling computer company. [D3.]
 
LVMH Raises Grand Met Stake
LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods company, spent $1.31 billion to increase its stake in Grand Metropolitan to 6.3 percent in another attempt to thwart the British food and drinks company's merger with Guinness. [D4.]

Concerns About a Tobacco Deal
As negotiators declared that a settlement in the tobacco talks appeared imminent, the White House grew more concerned that the costs of signing a deal with the industry might outweigh the political benefits. [A1.]
 
McDonald's Wins British Libel Case
McDonald's won the long-running "McLibel" case in Britain when a judge ruled that the company did not destroy rain forests, discriminate against employees or poison its customers. [A1.]
 
Court Sides With U.S. Over Alaska
The Supreme Court declared that the Federal Government owns ecologically fragile offshore areas along Alaska's coast, preventing Alaska from going ahead with plans to drill there for oil and natural gas. [A14.]
 
Stocks Return
To Record Territory
Stocks bounced back, with all major indexes at or near records. The Dow industrials overcame a slow start to gain 58.35 points and close at 7,777.06, just 5 points off their record high. And the Nasdaq composite rose 14.71 points to close at a record 1,447.14. [D8.]
 
Talks on TV Ratings Break Off
Negotiators for the television industry broke off talks with parent advocacy groups that are seeking changes in the TV ratings system, after Vice President Al Gore issued a statement supporting the position of the advocacy groups. [A13.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Award for McDonald's In British Libel Suit
The longest trial in British history ended with McDonald's winning a $96,000 judgment against two activists who helped distribute a pamphlet denouncing the company's practices. But the judge agreed with the claim of the activists that the company is cruel to animals, exploited children in its advertising and that its low wages tended to depress salaries in the fast-food industry. A1
 
British Tories Elect New Leader
William Hague, an opponent of British membership in a European monetary union, became the leader of the Conservative Party after defeating Kenneth Clarke in the third round of balloting of the 164 Tory members of Parliament. Mr. Hague, 36, is the youngest person in over 200 years to lead the party. A8 

Budget Worries French Leftist
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, in his first policy speech in France's Parliament, said the country's precarious finances might slow his progress on putting jobs before deficit reduction. Mr. Jospin, a Socialist, reaffirmed his intentions of joining the common European currency. A7
 
Clinton Praises Trade Policies
President Clinton chided critics of his free trade policies in a speech given on the eve of an economic summit meeting of eight nations in Denver. Mr. Clinton called on Congress to give him greater leeway in reaching trade accords with Latin American countries and not to revoke China's trading privileges with the United States in a vote next week. A10
 
Execution Draws Mexico's Ire
The execution in Texas of a Mexican citizen convicted of murdering an American motorist drew criticism from the Government of Mexico and protests from several groups. Thirty-three other Mexican citizens are on death row in 10 states. A6
 
Ban Relaxed on Ivory Sales
A worldwide ban on the sale of ivory has been eased to give Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe the opportunity to sell some of their stockpile of ivory. The three southern African countries have healthy, growing elephant populations but little money to take care of them. A3
 
No Apology in South Africa
The head of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, said he had no intention of apologizing for his remarks questioning the credibility of former President F. W. de Klerk's testimony before the panel. Mr. de Klerk, the leader of the National Party, said he would ask the courts to stop the panel's inquiry on the grounds that commission officials were biased against him. A3
 
Cambodia Rumors Unconfirmed
First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh of Cambodia said he had new information that Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader, was ready to surrender to former comrades, who are said to have him trapped. A5

Medicare Plans in Senate Face Mounting Opposition
Senate efforts to revolutionize Medicare and protect its finances encountered pained silence from House Republicans and withering attacks from Democrats. On both sides of the Capitol, high-ranking Congressional aides said the central elements of the plan -- to raise the Medicare eligibility age to 67 from 65 and increase payments by the well-off elderly -- were unlikely to become law. A1

The White House grew increasingly concerned that the costs of signing a deal with the unpopular cigarette industry may far outweigh the political benefits even as negotiators declared that a settlement appeared imminent. A1
 
Court Upholds Redistricting
The Supreme Court upheld a court-ordered redistricting plan that left Georgia with only one black majority Congressional district instead of the two that the Justice Department said was required by the Voting Rights Act and the Court's own precedents. A14
 
The Federal Government won a complete victory in the Court in an 18-year-long boundary dispute with Alaska over control of offshore areas along the state's Arctic coast that are both ecologically fragile and rich in oil and gas deposits. The Court's declaration that the United States owns the entire area in question forecloses Alaska from carrying out its plans to drill there for oil and natural gas. A14
 
Senate Revises Tax Bill
The Senate Finance Committee changed its tax-cutting bill substantially, making concessions to members of both parties on their priority issues. The committee agreed to add $8 billion in new funding for children's health insurance by raising the tax on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack. A16
 
Study Ties Virus to Cancer
Scientists have linked an AIDS-associated virus with a common blood cancer -- a surprising finding that is likely to intensify the hunt for viruses as causes of cancer. A23
 
AIDS Guidelines Issued
New Federal AIDS treatment guidelines detail when patients infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, should be started on the demanding and expensive three-drug cocktail that has been successful in suppressing the disease in thousands of patients. A23
 
New Allegations in Killing
Dexter Scott King said he now believes that President Lyndon B. Johnson must have been part of a military and governmental conspiracy to kill his father, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In a television interview, Mr. King suggested that the Army and Federal intelligence agencies were involved in the assassination in Memphis on April 4, 1968. SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: In Election Year, Debate Rages Over Using Public Money for City Ads

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
As the television camera glides through the picture-perfect streets of New York City, the voice of the actor Tony Roberts makes some very familiar points.
"There's never been a better time to find more motivated workers, to find safe neighborhoods to work and live in, or clean parks to play in," he says. "In a city that's the world's banking, arts and entertainment capital, with streets now safer than in any other major city in America." 
 It sounds like one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign advertisements, which are scheduled to begin running on television next week. But, in fact, the commercial was placed last week by the city's Economic Development Corporation -- not to re-elect the Mayor but to lure businesses to the city. It cost the taxpayers $1 million.
The advertisement never mentions the Mayor and doesn't use his voice. It does, however, work to create the same glowing picture of the city that Mr. Giuliani regularly invokes in his campaign appearances.
A separate radio commercial that was first broadcast this week links the Mayor in a far more explicit way to the new Metrocard free transfer between buses and subways that is to begin on July 4. That advertisement, which was written by the Mayor and features him speaking for a full minute, was placed by the Economic Development Corporation and the city's Department of Transportation. It cost the public $200,000.
"New Yorkers have a lot to celebrate these days, and come this Fourth of July, we'll have even more," the Mayor says in the advertisement. "Independence from two-fare zones. Free transfers. Free ferries. One city, one fare. I'm Rudy Giuliani." One of those phrases, "One city, one fare," sounds very much like the Mayor's old campaign slogan, "One city, one standard."
The Giuliani administration was not actually involved in developing the free transfer, but the city has agreed to spend about $35 million to subsidize transfers from private bus lines in Queens and from the Staten Island Ferry -- both in boroughs crucial to the Mayor's re-election.
The use of public money to directly or indirectly promote the Mayor's accomplishments during a re-election campaign drew criticism yesterday from his leading opponent and from two civic groups that monitor the often porous wall separating the political from the governmental.
Ruth W. Messinger, the leading Democratic challenger for mayor, issued a statement attacking the advertisements as "Radio Free Rudy," making it clear that she considered them political. "The timing of the ads right in the middle of the campaign just doesn't pass the ethical smell test, " said Leland Jones, her spokesman.
The leaders of Common Cause New York and the New York Public Interest Research Group wrote a joint letter to Deputy Mayor Randy M. Mastro yesterday, urging that the advertisements either be pulled or be paid for with campaign funds.
Mr. Giuliani defended the advertisements yesterday as having an "appropriate governmental purpose," and said they were similar to actions by other mayors. The Metrocard advertisements, he said, were necessary to educate the public about free transfers.
"This is a big transition that's taking place in the city," he said. "We want people to know about it, understand it and inculcate it."
Mr. Mastro said the administration decided to use the Mayor's voice in the advertisement because, as city government's most recognizable figure, Mr. Giuliani would be able to make the free-transfer program a much greater popular success.
A spokesman for the Economic Development Corporation, Russell Harding, said the agency's advertising campaign was begun as retaliation for a similar advertisement promoting the business-friendly atmosphere of New Jersey. Had that state not tried to lure away city businesses, the city would never have paid for the advertisements, he said.
"We have to talk about the positive aspects of the city," said Mr. Harding, the son of Raymond B. Harding, the Mayor's closest political adviser. "Things here are better, and we want to communicate that to business decision makers."
The issue of public advertisements that resemble campaign commercials comes up frequently at election time, and has embroiled Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Messinger in the past. In June of 1993, when Mr. Giuliani was in a tight race against former Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Giuliani campaign complained to the city's Campaign Finance Board that Mr. Dinkins was advancing his candidacy with an advertisement that promoted city bonds. The board eventually ruled that the advertisement was not campaign-related.
Last December, Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, spent $7,400 in city funds on radio advertisements criticizing the Mayor's plan to build superstores around the city, an act that outraged the Giuliani camp. The Mayor responded by raising $67,000 from real estate and construction interests to run advertisements promoting his plan.
Mr. Giuliani has also spent taxpayer money on advertisements to build public support for his proposal to drop the city sales tax on clothing and to preserve the city's rent laws. Ms. Messinger also used some of her public funds recently to urge that the rent laws not be changed.
In March, after receiving criticism, two utility companies ended a television advertising campaign that highlighted Gov. George E. Pataki's role in devising a plan to reduce Long Island's utility rates.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Divorce Lawyer Switches

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
One of of New York City's premier divorce lawyers, Eleanor B. Alter, is leaving Rosenman & Colin, her law firm of 15 years, and taking a team of family-law attorneys with her.
Famous for celebrity clients like Mia Farrow and Christie Brinkley, Ms. Alter will become a partner at Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman. The 76-lawyer firm, which she officialy joins July 1, is only four years old and currently has no divorce practice. Ms. Alter, 58, is making the switch with a large crew: five associates, three secretaries, two paralegals and a file clerk, as well as Helene Brezinsky, a family law partner. 
 This is not the first time Rosenman & Colin, a 240-lawyer firm, has suffered a brain drain at the hands of Kasowitz, Benson. Eric J. Wallach, head of Kasowitz, Benson's employment practice, left Rosenman after 20 years last September, taking four associates with him. Three of the four men in the firm's name -- Marc E. Kasowitz, Daniel R. Benson and Hector Torres -- are also Rosenman alumni.
 LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: From the Real World, a Critique of the E.P.A.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Imagine reading this in your paper: "The Environmental Protection Agency has announced that it intends to set strict limits on oxygen. Agency spokesmen say, 'Oxygen is toxic in high doses, is explosive, causes fires and can cause airplanes to crash.' Moreover, the Clean Air Act precludes the agency from considering the costs or the 'disbenefits' of banning oxygen. 'Business and conservative analysts have a history of overestimating the costs of environmental regulation,' officials say. 'To protect public health, especially children, Americans can learn to live with less oxygen.' " 
 It's great sport to poke fun at opposing views by taking an argument to the extreme, as we do using the E.P.A.'s logic in the above paragraph and as T. H. Watkins did to our research in his June 17 Op-Ed article. But Mr. Watkins did more than that; he made some statements that were not true. We have not "wondered out loud whether tropospheric ozone has anything to do with respiratory problems." Our article in The Wall Street Journal simply called for recognition of the trade-offs involved in E.P.A. regulations.
We rather like Mr. Watkins's world. Everything is good or bad. No trade-offs or difficult decisions need be made. As appealing as it may seem, we'll stick in the real world, where E.P.A. regulations can do more harm than good when they're based on poor science and bad economics.
 
WENDY L. GRAMM
SUSAN E. DUDLEY
Washington, June 18, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Yen As Trade Tension Seems Eased

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday as the prospect of trade tensions between the United States and Japan appeared to ease as a summit meeting of world leaders began in Denver.
On Thursday, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan pledged his commitment to an agreement with President Clinton on ways to smooth access to Japanese markets, soothing concern that leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations would dwell on Japan's trade surplus at the three-day meeting. 
 Later, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka said he and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had agreed to cooperate closely on stabilizing exchange rates.
"There will be a little talk on the trade surplus, but currencies won't be too much of a topic," said Robert Katz, chief currency trader at MTB Bank. They "won't dominate like they have in previous G-7 meetings," he said.
Fernando Medina, senior currency trader at Banco Atlanticom, said that "people are buying dollars in the event that nothing serious about trade is said" at the summit meeting. Even so, the dollar did not rise more because traders were thinking, "Don't go crazy, because you might get burned," he said.
Trade tension between the United States and Japan often hurts the dollar by causing speculation that the Clinton Administration will retreat from its longstanding support for a strong currency. That concern ebbed on Thursday when Mr. Clinton reiterated support for a strong dollar.
In New York, the dollar settled at 114.81 yen, up from 113.98 yen on Thursday and its highest closing level of the week. The dollar rose to 1.7275 marks from 1.7237 marks.
The pound, meanwhile, surged to a five-year high against both the mark and the dollar, lifted by expectations of higher British interest rates.
A survey by the Confederation of British Industry showed improving demand for manufacturing goods, reinforcing speculation that Britain's base lending rate, recently raised to 6.25 percent, might soon rise again.
In New York, the pound rose to $1.6559, from $1.6488 on Thursday, and its highest level since Jan. 21.

HEADLINE: Budget Deficit Narrowed in May

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
 The budget deficit narrowed in May from a year earlier, keeping the annual shortfall between revenues and expenses on track to fall to the lowest level in almost two decades.
The deficit totaled $48.494 billion last month as Federal spending fell below the total a year earlier, figures from the Treasury's monthly budget statement showed today. That is down from last May's deficit of $53.051 billion -- the largest ever in a single month. Analysts forecast a budget shortfall of $50.6 billion for May. 
 The Treasury is benefiting from strong tax collections as the healthy economy is bolstering paychecks and corporate profits. Americans "made gobs and gobs of money last year," said Astrid Adolfson of MCM Moneywatch in New York. "We're sharing the wealth with the Treasury."
Moreover, the growth rate of Federal discretionary spending has been restrained. The Treasury, which recorded a record monthly budget surplus in April of $93.939 billion, plans to pay down a record $65 billion in debt this quarter.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Old Rebuffs Spur Efforts On Racism

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE Rev. Dr. Suzan Johnson Cook still remembers the day she hopped on a school bus, all eager to make that first ride alongside another little girl from her Gun Hill Road neighborhood. Ms. Johnson Cook's parents had been the first black family to move into a block in the Bronx that had been home to many Jews and Italians.
"I invited a Jewish girl who was going to be in my class to sit next to me," Ms. Johnson Cook recalled. "She said, 'My mother said I can't sit next to a black person.' I told her I was brown, but that was it. The seeds of racism were already planted. In the life of every African-American there is a turning point when you recognize there is a difference." 
 More than 30 years later, the girl who was shunned on her way to school has been invited to sit with the President of the United States. Ms. Johnson Cook, the senior minister of the Bronx Christian Fellowship, has been appointed to President Clinton's seven-member advisory panel on race relations. She admits that the panel is not capable of erasing centuries of fear and distrust, but she says that its formation is a sign that the time has come to begin talking about issues glossed over by others who feel that civil rights is just a lesson in a history class and that affirmative action has run its course.
Coming from the Bronx, a borough whose black and Latino majority renders the word minority meaningless at times, Ms. Johnson Cook said that the experiences of communities like hers can teach the rest of the country how different groups can move forward into the next century.
"WE'RE trying to figure out where do we go from here," she said. "The President is raising the question can we be one America. On the local level, we ask if we can be one Bronx."
She had begun to answer that question three years ago, when she returned to her childhood borough to begin her new ministry. A former television producer, she had been ordained in the 1980's in the American Baptist Church, and had been the pastor of the Mariners' Temple in Chinatown. In 1993, wanting to gain a larger perspective on urban problems, she became a White House Fellow in urban policy. Soon, the Bronx beckoned.
"I wanted to embrace the community which had produced and nurtured me," she said. "The Bronx was the place to be. It was multi-ethnic, progressive and an undiscovered borough. It was the untapped borough."
While some lament the passing of the halcyon days when the Concourse was grand and egg creams flowed like water, Ms. Johnson Cook preferred to focus on those who stayed behind, as well as those who moved in, who worked to improve housing and social conditions. Her own ministry, inside a former bank at 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, stresses reaching out to all, regardless of race or class. During her Thursday afternoon prayer sessions, the room is filled with court officers, young professionals and church ladies smiling as they offer one another "holy handshakes."
"People can try to live segregated lives, but it's not healthy," she said. "The Bronx can teach us something. We have two predominant groups here in African-Americans and Latinos, and within that there are different cultures and nationalities. They live together. It's a small paradigm, but it's a beginning."
SHE sometimes wonders if that message has been heard by outsiders. She is especially worried about the dangers that await young black children, even those like hers who come from middle-class homes.
"You see them stopped by law enforcement and you fear," she said. "You see the lead stories on the news and the top 3 or 5 are of racial minorities in cuffs. Then there's the violence of kids going to school and getting killed. You think you're able to buffer the storm. But you feel for your children."
Those who don't live there wouldn't understand that, she said. Which is why it is important to her that these issues be talked about, to understand her community's strengths and remind others of the need to reach out and build economic and social bonds. The process will be painful at times, she said, but at least race will be on the table. So, too, will be the advice and hopes of her Bronx neighbors.
"How they experience life will be heard," she said. "When the advisory board is over, I'm still coming back to sleep in the Bronx."

HEADLINE: Baptist Rank and File Split on Disney Boycott

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: FALLS CHURCH, Va., June 20

 BODY:
The resounding vote this week in Dallas by the Southern Baptist Convention to boycott all things Disney seemed to carry the weight of a religious crusade.
Yet here in this middle-class suburb of Washington, where 3,000 local residents claim the Columbia Baptist Church as their principal house of worship, congregants expressed mixed views about a declaration adopted by 12,000 conventioneers to govern the leisure habits of 15.7 million people across the country who make up the nation's largest Protestant denomination. 
 In interviews today, six members of the Columbia church discussed the stand taken in Dallas. All agreed that the Walt Disney Company might be taken to task in some way for promoting homosexual life styles through so-called "Gay Days" at Disney World in Florida and for the ABC television sitcom "Ellen," which features a lesbian actress playing a store manager who is a lesbian.
But some questioned whether parents would honor a boycott that would also deny a child the opportunity to watch Disney films like "The Lion King" or "101 Dalmatians."
"An economic boycott is a good idea, but it should be more targeted," said K. Randel Everett, Columbia's senior pastor. He said he would prefer a boycott of a specific Disney property for a fixed period of time, like a week of turning off a Disney-owned network like ABC, ESPN or Arts & Entertainment. "I like to watch "Nightline" and ESPN. More than any other channel, I like ESPN. But if I vote for a boycott, I want to be able to keep it."
Joy Brody, a mother of three young boys, said she would not boycott Disney and instead would do what thousands of other Falls Church residents did in a recent five-year campaign to end sex education in the local public school system: "Make lots of calls and write lots of letters."
"I don't have to boycott," she said. "In fact, we're going to Disney World for a week this summer. But I will write a letter of protest." Turning quickly to Mr. Everett, she asked jokingly, "I'm not going to get thrown out of the church, am I?"
Brian Kirby, an elementary school music teacher, also disagreed with a widespread boycott, but not so much for the impracticality of it as for the image it creates for Southern Baptists.
"Rather than capitalize on the negative, I would love to see our convention as a whole capitalize on the positive," he said. "I would have rather seen us publish a list of things we're happy with, praise Disney for the positive things the company has done. You see lots of black lists; let's see some praise lists."
Lois Cox, a receptionist at the church, was the only person in the group who wholeheartedly supported the boycott. She said its expansive reach was the best way to demonstrate that Southern Baptists will not tolerate the promotion of lifestyles that violate Christian traditions.
"I'm glad they made the statement," Ms. Cox said. "I'm glad they are taking a stand. I object to Disney being a vehicle that promotes evil, and it's important for the leaders of our faith to say what we believe in."
But Barbara Wever, a retired administrator with Bell-Atlantic, said she would just as soon speak for herself. She objected to a group of Baptists she described as far more conservative than herself setting policy for so diverse a religious group.
"Other people don't think for me," she said. "I ultimately have to answer for what's right and wrong. I don't know if the boycott is a good idea. I buy every Disney video that comes out and give them to my grandchildren, but I never get anything for them that I don't sit down and watch with them. If there's something negative in there, my husband and I discuss it with them."
"Ultimately, it's a personal decision: you have to decide," said Enrique DePaz, pastor of Columbia's Hispanic members, who attended the Dallas convention and voted for the boycott.
But upon reflection, he acknowledged a certain ambivalence, born of the fervor when the vote was taken and the unlikelihood that compliance could ever be monitored.
"The need to boycott means the need to shut down your TV and boycott ABC," he said. "More than 80 percent of the people in Dallas agreed that was right. Maybe it's not the best way, but at least it's a place to start."
Mr. Kirby, the teacher, was not so sure. He said he was bothered by the notion that a call to boycott Disney might suggest to outsiders that Southern Baptists are not already discerning enough to tune out what they would consider offensive behavior.
"I would hope we have not come to the point where it takes a group of people to challenge us to be discerning Christians," he said. "I was discerning way before the convention Baptists made this decision."
As a result, Mr. Kirby said, the declaration in Dallas would have virtually no effect on his life, other than to strengthen his resolve to choose his entertainment ever more carefully.
But others who disagreed with the declaration said they have already experienced one residual benefit, a new dialogue within their families. Mr. Everett, the pastor, has a daughter who just graduated from high school and a son in college. "For us," he said, "it was a trigger for conversation. We're not all in harmony over this, but it did give us the opportunity to discuss what we should and should not tolerate."

HEADLINE: Big Volume Pushes Stocks To More Highs

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
The stock market drifted into the record books again yesterday, but just barely, in one of the busiest trading sessions ever.
The heavy activity resulted from what Wall Street terms a "triple witching day" -- the period once a quarter when the options and futures on stock indexes expire. But despite the volume, market gains were slim. 
 Among the most heavily traded shares yesterday were those of tobacco companies. Down for much of the day, tobacco issues rose just after reports of a historic settlement with regulators, but then tumbled near the close.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.45 points, to a new closing high of 7,796.51. For the week, the Dow was up just 14 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a closing high, with an even slimmer gain. It was up 0.71 point, to 898.70.
In the last 10 weeks, though, the S.& P. 500 has soared 21.8 percent, its best 10-week run since October 1982, when the market exploded out of a downturn.
The powerful run for stocks this year has been fueled by strong corporate profits, falling interest rates and diminishing fears of inflation.
"The market continues to react positively to the absence of inflation," said William LeFevre, a market analyst with Ehren krantz King Nussbaum. "And as long as individuals continue to put money into mutual funds, it's unlikely you'll have a significant selloff."
As a result, in recent days several Wall Street bulls have raised their forecasts for the coming year.
Ralph Acampora, a market analyst with Prudential Securities, said he had raised his year-end estimate to 8,750 points for the Dow, from 8,250. He also said he expects the Dow to reach 10,000 by next June.
"I don't see froth," he said. "I don't see speculation. I see the market broadening out, and it's broadening out because people feel comfortable. And when you put it all together, I see the Dow hitting 10,000."
Abby Joseph Cohen, the bullish strategist at Goldman, Sachs, has also issued a new forecast. Yesterday, she said she had raised her 12-month target on the S.& P. 500 to 950 points, the equivalent of the Dow hitting 8,250 by next June.
Of course, an 8,000-point Dow this year was not inconceivable to Laszlo Birinyi. The president of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn., has wavered little from bullish convictions he declared early this year.
Mr. Birinyi said that one force driving prices higher is that the S.& P. 500 -- which is up 21.3 percent this year -- is outperforming some active portfolio managers. So now those managers are frantically trying to buy the blue chips.
"What you've been seeing in the last couple of weeks is an attempt to narrow the gap," Mr. Birnyi said. "And I think as long as you have this tremendous gap between the indexes and the managers, you're going to see continued strength in the market and very minor corrections."
In fact, according to Morningstar Inc., the median gain for United States domestic stock funds is 14.1 percent so far this year -- a gap of about seven percentage points with the S.& P. 500.
Yesterday, though, was dominated by traders, closing out options and futures as part of the triple witching.
As a result, 653.1 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, its third-heaviest day ever, with declining issues outpacing advancers, 1,486 to 1,149.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 17 advanced yesterday, led by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which rose 2 1/4 a share, to 102 1/8.
Shares of Philip Morris, the nation's leading cigarette maker, rose and then fell after reports of a tentative tobacco accord; they closed at 45 1/2, down 2. Shares of RJR Nabisco Holding, whose subsidiary makes Camels, also fell: 7/8, to 35.
But analysts said that this week's soft market was simply a resting period after a broad and powerful run that began in mid-April.
For that reason, Mr. Acampora discounts yesterday's frenzied action and is looking toward even bigger gains. "Today was triple witching," he said. "It was all noise. This is all short term. But my message about the Dow at 10,000 is for investors, not traders."

LENGTH: 543 words

HEADLINE: Judge Orders Detroit Papers to Rehire Strikers

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
A Federal labor judge issued a sweeping ruling in favor of more than 1,000 former Detroit newspaper workers yesterday, finding that The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press had engaged in unfair labor practices in forcing a 19-month strike, and ordering the two dailies to put the strikers back to work, even if that means laying off replacement workers.
The ruling by Administrative Law Judge Thomas Wilks, of the National Labor Relations Board, was a sweet victory for the unionists, who have not had much to cheer about since 2,500 workers in six unions walked out on July 13, 1995. But the newspapers will not be required to rehire any strikers during the appeal that Detroit Newspapers Inc., the operating agency for the two dailies, immediately said it would file. Appeals could continue for months or years. Knight-Ridder Inc. owns The Detroit Free Press; the Gannett Company owns The Detroit News. 
 In his order, Judge Wilks upheld a complaint from the Detroit regional office of the labor board that Detroit Newspapers Inc. had bargained in bad faith on economic matters, had failed to provide the six striking unions with information they needed to bargain effectively and had imposed unilateral merit pay changes without bargaining with the unions, among other things.
The companies had argued before the labor board that the strike was over purely economic issues, which are not subject to unfair labor practice rulings.
The country's longest active newspaper strike officially ended in February, when the unions made an unconditional offer to return to work. The papers rehired 225 workers but have refused to displace those hired during the strike, including several hundred former strikers who crossed the picket lines. The remainder have still not been given back their old jobs. There is disagreement on the number of strikers affected. The union, evidently counting part-timers, says there are about 1,800; the newspapers say there are 1,019.
Now the focus of the dispute shifts to the company's appeal, first to the labor board, and then to the Federal courts if necessary. In addition, the Detroit office of the labor relations board requested an injunction in February to force the papers to take back all remaining workers immediately. The labor board has not yet ruled on that request.
William Schaub Jr., the Detroit regional director of the labor board, said yesterday's ruling was an important development.
"This is a major step in my mind," he said, "because it obviously means that the companies have in fact bargained in bad faith, and hopefully it means that we will be a little farther down the road toward a final solution."
"We are very glad with today's ruling," Shawn Ellis, a newspaper delivery driver and a spokesman for the Metropolitan Detroit Council of Newspaper Unions, said yesterday.
"We think we have proven that the companies used illegal activities to try to bust six unions representing 2,500 employees," Mr. Ellis said.
The timing of the ruling could hardly have suited the unions better: a major rally has long been planned for the weekend, with several national labor leaders in attendance.
"Obviously this ruling puts a very bright star on this weekend for us," Mr. Ellis said.

HEADLINE: Romania Raps on Door For a NATO Invitation

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
As diplomacy goes, the timing could have been better.
Victor Ciorbea, Prime Minister of Romania, is trudging through Washington this week to make the case for his country to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He has met Vice President Al Gore and conferred with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. He has prayed over breakfast with Senators. 
 Just one problem. The Clinton Administration announced last week that it wanted to invite only three countries to join the alliance -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- despite support among NATO allies for including Romania and Slovenia.
And that has turned Mr. Ciorbea's already difficult foray into something all but quixotic.
Still, barely two weeks before President Clinton and other NATO leaders gather in Madrid on July 8 to extend formal invitations, the matter remains bitterly unresolved.
"We didn't have any reason to be happy," Mr. Ciorbea acknowledged in an interview on Wednesday evening, looking weary after a day full of meetings. "Of course, we remain optimistic. And we have a duty for ourselves and for our people and for the countries who support us to struggle up to the end."
Mr. Ciorbea (pronounced CHORE-bah) was in the middle of planning for his visit here when Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen announced the American preference at a meeting of NATO's defense ministers in Brussels on June 12. He decided to come ahead anyway, if only because NATO admission carries such appeal back home.
In all the formerly Communist nations of Eastern Europe, admission to the military alliance that stood as a bulwark against Soviet domination would offer the prospect of security and stability. But for Romania and Slovenia in particular, it is seen as offering still more: the ultimate validation of their place in Europe.
"We had pretty big hopes," was how Slovenia's Ambassador in Washington, Ernest Petric, put it the other day.
The Administration's insistence on holding NATO's first round of expansion to three members has now all but dashed those hopes. In Romania, where the campaign for membership had become an obsession, a newspaper headline despaired, "Goodbye, NATO."
The decision -- not to mention the blunt, "our position is firm" way it was announced in Washington and Brussels -- has also angered America's NATO allies.
Although the United States has the strongest voice as the most powerful member of the alliance, NATO's decisions are ostensibly consensual. And at the meeting of NATO ambassadors last week, the alliance remained sharply divided, with a majority of the 16 members -- notably France, Canada and Italy -- at least publicly sticking with their support for five new members.
"The way the United States made its position known was seen by all as rather surprising and a bit brutal," a NATO diplomat in Brussels said.
The split has given a sliver of hope to Romania and Slovenia, though Mr. Ciorbea doubted he would succeed in persuading the Administration to change its mind. "We are not as naive as that," he said.
Still, he trudges on, meeting with more Senators, with research groups, and with reporters. Today he met with Secretary Cohen and laid a wreath at Arlington National Cemetery. The trip was not so much to berate the Americans, he said, as to build "a strategic partnership" with them.
"We don't forget and we can't forget that the Americans have been awaited in Romania for more than 50 years," he said. "And I think the moment has come for this dream and this desire of the Romania people to become a reality."
Mr. Ciorbea, a lanky, reserved 42-year-old lawyer, was appointed last November by President Emil Constantinescu, whose party swept aside the ex-Communists who had ruled Romania since its violent revolution in 1989. Mr. Ciorbea, formerly the Mayor of Bucharest, has led the new Government's efforts to reform its economy, imposing austerity in the name of qualifying for NATO membership, which was, he declared, Romania's first priority.
Romania, like Slovenia, was always a long shot, considered behind the three front-runners in solidifying democracy after decades of Communism. But it made huge strides in the last year and began to win supporters in NATO capitals.
In addition to its economic shock therapy, Romania made peace with its neighbors, Hungary and Ukraine. It also sent 400 troops to Albania earlier this year as part of an Italian-led peacekeeping force, having already dispatched peacekeepers to Bosnia and Angola.
For all the progress, though, the Administration decided it wanted to limit NATO's expansion to three, citing concerns about costs and questioning the extent of Romania's transition to democracy. Officials said choosing three now increased the likelihood of having a second expansion sooner.
From the start, an Administration official said, the United States made its views clear, never giving Romania or Slovenia false expectations. "Our consciences are clear," the official said. At the same time, the Administration took pains to insure that these emerging democracies at the crux of southeastern Europe do not feel alienated.
At the Pentagon today, Secretary Cohen praised Romania for the strides it has made. "I want to be perfectly clear," he said. "The United States did not say no to Romanian membership in NATO last week. It said, 'Not yet.' "
For his part, Mr. Ciorbea said he did not want to cause problems in relations with the United States, but rather to build on the relationship. If NATO passes over Romania now -- "God forbid," he interjected -- Mr. Ciorbea insisted his country would press ahead as it has with efforts to reform itself and forge closer ties to Europe.
"We will go on acting exactly as we did until now, going on with the process of reforms, because these reforms are not done for NATO," he said. "We do these reforms for us. They are, anyhow, absolutely necessary."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Historic Pact Proposed With Tobacco Industry
Tobacco negotiators announced a settlement proposal that could forever change the way cigarettes are marketed in the United States, provide the states $368.5 billion in compensation and permanently alter the nation's legal, regulatory and public health landscape. But despite concessions from the cigarette makers, the proposal would allow the tobacco industry to win reprieve from the gravest legal and financial threats it has ever faced. 
 The complex agreement was negotiated by a group of state attorneys general headed by Michael Moore of Mississippi, above, plaintiffs' lawyers and industry representatives. The nation's four major cigarette makers -- Philip Morris, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, Brown & Williamson and Lorillard -- described the proposal as "a bitter pill" that required previously unimaginable concessions. [Page 1.]
 
While Joe Camel and the Marlboro Man may be banned under the agreement, experts say there are enough weapons left in the marketing arsenal to enable cigarette makers to continue selling profitably for decades. [10.]
 
'Financial End of the Cold War'
Inclusion was the theme as the newly renamed "summit of the eight" opened in Denver. President Clinton met President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, now nearly a full member of the group of leading industrial nations. "In a sense, this marks the financial end of the cold war," said Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers. [6.]
 
The dollar rose against the yen as the prospect of trade tensions between the United States and Japan appeared to ease at the start of the meeting of world leaders in Denver. [34.]
 
Detroit Papers Lose Ruling
A Federal labor judge ruled that The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press had engaged in unfair labor practices in forcing a 19-month strike, and ordered the two dailies to put the strikers back to work, even if that meant laying off replacement workers. [11.]
 
Knight-Ridder, which owns The Detroit Free Press, plans to sell five of its smaller newspapers that it says are not meeting the company's profit standards, including The Press-Telegram in Long Beach, Calif. [37]
 
Boeing Gets British Order
British Airways exercised options to buy five Boeing 777 jetliners and placed orders for three of the 767 model in a contract valued at $1 billion. [46.]
 
Broker Admits Trading Conspiracy
A former stockbroker, Michael J. Morse, 54, of Atlanta, pleaded guilty to Federal charges of masterminding an illegal trading conspiracy that cost eight of Wall Street's largest brokerage houses more than $13.4 million in losses during the summer of 1994. [36.]
 
Suit to Cost Hancock $350 Million
John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance said it would pay at least $350 million to settle a class-action lawsuit with policyholders over reportedly deceptive sales practices. [37.]
 
Banking Overhaul Gains
Congress moved a step closer to tearing down the Depression-era barriers separating banking from other financial services, as the House Banking Committee approved an overhaul of banking laws. [37.]
 
Bonds Await News
In the absence of fresh economic news, Government securities traded higher. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.66 percent; for the week, the yield was down 6 basis points. [36.]
 
Metals Prices Up
Platinum and palladium futures prices jumped after Russia said it would not resume shipping the metals until July or later. Prices for gold and soybeans fell. [34.]
 
Bracing for El Nino
The potent weather disrupter known as El Nino is returning, which could have a major effect on crops in the Midwest. During the 1982-83 El Nino, torrential rains swept California and much of the southern two-thirds of the United States, causing floods, mud slides and coast-to-coast weather havoc. [7.]

HEADLINE: Camry Teaches Economics 101: Features Are Nice but Price Sells

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 20

 BODY:
Auto advertisers love to promote each new model as changing an industry, but only a few actually do so, like the 1986 Ford Taurus, which spawned a fleet of aerodynamic imitators.
Introduced last autumn, the 1997 Toyota Camry lacks the grace or beauty to alter automotive design -- indeed, its bland curves verge on the utilitarian. But the car is reshaping the nation's midsize car market because of its price tag of $16,448 to $24,088, down $550 to $1,745 from the 1996 model, depending on the version. The lower prices have narrowed substantially, without eliminating, the premium that American buyers have come to pay for a Japanese car compared with a similarly equipped American model. 
 The new Camry also has lower manufacturing costs, a result of a variety of changes like simpler headlamps and fewer fuel lines. The combination of lower prices and costs has forced rival auto makers to reduce costs, cut prices and offer larger rebates on their midsize cars.
The clearest sign of the Camry's success has come in the sales statistics. After five years in which the Taurus narrowly beat the Honda Accord to become the best-selling car, the Camry has easily moved ahead of both cars in the first five months of this year.
Toyota has sold 175,691 Camrys so far, compared with Ford's sales of 145,963 Tauruses and Honda's sales of 132,183 Accords. Whether the Camry takes the best-selling car title for the entire year will mainly depend on Toyota's ability to keep up production and a willingness to endure the political criticism in the United States that could accompany any dethroning of the Taurus.
Toyota's factory in Georgetown, Ky., which makes most of the Camrys for the United States market, is scheduled to begin producing the Sienna mini-van as well during the first week of August. That start-up will force Toyota to choose between importing more Camrys from Japan or ratcheting down sales.
The sales success of the Camry followed Toyota's decision, made last year when it redesigned the car, to lower prices on various versions of the sedan by an average of $899. That price cut, while not the first by an auto maker in the last couple of years, has contributed to a ripple of price reductions and generous incentives that is spreading across the nation's car market.
The most recent response came on Thursday, when Nissan announced that the main version of its completely redesigned 1998 Altima sedan, the Altima GXE, would sell for $1,508 less than a comparably equipped 1997 model. The Altima is a little smaller than a Camry or a Taurus and a little bigger than a Toyota Corolla or a Ford Contour.
Nissan may not be alone in lowering midsize car prices or forgoing price increases this year. Chrysler, for instance, has made several improvements in its midsize Cirrus sedan for this autumn, such as installing more luxurious leather and a sunroof, but the company will choose "an aggressive price position," said Steven D. Bruyn, Chrysler's marketing plans manager for midsize and large cars. Honda is redesigning the Accord for this autumn and is hinting that the vehicle will be larger and more comfortable but will stay the same price, without even an adjustment for inflation.
The new Camry was designed for cheaper assembly. The bumper, for example, has just 13 pieces, instead of 20 as on the 1996 model. While auto makers have long tried to simplify designs, Toyota went further than most with the Camry, and other auto makers are moving in the same direction.
Nissan officials have made similar changes to reduce production costs of the new Altima, which goes on sale July 10. The pillars on either side of the front windshield, for instance, are now installed at the factory as a single piece instead of three pieces, said Mark Perry, Nissan's marketing manager for sedans.
Judging by the Camry's sales, the design changes do not seem to have struck buyers as a reduction in quality. Campbell C. Shaw, the sales manager at Melody Toyota in San Francisco, said that the Camry's lower price was not the only reason for its popularity. "It's mainly due to the brand new car and the quality of the workmanship," he said.
Yet recent studies show that the quality advantage held by Japanese auto makers is rapidly disappearing, as American manufacturers adopt many of the same production techniques. According to surveys by J. D. Power & Associates, only 68 problems were reported for every 100 new Tauruses during the first 90 days of ownership this year, compared with 53 problems for every 100 Camrys.
By comparison, the Camry score in 1996 was 82, while J. D. Power did not report the Taurus score because it was worse than the industry average of 110. The quality consulting company does not disclose the actual number when the score is below the average.
The success of the Camry is all the more remarkable because even with the price cut it remains more expensive than comparably equipped American midsize cars, although the gap has narrowed.
A comparable Ford Taurus still sells for roughly $2,500 less and a comparable Chevrolet Lumina still retails for close to $4,000 less, partly because Japanese manufacturers have high vehicle-development and administrative costs.
"They're still pricing pretty high, based on higher perceived quality and resale value," said James Harbour, an automotive productivity analyst in Troy, Mich. Someday, he added, "people are going to look at themselves and say, 'Why am I paying $2,500 more than for a Taurus?' "
That day may have been postponed, however, by the dollar's brisk appreciation against the Japanese yen over the last two years, although the dollar retreated somewhat this spring. The dollar's strength has considerably reduced the cost of the many parts, like automatic transmissions, that Japanese auto makers still import for assembly into cars in the United States.
Chris K. Hostetter, Toyota's manager for product planning, said the Camry had been designed several years ago when the dollar's value was dropping, so Toyota engineered the car to be competitive even if each dollar of sales in the United States only brought it 90 yen. But with the dollar's recovery, a dollar fetched 114.81 yen in late trading today in New York.
Mr. Hostetter said that the dollar's level had not affected the final decision last August on how to price the Camry.
American auto executives have called repeatedly for the Japanese Government to take vigorous action to bring the yen to a range of 100 to 110 to the dollar at a minimum.
"We've said for more than a year that the yen was too weak," Alex Trotman, the chairman and chief executive of Ford, said in a policy statement on June 9. "The currency markets are starting to agree."
Susan Jacobs, an auto market forecaster in Rutherford, N.J., said that the yen must have played some role in the Camry's more competitive price now, but she added that the design changes almost certainly played a larger role.
Toyota's design alterations and the weak yen have clearly affected the midsize car market, amplifying broader trends such as an erosion in used-car prices that is already making it harder to sell many kinds of cars and other vehicles.
"The midsize market is probably shaping up to be the most competitive segment," Ms. Jacobs said.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Basks at Summit; Some Europeans Are Cool to U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 20

 BODY:
The newly renamed "summit of the eight" opened today with President Clinton, buoyed by an effervescent economy, meeting the revived Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and trying to soothe European anger over what they see as America's arrogance in NATO and the United Nations.
A fit-looking Mr. Yeltsin seemed thrilled just to be here, basking in the attention accorded a nearly full member of this group of the world's most important nations. Russia is taking part in every session except an hour of financial conversation on Saturday, and making Russia feel welcome is the main point, senior American officials said. 
 In many ways, Mr. Yeltsin came here to collect on the promises made to him by Mr. Clinton in March to make NATO expansion easier for the Russians to swallow. With his eye on critics at home, Mr. Yeltsin has refused to attend the NATO expansion summit party in Madrid in July.
It annoyed the Japanese that Mr. Clinton had decided on his own to invite Russia here in such a prominent way. The Japanese argued that in effect expanding the Group of 7 major industrialized countries to include Russia degraded the economic importance of these meetings. But the meetings in fact became more political than economic years ago.
Inclusion was the theme today. As he met Mr. Yeltsin in the Brown Palace Hotel, a beaming Mr. Clinton said: "Russia is fully included. This is the first time we've ever had a meeting where the Russians were here from the beginning to the end."
In his next breath, Mr. Clinton announced that negotiations were completed early today to admit Russia to the Paris Club of creditor nations, which manages the debt of developing countries. Mr. Clinton had promised to arrange membership during his March summit meeting with Mr. Yeltsin in Helsinki, when the Russian President first gave in to the inevitability of NATO expansion and agreed to negotiate a NATO-Russia charter.
Russia will have to write off a large part of Soviet-era debt, much of it for military purchases by poor Soviet allies, but Moscow was not going to be paid back anyway. In return, the new Russia gets the kind of international status that Mr. Yeltsin is using to convince his people of the worthiness of his bargain to join the Western market democracies, even in the face of NATO expansion.
"In a sense, this marks the financial end of the cold war," said Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers. "It reflects our aim to bring Russia into the international community, which has been our aim for many years."
But American officials also acknowledge that Russia has a long way to go and will not be brought into the World Trade Organization next year, as they had hoped. Mr. Clinton also pressed Mr. Yeltsin to push the ratification of the Start 2 arms treaty in his Parliament. Russia has also backtracked from ratifying the Chemical Weapons Convention.
If there was mostly happy talk with the Russians today, there were clear tensions with the Italians and especially the French, who are still pushing the expansion of NATO to include Slovenia and Romania, in addition to a consensus on admitting Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Mr. Clinton also met today with the French President, Jacques Chirac, and the Italian Prime Minister, Romano Prodi, to hear them out and to explain Washington's actions.
There is great resentment of Mr. Clinton's unilateral decision to keep expansion to three countries, said a French official who described the action as "fundamentally imperial." An Italian official echoed unhappiness with "American presumption."
"When exactly did the Americans go from leadership to hegemony?" another French official asked.
Most countries here have expressed annoyance with the American decision to pay only $819 million of its $1.2 billion debt to the United Nations, and then only in return for specific reforms and a reduction of the yearly American contribution.
A senior European diplomat said: "The Americans think they deserve a superpower discount. But why should we be happy about paying part of their bill?"
Mr. Chirac also stressed his concerns about the deterioration in the Middle East to Mr. Clinton, who has put the issue on the back burner. There was also extensive discussion on Bosnia, which was the main topic at a dinner tonight, held at the Phipps House, a historic site at the University of Denver. With Mr. Prodi, there was talk of the Italian-led multilateral force in Albania, which is preparing for elections.
This is the 23d of these summit meetings, which are increasingly pompous spectacles. But they are also more political in nature and have moved far beyond their quiet beginnings in 1975, when the French and Germans wanted real conversation about global economic trends.
The economic pronouncements are increasingly precooked, with the final economic communiques negotiated and written in advance, while much of the important political business, including the real economic debate, gets done bilaterally on the grating issues of the day.
The eight countries represented here are the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy, Canada and Russia. The European Union is represented by the president of its Commission, Jacques Santer.
