HEADLINE: Critics Say Airport Plan Risks an Expanse of Land

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., June 20

 BODY:
As part of his plan to turn the state-owned Stewart International Airport into a private, profitable venture, Gov. George E. Pataki has put up for sale a 7,400-acre expanse of woods, fields and wetlands west of the airport that is dear to hunters, bird-watchers and environmental groups.
Sporting and environmental groups have criticized the Governor's move because they want to focus development in existing commercial strips around the airport while preserving the undeveloped land for recreation and as a buffer to airport noise. While the Governor wants to preserve some land for recreational space, his sale proposal does not designate a specific amount of land as protected. 
 In contrast to environmental critics, some local elected officials support Mr. Pataki and say the vacant land should be returned to the tax rolls and put to productive use, to encourage business in this economically ailing region 60 miles north of New York City.
Mr. Pataki first proposed returning the airport to private hands early last year as part of an effort to privatize many state assets, including, most recently, an offer to sell a network of former mental hospitals.
The airport would be leased, but the State Department of Transportation would sell most of the adjacent land. The state bought the vacant tract through condemnation procedures in 1971, when Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller intended to make Stewart, which is west of Newburgh, into a fourth jetport for New York City. But the airport never grew as much as expected, and the rolling land has been used mainly by people eager for a bit of open space in an increasingly crowded part of Orange County.
The state's request for proposals, released by the Empire State Development Corporation on Thursday, emphasizes that any plans should "be environmentally responsible" and have as a priority "the preservation of open space and current permitted public recreational uses."
Instead of specifying how much land should be protected in any proposal, the state invitation says only that "a substantial contiguous portion" of the land should be used for recreation.
John Samatulski, a spokesman for the New York chapter of the Sierra Club, a nonprofit group, said: "We're extremely disappointed with the way the Governor has chosen to handle this. By not taking the land off the table prior to the request for proposals, he's setting up a dynamic for conflict."
Mr. Samatulski said many sporting and environmental groups, including his own, had spent months discussing other courses with the development agency, Mr. Pataki's office and state environmental officials. But the resulting plan invites developers to propose the balance of public land and commercial activity.
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the development agency, said: "We didn't want to tie the hands of the private sector by setting a number. The whole purpose of this process is to see what kind of creative ideas are out there." She also pointed out that the state request said "proposals that concentrate development in areas adjacent to Stewart Airport will be preferred."
George J. Meyers, the supervisor of New Windsor, which includes 90 percent of the airport property, said that no matter what developers proposed, 3,000 acres would remain open because they are wetlands. "We need the rest back on the tax rolls," he said.
But Frank Hartmann, the executive vice president of the New York State Conservation Council, a group representing hunters and other sports enthusiasts, said the great value of the tract was its unbroken expanse. Turkey, deer and other wildlife need room to roam, he said, adding that few expanses of such size remained in the Hudson Valley.
"If you chop it up, you destroy it," Mr. Hartmann said. "The Governor is trying to please both sides. He wants to be the environmental Governor and the economic development governor. But you can't be both when it comes to this land."
Michael McKuen, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said that environmental groups had already seen ample evidence of the Governor's commitment to preserving land, and that they should have confidence that recreation and wildlife will remain part of any accepted plan.

HEADLINE: 30-Year Bond's Yield Drops To 6.66 Percent

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
In the absence of fresh economic news, Government securities traded higher yesterday as investors remained confident that the Federal Reserve would maintain a steady policy and refrain from raising interest rates next month.
Yields, which move in the opposite direction of price, fell to their lowest level in four months. They have fallen about a third of a percentage point over the last three weeks as Government reports signaled a slowdown in consumer demand and low inflation. 
 The 30-year bond rose 7/32 , to a price of 99 18/32 to yield 6.66 percent, down from 6.68 percent. For the week, the yield is down 6 basis points.
Analysts say that on days when there is no economic news, traders often follow the most recent trend, which has been up. But, they say, with each passing day traders grow increasingly reticent.
Patricia de Blank Klink, president of Advisers Capital Management, a firm specializing in fixed-income portfolio management, says she thinks the market is in one of those periods where the odds to trade up are better than those for trading down. "We think certainly in the longer term going out, the economy will begin to project strength in the third and fourth quarters this year," she said, "but we will not see any evidence until we're well into them."
Ms. Klink does not expect the Fed to raise interest rates at its meeting on July 1 and 2, but she says its August meeting will probably be more interesting. By then, she says, new economic data will have become "stronger and less market-friendly."
Among statistics awaiting the market next week are two measures of consumer psychology for the month of June: the Conference Board's consumer confidence index on Tuesday and the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index on Friday. Both are expected to continue to show that consumers remain ebullient. The report on new orders for durable goods, which economists say is an extremely important economic indicator, is scheduled for release on Wednesday; orders are expected to have risen moderately during May.

HEADLINE: Compromise Included In Senate Panel's Tax Bill

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
When the chief Republican tax writer, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, pushed a tax-cutting bill through the House Ways and Means Committee earlier this month, he did it without a single Democratic vote.
His counterpart in the Senate, William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Finance Committee, took a different approach, and late on Thursday night it paid off. All 9 of his committee's Democrats joined 9 of the 11 Republicans in approving his version of the bill. Both bills wouldabout $135 billion in tax cuts over five years, offset in part by more than $50 billion in revenue from new and extended taxes. 
 Like the House version, the Senate bill would create a credit of $500 a child for most families, offer tax breaks for college tuition, reduce the top rate on capital gains for individuals to 20 percent from 28 percent and cut the Federal inheritance tax. Both bills rely heavily on extending and expanding a tax on airline tickets to pay for the other cuts.
But while they are similar in most of their major provisions, the two bills differ in important details. The House bill, for example, would allow investors to take the effects of inflation into account when calculating capital gains, while the Senate bill would not. The Senate bill was rebuilt at the last minute around a 20-cent-a-pack tax on cigarettes, a measure not included in the House bill and one likely to produce heated opposition from the tobacco industry.
Scores of other provisions, from incentives for economic development in the nation's capital, to the way the tax code deal with aging cows, will have to be reconciled after the two chambers pass their versions of the bills.
Mr. Roth's success in cultivating bipartisan support should make it more likely that the bill will win approval on the Senate floor, where it will face further amendment, and it should give him leverage with Mr. Archer when they meet to work out the differences between their versions.
"We're going to the Senate floor with Republicans and Democrats as a team," Mr. Roth said.
But White House officials continued to criticize many elements of the Senate bill. They said a proposal inserted in the bill late Thursday to make more moderate- and low-income families eligible for the child credit did not go far enough to insure that the benefits of the tax cuts did not go primarily to the wealthy. And they said the bill should not allow any of the proceeds of the cigarette tax to help corporations and special interests rather than children and families.
Much of the bipartisan support for the bill was cemented early Thursday evening, when the members of the Finance Committee, meeting behind closed doors, made the decision to support the tobacco tax, a step that would raise $15 billion over five years -- money they could use to resolve problems that members of both parties had with the bill as it was originally drafted by Mr. Roth.
Instead of the parties being divided over whether the tax cuts would favor the wealthy at the expense of lower-income families -- the argument that dominated the House debate over the bill -- the Finance Committee members quickly united in dividing up the prospective proceeds of the cigarette tax in a way that would make as many of them happy as possible.
"You will never see representative government more specific than in the Senate Finance Committee," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the panel's ranking Democrat, who fought for provisions as small as a reduction in taxes on draft cider, a request from apple growers in his state. "It's a form of accommodation, and in between you think about the national interest, because there are things we all share."
With an eye toward satisfying the airline lobbyists who were complaining to members of both parties that their industry and its customers were unfairly affected by the bill, the committee reduced a proposed package of new and extended airline ticket taxes by $3.5 billion. To address the arguments by liberal Democrats and the Clinton Administration that the tax bill would benefit the wealthy disproportionately, the committee allocated $3 billion to making more low- and moderate-income families eligible for the $500 a child credit.
Responding to demands from conservatives, the committee agreed to use several hundred million dollars to speed up a proposed reduction in Federal inheritance taxes and to slightly reduce capital gains taxes on commercial real estate. About $300 million went to a series of narrow tax changes of interest to particular senators, like a provision pushed by Senator Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, a Democrat, to allow Individual Retirement Accounts to be invested in gold bullion.
At the insistence of Mr. Hatch, who argued that the proceeds of the tobacco tax should not go to special interests, most of what was left of the $15 billion -- about $8 billion -- went to increasing health care coverage for uninsured children.
The result was to give enough members of both parties a reason to vote for the bill. When the committee emerged from behind closed doors, it quickly voted 18 to 2 to send the bill to the Senate floor, where it will be taken up next week. All nine Democrats voted for the bill. Nine of the 11 Republicans voted in favor, with only two conservatives, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, voting against, saying they were opposed to new spending on social programs like the expanded child health plan.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Pension Deal Is Rated

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A major financial rating service, Moody's Investors Service Inc., assigned an A1 rating yesterday to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's offering of $2.75 billion in bonds to bolster the state pension fund and help balance the budget. The rating is less than Moody's top ratings of Aaa and Aa, and the service warned that the bond deal could leave the state "less well-prepared" and less flexible to deal with a slower economy.
State Treasurer Brian Clymer said that Moody's was off base with its criticism, saying that the bond sale has the blessing of Wall Street and that municipal bond insurers are lining up to cover the sale. 
 Two other investors' services -- Standard & Poors and Fitch -- gave the bond issue ratings that were one notch below their top ratings. Standard & Poor's said the state "will continue to face fiscal challenges in the future, and economic growth will be necessary to maintain fiscal balance."

Unemployment Inches Up

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 5.3 percent in May, from 5.2 percent, the first increase this year, but State Labor Department officials said the change was statistically insignificant. Because the rate has been below 5.5 percent for the last three months, the economy is still considered very strong, said James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. The nation's jobless rate for May was 4.8 percent.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Gooden Pitches His Way Into Starting Forefront

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, June 20

 BODY:
Before Dwight Gooden dug his cleats into the mound, before he reached for the resin bag and before he uncorked his first official pitch tonight, he had been given an important comfort zone. The Yankees ripped Charles Nagy for three runs in the top of the first inning, and now to Gooden the Indians looked less daunting and Jacobs Field, which is rarely threatening to New York, looked even less imposing.
To a returning pitcher whose starts are being scrutinized and whose emotional state is still somewhat fragile, those runs meant everything. Gooden could relax, he could make a mistake, he could pitch his game. He did precisely that, never letting the gasping Indians breathe and pitching the Yankees to a 7-1 victory. He just might be a factor after all this season. 
 "That helped me a lot," he said of the early lead. "That lets you be more aggressive. If you fall behind, you can go after them a little more. That was real big."
Tonight's six superb innings were an important statement from Gooden, especially since Hideki Irabu tossed five more scoreless innings tonight, for Class AA Norwich, to continue steamrolling toward the major leagues. The triumph was also an important statement from the Yankees, who did not suffer a letdown following their riveting series against the Mets and continued their unparalleled success at this four-year-old ballpark.
But tonight was more about Gooden than the Yankees or Irabu. In his second start since his hernia surgery April 14, Gooden throttled the Indians on one run -- unearned -- and four hits while striking out two and walking two. If he pitches this way consistently, he will be chosen over Kenny Rogers and Ramiro Mendoza when Irabu cracks the rotation in three weeks.
"When Irabu gets here, we're going to have to make changes," Manager Joe Torre said. "The thing I like about Doc is he got better. He knows how to pitch. That's so important."
Although they pitched on the same night, Gooden treated questions about Irabu the way he now treats queries about his fight with an Arlington, Tex. cab driver.
"I don't think about that," he said. "I would love to pitch with him. But I'm not worried about someone taking my job or pitching out of the bullpen or being traded. I can't worry about things I can't control."
Gooden tossed an economical 88 pitches, making the Indians grimace again with the Yankees visiting. The Yankees were 6-0 at Jacobs Field last year, and they are 13-2 at this ballpark, making them the only opponent with a winning record here.
Gooden benefited from the outburst in the first -- Tino Martinez's 22d homer and run-scoring hits from Pat Kelly and Paul O'Neill.
"You can feel as comfortable as you want," Derek Jeter said. "You still have to go out and pitch. Doc did."
Gooden's dances with danger were infrequent, but he conquered them. With two Indians on and two out in the first, he struck out David Justice on a breaking pitch and plowed through the third after the Indians scored their only run. He held the Indians to one hit in eight at-bats with runners on base to improve his won-lost record to 2-0, chop his earned run average to 3.78 from 5.91 and vault the Yankees (40-30) 10 games over .500 for the first time this year.
Despite Gooden's rosy outing, his fastball was not overpowering.
"He's not there yet," Torre said. "I think he's going to get there."
Even Gooden said: "I'll take that, but I'm not going to kid myself. I need to have a better fastball."
Before some fans in the crowd of 43,019 had bitten into their first hot dog, the Yankees had abused Nagy, an eight-game winner, for three runs on five hits.
Jeter and Kelly stroked back-to-back doubles to make it 1-0, and, after Kelly stole third, O'Neill's single made the score 2-0. Two outs later, Martinez swatted a 1-2 breaking pitch off the right-field foul pole for his first homer in nine games and his second hit in 23 at-bats to shove Nagy in a 3-0 ditch.
Nagy had been the essence of consistency, pitching into the seventh inning in his last 14 starts, but he did not make it beyond the second tonight. Two walks and Jeter's single loaded the bases with two out in the second, and Nagy ended his evening by walking Cecil Fielder to boost the score to 4-0.
 
INSIDE PITCH
Either RAMIRO MENDOZA, who pitched a scoreless ninth, or KENNY ROGERS, who warmed up in the bullpen tonight, will start on Tuesday in Detroit. "They haven't said anything to me," Rogers said. . . . CHARLIE HAYES might rest his sore left groin longer since WADE BOGGS had two hits and a sacrifice fly. . . . DEREK JETER roped three hits and is batting .365 as a leadoff hitter.

HEADLINE: THE TOBACCO AGREEMENT: THE LAWMAKERS;
Lawmakers Vow Close Scrutiny of Tobacco Pact

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
News of a settlement between tobacco companies and antismoking forces today stirred cautious reactions from many on Capitol Hill and outright skepticism from others. But members of Congress on both sides of the debate agreed that any deal that eventually wins their approval will require a mountain of legislative and bureaucratic changes.
"We're going to look at it slowly and carefully," Speaker Newt Gingrich said. 
 News of the $360 billion settlement between the tobacco companies and the attorneys general of 40 states hit Capitol Hill when many lawmakers were already headed home.
Significantly, none of those who were still at work and eager to take the microphone to react, rejected the idea of a settlement outright. But within an hour, some lawmakers were making it clear that today's agreement would be taken by Congress as essentially a rough draft that would have to be rewritten.
"I don't expect Congress to rubber-stamp it," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a New Jersey Democrat and one of the most ardent tobacco foes on Capitol Hill. "There are devils in the agreement that we will have to get out of there."
Mr. Lautenberg said that among the "devils in the details" he foresaw were the need to enact laws to limit the liability of the tobacco industry and to decide who gets what money, including how much lawyers should be paid.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, complained that the proposal was "clearly under-funded" and contained one "glaring omission."
"Any agreement should include a very substantial payment to the Federal Government for the costs incurred by Medicare, veteran's health programs, and other Federal health programs for the treatment of tobacco-related illnesses," Mr. Kennedy said.
Initial reactions like those hinted at the subtle ways that the politics of tobacco have changed as the negotiations over today's agreement proceeded -- and at how the two sides of the fight over cigarettes will have to find new ways to accommodate.
President Clinton, for example, took credit in Denver today for forcing the tobacco companies to the bargaining table by seeking to regulate the industry. But he held the bargain itself at arm's length, as the White House had carefully kept the negotiations at arm's length, saying he needed to give the agreement "strict scrutiny" to see if it "advances the public health and will reduce the number of children who are smoking cigarettes."
As expected, Senator Lauch Faircloth, a North Carolina Republican who is one of tobacco's staunchest defenders, expressed some opposition, but in populist terms. Mr. Faircloth warned that he would fight any plan by big lawyers that he felt hurt the little guy -- tobacco farmers who form the base of his state's agricultural economy.
Some antitobacco lawmakers worried that any deal the cigarette companies signed must be a loaded one. And others began adding conditions.
Three Democratic Senators from non-tobacco-growing states, for instance, urged that any settlement approved by Congress and the White House include provisions to address worldwide tobacco sales by American cigarette manufacturers.
Many of those who reacted to the news of the tobacco deal said they had not had the chance to study it in any detail. But at first glance they said it would require major new legislation, including redefining the role of the Federal Drug Administration to give the agency more authority.
Mr. Kennedy, the senior Democrat on the Labor and Human Resources Committee, said that the deal raised more questions than it answered" and that he was wary of it.
"Given the track record, deceit, manipulation and bad faith by the tobacco industry, there is every reason to be skeptical of any agreement which the tobacco industry is willing to support," he said.
There is a sizable contingent of antitobacco members in both houses of Congress, where 76 members from both sides of the aisle are part of the Congressional Task Force on Tobacco and Health. But as Mr. Lautenberg warned today, "The industry still has friends in Congress."
No one on Capitol Hill is more supportive of tobacco than Mr. Faircloth, which would seem to make it unlikely that he would ultimately oppose a deal struck by the big tobacco companies themselves. But the Senator said today that he had some problems with the agreement.
"The Government, the public interests groups, the tobacco companies and the trial lawyers sitting at the negotiating table can all take care of themselves," Mr. Faircloth said. "My concern is the farmers and factory workers who aren't even allowed in that room."
"We may know the broad outlines of a settlement but I'm interested in the fine print," he continued. "People will continue to use tobacco, so surely an agreement can be reached that both stops under-age smoking and protects the interests of farmers and factory workers."
But the three Democratic Senators threatened an even wider fight over the issue, asking the President to back provisions for worldwide sanctions against tobacco companies.
"The responsibility of the Congress and the Administration in this matter does not end at our water's edge, Senators Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, Tom Harkin of Iowa and Ron Wyden of Oregon said in a letter to Mr. Clinton. "The efforts to reduce and eliminate smoking by minors in this country should not be bankrolled by the unimpeded and likely accelerated marketing and promotion of U.S. tobacco products to youngsters abroad."
In Denver, before a meeting at the economic summit meeting he is attending, Mr. Clinton commended the attorneys general and others who sued the companies. But he said that before judging the agreement's merits he was appointing Bruce Reed, his domestic policy adviser, and Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to examine it for "a matter of weeks, not months."
In the meantime, he said, the Administration would continue with its own efforts to regulate tobacco. The best political outcome, one senior Administration official said today, was also the most rigorous possible agreement with the industry -- or, failing that, the stiffest possible regulation to protect public health.
Mr. Clinton said today thathe still had many questions, including how much freedom the Food and Drug Administration would have to regulate tobacco.
"The No. 1 thing for us would be the scope and nature of the F.D.A. jurisdiction and then how will the money be spent, will it really advance the public health," he said.
Michael D. McCurry, the President's press secretary, said the negotiators late in the talks sought a signal from the White House about what it would consider acceptable. "The likelihood that this agreement will pass muster was increased by the fact that we refrained from sending that signal," he said, noting that the attorneys general "got concessions even at the 11th hour."
Another official said that, had it participated directly in the talks, the Administration would have faced two risks. The deal might look less palatable to the Republican Congress if it was perceived as a Clinton product; and if public health groups decided to fight the agreement, the tobacco industry might feel emboldened to resist all regulation.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 915 words

HEADLINE: Children's Books

BYLINE: By Christopher Paul Curtis; Christopher Paul Curtis is the author of "The Watsons Go to Birmingham -- 1963," a 1996 Newbery Honor Book.

 BODY:

FREEDOM'S GIFTS
 A Juneteenth Story.
 By Valerie Wesley.
 Illustrated by Sharon Wilson.
 Unpaged. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $16.
 (Ages 8 and up)
 
 A PLACE CALLED FREEDOM
 By Scott Russell Sanders.
 Illustrated by Thomas B. Allen.
 Unpaged. New York:
 Atheneum. $16. (Ages 5 to 8)
 
 CELEBRATION!
 By Jane Resh Thomas.
 Illustrated by Raul Colon.
 Unpaged. New York:
 Hyperion. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) 
 Novelists mosey in their work, taking great stretches of prose to develop character, setting and plot. Storybook authors have no such luxury, and must convey everything economically. The novelist, like a marathon runner, has time to recover from mistakes. If the author of a storybook stumbles, it usually means the race is over, no matter how hard an artist tries to compensate with illustrations.
Valerie Wesley's "Freedom's Gifts: A Juneteenth Story" is a "nine flat" sprinter of a tale. It takes off running and never slows. The setting is Texas during World War II, and within the story of a multigenerational family gathering is an explanation of how the freeing of African-American slaves in the Lone Star State came a full two and a half years after Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, on a day known as Juneteenth and, since 1979, celebrated as a state holiday on June 19.
The core of the plot is a visit by June's cousin Lillie, from New York City. She is none too impressed by Texas or this celebration of a "slave holiday." Wesley beautifully charts the girls' growing friendship, and Sharon Wilson's illustrations bring the text alive. Anyone who has seen two sassy little girls going at each other with hands on hips and lips stuck out will recognize the dead-on accuracy of the postures. The muted colors of Wilson's illustrations combine perfectly with Wesley's gentle text.
The author of "Where Do I Go From Here?" and "Afro-Bets Book of Black Heroes From A to Z" as well as the Tamara Hayle adult mystery series, Valerie Wesley makes the language in "Freedom's Gifts" sing. For children 8 and older, the ones who read independently but still like lots of illustrations, this is a delightful treat.
Scott Russell Sanders's book, "A Place Called Freedom," stumbles leaving the blocks. From the opening paragraph ("The master of that big house set us free in the spring of 1832") to the time that Papa, in what has to be the all-time record for bountiful harvests, raises enough cash to buy his own land in one season, it glosses over the horrors and difficulties faced by newly freed slaves.
Even coming from a 7-year-old narrator, many of the statements (like "Again and again Papa went back to Tennessee and each time he came home with more of the folks we loved") beg for some explanation. How did Papa accomplish such miraculous feats? The reader is left with the impression that leaving slavery was as simple as packing up and hitting the road.
Sanders is the author of many books for children, but the language here is sometimes awkward. The young narrator describes the land along the Wabash, "where the dirt was as black as my skin" -- hardly the kind of comparison an African-American would make in the 1830's. Until the mid-1960's, being called "black" was considered extremely pejorative by most African-Americans.
Even Thomas B. Allen's sensitive, beautifully drawn pastel illustrations, particularly lovely depicting people at work, are unable to make "A Place Called Freedom" seem an accurate portrayal of the growth of a free African-American town.
"Celebration!," written by Jane Resh Thomas and illustrated by Raul Colon, is a snapshot of an African-American family's annual Fourth of July picnic. Although grins abound (annoyingly so) in Colon's exuberant watercolor, etched paper and colored pencil illustrations, there is a lot of pain crammed into this slender book. What with Grandpa's stroke, Maurice's shoplifting, Uncle Frank's drinking problem, the appearance of buppie Uncle Charlie in his Bermuda shorts and the consumption of uncooked hot dogs, there seems to be scant cause for this group's levity.
Most problematic is the way the story brushes uncomfortably close to stereotypes. We meet the apparently unmarried "broody old hen" Aunt Lou, with her six young children; the basketball-obsessed Maurice, who wants to change his name to Michael to honor Michael Jordan; and Kenny, who constantly practices shuffling cards and (in a line that made me go back several times to make sure I hadn't misread it) aspires to be a tap dancer when he grows up.
"Celebration!" also has some false notes. One of the young girls in the story has a doll described as "her best brown doll," which simply does not ring true. If the story were being told about a white child, a line about "her best pink doll" would be jarring -- the converse is equally unsettling. There is also a passage that describes Uncle Frank bringing boxes of sparklers to the party, yet the illustration shows him carrying what appear to be boxes of videocassette tapes (they even seem to have "VHS" written on the sides).
These flaws keep "Celebration!" from hitting its stride. Since we learn so much negative information about this family so quickly, we come to think that instead of getting together to celebrate, they've come together to dish the dirt on the late arrivals. Which from an adult perspective is, I suppose, probably a little too much like a real family reunion -- but not enough like a story for 4- to 8-year-olds.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 5; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1290 words

HEADLINE: Beautiful Dreamer

BYLINE: By Margo Jefferson; Margo Jefferson is a cultural critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:

DOO-DAH!
 Stephen Foster and the Rise
 of American Popular Culture.
 By Ken Emerson.
 Illustrated. 400 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $30. 
 Popular music exists to make everything we hold pure -- traditions, styles, techniques, ethnic and racial boundaries -- impure. It bastardizes and crossbreeds whatever it finds, and that includes our definitions of good and bad taste. The good, the bad and the shameless are right in there together; they inflect (or infect) one another within an instant or a microtone.
No songwriter illustrates this better than Stephen Foster. You know his songs; you probably sang them at some impressionable stage in your youth, complete with gimcrack Negro dialect or genteel Anglo-Saxon versifying: "Beautiful Dreamer," "Oh! Susanna," "Jeanie With the Light Brown Hair," "Old Folks at Home" and "Camptown Races." Foster's once-celebrated slave elegy "Old Black Joe" is shamefully easy to confuse with his once-celebrated canine elegy "Old Dog Tray," but "My Old Kentucky Home, Good-Night!" and "Hard Times Come Again No More" are still as easy to love as they are to sing.
Foster was the first professional American songwriter to show that the United States was capable of achieving cultural as well as political independence from Europe. Ken Emerson's "Doo-dah!" (as in "De Camptown ladies sing dis song / Doo-dah! Doo-dah!") is aptly subtitled "Stephen Foster and the Rise of American Popular Culture." It is a vigorous, thoroughly researched, amiably chatty tour through his life and his times.
Foster was born on July 4, 1826, as the nation was marking its 50th year of independence from England. He died in 1864, one year before the end of the country's second struggle for independence, the Civil War. His life as a songwriter drew on every national and cultural conflict. His songs incorporate the tradition of feminized, Euro-American lyricism and that of masculinized, Afro-Americanized minstrelsy (styles in whiteface versus styles in blackface). Proslavery pieties are layered over intimations of abolitionism. Art song aspirations are found alongside folk song imitations. Hymns and chaste parlor ballads cohabit with polkas, jigs, breakdowns and rowdy buck dances.
Foster grew up in Pittsburgh just as his prosperous family began a decline into shabby and resentful gentility. His earliest sense was of bygone pleasures and glories. Adored by his mother and tolerated by his father, he turned out to be good for nothing but music, dropping in and out of schools, rejecting careers in the Army and Navy, and fleeing the business world that his brothers kept working in and his father kept failing in. Small wonder that his musical imagination veered toward the naive, the elegiac and the Edenic. Whether in the highbrow parlor tradition or the lowbrow minstrel vein, his songs evoke a world of bourgeois prettiness he had lost or a world of plantation griefs and joys he had never experienced.
"Not once in his entire career," Emerson tells us, "did Stephen Foster write a song . . . that alluded to Pittsburgh. He was in deep denial, if not outright defiance, of the economic, political, racial and even environmental realities of the city where he passed most of his life."
But in fact if not in fiction, popular culture always thrives on technology and industry. Improvements in transportation, printing and communications made Foster's songwriting career possible, though copyright laws kept it from being very remunerative. "Oh! Susanna," published in 1848, was his first hit; it became an anthem for the gold rush and the temperance movement, and was translated into languages as far-flung as Latin and Hindi. Foster gave it to his publisher for nothing, and the publisher made something like $10,000 from it.
It was the presence of new (or at least fresh) music in the United States that made Foster's songs last. His music responded more readily than his lyrics to what was contemporary and unsanctioned. He responded to the Irish, Scottish and English ballads that were being imported and amended. He responded to all kinds of dance forms. And most important, he responded to the vulgar, heady minstrel show, with its love-hate ties to African-Americans and to music-theater miscegenation. (Minstrelsy swept the country in the 19th century just as ragtime, jazz and rock would in the 20th.)
Inevitably, he got caught in the middle of America's continuing race and culture wars. "Mr. Foster possesses more than ordinary abilities as a composer; and we hope he will soon realize enough from his Ethiopian melodies to enable him to afford to drop them and turn his attention to the production of a higher kind of music," a writer for a journal called The Musical World pontificated in 1853. "We were glad to learn from Mr. F. that he intends to devote himself principally hereafter to the production of 'White men's' music."
Not long before, Foster had written an anguished letter to the leader of the minstrel troupe that performed -- and took credit for composing -- his blackface melodies. He had left his name off them, he said, "owing to the prejudice against them by some, which might injure my reputation as a writer of another style of music, but I find that by my efforts I have done a great deal to build up a taste for the Ethiopian songs among refined people by making the words suitable to their taste, instead of the trashy and really offensive words which belong to some songs of that order. Therefore I have concluded to reinstate my name on my songs and to pursue the Ethiopian business without fear or shame. . . . I find I cannot write at all unless I write for the public approbation and get credit for what I write."
He got credit, he made the best living he could, and in the end he drank most of that living and much of his talent away. Foster died at the age of 37 at Bellevue Hospital in New York City.
Emerson, a former editor at New York Newsday and The New York Times Magazine, wants his book to be a cultural epic, and to that end he has surrounded Foster with a huge cast of well-known characters. Harriet Beecher Stowe makes a brief appearance (Foster's original title for "My Old Kentucky Home, Good-Night!" was "Poor Uncle Tom, Good Night"). So does Louis Moreau Gottschalk, who incorporated Foster's Ethiopian melodies into a symphony. So does Martin Delany, the black radical, who turned "Old Uncle Ned," Foster's treacly lament for a dead slave, into an abolitionist's revenge anthem. Assorted 19th-century writers are quoted liberally, as are assorted 20th-century cultural historians.
EMERSON continually compares minstrelsy to rock-and-roll, and he's right to, though he names too many names along the way (Elvis, the Beach Boys, Berry Gordy, John Lennon, the Beastie Boys). He is also right (and more precise) when he shows how quickly certain stylistic and commercial pop conventions were codified: the sexual segregation of the marketplace, for instance, into male performers and female consumers; the struggle between the music people loved and the music they respected; the nasty racial and ethnic conflicts side by side with canny racial and ethnic collaborations.
Can a writer help taking on some of his subject's best and worst characteristics? Emerson keeps emphasizing the unsettling divisions in Foster's life and work: the way he veered from melancholy to ebullience, shrewdness to near-hopeless naivete, conservative to progressive impulses. His own book keeps veering from historical minutiae to grand metaphorical assertion. It is not that both don't belong there; it's that for all the book's virtues, they're a little out of control. The intentions are exactly right. The proportions are slightly off.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2969 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
London, From the Outskirts In

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
EARLY one morning in May, I saw a red fox in Holland Park in London. It scurried across the lawn in the Kyoto Garden before vanishing into a rhododendron bush. Amazed, I sank down onto a bench, wondering whether the Mad Hatter would turn up next.
Later, I learned that foxes aren't uncommon in the leafy precincts of Holland, Regent's and Hyde Parks. But spotting one seemed an intimate encounter with the city I had known only as a collection of tourist attractions: the Tower of London, the theaters of the West End, Buckingham Palace. 
 Returning just to deepen my acquaintance with the city would have been reason enough for another trip. But since my last visit two years ago, London has become energized and flush, with a rebounding economy, hopeful new Labor Government and tourists arriving in flocks.
The influx has affected prices, particularly in sophisticated new restaurants, where pies and roasts have given way to entrees like medallions of rare tuna in wasabi sauce and the bill for a three-course dinner is generally 50 percent higher than in New York.
Finding reasonably priced lodgings in London has always been a challenge. Recently, a number of small boutique hotels have opened with theatrical rooms for $100 to $140, and a hostel with a futuristic theme called the Generator has come to Bloomsbury. But for those who just want a clean, quiet, inexpensive place to sleep, the choices are the same as ever: B & B's in private homes and budget hotels along confusingly similar 19th-century terraces, providing full English breakfasts and cramped, rather characterless rooms in the $65 to $100 range, with sinks (or en suite baths for $15 to $35 more).
So I decided to seek out three places to stay (for two nights each) in interesting neighborhoods -- in the hope that the areas themselves would lend color to otherwise bland budget accommodations. It wouldn't trouble me if the neighborhoods were some distance from the heart of the city, because I knew I could trust London's mass-transit system to take me into central London whenever I wanted. But mostly, I planned to settle in, eat at restaurants favored by residents, and find out what there was to see close at hand.
I had in mind areas like hip Notting Hill, Camden Town, with its popular weekend market, and the recently revitalized Docklands, a development of condos and office buildings among the old warehouses of the East End. But there are almost no budget hotels in these places, so I chose Kensington, just south of Notting Hill, Marylebone, in easy reach of Regent's Park and Camden Town, and Greenwich, connected to the Docklands by a foot tunnel under the River Thames.
The Abbey House Hotel in Kensington is a budget London classic, on a peaceful Victorian square surrounding a pretty little private garden just west of Kensington Palace. The Abbey and the Vicarage next door are the only hotels in the immediate area. When I arrived, a young American student who'd just finished a course at the nearby Kensington Campus of King's College and her fatigued mother were lugging huge suitcases up the elegantly balustraded stairs. There was no bellboy, or even an elevator, and my small single (about $65) was on the third floor.
I know people who have baths the size of this room. But a comfortable single bed, TV, armoire, desk and chair fit in it (with the toilet and shower rooms just down the hall), and there was a big window overlooking the square.
Bounded by prim Kensington Gardens to the east, shaggier Holland Park to the west, the 250-foot spire of the Gothic Revival St. Mary Abbots Church to the south and a useful Underground stop (Notting Hill Gate) to the north, Kensington has a well-off, settled air. Open curtains revealed handsomely furnished living rooms and in one case, a maid, wearing the sort of white and black uniform you normally only see in Marx Brothers films.
Department stores line Kensington High Street, but its bustle gives way to antique shops on Kensington Church Street. A block east, a graceful private road with a guard booth and foreign embassies leads directly to Kensington Palace, a stately building that became a royal residence in the reign of William and Mary, and was renovated by two great Renaissance architects, Christopher Wren and Nicholas Hawksmoor (admission $8.50). The Princess of Wales, Princess Margaret and the Duke and Duchess of Kent have apartments there (which, of course, you can't see), but the beautiful bed in which Queen Victoria was born in 1819 impressed me most.
The sunken garden, Orangerie tea house, bushes trimmed to look like gumdrops and Round Pond nearby are beautiful, too, providing a striking contrast to the romantic disorder of Holland Park. It spreads across 54 acres surrounding Holland House, built in 1605 but so heavily damaged during the Blitz that it now remains a dreamy sort of ruin. The restored east wing, is occupied by a hostel, where those who don't mind dormitory accommodations can find a bed-and-breakfast for about $30 a night.
I liked to roam in the park, spotting moorhens, sparrow hawks and Londoners taking the sun in shockingly skimpy bathing suits. Then I'd retire to a pub nearby called Windsor Castle, serving light fare like mussels cooked in the Belgian way with leeks and cream ($10), or to Geale's Fish Restaurant just off Notting Hill Gate, where I finally understood why the English are so mad about fish and chips. I've never tasted fried fish as delicious as the haddock I had there ($11).
ON my last afternoon in the neighborhood, I wandered north into Notting Hill, once crowned by a race course called the Hippodrome and later by more Victorian terraces occupied by wave after wave of immigrants from Ireland, eastern Europe and the Caribbean.
The neighborhood hit hard times in the 1950's, but has since rebounded in its own funky way, with a rambunctious August street fair that draws pop music fans from all over Europe, the headquarters of Virgin Records in an old dock by the Grand Union Canal, trendy restaurants and bars like Beach Blanket Babylon, and a market on Portobello Road. There, fruit and vegetable peddlers call out their wares as if in a musical comedy, shops sell or rent glad rags from the 60's, and on a cross street, Blenheim Crescent, I chanced upon the Travel Bookshop, where I spent a blissful hour.
The move to Marylebone was something of a shock, particularly when the first thing I saw upon ascending to the street from the Baker Street station was a tout in a checkered cape, with a pipe, urging me to visit the Sherlock Holmes Museum, near Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum. I didn't bother with either, though the lines at Madame Tussaud's made me wonder what I was missing.
Instead, I got to know Marylebone, once a village named for St. Mary-le-bourne outside the city of London with a twisting main street known as Marylebone Lane, and still more terrace homes facing their own private gardens. On Paddington Street, I dined on swordfish tandoori ($15) and a delicious eggplant dish called bonjon ($8.50) in an Afghan restaurant, Caravan Serai.
And around the corner in a French bakery called Patisserie Valerie on Marylebone High, I learned that Londoners really prefer croissants and cafe au lait to those big, unvarying English hotel breakfasts -- a cereal course, followed by eggs, sausage or bacon, grilled vegetables and cold toast.
That's what they served at the Hart House Hotel on Gloucester Place where I stayed while in Marylebone -- an exceptionally well-kept place on a Georgian terrace favored by refugee aristocrats during the French Revolution. Recently renovated, the hotel has handsome trappings: patterned carpets and matching bedspreads and curtains, spotless shared baths and $83 single rooms slightly larger than those at the Abbey House.
All of the singles overlook Gloucester Place, a noisy bus route. After one night, I told the front desk clerk that I'd have to leave if she couldn't find me a quieter room (Gloucester Place has plenty of lodging alternatives). So she gave me a deal on a spacious, tranquil double in the back, normally $117, but $102 for the aggrieved.
Buses may be noisy, but they do help you get around, as I found when I caught a red double-decker on Gloucester Place (for $1.55) to the Camden Town market on a balmy Saturday afternoon. There, stalls selling clothes, food, tapes, jewelry, used furniture and bric-a-brac spill out from Chalk Farm Road. I had vegetable curry for lunch ($4.25) at one called the Hungry Elephant, followed by a scoop of lemon sorbet at Marine Ices ($1.70).
A long, narrow canal boat called the Jenny Wren still plies a small section of the Regent's Canal, which passes through Regent's Park and Camden Town on its way to the River Thames. The canal was built around 1820 by George IV's favorite architect, John Nash, who was also responsible for Regent's Park and a number of the stately neo-classical terraces that surround it.
I took the Jenny Wren one way ($6) to the pretty canal-side hamlet of Maida Vale, passing the old Gilbey's Gin Factory, London Central Mosque and long-horned sheep grazing in the London Zoo along the way. When I debarked, I found a picturesque spot for a cappuccino, the Cafe Laville, built atop a tunnel that spans the canal at Edgware Road.
From there it was about a 20-minute walk to glorious Regent's Park, which Nash conceived as a residential estate for "the wealthy and the good." A few mansions were built, like St. John's Lodge, with a pretty secret garden, but eventually its sweeping greenswards, serpentine lake and manicured Inner Circle were opened to the public.
The zoo and an open-air theater were added this century, as was Queen Mary's Garden in the gated Inner Circle -- like a page out of a Laura Ashley catalogue, where neat beds of roses tilt their heads to the sun, couples picnic beneath bowers and little girls in Mary Janes chase butterflies. If you cross over Bayswater Road to the north, you can climb to the top of Primrose Hill for a nonpareil view of the city from St. Paul's to Westminster.
Maybe it was this that made me yearn for central London again. So the next day, I took the subway to the Victoria and Albert Museum, primarily to see Raphael's tapestry cartoons and a special exhibit called "The Cutting Edge: 50 Years of British Fashion," showcasing the work of English designers from 1947 to the present (admission $8.50). The fancy dresses there were divine, especially a cream satin strapless gown designed in 1957 by Norman Hartnell for the Queen, a remarkable green silk neo-rococo creation by Vivienne Westwood, "Watteau 1996," and a black crepe mini-dress by Mary Quant I wondered whether I could pull off wearing.
Marylebone has its own splendid museum, the Wallace Collection, which is free. It is in the dignified Hertford House on Manchester Square, which remains largely as it was in 1897 when Lady Wallace gave her late husband's art treasures to the state. Its 18th-century French paintings rival the Louvre's, including frothy works by Fragonard, Boucher and Watteau, and there is Sevres porcelain, arms and armor and other riches.
To reach Greenwich, I took an excursion boat ($9.50 one way) from Westminster Pier five miles down the River Thames around the Isle of Dogs, which is really a peninsula. The garden at its southern tip is a stop on the new Docklands Light Railway, an elevated train that takes East Enders along the north bank of the river to a station near the Tower of London. Island Gardens also looks across the Thames to one of London's most magnificent sights -- the Queen's House, the National Maritime Museum next door, the twin-domed Naval College, the Old Royal Observatory at the summit of Greenwich Park and the filigreed rigging of the Cutty Sark berthed at the dock.
Many visitors to London make Greenwich the subject of a day trip, but you can't begin to see it in so short a time. I'd planned to stay for two nights, though it wasn't easy finding accommodations because the town has just one rather unattractive hotel, the Mitre, which is a pub with nicely renovated rooms upstairs, and a handful of B & B's. I stayed at one of them, lured by the $34 rate.
It was about a 20-minute walk west of the dock, in an area of row houses and housing complexes where the town's charm peters out. But the owners, Chris and Carol Courtney, made all the difference, introducing me to other guests from Hong Kong and France, offering me coffee and dessert in the evenings, and chatting over breakfast about subjects as varied as a single European currency and the peccadillos of the royal family. My first-floor single was a little dark, but comfortable, the shared baths were clean and when I snooped around, I found three other rooms more pleasant than mine.
In two days, I managed to tour the Queen's House; jog around the observatory bisected by the Prime Meridian; meander east along the River Walk to the Trafalgar Tavern, built in 1837, for a sunset gin and tonic; sample a chicken and mushroom pie at Goddard's Pie and Eel Shop on Greenwich Church Street ($3.60); walk through the foot tunnel to the Isle of Dogs to catch a ride into London on the Docklands Light Railway, and take in an exhibit at the Maritime Museum on the exploits of Admiral Nelson, who went to sea at age 12 and became one of England's greatest heroes. (Admission to the Queen's House, Maritime Museum and Old Royal Observatory costs $9.35 total, but I got it for a 20 percent discount by showing my Thames cruise ticket stub).
On my last night, I splurged on dinner at a simple but elegant small restaurant called the Spread Eagle in Greenwich, with a prix fixe menu for $29. I ordered smooth, delicious celery and stilton soup, followed by chicken fricassee. Usually, I pore over a guidebook while at meals. But this time I tucked mine away, and sat there like an habitue.
 
The bottom line: Central London is but a train or boat away
I spent an average of $106 a day while in London, including $60 for accommodations.
To reach London from New York in mid-May, I bought a round-trip ticket from an airline wholesaler, Discount Travel International, 169 West 81st Street, New York, N.Y., 10024; (212) 362-3636. I flew on Virgin Atlantic for $437.
London subways and buses are highly recommended; fares depend on how many zones you plan to travel.
One-day and one-week travel cards that include the Underground, Docklands Light Railway, some buses and Southeast Network trains (which stop at Greenwich) are available. Daily cards cost about $4.75 to $6.40; weekly cards cost $18.60 to $52.75. For information, contact London Regional Transport, (44-171) 222 1234.
Westminster-Greenwich Thames Passenger Boat Services can be contacted at (44-171) 930 4097. Its cruises embark from Westminster Pier on the Victoria Embankment, and some include rides on the Docklands Light Railway.
The Jenny Wren cruises the Regent's Canal from Camden Town to Little Venice. For information, call (44-171) 485 4433.
General information is available from the British Tourist Authority, 551 Fifth Avenue, Seventh Floor, New York, N.Y. 10176; (212) 986-2200.
Next door, Britrail's British Travel Bookshop, (212) 490-6688, fax (212) 490-0219, fax , is a good source for guidebooks. While there, or in London, look especially for an invaluable street atlas, "London A-Z," published by Geographers' A-Z Map Company ($10.95).

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Restoring a Fine Khmer Craft Rent by Revolution

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
IN 1995, KIKUO MORIMOTO, a Japanese weaver and textile expert, traveled by motorcycle, by boat and on foot through the forests and jungles of Cambodia in search of master weavers. Everywhere he went, he showed pieces of boldly patterned Khmer silks taken from 19th-century costumes and temple hangings to shopkeepers in hopes of finding weavers who were still producing such work.
For centuries, men had raised the silkworms, and women had tie-dyed the yarns and woven them into ikat fabrics, for which Cambodia was renowned. Then in 1970, when civil war broke out, women had to abandon their looms. Five years later under the Khmer Rouge, families were uprooted and forced into slave labor, digging canals and working fields far from their own villages. As a result, traditional silk weaving ceased, natural dyes disappeared, silkworms vanished, and the mulberry trees, grown for the leaves fed to the silkworms, were left untended and died. 
 In his travels, Mr. Morimoto visited 50 villages in 8 provinces, and what he found was that as Cambodian society begins to return to normalcy some looms are humming again. Today, affluent women are seeking the brilliantly colored silks that for centuries have been worn in costumes on national holidays or hung behind the Buddhist statues in their temples and homes.
"We want to restore weaving to Cambodian village life," said Mr. Morimoto, who at 49 divides his time between here and Bangkok, Thailand, where his wife and children live. He has spent the last 15 years teaching traditional dyeing and weaving techniques primarily in the refugee camps in Thailand and Cambodia. The goal of his trip was to conduct a survey of Cambodian weaving, a study that was commissioned by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
After he completed his research and submitted his report, Mr. Morimoto set up the Institute for Khmer Traditional Textiles, of which he is the acting director. The institute is helping to revive traditional weaving in Cambodian villages. The bulk of its financial support, $50,000 a year for the last two years, comes from the Japan Foundation, a Government agency that supports cultural exchanges, and the institute is housed in a two-story studio in Takhmau, a town about 10 miles southwest of here.
Mr. Morimoto's efforts are attracting the attention of textile experts far from here. When H. Leedom Lefferts Jr., an American, visited the studio last December, he was impressed by what he saw.
"In addition to producing fabrics for their own clothes, weaving gives Cambodian women a supplementary income," said Mr. Lefferts, an expert on Southeast Asian textiles who is a professor of anthropology at Drew University in Madison, N.J. "Most important of all, it gives them a role in Khmer culture."
These days, thanks largely to Mr. Morimoto's efforts, traditional weaving is on the upswing in Cambodia. Mr. Morimoto planted 60 mulberry trees of different varieties in the front yard of the institute's studio and expects to raise silkworms there too in the future. The silkworms raised in Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam, he said, produce distinctive yellow yarns that are finer, stronger and more lustrous than the white ones found elsewhere in Asia.
Under Mr. Morimoto's direction, a pilot program of silkworm cultivation has begun in the village of Takov in Kampot province, some 75 miles south of the capital. There a team of 43 villagers, including 15 who are mostly in their 60's and 70's, are involved, in cultivating silkworms using methods they learned in their childhood.
Most of the 17 skilled weavers he discovered in his research now work for the institute, and in contrast to former times when only women did the weaving, three of them are men. The weavers restore old fabrics and reproduce the kind of 19th-century ikats that Mr. Morimoto carried with him on his travels two years ago. The yarns used in the ikats are tie-dyed to create the geometric, linear and figurative images of flowers, elephants and people that pattern these fabrics. The weavers work on old looms found by Mr. Morimoto in marketplaces throughout the country.
SOON THESE FABRICS WILL BE available for sale and provide an economic boost for a country where 80 percent of the people still live in rural areas. The weavers have formed a cooperative that will produce and market fabrics later this year. Eventually, they hope to export them to the United States and Europe.
Mr. Lefferts, who calls himself a "mainland Southeast Asian chauvinist," views Mr. Morimoto's project and similar work done by UNESCO as proof that Cambodia has much to offer the world today.
"It's very important that this be recognized -- by Cambodians and everyone else," he said. "These projects will help restore the ethnic Khmer identity. Cambodians produced some of the finest weaving in the world prior to 1970. Now Khmer hand weaving, which in my book is absolutely first rate, may become available worldwide."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Street Crime Plagues Papua New Guinea

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea

 BODY:
DON'T go onto the golf course alone. Don't go out to eat on Fridays, when people are getting drunk on their government salaries. Don't walk around too much. For goodness' sake, don't drive alone at night.
There is an epidemic of violent crime in Port Moresby (and to some extent in the rest of the country, too), and this is one of the most fearful cities in Asia. It is possible, if you ask around, to be warned off doing just about anything. 
 That would be a mistake.
Papua New Guinea is one of the most exotic, beautiful and unspoiled countries in Asia, with some of its most charming and friendly people. It would be a pity to miss meeting and chatting with highland villagers wearing grass skirts and feather headdresses. Even in the cities, men and women in Western clothes sometimes place a bright green leaf or a flower in their hair, just for the pleasure of it.
Most visitors come on organized tours, a good way to enjoy the country's pleasures and avoid street crime.
The tourism industry here is still young, and overdevelopment has not yet reached Papua New Guinea. A visitor has a choice of scuba diving amid the coral reefs, visits to tribal ceremonies or tours of wildlife sanctuaries that are home to multitudes of brightly colored birds and the world's largest butterflies, with black and green wings more than a foot long.
But the violence is real and pervasive, and caution is particularly in order at this moment of political turmoil in Papua New Guinea. A brief, peaceful military revolt last March led to two days of rioting and looting in Port Moresby.
Prime Minister Julius Chan, who had angered the military by hiring mercenaries to control rebels on the eastern island of Bougainville, stepped aside temporarily and defused the violence, but the Government crisis is not over and instability could return.
The long-running separatist insurgency on Bougainville has caused the Government to withdraw police, medical and other services, and it is a place of particular lawlessness and instability. Travel there is restricted by the Government.
Quite apart from politics, though, Port Moresby has become increasingly unstable, with a large-scale influx of unemployed young men over the years. As many as 90 percent of young men in the city have no job, by some estimates. And although there are no reliable figures on rising crime, there is broad agreement here that the problem is getting worse.
Most Americans in this nation of 4.4 million people are missionaries or anthropologists. Just 300 Americans live in the capital, which has a population of nearly 300,000, and their homes sometimes resemble small fortresses.
The United States Embassy cautions visitors, stating in a consular information sheet, "Crime and personal security are serious concerns in Papua New Guinea."
Most at risk are women traveling alone. Rapes, sometimes by groups of men, are common.
A Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the rapes were part of an attitude of "fundamental disrespect for women" that "this country has to get over."
The consular information sheet also says: "Armed robberies and carjackings are a major problem throughout the country. Criminals occasionally victimize and rob people in large crowds, such as those at sporting events, concerts or political rallies. Hiking in rural areas and visiting isolated public areas such as parks, golf courses, beaches or cemeteries can be dangerous."
The embassy cautions about travel outside Port Moresby at night because bandits sometimes set up roadblocks to rob passengers in cars and buses. And it repeats the common warning to drivers here not to stop in case of an accident but to head directly to the nearest police or Government office.
"Reactions by crowds after road accidents in Papua New Guinea can be emotional and violent," the information sheet says. "Crowds form quickly after an accident and may attack those that they hold responsible or burn their vehicles."
In general, the Western diplomat said: "There is a lack of effective law enforcement. Something could happen at any place, any time, so you are constantly on your guard."
Government officials did not respond to requests for comment.
In April, a National Court judge, Timothy Hinchliffe, lamented the rise in violent crime, particularly among teen-age boys. He pointed to Bougainville as one of the most frightening examples of this.
"It is an example of what happens to a place when the youths grow up to be lawbreakers and have no respect for human life," he said. "The community crumbles until there is almost nothing left. People live in fear and misery, and sadly, that is Bougainville."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Life or Death? Stay Tuned

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES 

 BODY:
"NEWS RADIO" ISN'T THE ONLY
show being kept alive by heroic measures. Here are some other series that are ailing, with a network's hand hovering near the plug, and what the networks are doing this fall to encourage miracle recoveries. ANITA GATES
 
ELLEN On April 30, the coming-out episode for prime time's first lesbian title character was watched by 40 million or so Americans. But the next week, only 12.3 million tuned in to watch her share the news with her parents. Ellen DeGeneres's sitcom, which began as "These Friends of Mine" (with completely different friends) in the spring of 1994, still has a lot to prove to ABC. 
 The network's strategy: Move the show a half-hour later, to Wednesdays at 9:30 P.M., to cash in on the strong "Drew Carey Show" lead-in and to get as far away from the family hour as a 30-minute show can get. ("Ellen" started out last season on Wednesdays at 8.)
 
JUST SHOOT ME NBC's sitcom about an unemployed broadcaster forced to work for her womanizing father's womanizing magazine. This one, starring Laura San Giacomo and George Segal, had its premiere in March, in the Wednesdays at 9:30 time slot, and was not a hit with critics or viewers. But it's back for next season.
 The network's strategy: Put it on Tuesdays at 9:30, right after "Frasier."
 
THE NAKED TRUTH After the show's premiere in fall 1995, Tea Leoni lasted only a season on ABC as a wacky tabloid photographer and divorcee. Earlier this year the series moved to NBC, Ms. Leoni's character became a columnist-reporter, and the tabloid got a new editor: George Wendt, a touch of "Cheers." But even the slot between "Seinfeld" and "E.R." didn't make this show a hit.
The network's strategy: Try a last-ditch time slot, Mondays at 9:30, between "Caroline in the City" and "Date-
line NBC."
 
PROMISED LAND In this spinoff of CBS's "Touched by an Angel," Gerald McRaney is the head of a family that travels America in a camper looking for people to do good deeds for. Critics have called it charmless and "skippable" and the ratings are disappointing, but CBS contends that the network is behind the show all the way.
The network's strategy: Move the show to Thursdays at 8 as an alternative for viewers who consider "Friends" too sexy.
 
SPIN CITY Michael J. Fox was so adorable as a Presidential aide in the film "The American President" that ABC made him a Deputy Mayor of New York in this sitcom. The show held its own in its first season, against "Caroline in the City" (Tuesdays at 9:30), but ABC had promoted it heavily and expected more. The producers have already moved Mr. Fox's character's live-in girlfriend out of town. Between now and fall, they'll decide whether to put the emphasis in future scripts on his sanity-challenging work life (coping with a Mayor who's out to lunch and a press secretary who can't be trusted) or his love life (baby-faced bachelor on the loose in Manhattan).
The network's strategy: Move the show to Wednesdays at 8. That's early for a sophisticated comedy, but the competition consists of "The Nanny" and the new "Tony Danza Show," neither of which is likely to be accused of sophistication any time soon.

HEADLINE: Seeing Upswing For U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA HALL 

DATELINE: BRONXVILLE

 BODY:
MICHAEL ELLIOTT and his wife, Emma Oxford, are at home here this morning -- hospitable and at ease. Mr. Elliott, from Liverpool, England, is on a roll these days. Last year, he became editor of Newsweek's three international magazines, and before that, he had been Washington bureau chief for The Economist.
Simon & Schuster published his book "The Day Before Yesterday: Reconsidering America's Past, Rediscovering the Present" last year. It is good natured without being saccharin. Mr. Elliott debunks the notion, held dear by many observers of the American scene, that America is in a state of decline. In short, he suggests that the naysayers wrongfully compare our times to the Golden Age -- the boom Americans basked in just after World War II. This period, he writes, was followed by the traumas of a Presidential assassination, the Vietnam War, Watergate and the end of the Cold War in 1989. 
 The book's premise is that the United States has attained a maturity after years of jarring change, and within the folds of that maturity are the seeds of stability and hope.
Mr. Elliott was asked to expand on his observations in the book. "Yes, the country is on the upswing," he said. "If I was writing a concluding chapter to the book -- which I'll be doing for the paperback -- I'd consider the growing signs of the new, surprising stability after years of fragmentation."
On politics, he said the paltry turnout for the 1996 election did not faze him. "It was about picayune issues rather than grand issues," he said. "It was the stuff of consultants and spin doctors. The low turnout was quite natural at a time when people were generally satisfied."
On the inauguration in January, he said it was a ceremony that in its essentials is 200 years old. "There is no other democracy which has a ceremonial introduction of a new political leader within an unbroken tradition," he said.
Turning to another subject, he said that baby boomers seem to be seeking what he called eternal truths. This may account for an increase in religious observance across the country, and it may also account for the popularity of books like William Bennett's "Book of Virtues," he said.
"The book's popularity reflects a sense at the end of the 60's and 70's that there had to be a better way."
In his book, Mr. Elliott writes that this yearning for meaning may derive from the dearth of folk memory in American society.
"It's all of a piece -- the concern for education, religion, a distrust of big government, an increase of local volunteerism," he said. "There's a sense of trying to find some roots, some fixed point, in times of turmoil and change. In education, we're asking more all the time of our teachers. We're probably asking too much. We're asking the schools to solve all our problems."
Then, in an exercise he called free association, he said: "I'm increasingly interested in friendship. Friendships really undergird people's social lives. It's not a subject that has been written up much."
And, he went on, not just friendships at home. "Civility and respect at work are not insignificant. It's not trivial to say people should treat each other with respect at work."
When asked about the role of women, he referred to the women here in Bronxville: "The women here are the backbones, the bedrock of the community. To me, it's astonishing. It's incredibly tough for them. They hold the community together, and throughout they can't be resentful."
As for women in the workplace, he said, "The next generation of women won't carry quite the weight of being pioneers."
On the issue of race in the United States, he said, "The old polarity between blacks and whites is on its way out now."
Hispanic Americans, he predicted, will be a major force on the American horizon, particularly in the cities.
He paused at this point, then returned to matters closer to home.
Mr. Elliott and his family lived in Washington for 10 years until less than a year ago, when they settled here.
Why Bronxville?
"We looked past Manhattan, at various suburbs. Bronxville appeared to be a genuine community. That is difficult to find.
"I'm impressed at how pleasantly old, indeed old-fashioned and established it is here.
"One of the pleasures of Bronxville is the schools, which are the hub of the community. Our daughters are 8 and 6 years old. They're into everything -- soccer, chess, computer club.
"We found a very warm, welcoming community of families and children."
