HEADLINE: Bradley's Real Growth Is in Air Cargo

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
PEOPLE who fly out of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks were not surprised to hear passenger traffic there increased last year by 5 percent, a faster pace than most airports in the Northeast. But even stronger growth is taking place in an area most people never see as they rush to the ticket counters for passage to Washington, D.C., or West Palm Beach: Cargo shipping was up 13.5 percent in 1996, to more than 261 million pounds. And it is cargo that gives the strength to Bradley's international designation, with regular shipments to Europe, Mexico and Africa. The growth shows no signs of slowing; in January alone, shippers reported moving 27.6 million pounds of cargo through Bradley, up 43 percent from the same month a year earlier.
"It's almost scary to see it increasing that rapidly," said Andre J. Libert, director of marketing and air service development for the State Department of Transportation, which runs Bradley. 
 "We are not trying to promote one over the other; it's just that one has the potential for more growth, namely cargo," said Charles P. Watras, chairman of the Bradley International Airport Commission. "Logan, Newark, J.F.K. -- they're all busting at the seams now. If they can't handle the increased traffic, it's up for grabs."
Daniel J. Carstens, publisher of Airport News and president of a freight operation in Windsor Locks, said cargo's contributions to the region's economy go largely unrecognized. "We all take for granted the Hamilton Standards and the Pratt & Whitneys in Connecticut, but there are 60 to 75 air freight companies operating out of Bradley alone," he said. "I bet most people who live here probably couldn't name 10 of them."
Last year Mr. Carstens was named operator of Foreign Trade Zone 71 at Bradley. Although the zone was authorized by Congress in 1981 it has never been activated; Mr. Carstens hopes for activation in a matter of months. Foreign trade zones give significant customs and tariff advantages to importers and exporters. Exports from foreign trade zones already exceed $17 billion a year, the Commerce Department reports.
"It will make it a lot more attractive to the cargo community in this region," Mr. Carstens predicted.
Two years ago four towns around the airport -- Windsor Locks, Suffield, East Granby and Windsor -- formed the Bradley Development League to promote economic activity, and members say they are beginning to see the potential of increased cargo shipments. James E. Maitland, chairman of the Windsor Locks Economic and Industrial Commission and a director of the league, said Lego, Kaman, Stanley Works, Pratt & Whitney Aircraft and Colt Firearms are among large companies in the Hartford area that rely heavily on international commerce.
"With the foreign trade zone, hopefully we can lower their costs," he said, "make them more competitive, and bring even more jobs and investment into the state."
Bradley earned a profit of $3.1 million in the fiscal year 1995-96, $900,000 more than the Transportation Department estimated it would, on revenues of $38.3 million. The airport handles nearly 262 flights daily and is served by 19 major, regional and low-fare carriers.
Improvements have seemed non-stop and last fall the state broke ground on an $8 million, 14,500-square-foot control tower and terminal radar approach control building to replace one built in 1951. It will be capable of handling more than 490,000 aircraft takeoffs and landings a year.
The 5 percent increase in Bradley passenger traffic last year was in marked contrast to what is happening at other airports. La Guardia in New York was down 0.5 percent, Kennedy International in New York was up 2 percent and Logan in Boston was up 1 percent.
But developments in cargo operations are far more dramatic. Federal Express last year expanded its service out of Bradley, adding larger planes. In mid-August of last year, three 747 international cargo flights a week to Manchester, England and Luxembourg went into service. In addition, the cargo carrier Arrow Air resumed operations at Bradley last fall. Currently, there is a request for proposals on a third cargo center on the airport grounds, because the two existing operations, one on the airport and the other off the grounds, are nearly at capacity.
Cargo shipping out of Bradley is still only a fraction of larger airports -- Newark International Airport shipped seven times as much, or 955,000 tons, last year. But Newark's total was up 9 percent, compared to Bradley's 13.5 percent gain.
And most officials involved with cargo shipping say a significant development came this year, when United Parcel Services began construction of a $41 million air cargo sorting operation. The state-of-the-art center will be ready for occupancy later this year, and is expected to be at full capacity in 2003, with 850 employees sorting 30,000 packages an hour.
"Those guys do a lot of homework before they choose a site," said Joseph R. Calsetta, general manager of Roncari Associates Inc., which operates 90,000 square feet of cargo space at Bradley and has handled flowers, chickens, oil filters, toys, pharmaceuticals and automobiles, among other products. "The fact that U.P.S. is at Bradley tells you something."
One thing that it tells you is that Bradley's location is getting a second look from many major shippers, officials say.
"You can make one landing at Bradley and serve Boston or New York or anyplace in between, and do it one heck of a lot cheaper than in either of those cities," said Mr. Libert. "Obviously, we're no Kennedy and we're no Logan, but we have some advantages -- no tolls, no tunnels, no labor problems, and things don't fall off the trucks."
Bradley also has a lot of unused space, about 750 acres on the airport itself, and an estimated 4,000 acres more in a five-mile circle around the runways.
"To get access to that much land in an arc around J.F.K., you'd probably be up into the Windsor area anyway," said Harry H. Freeman, economic development coordinator for the Town of Windsor. Mr. Freeman said Windsor is one of the few towns in the state that is a net importer of workers; it has 13,000 people of working age, and 19,000 jobs. There is a vacancy rate of less than 5 percent in the town's 6 million square feet of industrial space and 3 million square feet of class-A office space, and the town has added 200,000 square feet of new business development in just the last four years.
"We like to say we're the only ones growing faster than the Pequots," Mr. Freeman said, "and a lot of it is tied to the airport."
Local officials are trying to tie even more success to the airport. Alexander Oley Carp, executive director of the Suffield Economic Development Commission and a director of the Bradley Development League, said over the last couple of years the towns have been working with a Dutch company that imports cut flowers with the intention of putting in a warehouse that could handle their product.
"It started out specifically for cut flowers, but has since developed into something where we're considering all perishables -- flowers, foodstuffs, pharmaceuticals, and so on," Mr. Carp said. Several state agencies, banks and other groups have joined in the discussions, and the league is in the process of putting together a project development team to obtain financing and begin construction.
Newark, J.F.K. and Logan all have the capability of handling perishable goods. "At Bradley, what we're trying to do is consolidate all those efforts into a single access point, to make it easier for the distributors," Mr. Carp said.
Mr. Maitland said the biggest change locally has been that towns no longer see Bradley as an intruder, but as an integral part of the community. "In the past," he said, "Bradley was moving along quicker than the towns. The towns wanted to maintain their own identity. Now, everyone's putting those differences aside and saying, 'We have to make the airport work for us all.' "

HEADLINE: After Graduation, Heading for the State Line

BYLINE: By DIANE SIERPINA 

 BODY:
WHEN Connecticut's recent high school graduates pack their bags for college this summer and fall, more than 40 percent will be heading for schools -- and probably future jobs -- across the state's borders.
This major exportation of the state's best talent (the third biggest exodus in the nation behind New Jersey and Illinois) is not a new phenomenon. It's been going on since record-keeping began 40 years ago. But it's a growing concern among state educators, legislators and business leaders who fear that the continuing loss of high-skilled labor -- and a growing number of undereducated young people -- could jeopardize Connecticut's future economy. 
 Despite the seriousness of the problem, say state education officials, there is no systemic effort in Connecticut to promote the rich mix of collegiate institutions here among in-state high schoolers and their families or those from neighboring states.
"Is this problem of interest to the policymakers of Connecticut?" asked Joseph Zikmund, chief information officer for the Connecticut Department of Higher Education, who documents the statistics. "It certainly hasn't been thoroughly discussed since I've been here, which is the last seven years."
State Representative Robert Farr, a West Hartford Republican and ranking member of the Higher Education Subcommittee of the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee concurred. "The state is willing to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to promote sports and to promote tourism," he said, "but the economic impact of those industries pales in comparison to the economic impact of higher education and yet we've never made that connection, or appear not to. That's a great mystery to me."
Most of the state's 44 colleges (18 public, 25 independent and the Coast Guard Academy) could accommodate more students, said Mr. Zikmund. Although there's no way to define capacity, he maintained Connecticut consistently has been losing enrollment since a high of 170,000 students in 1989. There were 155,083 undergraduate and graduate students in the fall of 1996.
Mr. Zikmund estimates that if a Connecticut student spends a minimum $10,000 a year to attend college elsewhere, at least $100 million in Connecticut money flows to other states annually.
According to Mr. Zikmund's latest figures, 10,962 of the 25,661 new college students in 1994 (43 percent) left the state for college elsewhere while Connecticut imported 6,826 out-of-staters, for a net loss of 4,136 in new college students. That was, however, better than 1992, when the exportation rate was 48 percent, or 10,218 students. "It's a sign in the right direction," Mr. Zikmund said, "but we're still losing 10,000 students." All the change is based on the larger pool of students and the ability of more families to pay for college because of an improving economy, he surmised. Mr. Zikmund said he suspects the pattern continues today.
Educators have their theories why so many of the state's high schoolers go elsewhere to attend college. Tops are the higher costs of tuition and board here compared to other regions of the nation, the financial ability of many families to be selective, the recruitment efforts of colleges in neighboring states, the small geographic size of Connecticut and the simple desire to leave home and explore new places.
"Nationally, most students choose a college within 500 miles of home," explained Valerie Lewis, deputy commissioner of the Connecticut Department of Higher Education. "But 500 miles of home in Connecticut takes in a seven- or eight-state region. "There also is a perception, especially among higher income families, that there is prestige in attending an out-of-state school."
How to do a better job of marketing the state's higher education institutions? One problem, as always, is money. Departments are fighting just to retain their current budget lines, she said. More aggressive marketing and recruiting is being conducted by individual colleges and in pocket areas around the state, but not systemically, she said, adding that still more might be done with guidance counselors, parent associations, teachers and business groups.
Connecticut high schoolers are being drawn primarily to other New England schools, especially in Massachusetts -- the University of Rhode Island, Boston College, Boston University and Northeastern University in Boston, according to Mr. Zikmund's statistics.
Those students who leave New England altogether prefer schools in upstate New York, Pennsylvania and Washington, D.C., said John C. Hoy, president of the New England Board of Higher Education. The top four are Syracuse University, Ithaca University, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and Cornell University, he said.
"I have a feeling there is an interesting connection between upstate New York and New England," said Mr. Hoy. "The students are somehow comfortable there and these schools do a very good job of recruiting."
Carol Brophy of Fairfield said her two college-aged children did not even consider Connecticut schools, primarily because of lower tuition costs and larger financial aid packages from out-of-state schools. Son Christopher chose Arizona State University and daughter Corinne, Lafayette College in Easton, Pa.
Mr. Hoy, a former dean of admissions for Wesleyan University in Middletown, said Connecticut is doing far less than neighboring states to promote its collegiate institutions around the region.
"I don't think they have worked hard at it," he said. "For a decade, Connecticut has been very concerned with Connecticut's problems. It is less welcoming and less willing to tell the world about its rich economic resources. Connecticut has every single program a student could wish for that Massachusetts has."
Michael Gerber, president of the Connecticut Conference of Independent Colleges, says the state's exportation rate would be a bigger problem if its independent colleges and universities, which attract 24,000 out-of-state undergraduate and post-graduate students annually, did not enjoy such good name recognition and reputations.
Federal and independent research indicates that where a student goes to college directly correlates to family income, parental education level and the desire to get away from home, he said. Nationally, just over 20 percent of college freshmen leave their state for college.
The state's exportation rate "concerns me," he said, "but I don't think there is a great deal from a policy point of view that can be done to change the behavior patterns of this group of young people."
Mr. Gerber said he is more concerned about the state's overall high school dropout rate of 16 percent (10 to 11 percent among Caucasians and Asian-Americans, 30 percent among African-Americans and 40 percent among Hispanics) and the fact that nearly 30 percent of all high school seniors in the state don't go to college at all.
"The jobs of the future are going to require more education," he emphasized. "Income and quality of life directly depend on education."
Ms. Lewis agreed. "We need everybody to be educated today," she said. "We can't afford to have folks who don't go to school. Even with a high school diploma, studies indicate that's not going to be enough to sustain the quality of life here in Connecticut."
Merit scholarships have been suggested by state legislators as a means of keeping Connecticut's brightest students at home, said Ms. Lewis, but the proposed programs have been limited in number and kind. Debates rage over using the state's limited resources for merit- or need-based financial aid.
"Three-quarters of the population of Connecticut feel that to go to the school of their choice, they need financial aid," said Ms. Lewis. "Need-based aid is a critical element in keeping a door open for those folks, whatever the door is. Very few families, even affluent families, have saved well for college."
In the last two days of its session this month, the General Assembly unanimously passed and sent to Gov. John G. Rowland a bill that would create the Connecticut Higher Education Trust, a broad college savings program administered by the state treasurer as a means of helping families afford higher education. Interest earned would not be taxable by the state until dispersed and then at the student's lower tax rate. But the bill does not require a student to attend a Connecticut college.
The state does not track whether students who leave Connecticut to attend college return home. But, said Mr. Zikmund, "Our presumption is most don't come back."
That presents Connecticut with a dilemma. "In periods of economic growth, Connecticut has imported skilled labor rather than grow its own," he said. And that, he explained, costs more money in recruitment.
Lauren Kaufman, vice president and director of the Education Foundation of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said the state's economy is doing well now and college graduates, especially with engineering, science-related and computer skills, are in high demand. "It's important we get the word out that there are lots and lots of job opportunities in the state," she added.
On the other hand, she said, "One of our problems is that we're pricing ourselves right out of the market. We're a very high cost state and it's hard for young people to establish themselves, buy a house and start a family."
The Connecticut Conference of Independent Colleges has suggested, among other things, the development of a mentoring program to connect Connecticut college students with urban youngsters in an attempt to reduce the high school dropout rate, establishment of an economic development partnership between the academic and corporate communities and getting state officials together to create a plan to link higher education and economic development.
"The governor has been receptive to this," said Mr. Gerber.
State Senator Tom Gaffey, a Meriden Democrat, said, "The first step is to recognize where we haven't done the job and to try to focus on how we can do it much better. We've got to place a much higher priority on recruiting students to stay within the state of Connecticut."
Connecticut's high school graduates and work force generally are admired nationwide, state education and business leaders agree. It doesn't surprise them that the brightest students would be courted away. "Our students are in high demand," said Tom Murphy, spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Education.
Added Mr. Gerber, "where a person lives after graduation depends more on where he can get a job." If the jobs are here, he said, "I think they will come home."

HEADLINE: A Festival Is Focus Of Urban Effort

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
IT took about 20 years, but in downtown Charleston, S.C., where once there was only blight, now there is a vital tourist destination.
Dilapidated, boarded-up, 18th- and 19th-century mansions have been freshened up and 50 restaurants operate when two decades earlier there were only two. Saks Fifth Avenue anchors a high-rent shopping district. 
 Hotels offer about 10,000 rooms. People from around the country have chosen the city for their second homes or retirement.
In New Haven, two community activists are convinced a similar rebirth can happen and they have borrowed a Charleston concept to attract people: a performing arts festival. In Charleston, it's Spoleto U.S.A., started in 1979 and, according to South Carolina Gov. David Beasley, the spark for a a $1 billion economic impact.
In downtown New Haven, it's the International Festival of Arts and Ideas. Last year, 60,000 people attended the inaugural event, which featured hundreds of performers and artists, including South African singing group Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Panamanian salsa musician Ruben Blades, the Shanghai Quartet, the Beijing Opera and Cirque Baroque, a French circus-theater troupe.
The second festival, which organizers hope will attract 80,000 people, opens Wednesday with a parade and runs through next Sunday. Among the 200 events are jazz and film festivals as well as classical, salsa, klezmer, blues, gospel and folk/rock music, street performers, a rough and tumble "Antony and Cleopatra," and children's entertainment ranging from storytelling to hands-on activities.
Festivals and other events aimed at promoting tourism are the latest trend among cities seeking economic development, said Dr. Norman J. Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. "Some have been successful at it, others haven't," he added.
The New Haven festival started with Anne Tyler Calabresi, 62, a Woodbridge resident and a founder of programs for city children. As the wife of Guido Calabresi, who was dean of the Yale University School of Law for 39 years, she has been an integral member of the Yale establishment.
Ms. Calabresi acknowledged New Haven's serious poverty and resultant urban problems, but stresses its pluses: theaters, museums, symphony, Greek architecture, historic green and tree-covered streets. To her, it's a shame that surbanites are so fearful of the city and there is "a deeply segregated society, more segregated in many ways than Louisville or Nashville."
She thought that a festival could attract a diverse audience that would see the positive attributes of the city. However, she had no idea how to implement her idea. She went to Jean M. Handley, 70, who is retired from the Southern New England Telephone Company where she was the first female vice president, and has long been active in arts, education, health and business boards in New Haven.
Ms. Handley, a Guilford resident, commissioned a market study, went to arts festivals in Charleston and Edinburgh, Scotland, arranged what she called "a crash course" with festival organizers from around the country, and checked weather patterns for the last decade.
The women succeeded in creating the event last June, after only beginning to book acts the previous October. Ms. Handley is proud of the festival's ideas component -- includes readings, lectures and discussions led by the poet laureate Robert Pinksky, performers at the festival and experts on the arts.
Matthew Nemerson, president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, said that there had been previous discussions about putting on such an arts festival. But obstacles included a resistance from leaders of existing arts organizations concerned about losing their audience and financial support, and a depressed business climate.
Ms. Handley and Mrs. Calabresi argued that a festival would enhance attendance at existing institutions, enticing people to return to the city. They also promised not to accept contributions that otherwise would have gone to local institutions.
That cost them some potential contributions, Ms. Handley said, so she widened the search for sponsors to include, for example, the Mashantucket Pequots.
Mr. Nemerson said that the combination of Ms. Handley and Mrs. Calabresi "brought the clout and Rolodex of a corporate C.E.O. to the table."
Barbara Pearce, president of H. Pearce Company and Long Wharf Theater, said, "A lot of people told them it couldn't be done. If they had listened, there would be no festival."
Some warn that a festival can't revitalize a city by itself. In Charleston, Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. has been in office as long as Spoleto has been in existence, and he has aggressively pursued hotels and other businesses to the city, says Nigel Redden, general director of Spoleto U.S.A.
Dr. Glickman of Rutgers said that in Austin, Tex., a musical festival called South by Southwest has brought the city a "huge number" of visitors. But, he added, "it's part of a larger strategy that has worked very well."
In New Haven, Mayor John DeStefano Jr. said, "I'm not going to say it's going to make 300 restaurants open." But, he added, "it's one of the things a healthy community ought to be doing."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Housing to Rise on Site of Abandoned Aloca Factory

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THE cavernous structure overlooking the Hudson River in Edgewater that once housed an Alcoa plant is an industrial wreck, idled by time, neglect and environmental problems.
In the 33 years that the 1.1-million-square-foot landmark has sat mostly vacant, several attempts were made to redevelop it. All were foiled, leaving its fate uncertain and its cleanup incomplete. 
 Now there is a plan to clean the 10-acre site on River Road by razing the contaminated structure and redeveloping it to housing. Brokered by Bergen County, the agreement involves the owner, the Aluminum Company of America and North River Mews Associates, a local developer that plans a residential rental complex a block from the river.
On Wednesday, the Bergen County Freeholders approved the agreement, which was signed at a news conference the next day at the Alcoa site in Edgewater.The state's Department of Environmental Protection, which has agreed to the remediation plan, will oversee the cleanup.
County Executive William Schuber said the plan was intended to achieve several goals -- to eliminate an eyesore, clean up the site and create a tax-producing project. It will remove an obstacle to the continued resurgence of the county's Hudson River shoreline, he said, adding: "All at no cost to county taxpayers."
At one point the building sits precariously close to River Road, which parallels the river and is being widened from two to four lanes -- a county project Mr. Schuber said was essential to accommodate present and future riverfront development. "It's a win-win for everyone involved," he said.
The plan, which now will undergo further public review, also reflects a trend in the region and the nation: The formation of public-private partnerships to recycle so-called brownfields.
Its proponents say the public benefits of razing the building, which is listed on the State and National Registers of Historic Places, outweigh preserving it. Historic designation does not save landmark buildings from the wrecking ball if they are in private hands, as is the case with the Alcoa plant.
"Our hope in the beginning was to preserve the building, but that is not possible," said Mayor Bryan Christiansen of Edgewater, adding that "all residents want to see the building go." Finally, he said, the market and technology caught up with this project, making it feasible to move ahead.
Under the plan, parts of the block-long concrete building where high levels of PCB's and other pollutants have settled will be removed and will be taken to a designated landfill.
The rest of the building will be torn down and its jumbled remains crushed into tiny pieces and then tested. Those particles containing high levels of pollutants will be carted off site; those with acceptable or low levels will be recycled -- perhaps even as fill for the road project.
T HE key to the plan is that the contaminates are in the building material, not the ground," said James H. Cobb Jr, special assistant to Robert C. Shinn, Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection. "There is no longer a concern about contamination once the building is removed."
Nevertheless, because of the site's industrial past it will be cleaned to residential standards required by state environmental laws before housing is built, Mr. Cobb said. It then will be sold for $8 million to North River Mews, which plans to reshape it into a rental enclave, subject to approvals from the Edgewater Planning Board.
Under present zoning, the developer said, some 400 attached residences could be built at the site, on which there is also a 1.3-acre historic cemetery where an Indian princess is said to be buried.
Alcoa will pay for the demolition and cleanup, estimated to cost $9.5 million to $12 million and take up to 18 months to complete. To guarantee that the work is carried out, the county is requiring Daibes Brothers, the local contracting company doing the demolition, to put up a bond and to pay for any work that exceeds projected costs. Fred A. and Joseph A. Daibes, the company's principals and Edgewater residents, are also partners in North River Mews Associates.
The Alcoa plant was built in stages from 1919 to 1940 and used to fabricate aluminum, rolling out such products as aluminum foil and aluminum sheets used for soda cans. Alcoa closed the plant in 1964 and sold it four years later.
SINCE then the building was sold several more times with two previous owners unsuccessfully trying to convert it to housing. That was what the last owner -- the Amland Properties Corporation, whose principals were Oskar Brecher, a Manhattan developer, and Olympia & York, the Canadian real estate company -- wanted to do during the mid-80's building boom. But the cleanup proved too costly. Amland sued Alcoa, contending, among other things, that it had caused the pollution and was responsible for the cleanup. In a 1991 out-of-court settlement, the giant aluminum maker took back the site.
Kevin McKnight, remediation manager at Alcoa, said his company had been in the process of evaluating its options for the property, including demolishing the building and marketing the site for development, before being approached by the county.
"Alcoa is not in the real estate business," Mr. McKnight said. "We sold our real estate interests back in the 1980's. This way we are also insuring that the property does not cause long-term risk to Edgewater, or to Alcoa."
Proponents of the plan to raze the old Alcoa building consider it a further step in the revival of the waterfront in Bergen County in general and in Edgewater in particular. The borough's 3.5 mile riverfront -- deserted by major manufacturers, like Alcoa, more than three decades ago -- began its revival in the 1980's, but was stalled by the recession and is now getting a second wind. Indeed, some 1,000 housing units are under construction.
"It has been a hindrance to our redevelopment efforts," said Robert Corcoran, an Edgewater Councilman, referring to the old plant. "That is the last area where no real action has happened." For several years the borough has unsuccessfully tried to prod Alcoa "to do something with the building," he said, adding that the idea it will be torn down "is the best thing that could happen."
Razing the building also provides a more efficient way for the county to accomplish the second phase of the widening of River Road and ultimately get a safer road, said Farouk M. Ahmad, assistant director of the Bergen County Department of Planning and Economic Development. River Road is the main access to the county's waterfront and the major artery in this pencil-shaped borough at the foot of the Palisades.
Mr. Ahmad said the second phase of the road project was more difficult than the first two-mile long phase, which was completed a few months ago, because it goes through the more heavily developed portion of the borough.
This phase starts just south of the Alcoa building and extends north for a mile to Route 5. As part of the agreement, Mr. Ahmad said, less than an acre of land from the Alcoa site will be donated for the road project, which is to be completed in 1998.
Fred Daibes of North River Mews said he got involved with redevelopment of the Alcoa site because of the three-way agreement, which he called key to the participation of his group. Today's improving economy and strengthening housing market also supported the project, he added. Mr. Daibes said he would purchase the site contingent upon local approvals for the $50 million project he and his partners envision.
Preliminary plans call for replacing the Alcoa plant with 400 rental apartments in three mid-rise structures. Demolition of the existing plant is expected to begin in July with construction of the new housing to start the summer of 1998, he said.
With the Alcoa and River Road projects in place, Mayor Christiansen said, the borough is well on the way to a long-sought revival.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Mortgage Recording Taxes

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
IT'S frustrating paying income tax on money you earn. It's even worse paying sales tax on money you spend. But what could be worse than paying a mortgage tax on money you borrow?
How about paying it twice? 
 Many property owners in New York who have refinanced their mortgages in recent years have been doing just that. And at least one New York lawmaker is doing something about it by compiling a list of "consumer friendly" lenders who have agreed to help borrowers avoid paying a second tax when they refinance.
Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, Democrat of Brooklyn, explained that until 1989 or so, homeowners who refinanced their mortgages could legally avoid paying mortgage taxes -- which can amount to hundreds and even thousands of dollars -- by having their old mortgage assigned to their new lender.
In 1990, however, a change in the law made it optional for lenders to agree to an assignment. And that, Mr. Feldman said, has hurt homeowners because it forces them to choose between refinancing with a new lender -- which typically results in the payment of a second tax -- or renegotiating their current loan on terms dictated by their lender. "Either way, you lose," Mr. Feldman said.
He said he had become aware of the problem when he decided to refinance the mortgage on his home in Sheepshead Bay several years ago. Being a smart borrower, Mr. Feldman figured he would shop around for the best deal and then ask his original lender to match it.
When he presented his lender with a competitor's advertised interest rate and closing costs, the lender offered a similar interest rate but higher closing costs. Mr. Feldman decided to go with the competitor.
Mr. Feldman knew that by going to the new lender he would be required to pay the mortgage recording tax. But if he could have his existing mortgage assigned to the new lender -- a common practice in commercial loan transactions -- he would not have to pay the tax.
So Mr. Feldman asked his original lender to assign his mortgage to the new lender. But the original lender declined to do so, forcing Mr. Feldman to make a choice: Either take out a new loan with the new lender and pay a new mortgage recording tax, or refinance his existing loan with his original lender and pay higher closing costs.
Then Mr. Feldman noticed something that bothered him: The closing costs were just slightly less than the taxes he would have to pay if he went to a new lender.
"They set their rate just high enough to squeeze every penny out of me and just low enough to make it more expensive for me to go to another lender," he said.
In fact, Mr. Feldman pointed out, what the lenders are doing is quite legal as the result of the change in the law in 1990.
Prior to that, he said, state law prohibited lenders from unreasonably withholding assignments of mortgages because the mortgage recording tax was only intended to be a tax on new money being borrowed.
When a homeowner refinances an existing loan, he said, the old loan is merely being replaced by a different one. Since the borrower already paid the tax on the original mortgage, no tax should be due on the refinancing.
So, ever since Mr. Feldman's run-in with his mortgage company he has been trying to restore the prohibition against the unreasonable withholding of an assignment. Twice he has successfully shepherded bills through the Legislature only to see them vetoed -- first by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1994 and again by Gov. George E. Pataki in 1996. In both cases, Mr. Feldman said, the reason offered for the veto was the potential loss of tax revenues.
Indeed, mortgage recording taxes do amount to a significant amount of money -- particularly for the person who has to pay them and particularly when the mortgage is on property in New York City.
Douglas F. Wasser, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that for mortgages under $500,000 on one-, two- and three-family homes outside New York City, the recording tax is 1 percent of the mortgage amount. Of that 1 percent tax, the lender pays 25 percent and the buyer the rest, less $25. For similarly sized mortgages on city property, however, the recording tax is 2 percent, but the lender pays only 12.5 percent of that amount, and the buyer the rest, also less $25.
That means that on a $200,000 mortgage refinancing of property outside the city, Mr. Wasser said, the mortgage tax due from the borrower would be $1,475 and the amount due from the lender would be $500. For the same size mortgage on a house or condominium in New York City, the tax due from the lender remains the same while the tax due from the borrower increases to $3,475. (Co-op shareholders are unaffected by these fees since there is no mortgage recording tax on the share loans used to purchase co-ops.)
Mr. Feldman has introduced yet another bill to prohibit the unreasonable withholding of an assignment. Since his prospects for success haven't changed appreciably, however, Mr. Feldman recently adopted a new strategy. Earlier this year, he mailed out "pledge forms" to more than 1,000 lending institutions, asking them to return the form if they were willing to promise not to unreasonably withhold assignments of mortgages. Nineteen lenders responded affirmatively.
Don Romano, president of the New York Association of Mortgage Brokers, pointed out that it should not be assumed that the lenders who responded are the only lenders who will agree to assignments of mortgages.
"This is not an all-inclusive list by any means," Mr. Romano said, adding that while most lenders will readily agree to accept an assignment, many are hesitant to make an assignment because of the difficulty involved in tracking down the original paperwork. In some cases, Mr. Romano said, it may not even be possible to make an assignment because the loan has been sold to another lender who will not permit it.
"It's usually a judgment call," Mr. Romano said.
The lenders who agreed to Mr. Feldman's pledge are the Sound Federal Savings and Loan Association, Mamaroneck, N.Y.; the Greater New York Savings Bank, Mineola, L.I.; the Reliance Federal Savings Bank, Garden City, L.I.; the Columbia Federal Savings Bank, Woodhaven, Queens, and the Dime Savings Bank of New York, Uniondale, L.I.
Also, the Long Island Savings Bank, Melville, L.I.; the Flushing Savings Bank and the China Trust Bank of New York, both of Flushing, Queens; Interbank of New York, Astoria, Queens; the Ridgewood Savings Bank, Ridgewood, Queens; the Atlantic Liberty Savings Bank, Brooklyn, and the Ponce de Leon Federal Savings Bank, the Bronx.
Also, the Arab American Bank, the BPD International Bank, and the Habib American Bank, all of Manhattan; and upstate, the Cayuga Savings Bank, Auburn; the Cohoes Savings Bank, Cohoes; the Rome Savings Bank, Rome; the Cortland Savings Bank, Cortland, and the Savings Bank of the Finger Lakes, Geneva.

HEADLINE: A Dream Grows in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
WHEN the Regional Plan Association published a study in 1983 arguing that the way to reverse the deterioration of downtown Brooklyn was to turn it into the city's third central business district, after downtown and midtown Manhattan, the outcome was anything but certain. The uncertainties continued over the years even as the cluster of buildings known as Metrotech Center rose and filled with offices; one developer, after years of frustration, pulled down a billboard promising a hotel's imminent arrival.
Now the steelwork for that hotel, the first new one in Broolyn in 50 years, is rising next to Metrotech, which has become a $1-billion, five-million-square-foot development of new and renovated buildings around a landscaped commons. The latest building, known as Renaissance Plaza, will house a Marriott hotel with 384 guest rooms and large meeting spaces, as well as a 32-story office tower with a total of 1.4 million square feet of office space. 
 The hotel will make the business district self-contained, since the companies located there will be able to house visitors and hold conferences without having to go to Manhattan, as has been the case in the past.
And Polytechnic University, one of five colleges in the area, is in the midst of a $150 million fund-raising campaign to complete its campus, including the renovation of its main building, which was once a razor-blade factory.
The redevelopment of downtown Brooklyn is the result of something that is often proposed but seldom successfully executed -- a partnership between academia and industry with a significant dollop of government assistance.
The idea that became Metrotech was first advanced by the then-president of Polytechnic, who feared the engineering school would be unable to attract students or faculty because of the shabby, apparently dangerous nature of its neighborhood.
"The original concept was developed by George Bugliarello, who wanted to build a research and development facility modeled on Silicon Valley," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "The developer had a better feel for the for the market, but the idea was George's."
Mr. Moss said that Metrotech, which includes the Polytechnic campus, and Renaissance Plaza were particularly important to the economic health of the borough because they are clustered together in a compact area with high employment that helps to sustain retail and services businesses in the area. "If you look at Citicorp's tower in Long Island City, you see that it is an island that provides no benefit to the community," he said. "You have to have a critical mass."
Indeed, there are those who think the business district in Brooklyn will continue to grow, as office space in Manhattan becomes more expensive. "This is a wonderful time for new development in Brooklyn because of the prohibitive cost of deals in Manhattan and the incentives being offered in Brooklyn," said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a tenant's broker.
The downtown Brooklyn revival, which has brought 25,000 new jobs to the area, represents a triumph over "incredible obstacles," said Howard Golden, the borough president. What kind of obstacles? "The whole issue of Manhattan versus the boroughs and the fact that we live as second class citizens," he said. Most city development money has been spent in Manhattan over the years, to the neglect of the other boroughs, he said, although that has changed in recent years. Particularly galling, he said, was the inability to attract a hotel project.
I'VE had people from organizations call me and say they don't want to go to Manhattan to hold their meetings -- it's too expensive and there is not enough parking," said Mr. Golden. Nevertheless, he said , hotel development continued to be concentrated in Manhattan, often with city assistance.
As with any discussion of relations between Brooklyn and Manhattan, there is an undercurrent of tension from the knowledge that if the borough were a separate city, as it once was, it would be the nation's fourth most populous.
"We are talking 2.5 million people and 60,000 businesses with some of the best transportation links in the city," said Joshua L. Muss, whose Muss Development Company struggled with the hotel project's ups and downs starting in 1983.
"There were six professionals working on this every day for 13 years," he said. "It became an odyssey; we went through 7 or 8 formal financing interludes. Each time we thought it was set, something unraveled. And through it all, there was a constant refrain: A hotel in Brooklyn is a piece of pork in a kosher butcher shop. you cannot finance it."
In fact, at one point Mr. Muss took down a billboard saying the development was "coming soon" after the sign had been up for six years with no visible progress.
Finally it all came together last year and the hotel-retail-office complex is expected to open next summer. It will occupy about a third of a long block bounded by Jay and Adams and Willoughby and Johnson Streets. The $230 million project will include, in addition to the hotel rooms and office tower, a fitness center, on-site day care, 20 conference and meeting rooms including a ballroom that will be among the largest in the city and an 1,100-space underground garage.
City and state economic development authorities have provided a package of incentives that will make space in the office tower $12 a square foot cheaper than midtown Manhattan and $6 less than downtown. Rents in Metrotech run to the low to mid $20s per square foot, brokers say.
The incentives include abatement of real estate taxes completely for 15 years and a gradual increase to a normal level over the next 10 years, $1,000 a year subsidy for each employee relocated from Manhattan below 96th Street or from outside the city, energy rate savings from Consolidated Edison and an exemption from the state tax on the purchase of business equipment.
Mr. Muss is dwelling on incentives and the cheaper cost of living in Brooklyn because, although he has as anchor tenants the Kings County District Attorney's office and the Empire Insurance Company, he still must lease 233,000 square feet of space on seven upper floors.
The chief landlord's broker for Renaissance Plaza, Jerry L. Cohen of Cushman & Wakefield, said any negative image associated with Brooklyn had been erased when financial firms such as Chase Bank and Bear Stearns & Company began moving their back office operations into Metrotech in the late 1980's. Metrotech is virtually completely leased, according to brokers.
"The way downtown Brooklyn is today is like the central business district of many cities," he said. "There is housing nearby, shops and retail is picking up. There are lots of bright young people at the colleges in the neighborhood and the rest of the labor pool is excellent."
Certainly the gleaming new buildings, the tree-shaded commons at Metrotech and the bustle on the street are a far cry from when Dr. Bugliarello, who was being recruited as president of Polytechnic from his post as dean of engineering at the Chicago campus of the University of Illinois, took a look at the neighborhood in 1973.
"I had been interviewed at a fancy club in Manhattan," he said. "So I took a cab out here and turned the job down."
He described the university's surroundings as "a disaster." "There were less than 200 people living in the area and most of the buildings were rundown or torn down for parking lots," he recalled. In addition to the depressed surroundings, Polytechnic was in a difficult position financially.
A PRIVATE college built in the years leading up to the Civil War to educate the sons of well-off families in Brooklyn, the college never built up an endowment and in more recent years relied on a dwindling supply of research projects from government agencies to try to close the financial gap.
"By 1973, there had been 13 years of deficit and Poly had spent five years trying to become a state or city institution," said Dr. Bugliarello, who was eventually persuaded to take the presidency.
The state stepped in and provided financial assistance for Polytechnic to merge with New York University's School of Engineering and Science. That school had been housed at N.Y.U.'s uptown campus in the Bronx, which was scheduled to be sold. Combining two very similar schools at a time when there was great pressure to balance Polytechnic's budget produced a harsh environment.
"We had to let go all the nontenured faculty," Dr. Bugliarello said.
As he surveyed the school and its neighborhood, he recalled, he became convinced that improving the location was the key to attracting more students and that the way to do it for an institution devoted to technology was in partnership with industry with the assistance of government.
Dr. Bugliarello, who was president of Polytechnic from 1973 to 1994 and now holds the title of chancellor, sold the idea to borough and city officials who designated the university as the developer of Metrotech. But it was expected all along that the partners in the undertaking would recruit a commercial developer to do the actual clearing and building.
None of the city's established developers was interested in Brooklyn, but Bruce Ratner, a Columbia Law School graduate who had been the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs from 1978 to 1982, was. "I had traveled all the boroughs as Commissioner," he said, "and I knew downtown Brooklyn had excellent transportation."
While the Regional Plan Association had designated the area to be a third node of commerce in the city, Mr. Ratner said, it had not described how it was to be done. Polytechnic had advanced a plan to develop 1 million square feet of space, with an emphasis on high technology.
"We looked at it and determined the area was not appropriate for another Silicon Valley," said Mr. Ratner, who was backed by Forest City, his family's development company, which is based in Cleveland. "We did find that what tenants really wanted was lots of high-tech space for back-office operations. And we also found that 30 to 35 percent of the people who work in downtown Manhattan are from Brooklyn."
So the plan was rezoned to 4 million square feet, and the search for prospective tenants was begun. A critical point was passed, Mr. Ratner said, when Morgan Stanley, the securities corporation, agreed to move into a building at 1 Pierrepont Plaza.
Although not part of Metrotech, the triangular property bounded by Pierrepont and Clinton Streets and Cadman Plaza West is nearby and helped gain credibility for the area as a location for major offices.
"Morgan Stanley was the beginning of Brooklyn's revival because it gave the appearance of reality," Mr. Ratner said.
Putting together the first deal in Metrotech proper was tricky because no company wanted to be the first to commit to the project without the assurance that someone else would take the risk as well.
"Brooklyn Union Gas was willing to move if we could find another tenant" for the buldings that eventually became 1 and 2 Metrotech Center, Mr. Ratner said. That requirement was met when the Securities Industries Automation Corporation, which develops specialized software for Wall Street, agreed to move in, taking about 80 percent of the space in the 535,000-square-foot 2 Metrotech Center..
Since then Chase Bank, Bear Stearns, Goldman Sachs, the city's 911 emergency service and Fidelity Contingency Trading have moved offices to Metrotech, to be joined by the Fire Department once its headquarters is completed later this year.
To make the development more attractive, the buildings are arrayed around a four-acre, vehicle-free landscaped mall. This gives workers a pleasant place to eat lunch and socialize without having to cope with traffic on Flatbush Avenue and Jay Streets. Indeed, if Polytechnic completes the project it is planning for its buildings, the main entrance will be from the mall, rather than from Jay Street, as it is today.
Although it was rundown, the area was not abandoned, and so all the problems of urban renewal arose. "There were 160 people and businesses on the site that had to be moved," Mr. Ratner said. There were lawsuits, of course, but Mr. Ratner said in the end the developers settled with individuals, rather than groups. "We sat in a room on Saturdays and Sundays and met with people making offers," he said. "In the end, it cost $19 million to $20 million to get it done."
There were other complications: Cherished local institutions like Sid's Hardware store had to be reconstructed near its old location, but as part of the Brooklyn Union Gas building. An old school building was converted to lofts for a group of artists that was being displaced. An old Fire Department building was converted into housing for the elderly so that many long-time residents could continue living near their old neighborhood.
Attracting back-office operations from Wall Street meant offering the latest in electrical and telecommunications infrastructure and plenty of redundancy. "You could unplug the building that has 911 and it could keep operating for seven days," Mr. Ratner said. The buildings were built with unusually large spaces between floors so that two-foot raised floors could be installed to accommodate wiring systems without making workers feel closed in.
There is one site left at Metrotech whose future has not been decided, but which could support a structure with between 300,000 and 400,000 square feet, Mr. Ratner said. He said he expected companies to keep moving labor-intensive operations out of Manhattan, adding that Forest City was looking for other likely sites in Brooklyn.
Of course, he is likely to have his hands full over the next few years as a major participant in the renewal of Times Square. Forest City Ratner is signed up to develop part of the south side of 42d Street with a 25-screen cinema, Madame Tussaud's wax museum, a music store and other retailers. "Based on Madame Tussaud's in London, we are expecting two to two and a half million people a year," he said.
As the commercial part of Metrotech nears completion, the intellectual parent of the development, Polytechnic University, is seeking to complete its own building program, to make the school attractive to a broader range of students than the local commuters take make up the bulk of its current attendance.
THE first phase is the construction of a new building to house a dormitory, athletic facilities and a cafeteria. The dormitory will allow the university to attract students without local housing and give it a more campus-like feel.
"We are building the dorm for commuter students as well, because we think it will become a center of student life," said Dr. David C. Chang, Dr. Bugliarello's successor as president. He said having a social center was important for a school like Polytechnic because of the impersonal nature of commuting and because many of the current students are immigrants or the first generation children of immigrants.
A new wing will be added the main academic building, Rogers Hall, that will provide up-to-date space and supply both the dormitory and Rogers Hall with modern heating and air-conditioning.
The second phase would be a gut renovation of older parts of Rogers Hall and the addition of an atrium linking the university with Metrotech. The entire project should take about four years, Dr. Chang said.
Dr. Bugliarello said that although Metrotech did not develop as he originally thought, it remains a good example of how a university can team up with industry and government to promote change. He said that because of the interest of banks, securities firms and city agencies in computing and telecommunications, Polytechnic had secured grants to establish its Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications to perform basic research in the field.
HAVING the center helped convince people on Wall Street that Polytechnic was the last word in telecommunications," he said. And since the Securities Industry Automation Corporation has been in Metrotech it has commissioned some research at the university into issues of interest to it and its stock exchange owners. He said the companies are also a source of students, many of them working professionals seeking advanced degrees.
Although most successful university-industry undertakings, like Research Triangle Park in North Carolina, have been located in spread-out, suburban settings, Dr. Bugliarello said Metrotech demonstates that similar projects can be successful in cities as long as they are tailored to an urban environment. "An urban park like Metrotech compresses in a few acres industrial and academic activities that in different environments are spread over thousands of acres," he has written.
Having a clear concept and sticking to it is more important than financial muscle, he argues. Polytechnic has invested about $40 million in Metrotech while the private sector and the City of New York have together invested over $1 billion.
Bringing in all those new jobs has helped reinvigorate the area, but the economic effects have been uneven. Retailing has benefited little, other than a pick-up in lunch time business, because most office workers leave the area after work, brokers specializing in retail leasing say.
"Metrotech is pretty self-contained, although some people probably wander over to Livingston street for a burger," said Albert Firstman, a broker with New Spectrum Realty Services who specializes in Brooklyn. "But at night they do not like to hang around. They rush home."
That is not surprising, said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG. "Retail lags behind other development because most retailers cannot survive on lunch trade alone," he noted. He said it took the much larger World Trade Center almost 20 years before there was enough night-time and weekend traffic to attract a Borders bookstore.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Making Do in a Year When Money Abounds

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
As they put the finishing touches on a new election-year budget, state lawmakers and Governor Whitman found themselves in a political quandary: there was too much money to spend.
Gone are the dire warnings made only a few months ago that hundreds of state workers would lose their jobs. The bull market on Wall Street and the state's strong economy have poured at least $590 million in unanticipated tax revenues into the state's coffers. And the Legislature's approval earlier this month of Governor Whitman's $2.75 billion pension borrowing plan clears the way for the state to skip $590 million in scheduled pension payments this year. 
 Even though the New Jersey State Supreme Court handed an unexpected $246 million bill to the state last month to help end the spending disparity between rich and poor schools, the state is still flush with cash.
State officials said it appears that there will be no layoffs at all in the coming fiscal year, with the exception of the elimination of up to 1,200 jobs as a result of the closing next year of the North Princeton Developmental Center and Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital. Administration officials said that they will try to move as many of those workers as possible into jobs at group homes that will be created.
After three years of cutting taxes and reining in government spending, Governor Whitman took a different approach in January when she first unveiled her proposed $16.4 billion budget. Instead of the deep spending cuts in almost every state agency that she proposed last year, she recommended that spending either remain at current levels or increase for most programs in the coming year.
She proposed spending increases for public schools, prisons and the environment, and more than a dozen modest initiatives aimed at Democratic and swing voters. She also promised to expand low-tax zones in cities, offer health insurance to uninsured children, expand drug treatment programs for women with children, open a second boot camp for juvenile offenders and eliminate the waiting list for disabled people seeking access to group homes and day care centers.
But once unanticipated tax revenues began pouring in, and the bond plan was approved, and the state budget picture began to look even rosier, Mrs. Whitman and Republican leaders were reluctant to be viewed as spending too much money.
Extra money to spend during an election year is not usually considered such a terrible ordeal for politicians. On the campaign trail, incumbent legislators always find it helpful to point out that various local organizations and programs recently received an infusion of state funds.
But since 1991, the Republican-controlled state Legislature has prided itself in keeping spending down. In 1993, as the gubernatorial race began, they trimmed $200 million from former Gov. Jim Florio's $15.7 billion budget.
And in January, Governor Whitman boasted that her $16.4 billion budget proposal was only 1.3 percent above last year's appropriations, well below the rate of inflation. "This gives us the lowest four-year growth rate in government spending in a quarter century," she said in her annual budget message to the state Legislature.
Governor Whitman cannot make the same claim now. However, she was determined that spending would not rise to $17 billion, as some lawmakers had predicted earlier in the week. Under the agreement that was finally worked out among Legislative leaders and Whitman aides last week, the new state budget will be approximately $16.8 billion. Spending would increase by at least $260 million above what she proposed in January, and $583 million above last year's budget.
The major changes that the Legislature made to the Governor's budget include extra money for caseworkers, colleges and municipalities wrestling with high debt service payments on school construction.
To end the threat of college tuition increases made by several state colleges this spring, lawmakers restored $20 million to state colleges and universities that Mrs. Whitman cut in her proposed budget. The Legislature also budgeted $8 million more than Mrs. Whitman requested for community colleges.
The new budget will also include $18 million more than the Governor initially recommended to hire more caseworkers at the state Division of Youth and Family Services. And $20 million more to help municipalities pay off debt on school construction. There is also about $20 million for small programs and projects that legislators have requested for their individual districts.
Overall, unlike last year, it is not a budget that is going to make too many people unhappy.
That presents some political problems for Democrats. The 30 percent income tax cut has been fully enacted, and it is difficult to explain to voters that a pension bond plan is how Mrs. Whitman has been able to avoid deep spending cuts.
However, they believe that they have found a new niche.
"The Governor does the easy part," said State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democrat from Woodbridge who is challenging Mrs. Whitman this fall. "But she did not take on the difficult job of reinventing government. Ironically, the Governor has redefined the Democratic Party as fiscally responsible."

HEADLINE: Imagining The Future Of Downtown

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: CRANFORD

 BODY:
IN the early 1980's, the people of this Union County township became concerned about a rising vacancy rate in stores and other signs of deterioration and began plans to make their downtown more attractive, and robust.
They replaced broken sidewalks with brick paving stones, installed elevated planters brimming with flowers, placed benches every so often to invite shoppers to sit and highlighted the turn-of-the-century architecture of shops and businesses with Victorian-style lamps. They also took an unsightly corner near the train station and built a brick plaza with a majestic ornamental clock that has become the town center. 
 The project took almost 10 years. About three weeks ago, 28 people from various walks of life here -- residents, shop owners, government leaders -- met in the Cortina Restaurant to review what they had accomplished. They spent the next four hours basically confronting one question: Now what?
It is a question with no clear answer. Although the question implies a need to strengthen old businesses and attract the new, the answer lies essentially in identifying what kind of town they want Cranford to be, or continue to be.
Cranford is not alone in asking the question. More and more towns across the state are asking themselves how they can best revitalize their downtown business districts in the face of competition not only from old adversaries like the shopping malls and highway outlets but also newer ones like mail order houses and the Internet.
Cranford was the first municipality in New Jersey to take advantage of legislation allowing it to create a business improvement district (it's officially called a special improvement district, or Sid) which empowers downtown merchants and property owners to form a partnership with town government to assess themselves for improvements and create a management system to carry them out.
In Cranford, the district was established in November 1985, with actual streetscape improvements beginning in 1987. Since then, the number of improvement districts has grown to 35, in 29 municipalities. The greatest growth has come within the last three or four years as more towns have become aware of the program. Nine more are expected to be established by next year.
But those involved with downtown revitalization, like the people of Cranford, are coming to realize that no matter how many improvements they make, no matter how they shore up their existing stores and attract new ones, no matter how healthy their downtowns become, their work will never be finished. They are also coming to realize that no matter how successful that process, the towns can never be the way they were, that they will evolve into something new and different.
Beth Peterson, executive director of Downtown New Jersey Inc., a statewide, non-profit organization that is an advocate for central business districts, believes that downtowns represent the old home town in our consciousness and therefore exert "an emotional pull."
"It comes back to the fact that downtowns are an important part of community life," Ms. Peterson says. "You're not going to hear anybody say, 'I come from the Bridgewater Commons Mall.' They say, 'I'm from Somerville.' "
"No matter what the state our downtown is in, there is a move afoot to say this is a valuable part of our community life, and we don't want it to deteriorate any further."
There are some 1,200 business improvement districts across the country, says Lawrence O. Houstoun, Jr., who played a major role in drafting the legislation in New Jersey. Such districts, along with other programs for downtown revitalization, stand as a symbol of a new feeling toward downtown America.
"The revitalization has begun to change American attitudes about downtown," said Mr. Houstoun, a principal in the Atlantic Group, an urban-development consulting business in Cranbury and Philadelphia.
"A decade ago, smart writers were saying downtowns were dead," he said. "Now they're saying how they're coming alive again. It's meant changes in our perception. One of the changes is the sense that one can change the human environment, that places we call downtown can be revived."
 
A Mile-Square District In a Century-Old Town
 Cranford's special improvement district occupies about a square mile of the town's 4.79 square miles, and Meryl Layton's shop, the Cranford Book Store, sits in the middle of it on North Avenue West.
It is located across from the railroad trestle in the turn-of-the-century Cranford Trust Company building, a three-story edifice of red brick and stately columns that takes up most of the block to another main thoroughfare, North Union Avenue.
Next to her bookstore is the Cortina Restaurant, one of the best of the small number of restaurants in town, and next to that is the Village Shoe Store, Sovereign Bank of New Jersey, the Cranford Barber Shop, Martin Jewelers, whose name appears with Rolex on the face of the $20,000 Victorian clock in Eastman Plaza across the street. Next to Martin Jewelers is First Union bank. Writing on second-floor windows shows there are two dental offices there.
There are new signs on some of the shops, impatiens and holly bushes in the planters and the American and Cranford flags jutting from the Victorian-style lamps. There are signs on the railroad trestle saying "Walk/Talk/Shop Cranford" and advertisements for "a duck derby" sponsored by the firefighters association, an "Olde Tyme Circus" at a local school and the soccer club in "Cranford, N.J. U.S.A." The overall effect is one of quaintness and neatness, of being modern with roots in the past, an American town.
Under the local ordinance that created the district in 1985, Meryl Layton, like some 180 other downtown property owners, pays 40 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation to support the annual budget of the district, on top of what she pays on her regular tax bill. The 1997 budget is $309,770.
John F. Laezza, the township administrator, says that assessment covers the following:
Annual payment of $100,000 toward the $3.2 million debt the property owners incurred to spruce up the district; $80,000 for administrative expenses of the Downtown Management Corporation, which manages the district, mainly the salary of the manager and an assistant; $60,000 in salaries for two workers to maintain the planters, sidewalks and other amenities, and the rest in reserve for future capital needs, materials for repairs and marketing.
Downtown property owners are allowed to pass their assessment onto their renters. The township contributes $140,000 annually to pay for government-owned and tax-exempt properties in the district.
"That costs the average homeowner no more than $17 a year," Mr. Laezza says.
Ms. Layton, for her property, assessed at $303,000, paid an assessment of $1,213.20 in addition to her regular tax bill of $8,000 last year.
Some property owners in other towns have objected to the assessments for services they say should be provided by government anyway. And in some towns, like Morristown, they have fought the assessments in court.
But Meryl Layton sees the assessment as a "worthwhile investment."
"In the beginning, property owners really hated it," she said of the investment. "They were afraid that the tax and the passing on of the tax would make it difficult to rent their properties. But that hasn't been the case."
Ms. Layton, who until last December served on the board of the Downtown Management Corporation. for 10 years, said there was "a lot of dissent" when the district was first formed.
"The retailers weren't thrilled with it," she said, "because, who needs change, No. 1. No. 2, the tax would make their rents prohibitive. And that they'd be forced out of business. But I don't know of any, any, any business that's gone out because of the additional tax."
Norman J. Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University, says that funding mechanisms like special improvement districts are necessary if many downtowns, especially in the state's older cities, are to survive."
"Cities have gone to these public and private partnerships because they haven't had the money to provide the services they used as a matter of course," Professor Glickman said.
Cranford, like other municipalities, began noticing things were not right in town back around 1982, town officials say.
More stores along South and North Union Avenues and along North Avenue East and West were becoming vacant and the general look of the stores and the streets and sidewalks in a downtown that was more than 100 years old appeared to be suffering slow decay. Mr. Laezza says.
"You had a downtown that was stagnant," said Mayor J. Robert Hoeffler. "You had a downtown that didn't have any pizazz."
In 1984, a group of concerned residents and business people created a private downtown improvement group and solicited funds for beautification, said Ms. Layton, but the program failed.
As Cranford officials were grappling with the problem, New Jersey passed the special improvement district legislation in 1984 that provided statutory authority for municipalities to create tax supported business improvement districts and non-profit organizations to manage them.
Cranford created its district on Nov. 12, 1985, and hired a consulting firm from Baltimore for $50,000 to determine what direction the township should take over the next 10 years.
It created a Downtown Management Corporation, a board of directors that now numbers 10 and that consists of three downtown property owners, three downtown business owners and three township residents, plus a township committee person.
The township also eventually hired a manager for the corporation to oversee the work of the district.
Beginning in 1987, the Downtown Management Corporation proceeded with what is known as "streetscape," a program of digging up sidewalks, putting in new electric lines, laying sidewalk stones called pavers and erecting street lamps, planters and generally helping merchants improve the look of their stores with new signs
The work was done in phases, says Paul LaCorte, the chairman of the Downtown Management Corporation who was Mayor in 1987, because the members wanted to pay as they went along.
By 1991, besides Cranford, other towns that had created districts were Englewood, Trenton, Somerville, New Brunswick and Elizabeth, said Seth A. Grossman, manager of New Jersey's Business Improvement District Program.
 
An Idea Catches On: 35 Districts Statewide
 By 1993, there were more than 15 and today there are 35 in Atlantic City, Bayonne, Bound Brook, Elizabeth, Englewood, Fair Lawn, Fort Lee, Freehold, Iselin, Jersey City, Linden, Maplewood, Millburn, Morristown, New Brunswick, Ocean City, Paterson, Perth Amboy, Rahway, Red Bank, Rutherford, Somerville, Summit, Teaneck, Trenton, Union Township and Vineland.
Mr. Grossman says the increase in downtown-improvement programs came about through efforts by his office, local governments and Downtown New Jersey Inc. to publicize the program as well as the increased number of project consulting groups.
Newark, the largest city, is looking at creating two districts, one of which would take in the entire Ironbound section, Mr. Grossman said, while Galloway Township near Atlantic City is actually looking to build a town center, or downtown, to enhance a sense of community.
Every town looks at similar areas to improve, like security, cleanliness, re design, accessibility, shopper friendliness, streetscaping and so on, but all go about it in different ways, he says.
Red Bank, one of the more successful districts, began its district in 1991 but is just starting on infrastructure improvements, having chosen instead to create a marketing strategy to promote Red Bank inside and outside the community and to put businesses into stores in a downtown that had a 35 percent vacancy rate.
"We wanted to create a lot of internal excitement and also to create visible change on the street to stimulate investor confidence," said Tracy Challenger, executive director of the management group Red Bank River Center.
The vacancy rate is now near zero, and people have decided it's time for more of a capital improvement program.
Cranford was unusual in starting with its streetscaping program first, urban specialists said, but many think now think the town is at a crossroads.
"Cranford was looked on as a model for the first generation of Sids," said Marta Person, who managed both the Cranford and Red Bank business districts and now has a private consulting concern called Square Foot in Red Bank. "Now there are others doing more innovative things like Red Bank that Cranford can learn from."
Cranford, which has been without a downtown manager for at least six months, hired one earlier this month: Michele Picou, who was manager of the successful Main Street program in neighboring Westfield.
On her first week on the job, she joined 27 others from Cranford at a meeting, including town officials, heads of major departments in town whose cooperation is needed if downtown revitalization is to move forward, and retailers and property owners.
"It was called a retreat," said Ruth Yablonsky, a longstanding member of the board and a naturalist who often is seen working alone or with the maintenance crews pruning the planters or trimming the trees. "But I would rather call it an advance."
"The feeling was, now that we finished with the streetscape and capital improvements program, there are a number of directions we can go in," Mrs. Yablonsky said. "Some felt we should be working on a marketing scheme. Others felt we should be doing recruiting and retention of businesses. And others felt we should be looking further into the future than that."
Ms. Picou, who will be instrumental in helping Cranford create its vision of how it wants to be, said the most important thing that came from the meeting was an awareness that the Downtown Management Corporation had to be the prime mover.
"The major outcome was that the people who serve on the board, people who are in key departments, everyone in the group felt that the D.M.C. is the lead organization for determining appropriate development for the downtown," Ms. Picou said. "And the township committee made it clear they are looking to the D.M.C. to provide the leadership for that role."
Speaking in general about the future of downtowns, she said: "Some people think you start a downtown program to fix a downtown, and at some point you stop because the downtown is fixed. But a downtown, just like a school system or library, is never finished. It needs continuing maintenance and nurturing."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Susan Meyer And Charles Ross

 BODY:
Susan Lynn Meyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Meyer of Wellesley, Mass., was married last evening to Charles Nicholson Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Ross 3d of Claremont, Calif. The Rev. Dean Wolf, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Boston.
Mrs. Ross, 31, is an assistant district attorney in Middlesex County, Mass. She graduated from Brown University and Vermont Law School. Her father is a managing director of the institutional client group of Merrill Lynch & Company in Boston. Her mother, Phyllis C. Meyer, is a business-writing consultant in Wellesley. 
 Mr. Ross, 32, is a consultant at the Monitor Company, a marketing consulting concern in Cambridge, Mass. He also sings in the Thrillionaires, an a capella group. A graduate of Bowdoin College, he received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. His father is the presiding administrative law judge in Rancho Cucamonga for the California State Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board.
