HEADLINE: In One Somali Town, Clan Rule Has Brought Peace

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: BOSSASO, Somalia, June 17

 BODY:
Like many people in this town on the northeastern Somali coast, Halima Farah Jibril knows what it means to lose everything and start all over in a barren place with no friends.
Her husband, a successful veterinarian in Mogadishu, the nation's capital, was killed by a stray bullet in 1991 as he tried to protect their five-bedroom villa from looters. 
 Mrs. Farah Jibril fled the city with her five children in the back of a truck, bumping several hundred miles through deserts and mountains. She headed north to Bossaso, her clan's homeland, where she had heard there was relative peace.
Now she sleeps on the ground in a tattered tent of plastic and rags behind a rough-hewn wooden kiosk, where she serves passers-by tea to eke out a living. Her children cannot go to school because she is too poor to pay their tuition. She must pay $20 a month for the patch of parched earth where she and her family live.
"We were living a very luxurious life," she said, pulling her little boys closer in the dappled shadows under her tent, "but now we are barely staying alive. Somalia has fallen into the hands of wolves, who believe only in tribalism. It will be hard to repair the damage."
Mrs. Farah Jibril, who is 40, is one of tens of thousands of people from all over Somalia who have flocked to the Red Sea port of Bossaso since 1991 to begin rebuilding their lives after civil war and famine shattered them. Once a sleepy town of fewer than 10,000, it now has more than 80,000 residents, a stable government and a growing economy.
If Somalia has a future after the anarchy and clan warfare of the last seven years, it may be glimpsed in the dusty, oven-hot streets here.
This nation has been without a government since 1991, when President Mohammed Siad Barre was overthrown and a civil war erupted over who would succeed him. A famine caused by the fighting killed about 300,000 people in 1992.
Since then, the faction leaders have carved up the country, endlessly skirmishing over its carcass. The fighting has closed down the ports in Mogadishu, Merca and Kismayu. Again and again the faction leaders have failed to reach agreement on forming a national government.
But in Bossaso, the local military and political leaders have established a regional government controlled by clan elders, bringing stability to three northeastern provinces in the Horn of Africa, an area about the size of California.
Though the six million people of Somalia share language and culture, their society is sharply divided along clan lines. For Somalis, until recently a completely nomadic people, the clan is the most important organizing principle.
It provides each person not only with an identity but also with a system for resolving disputes and, if necessary, a small army of warriors willing to fight to avenge an attack.
The five principal clans are the Dir, the Isaaq, the Hawiye, the Darod and the Rahanweyn, but there are dozens of subclans as well. Not surprisingly, the political factions break down along these lines.
The northeastern region, known as Puntland or Majerteinia, is controlled by Gen. Mohammed Abshir Musa, 72, leader of the Majertein clan's political wing, the Somalia Salvation Democratic Front.
Partly because the region is dominated by the Majertein clan, in contrast to areas like Mogadishu, where no single clan dominates, the elders here have managed to keep the peace. Political fights are settled in smoky back-room debates at a Bossaso hotel rather than with guns in the streets.
In reality, General Abshir's administration is an experiment in clan-based government. The 13-member council of Majertein elders appoints parliaments to administer each region, drawing the members from the leadership of various subclans and minorities. If there are unresolved disputes in the parliaments, the ultimate power rests with the elders' council.
"We have an elders' council here and it's respected," said Abdullahi Dahir, a hotel manager who moved from Mogadishu in 1995. "It's like a court. Whatever they decide, even if it's very sour, you accept."
It is a measure of the elders' power that there has been no violence in Bossaso since the regional governor resigned last month in a disagreement over the use of port taxes and a dispute broke out over succession. The governor's seat has yet to be filled, but local politicians say it is unlikely that blood will be shed in the process.
"In the northeast, God forbid, we disagree but we don't shoot each other," General Abshir said.
The relative security of Bossaso has attracted thousands of southern people trained in business and other skills. As a result the economy is growing steadily, despite some setbacks. Electricity and running water are plentiful. Telephone companies have set up satellite links with the rest of the world.
Police officers in new uniforms patrol the rubble-strewn streets. The Bossaso market is full of goods. Buildings are going up everywhere, testament to local business people's faith in the region's stability. There are also plans to institute a civil court to supplement the traditional Islamic court, which has been the only form of justice for a year.
More important, trade is thriving again along its ancient routes. Every day the port is crowded with dhows coming in from Kenya, Yemen, Saudi Arabia, Dubai and India. They bring in flour, cloth, rice and manufactured goods. The Somalis ship out their camels, goats, sheep, frankincense, shark meat and other seafood.
A few traders are making fortunes, aid workers say. About 50 mercantile families are now operating in Bossaso, many originating from strife-torn areas.
Yet the vast majority of the new arrivals in Bossaso are like Mrs. Farah Jibril, impoverished refugees who face enormous hardships. There are no public services to speak of, no sewers, no public schools, few hospitals, fewer paved roads. The town also needs investment to build canning factories, slaughterhouses, milk processing plants and cement factories, politicians say.
"There is a lot of unemployment in the area and the town lacks services," said Hadje Hussein Gaite, chairman of the local parliament. "We know our deficiencies and weaknesses but we hope God will help us. If someone gets sick and tries to cure himself, the recovery doesn't come immediately."
Despite these problems, most people who have migrated to Bossaso say they prefer it to anywhere else in Somalia, because at least one can walk the streets without fearing the sudden, deadly rattle of gunfire. Even if a national government is resurrected, many recent arrivals say they intend to stay put.
"I'm not willing to go back to the south," said Ali Farah Ali, a fishery expert who moved from the capital three years ago. "I had invested in Mogadishu. I had a house and I had to leave everything -- everything. I'm not going repeat that mistake."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Halima Farah Jibril, right, a war widow whose affluent life in Mogadishu was destroyed, now sells tea in Bossaso. But at least she and the children she embraces so protectively can live without fear of a stray bullet. (Luigia Spadano for The New York Times)
 
Map showing the location of Bossaso, Somalia: The peace in the provinces around Bossaso has attracted refugees.

HEADLINE: Limits on Lawsuits and Damage Claims Could Bring Years of Legal Fights

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
A day after cigarette makers and the attorneys general of seven states proposed a historic agreement to settle claims against the tobacco industry, legal experts predicted that even if the proposal overcame hurdles in Congress, it was certain to be tied up in years of litigation.
"It is a highly innovative proposal, but it is very uncertain whether it will survive," said George L. Priest, the John M. Olin Professor of Law and Economics at Yale Law School and an authority on product liability. "No one believes people will stop dying of lung cancer. My suspicion is that litigation surrounding cigarettes will never end." 
 The proposed settlement, which needs the approval of Congress and the White House to take effect, received only a lukewarm reception on Capitol Hill and a noncommittal response from President Clinton on Friday. Experts said that even if it was ultimately adopted, court fights could delay many, if not all, of the provisions -- particularly disputes on lawsuits from victims of cigarette-related health problems, whose lawsuits and damage claims would be sharply limited under the proposal.
And while it is uncertain how the proposal will be changed by Congress and the White House, it is also not clear whether all the states will sign the accord. One Attorney General, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d of Minnesota, has criticized the settlement proposals as, in effect, a sellout to the industry, and officials from other states have said they will have to study the plan carefully before they decide what to do.
Even though the tobacco companies described the agreement as a "bitter pill," in truth it was a potentially lifesaving palliative. By putting a cap on the amount that companies would be liable for in lawsuits, the settlement removes a dark cloud that has shadowed the industry.
But the same provisions that are attractive to the industry -- the cap on damages and limits on class-action lawsuits -- threaten to undo the agreement. The legality of efforts to bind or restrict future claimants is largely unsettled, but the Supreme Court could speak to the issue in the next few days in Amchem Products v. Windsor, an asbestos class-action suit that seeks to limit the rights of future claimants.
"The concern is that the settlement inevitably will affect plaintiffs in a rather negative way," said James A. Henderson Jr., the Frank B. Ingersoll Professor at Cornell Law School and the author of numerous books and articles on product liability. "The deal, let me put it bluntly, leaves almost everyone well off. The attorneys general look good and will become governors and senators. The plaintiffs' lawyers will get their stuff.
"But there may be some people affected by cigarettes who are left with no relief."
Although tobacco companies have the strongest winning record of any industry in the courts, it has long been the fear of cigarette executives that the tide might soon turn, particularly as more internal documents have begun to surface suggesting that the companies have known the dangers of cigarettes for many years.
So experts said that it was not surprising that a centerpiece of the proposed settlement was important new restrictions against future court claims, along with other safeguards that would make it significantly harder for smokers and other victims of cigarette-related health problems to prevail in the courts.
"This proposal looks like a large payment to avoid punitive liability," Professor Priest said. "The companies have been winning on the liability issues. They have not faced punitive damages. Why are they doing this? The reason has to be the fear of punitives, and the fear of class-action lawsuits running out of control."
Companies in the asbestos and pharmaceutical industries have already been forced into bankruptcy by the wave of lawsuits from their products, and tobacco executives, despite ultimately winning every lawsuit ever filed, had begun to grow concerned that the rising hostility in the United States to smoking could start to affect juries.
The proposed settlement would dramatically alter the legal landscape by barring the most threatening kinds of lawsuits and sharply limiting damages. Future class-action suits, in which large groups of people in similar situations file claims in one suit, would be barred, and current class-action suits would be settled under terms that have not been fully outlined.
Plaintiffs like class-actions suits and companies hate them because they can result in far larger awards than can individual suits.
The agreement would also ban punitive damages for any of the past behavior of companies. Such damages are typically awarded when a judge or jury finds egregious examples of misconduct, like deceit or concealment of research -- the kinds of conduct that tobacco critics say is documented in the company papers made public in recent years by industry whistle-blowers.
Though cigarette smokers, their survivors and victims of second-hand smoke would still be able to sue individually, the proposal would limit the total amount that the industry would have to pay in court settlements to $5 billion a year.
The companies would be required to reserve $4 billion a year for a fund for those court payments, and if it was depleted payments to plaintiffs would be made the next year. Any money left in the fund at the end of each year would be transferred to new anti-tobacco programs rather than be returned to the industry.
The attorneys general and the companies said on Friday that they were confident that these amounts would be more than sufficient to satisfy any claims.
Paradoxically, the proposal would require new warnings on cigarette packages and educational programs sponsored by the cigarette companies that would make it easier for the companies to claim that they had given ample notice to smokers, making lawsuits against the companies harder to pursue.
The warnings that cigarette companies were required to put on packages in the 1960's were ultimately used by them as parts of successful defenses in later lawsuits.

HEADLINE: New York May Use Money to Aid Children

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 21

 BODY:
Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York said on Friday night that he would urge legislative leaders to dedicate half the money the state would receive under the legal settlement with the tobacco industry to establish a program providing medical coverage to hundreds of thousands of uninsured children each year.
Mr. Vacco estimated that the state would receive $400 million this year as a result of the settlement of its lawsuit against tobacco companies. That figure will grow in subsequent years as it is adjusted for inflation, increasing to as much as $700 million four years from now, he said. 
 Mr. Vacco said he was confident that the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki would use half the proceeds from the settlement to provide medical coverage to the state's 620,000 uninsured children because they would otherwise have to return the money to the Federal Government.
The other half of the money would be evenly divided between the state and local governments, which could use it for such varied purposes as closing gaps in their budgets and making up for tax cuts, Mr. Vacco said.
"This agreement is far more than I could ever have anticipated back in January when I filed this lawsuit," Mr. Vacco said at a news conference on Friday night after returning from the tobacco negotiations in Washington.
The effects of the proposed settlement were less clear among officials in New Jersey, where the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was uncertain about how much the state could expect to receive. Still, officials said about $100 million of the settlement money would be used to repay hospitals for what they spent providing treatment to uninsured patients.
In Connecticut, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said the state stood to gain as much as $100 million a year from the settlement. He said at least half of that money would be spent on providing medical care to uninsured children. Mr. Blumenthal also said much of the remaining money would be used to cover the cost of treating smoking-related illnesses and legal fees.
Mr. Vacco sued the tobacco industry on Jan. 27 to recover money that New York had spent on illnesses caused by smoking, making the state the 19th among 40 so far to file such a lawsuit. Democrats and health care experts had criticized Mr. Vacco, a Republican, for not suing the companies earlier.
But Mr. Vacco said he had tried for six months to avoid a lawsuit, seeking $656 million in damages -- a settlement that his critics said was far too small.
Connecticut and New Jersey filed their lawsuits months earlier.

HEADLINE: Russia Sits with 'Big 8,' Party Crasher No More

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: DENVER, June 21

 BODY:
In 1991 in London, Mikhail S. Gorbachev was invited to join the leaders of the Group of Seven only for lunch, after their working sessions.
In 1992, Boris N. Yeltsin came to the meeting in Munich as a penitent, getting some aid and two meals, though by most accounts he crashed dinner. 
 Mr. Yeltsin had to skip last year's meeting in Lyons, France, because he was in a difficult re-election campaign, which was followed by a heart attack, open-heart surgery and a serious case of pneumonia.
But here in Denver, with the strong support of "my friend Bill," as Mr. Yeltsin calls President Clinton, Russia is being treated as a full-fledged member of what is now being called the Summit of the Eight.
It is an extraordinary change for Russia, which used to be the troubling focus of Group of Seven meetings, where Western leaders worried about Moscow's political chaos, nuclear weapons and inflationary economy. Today, Russia sits with the rest, worrying about China.
Mr. Yeltsin -- expansive and self-confident, by all accounts drinking less, and telling everyone he meets that he's lost nearly 60 pounds since his surgery -- is relishing his new status.
No matter that the Japanese, and more quietly the French, believe Russia's economy, chaotic and comparatively small, does not warrant full membership in this group of the most important industrialized democracies.
The Japanese in particular are angry with Mr. Clinton's decision to give the Russians such a prominent role here, and are asking why China is not invited, if Russia is. The American answer is, shrugging, that Russia is a democracy and China is not, as if NATO expansion and the success of Russian reform were afterthoughts.
Except for a single hourlong meeting today on financial targets, Russian officials are taking part in every session, and Mr. Yeltsin will sign Sunday's final communique along with the other leaders.
"What you see here is a sweeping integration of Russia into the major decision-making institutions in the world in a way that is very positive for the rest of us," Mr. Clinton said on Friday.
"It's quite a hopeful moment for the world," he continued. "This is the first time we've ever had a meeting where the Russians were here from the beginning to the end. It's a great tribute I think to President Yeltsin's leadership and to the commitment of the Russian people to democracy and reform."
Russia's inclusion also reflects Mr. Clinton's new willingness, as a relatively senior member now of the group, to take the lead.
Mr. Clinton's foreign policy has been marked by uncompromising support for Mr. Yeltsin throughout his wild and eventful stewardship of a new Russia -- through all the difficulties of coup attempts, erratic behavior and brutal wars against secessionists in Chechnya and part of Georgia.
In return, Mr. Yeltsin has swallowed the expansion of NATO, but has insisted nonetheless that Russia, however reduced in power and reach, take its place as one of the world's great nations.
"Russia sees the importance of prestige," said a senior diplomat from a formerly Communist nation. "It demands to be treated as a great country seated at the table with other great countries."
Russia is best able to accept its strategic defeat -- which was also a self-liberation from Communism -- if it can don the trappings of the superpower it used to be, suggested Andrei Piontkovsky, director of Moscow's Center for Strategic Studies.
"It is part of the West's psychotherapy for Russia, and for Yeltsin personally," he said.
So it was no surprise that the Russians told the interior designer who remodeled Mr. Yeltsin's rooms at the Embassy Suites here to give them "an Oval Office feeling," The Rocky Mountain News reported.
Or that Mr. Yeltsin and his spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, gloat that they are in Denver, and not the Chinese.
"As soon as you leave the airport here, you see signs saying 'G-8,' " said Mr. Yastrzhembsky. "Denver has clarified this formal position."
He noted that Mr. Clinton had given Mr. Yeltsin the honor of speaking first at Friday's night's opening dinner for the meeting, and said proudly: "This time there will be no special meetings dedicated to Russia, as in the past. That means that Russia is a full-fledged member of the eight," which the Russians insist on calling "the Big Eight."
During the hourlong meeting that Mr. Yeltsin will miss, he will meet representatives of leading American companies, most particularly the Lockheed Martin Corporation, which has worked very hard to make the Russians feel at home here.
The company -- which has lobbied hard in Washington for NATO expansion, hoping to sell new members its F-16 fighter planes -- helped throw a lavish cocktail party for Mr. Yeltsin on Thursday night at the Denver Museum of Natural History.
Mr. Yeltsin, after a change of plans, arrived too late to attend, but the Russian Ambassador, Yuli M. Vorontsov, gave a warm toast, and Russian officials like the consul general in San Francisco, Vladimir Kuznetsov, spoke proudly of how "Russia in space still has great achievements to its name."
Lockheed is buying a largely Russian-designed rocket engine, produced as a joint venture between NPO Energomash and Pratt & Whitney, for its Atlas IIAR commercial rockets -- originally created in the 1950's to hurl nuclear warheads at Russia but now designed to put telecommunications satellites into space. This is not just a gesture, Lockheed insists. Just before Mr. Yeltsin's arrival, Lockheed announced that it would buy up to 101 engines for about $1 billion.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright also did her diplomatic bit here, taking Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov to dinner at a Denver restaurant featuring rattlesnake and "Rocky Mountain oysters" -- buffalo testicles.
Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, said that for 50 years, "we defined our relationship in the world in distinction to the Soviet Union."
"We spent hundreds of billions of dollars fighting the cold war," he said. "We now have an opportunity to integrate a democratic Russia into the global economy and into the institutions of the international community, and that has enormous payoff for the American people if it succeeds and enormous downside if it fails."
If massaging Russia requires a degree of fakery and disingenuousness, a senior American official implied, it is a small price to pay.
"I don't really care what Yeltsin does here," the official said. "What's important is that he is here."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC UNEASE LOOMS OVER TALKS AT DENVER SUMMIT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 21

 BODY:
President Clinton and the leaders of Russia, Japan and Western Europe plunged into the messy business of defining their new roles in the global economy today, with Russia pressing for quick entry into the World Trade Organization and Europe struggling to save its effort to unify under a single currency.
Buoyed by the strongest economic performance in the world, Mr. Clinton exuded optimism at the opening of the summit meeting, which until this year was called the Group of Seven, but now, with the inclusion of Russia, is formally called the Summit of the Eight. Nevertheless the President's aides were clearly skeptical that Russia and Europe were prepared to adopt the major economic reforms that American officials believe are necessary in the next year or two. 
 In return for its grudging agreement to the expansion of NATO, Russia was all but promised entry by next year into the World Trade Organization, the club of trading nations. The move would greatly help its exports by lowering tariffs on Russian-made goods.
But Administration officials say they are highly skeptical that President Boris N. Yeltsin can move that quickly to push through the wrenching market openings and legal changes that are the price of entry. Similar problems have bogged down negotiations over China's effort to enter the trading group.
As the weekend meeting of the eight leaders opened here on Friday, Administration officials were also dancing around the question of whether Europe's effort to create a single currency, the euro, by 1999 could threaten the financial stability of America's oldest trading partners. European officials had pressed for a blanket endorsement of the single currency in an economic statement released today.
But the United States, with the backing of Japan and Britain, insisted on a far more conditional endorsement. The final statement says the leaders would welcome monetary union if it was accompanied by major economic reforms, and "would contribute to the stability of the international monetary system." Those are code words for an end to the inflexible rules that have prevented companies from paring down, moving workers, and becoming far more competitive on world markets.
"France, Germany and Italy share the challenging task of restoring strong employment growth," the economic statement said. "While pursuing efforts toward restoring sound fiscal positions they will need to deepen structural reforms to reduce barriers to job creation and to increase efficiency of government actions and, where necessary, reshape its role in their economies."
In today's discussion among the leaders, there was a vigorous debate between France and other participants over whether it is possible to shorten the French work week, which the new Socialist Government has promised, without slowing economic growth. American officials have argued that Europe's work week needs to be lengthened, but it is unclear whether the United States pressed that argument today.
A senior Administration official said here on Friday that beneath the bland wording of the statement, "there is a lot more nervousness than there was just a month or two ago that the Europeans haven't grappled with the real implications of what they are attempting."
"We haven't gone as far as saying that they are on the verge of messing up the Continent -- that would only fuel their resentment -- but you'll probably hear some more explicit description of the risks," the official said.
Today's sessions, largely devoted to questions of economic integration, marked the middle day of the annual summit meeting. Mr. Clinton was an ebullient host, alternately drawing his guests' attention to the soaring American economy and the soaring view of the Rockies from downtown Denver, where the formal meetings are taking place at the public library.
Tonight, the leaders are dining at The Fort, a popular tourist attraction made to look like an old adobe fort. Buffalo meat is the house speciality.
At Friday's meetings, the boasting about America's economic performance among Administration officials was growing so pronounced that Mr. Clinton cautioned his aides to tone down unflattering comparisons to Europe and Japan.
But it was too late: his aides had already distributed an 11 page packet comparing America's economic performance since 1990 with that of the other nations present.
The statistics showed the United States exceeding those nations in economic growth, job creation and investment in factories and new technologies.
"I think the President decided we were laying it on a little thick," one of his aides said on Friday.
During his meeting with President Jacques Chirac of France, for example, President Clinton hailed France's comprehensive medical care system, particularly for children, and declared that the United States had much to learn from the French approach.
Those comments clearly seemed intended to balance the Administration's many suggestions recently weeks that France's election of a Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, threatened to send the country into an era of overspending instead of austerity.
The political communique scheduled for release on Sunday -- but posted on the Internet today by a Canadian university that had obtained an early copy -- cautions China to respect Hong Kong's "fundamental freedoms." A breach of China's commitments to do so, it warned, using language that American officials had been repeating for some months, could undermine "the essential undepinning for Hong Kong's future economic success."
The communique called for relatively quick democratic elections for a new legislature to govern Hong Kong.
The draft also included an indirect warning to Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, and to Franjo Tudjman, recently re-elected Croatia's President, insisting that refugees have the right to return to their homes or the government will risk a cutoff in economic assistance.
That reinforces a position that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has taken in recent months but adds the voices of the other major powers.
The leaders had spent some time this morning discussing a new movement among the industrialized nations, propelled by the United States, to make the bribery of foreign officials a crime.
Until recently such bribery of foreign officials was tax deductible in Germany, while in the United States it has been a felony since the passage of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act two decades ago. American companies have complained for years that they are at a disadvantage in the cutthroat international competition for multibillion-dollar contracts for building everything from satellite networks to new airports.
The countries represented here committed today to submit legislation to their parliaments by April 1998 to criminalize such bribery.

HEADLINE: Environmental Groups Say Gore Has Not Measured Up to the Job

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, one of the environmental movement's steadiest allies, is under attack from major conservation groups in an unlikely turn that carries important implications for environmental policy as well as Presidential politics.
The groups say they are frustrated, even angry, that, in their view, Mr. Gore has failed to exert strong influence on two of the environmental movement's top priorities this year: toughening air pollution standards and negotiating deep cuts in worldwide emissions of greenhouse gases. In the next few days, President Clinton, who defers to Mr. Gore on most environmental matters, is expected to spell out his positions on both questions. 
 Although environmentalists form the core of Mr. Gore's political base, organizations that have sided with the Vice President throughout his public career are now using extraordinarily blunt language to warn that "green" voters might abandon him in the Democratic primaries in 2000 unless he delivers now on these crucial issues.
Top environmental lobbyists have even met with Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader who is a leading rival for the Democratic nomination, urging him to demand that the White House display more leadership on their issues.
The environment is but one issue in which Mr. Gore's positions and influence in the White House will draw intensified attention as he gears up to run for President.
Mr. Gore has for years also scored politically on other issues that are very much in the news now, like telecommunications policy, anti-tobacco measures, television ratings, biomedical ethics and censorship on the Internet. Now that many of these issues have become particularly contentious, Mr. Gore may well be forced to play a more public role in the debates over them.
In an interview late Friday, Mr. Gore defended his environmental record and said that his job demanded that he work behind the scenes. "Everybody knows my views," he said. "But I am not going to publicly try to back the President into a corner. I never have done that, and I never will."
Mr. Gore acknowledged that the pressure from environmental groups had been intense in recent weeks. The Sierra Club has begun television advertising campaigns in early primary states, urging Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore to "stand up to the special interests."
Environmental groups have distributed a polemic to editorial writers that derides remarks by the President and the Vice President on global warming as "hot air."
And in a letter last week on the air standards, 84 environmental and health groups wrote, "We are deeply disturbed and perplexed by the apparent lack of visible and vocal support from the White House for the proposed new standards."
"What we need and what we expect is leadership," said Deb Callahan, president of the League of Conservation Voters, a political action committee that stands out from other environmental groups because it openly endorses candidates. "Not to speak out and not to influence the President is not leadership. It is a bit perplexing that he would step back from providing this leadership." Ms. Callahan worked for Mr. Gore's Presidential campaign in 1988.
Philip E. Clapp, president of the Environmental Information Center, a relatively new but increasingly influential advocacy group, put it this way: "The failure of the White House to provide any leadership on the clean air standards and on climate change raises real questions about what real environmental progress Vice President Gore can point to in claiming the mantle of the environmental candidate in the year 2000."
In the interview, Mr. Gore did not seem distressed by the barrage of criticism. "I quite understand why some group that feels passionately would decide to pull out all the stops to try to gain leverage in any way they can," he said. "And that is their job. My job is not to publicly argue for a specific policy that has not yet been formally recommended to the President and take options away from him."
But as the complaints about what one environmentalist called "Al Gore's silent spring" have intensified, the Vice President has scrambled in the last two days to reassure environmental leaders privately. And his aides have begun to signal that Mr. Gore was weighing in behind the scenes for a decision on clean air standards that would satisfy the environmentalists.
Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, said in an interview: "There is no doubt in my mind that the Vice President is in there doing what he has done on many difficult issues.
"He is moving the ball," she said, "providing the leadership, making the case for strong public health protection." For months, Ms. Browner advocated tougher air quality rules without a word in her defense from the White House.
Mr. Gore's advisers accused his newfound critics of an orchestrated drive to prod him even further on their issues. "I guess the problem is, you always hurt the one you love," said Kathleen McGinty, the senior environmental aide at the White House. "The environmentalists have a strategy here to send a message to us because they know the Vice President does care about what they say."
The Administration's proposals on air quality and global warming have come under intense criticism in Congress and from major industries, especially oil, coal and car companies, and White House economic advisers are battling with environmental officials over how aggressive a stance to take.
Some environmental leaders accused Mr. Gore of taking his environmental support for granted so he can make overtures to business and labor interests that could help him raise millions of dollars to compete in the Democratic primaries.
This is not the first time that environmentalists have criticized Mr. Gore for wavering on their issues. But never before has the message been delivered so bluntly. Administration officials are bracing for demonstrators next week when the President and Vice President are in New York to meet with world leaders for a conference on climate change.
And no longer is it only Republicans who are tearing apart copies of Mr. Gore's book on the environment, "Earth in the Balance." Now, environmental groups are distributing passages from the book as evidence of the Vice President's failure to make progress on the environment.
While environmentalists also criticize the Administration's positions on endangered species issues, the regulation of toxic water pollution from paper mills and a forest service plan for continued logging in the Tongass National Forest, the debate has become feverish as two of the environmentalists' top priorities -- clean air standards and global warming -- have come before the White House. The Administration is under a court order to decide within a month how tightly to control emissions of smog and soot, and the White House's economic advisers, heeding pleas from industry, have been urging the Environmental Protection Agency to ease its earlier proposals.
The other pending environmental issue, strengthening the treaty on climate change, will be at the forefront at a United Nations conference in New York beginning on Monday. Signatories to the treaty, written five years ago in Rio de Janeiro, are trying to negotiate by year-end a tougher version setting mandatory limits on the emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, which are implicated in global warming and are continuing to rise. But the United States has refused so far to commit to a timetable for reducing greenhouse gases and has signaled that some other countries' targets may be too ambitious.
The Natural Resources Defense Council, one group joining in the chorus for stronger actions on climate change, has bought newspaper advertisements to that effect on the eve of the United Nations meeting.
But John Adams, the head of the group, spoke sympathetically of Mr. Gore in an interview. "I know people are angry and are upset and they want to win here, but I want to have a relationship based on the total record," he said. "This is a good man who cares about the environment -- and he is a good man to have on our side."
Some environmentalists suggested that part of Mr. Gore's calculation was to win favor from Mayors Richard M. Daley of Chicago and Dennis W. Archer of Detroit and other influential Democrats who strongly oppose tightening air standards and could be important allies in the Presidential primaries. Potential Republican rivals -- Govs. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, George E. Pataki of New York and William F. Weld of Massachusetts -- are already speaking out for stronger clean air standards.
And Mr. Gore, party strategists say, cannot appear too willing to support environmental policies with no concern about the economic consequences. Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster, said the Democrats could not afford to be "too hard on business at the risk of reducing job growth -- that's the conundrum they're in."
Ronald Klain, Mr. Gore's chief of staff, rejected those criticisms. "They should have a little faith," he said of the environmental groups. "His views on the environment have never been about votes or having things in his pocket, but about an agenda he deeply and personally believes in."
Even a senior aide to Mr. Gephardt, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said the Vice President might well survive the onslaught from environmentalists. "They may be downplaying their expectations," the adviser said of calculations in the White House, "so Gore can claim he saved the day" for the environmental movement.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said Mr. Gore could use these looming environmental decisions to repair his relationship with businesses. "He's got a poor relationship with the business community on all of these regulatory issues," he said. The environmental groups are worried, he said, because "if they lose Gore, they don't have anyone left."

HEADLINE: VOLLEYBALL;
Sand Game Hampered By a Lack Of Unity

BYLINE: By TARIK EL-BASHIR

 BODY:
Sun and sand are not all that professional beach volleyball is in search of these days. A year after the sport made a successful debut at the Olympics, it continues to search for an identity.
This weekend, Central Park is the host of the Bud Light Pro Beach Volleyball League tour, which features many of the sport's top athletes. The Association of Volleyball Professionals, pro beach volleyball's premier tour, is in Chicago. At the same time, the Women's Professional Volleyball Association, a pro tour featuring Deb Richardson and Linda Chisolm, two of the most accomplished players in the world, is in Atlantic City. 
 The fractured state of the sport is one reason beach volleyball has not been able to take full advantage of the attention it received at the Olympics last year, when the American men took gold and silver medals, said Craig Elledge, the president of C.E. Sports, the company responsible for operating the Bud Light tour.
Beach volleyball does, however, seem to be gaining in attendance and in television exposure. This weekend's event at Central Park's band shell had a few hundred spectators yesterday for round-robin play, in which Gabrielle Reece led the women's two-time defending champion Team Nike to a 3-0 record; it is expected to draw a bigger crowd for today's semifinals and finals and will be shown on ESPN next month. The event in Chicago was broadcast on NBC yesterday.
"I think beach volleyball truly has a huge appeal -- just look at how much attention it got at the Olympics last year," Elledge said. "But the fans here in the U.S. are so sophisticated. For us to capture their attention, I think there will have to be some changes. It needs to be one sport, not the A.V.P., the W.P.V.A., the A.B.V.L. and F.I.V.P. It's alphabet soup."
In addition to the different tours, each with its own rules, there are different formats -- doubles, which allows for two players on each side, and fours, which has four players per team. The Olympics include only doubles, while this weekend's event in Central Park is fours. The A.V.P., which visited Central Park last year, plays doubles.
"I don't think that beach volleyball has gotten as big as people thought it would have, not after the Olympics," said Reece, the most recognizable face in pro beach volleyball and captain of Team Nike. "It's so divided. It's hard because it has stars in doubles and in fours and stars on different tours right now. Right now, I think the attitude of the fans is, if I catch it, then I catch it. If I don't, then I don't."
But the division within the sport seems to be only one of many problems afflicting beach volleyball. Lack of sponsors and a relative lack of televised events, though more events have been shown in recent years, affect the economic stability of the sport. For example, Bob Ctvrtlik, the captain of the 1996 Olympic volleyball team, is also the captain of the Team American Beach Volleyball League, the best men's team on the Bud Light tour. But the team, which was 2-0 in the round robin yesterday, has no sponsor.
The first change may be to begin charging for seats at events. The event in Central Park is free, as are many other beach volleyball events.
One change that has already been announced is a world championship of beach volleyball, to be played in Los Angeles in September. The best players from around the world, regardless of the tour they play on, will compete.
"The Olympics were good for beach volleyball, but I don't kid anyone that we're pushing back basketball, football or baseball," Ctvrtlik said. "If you want to grow a sport, you have to be on TV and people have to like it."
Besides the free entertainment that beach volleyball tours provide, they also help Olympic hopefuls hone their skills, Ctvrtlik said.
"The Olympics are a showcase," Ctvrtlik said. "A lot of the guys here are going to be trying to play in the Olympics in 2000. You have got to give guys that ultimate goal."

HEADLINE: Newfangled 'Grouping' in Schools Looks Like Oldfangled 'Tracking'

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 20

 BODY:
Since the 1970's, grouping students by intellectual ability, or tracking, has been taboo in the schools of the New York City region, the victim of concerns about racial pigeonholing and fears that the pride of students would be wounded by labeling.
Ask school administrators whether they sort children into bright, average and slow classes, and they will flatly say no. 
 But in Trinity Elementary School here, as in many schools in the region, classes in the same grade are working on distinctly different levels. Ruth Katz's fifth-grade "Kaleidoscope" mathematics class, for example, is trying to figure out 95 percent of 10, a problem students do not usually encounter until sixth grade.
"Think, think, think, folks!" Mrs. Katz prodded them. "If you get a 95 percent score on a test, is that getting most of the answers correct or incorrect?"
By contrast, just across the hall, Penny Constantine's mainstream class is working with the less elusive concepts of subtracting fractions.
Tracking, in short, endures, though in more variable forms than a generation ago, when critics began questioning the racially discriminatory effect of the I.Q. tests used to assign children to tracks. Most school districts do some sorting of children by ability as early as elementary school, then start more traditional tracking by junior high school with full-time honors classes. By high school, students can pick their own tracks by choosing honors or advanced placement classes instead of standard courses.
"The word tracking has become such an evil, nasty thing that the typical response is we don't do that," said Jeannie Oakes, a professor of education at the University of California at Los Angeles, who wrote an influential 1985 book, "Keeping Track." "But when you probe how students are grouped for instruction and what kinds of programs some students have available to them and others do not, you find the phenomenon of dividing students according to judgments about their academic potential alive and well."
A variety of grouping methods supplement the regular curriculum -- pullout enrichment programs, half-day programs, two-day-a-week programs and ability groups within a class.
In establishing such programs, most school districts seem to have learned to avoid the political pitfalls of rigid tracking, which has often been attacked for consigning black and Hispanic students more often than whites to the bottom tiers. They use criteria beyond I.Q. tests and reading scores, like recommendations from teachers, to achieve racial diversity, a success confirmed by visits to half a dozen suburban schools.
And yet, supplementary enrichment programs have their critics. Too often, they say, the programs deal with marginal studies outside the standard curriculum. In Tarrytown, one gifted sixth grader worked for a year on a history of the Brooklyn Bridge and another year on a history of hats. In the once-a-week gifted program in Oceanside, N.Y., students pretended they were town planners and drafted budgets geared to what they saw as the town's priorities. Critics ask, how do such programs improve basic math and reading skills?
"People are starting to ask embarrassing questions, like 'Do they work?' " said Dr. James H. Borland, associate professor of education at Teachers College at Columbia University. "There's no evidence that they do or don't work. People know these kids need more, but nobody's sure what."
 
Practice of Grouping Started Long Ago
The issue of tracking has been unsettling public schools since the turn of the century. America's industrial economy needed trained accountants, engineers and secretaries and, in New York, the swarms of immigrants from other countries and migrants from the South needed to be educated. The school system responded by adapting the curriculum into academic, commercial and vocational streams, and the I.Q. tests developed for assigning World War I recruits was a handy sorting tool.
Tracking softened during periods of national well-being, but the orbiting of Sputnik in 1957 started a debate on how well schools were preparing American youngsters to compete with the Soviets. Tracking again was in fashion.
By the 1970's, as the nation awoke to its shabby treatment of minorities, it began questioning the use of I.Q. tests and tracks. "Tracking tends to divide by race and economic class, and that in itself is a potentially significant problem for us as a society," said Dr. Francis Murphy, the Superintendent of Schools in Scarsdale.
To a degree, tracking has been replaced by special programs for children identified as gifted.
Most educators now say they avoid tracking because it labels students as "dummies" at an early age, diminishes their aspirations and strips classes of the bright children that might inspire or help them.
At the same time, educators recognize that there are students who are unusually thirsty for information and exotic ideas or may have a passion for scientific experimentation or mathematical enigmas. Such students will feel stymied in classrooms aimed at a bland middle.
"If we going to compete in the world, we have to develop our best and brightest," said Dr. Elliot Garfinkel, the Superintendent of Schools in Oceanside.
A common response has been pullout enrichment programs. In Baldwin, N.Y., 100 students identified as gifted are pulled out of regular classes for two days every week and bused to a school building where they study subjects like architecture and archeology. Such programs keep bright and average children together for much of the day, but the drawback, some critics say, is that they must make up the work they missed while being enriched.
Some school systems use more traditional forms of grouping. The South Orange-Maplewood district in New Jersey, a district of 5,800 students with roughy equal numbers of white, black and Hispanic children, starts separating students in the sixth grade. A student can be in a top mathematics class, a medium English class and a standard social studies class. But some residents say a large number of the students who have recently moved from neighboring districts like Newark and East Orange end up in the lower tiers.
"We do get complaints that the top track is heavy with white kids," Jim Memoli, the district's curriculum coordinator, said.
 
Teaching Groups One at a Time
People who grew up in the 1960's, when a grade would be strictly stratified from, say, Class 6-1 to 6-6 but the teacher taught the whole class at once, would not recognize Alice Galanka's fifth-grade class.
In Tarrytown's Washington Irving School, Ms. Galanka, a tall, broad-shouldered, masterful teacher in just her second year of teaching, divides her class into four different groups for some subjects.
For math the other day, her most advanced math students were poised in front of a computer monitor clicking their mouse on a new game that teaches them how to graph coordinates in three dimensions.
While they worked on their own, Ms. Galanka reviewed a more basic skill with her bottom group -- adding fractions that have different denominators.
Meanwhile, the second-strongest math contingent was working with a student teacher on solving math problems by using sketches to plot their computations. A sample went like this: "A sleepy koala bear wants to climb to the top of a tree that is 10 meters tall. Each day he climbs up five meters, but at night while asleep, he slides back four meters. At this rate, how many days will it take the bear to reach the top?"
And the fourth group toiled by itself over a worksheet that coached them for a coming statewide test.
What distinguishes this class from tracking is its fluidity, Ms. Galanka said. Students can move up by mastering a given concept. And because students are together for much of the day, Ms. Galanka argued, bottom-rung students may improve because of exposure to the top achievers.
"A boy like that who is bright finds out in class that it's cool to be smart," she said of one bottom-rung student. "That wouldn't happen in a homogenous class."
On the other hand, she said, some of the children in the lower groups have talents, like a flair for dramatics, that can "inspire kids getting 100s in math to loosen up and explore their talents."
Critics would argue that such grouping requires Ms. Galanka to prepare four lesson plans nightly. They also point out that she must leave some groups untended while she focuses on one.
Often the brightest students get the least of Ms. Galanka's attention. Yet, Tarrytown officials, like her principal, Sal Tricamo, argue that research shows that gifted students do not suffer in mixed classes. "The truth is those more able kids don't need as much," Mr. Tricamo said.
In Tarrytown, such in-class grouping serves to maintain diverse classes in a district that includes the children of Tarrytown's wealthy and professional families as well as the children of Latin American immigrants moving into the apartments once occupied by General Motors plant workers. In fact, 47 percent of the district's students are Hispanic, 40 percent are white and 10 percent are black.
"If you're constantly told you're no good in baseball, what would you do?" Dr. Donald R. Kusel, Tarrytown's Superintendent, said. "You'd drop out. You can't do that with learning. So you become a behavior problem. We have consigned kids to failure, especially immigrant kids and kids of color."
Yet, for its 75 very brightest students, Tarrytown has what it calls a Challenge program, in which gifted students in the fourth, fifth and sixth grades are pulled out for 45 minutes every other day to work on offbeat projects. Nina Fixell, a sixth grader, used the Internet to find a way to cut glass with a pair of household scissors. She cut it under water, which weakened the glass's molecular bonds.
Nina said she would prefer being among the Challenge students for the entire day, but does not mind the present system because she gets to help other children.
Ultimately, educators admit they are still struggling to find the right balance.
"I don't think anybody can say when you're dealing with human beings what absolutely works," Mr. Kusel said.

HEADLINE: Unlikely Allies in Fight for Hemp

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: MODENA, N.Y., June 20

 BODY:
Fred A. Maslack made the long drive down from southern Vermont in the oldest car with Vermont legislative plates, his rusting 1982 Dodge Diplomat.
Mr. Maslack, 38, a conservative Republican State Representative, had come to this village, 70 miles north of New York City, to give the keynote address at a three-day event that was expected to attract 4,000 people. 
 "It's about a classic Republican issue," said Mr. Maslack, who is also a slate quarrier from East Poultney, Vt. "It's all about getting government out of the way so people can go out and make money."
But nothing around him at the Lembo Lake campground appeared remotely Republican. A rainbow-haired band called the Cheezbutts thrashed through a pounding rock tune. Hemp burgers sizzled on a griddle. A vendor in a tie-dyed T-shirt hawked skull-shaped hashish pipes. And the breeze held the distinct, pungent tang of marijuana smoke.
The issue that the Vermont legislator shared with the crowd around him was legalization of the cultivation of hemp, a low-potency variety of Cannabis sativa, the ancient multipurpose weed that during World War II supplied Allied troops with cord and rope and during the 1960's supplied hippies with altered states of mind.
Mr. Maslack's goal was to pass laws in Vermont that permit the licensing of farmers who seek to grow industrial varieties of hemp that contain no significant concentration of THC, the chemical that causes a high among marijuana smokers. "Our farmers need all the help they can get," he said.
The goal of Robert Robinson, the manager of the annual three-day festival billed as "Hemp Splash," was to promote the legal use of marijuana to get high.
"The last census said that 60 million Americans smoke," Mr. Robinson said. "For proof positive, just look around."
Mr. Maslack is part of an informal network of legislators from nearly a dozen states where farming of industrial hemp has been promoted as a way to improve agriculture and create textile and other jobs. "It fits Vermont's niche," Mr. Maslack said, explaining that hemp is easily cultivated even on rugged slopes. He held up a tuft of fibers next to a bale of raw hemp stalks and told how the material could be turned into linenlike cloth. The plant's high-protein seeds, he added, could be made into everything from soap to the burgers being served nearby.
At the festival, Mr. Maslack set up camp near the booth of the Vermont Hemporium, a company selling hemp necklaces, backpacks, and other gear -- all made from imported fibers instead of home-grown material.
Joseph Shimek, the company's owner, said he smokes marijuana, but was mainly concerned with getting a cheap, local source of the raw material for his goods. "This is about trying to make a stable business," he said. "Fred's an angel to us."
He helped Mr. Maslack promote legislation last year that allowed Vermont to study the crop's economic potential. The state's Democratic Governor, Howard Dean, had opposed an earlier version of the law that would have licensed hemp growers.
Mr. Maslack said he had taken on the hemp issue not only because the crop could spur Vermont's agricultural economy, but also because he resented how the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration had increasingly lobbied states to prevent any shift toward legalizing cannabis in any form.
Nancy J. Sheltra, a Republican colleague of Mr. Maslack's from Derby, Vt., said in a phone telephone interview that it surprised her to think of Mr. Maslack speaking to several thousand people at a rock concert. "Except for this one issue, he has been very conservative in the Republican Party here," said Ms. Sheltra, who opposed the hemp licensing legislation.
But Mr. Maslack said he had no qualms about speaking at such a gathering. He said what people do in private is their concern, adding that he was determined to exploit the economic value of hemp as a source of fiber and food.
As Mr. Maslack explained his dream of waving fields of fibrous hemp, those around him in the in the sprawling apple orchard that doubled as a campground remained more focused on marijuana's other uses. Behind a drape of hemp cloth, a man offered passers-by a chance to "vaporize."
"It's the safest way to inhale," he said, explaining that the marijuana releases its potent vapors when it is heated to just below the temperature at which it burns.
As dusk settled over the orchard, the crickets and cicadas were joined by a chorus of clicking lighters.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

TOBACCO SETTLEMENT
A $360 Billion Answer
Tobacco companies agreed to a $360 billion product liability settlement with state attorneys general and public health representatives. The agreement is subject to approval in Congress, where a tough fight is expected. President Clinton, whose backing is regarded as crucial, said he would review the pact. Under the deal, smokers would see dire new warnings on cigarette packs, get free medical help to kick the habit and be inundated with nationwide anti-smoking advertising. Tobacco ads would be strictly curbed. In return, tobacco companies and investors would get relief from the uncertainty posed by hundreds of pending lawsuits. The $360 billion would be paid out over 25 years. Tobacco stock prices, up during the week, fell after the deal was announced.
 
THE GLOWING ECONOMY
Washington and Wall St. Cheer
Economic statistics were so favorable last week that stocks continued their winning ways -- and Washington cheered. In Denver, President Clinton, preparing to open the annual summit meeting of the major industrial nations, boasted, "We host our partners at a time when America's economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world." Indeed, if inflation has not been vanquished, it at least appears comatose. The Consumer Price Index rose a barely noticeable one-tenth of 1 percent in May; so far this year it is running at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent. Industrial production rose a strong four-tenths of a percentage point in May, and capacity utilization rose to 83.7 percent. The nation's foreign trade deficit increased 7.8 percent in April, to $8.4 billion, from a revised $7.8 billion in March -- but even that was not as bad as expected, thanks to surging export growth. 

SURGING STOCKS
The Records Keep Falling
Stocks, having set records the previous week, toppled them last week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.47 to 7,796.51. In the last 10 weeks, the Dow has surged more than 22 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.43 to 898.70, and the Nasdaq composite index, laden with computer companies, rose 27.04 to 1,447.10. Airline stocks, including AMR, parent of American, and UAL, parent of United, rose after members of the Senate Finance Committee agreed to drop a proposed tax on international airline tickets. Among other strong issues were I.B.M. and Boeing, which won a $1 billion order for jetliners from British Airways. Stocks of financial companies, like Travelers and J. P. Morgan, benefited from a drop in interest rates. The yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell to 6.66 percent from 6.72 percent a week earlier.
 
STORE CLOSINGS
Farewell to a Barneys
Barney's Inc., the stylish specialty chain now in bankruptcy, said it would close its original, 74-year-old store at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street, as well as stores in Houston, Dallas and Troy, Mich. The Texas Pacific Group, an investment group led by David Bonderman, expressed interest in bidding for Barney's in bankruptcy court, as have Saks Holdings and Dickson Concepts (International), which is based in Hong Kong and owns the Harvey Nichols store in London. In another blow to New York retailing, the Doubleday Book Shop on Fifth Avenue said it would shut by the end of the month, a victim of high rents. It will be the seventh bookstore to close on the avenue since the early 1980's, leaving the avenue's more cerebral shoppers with only Barnes & Noble at 49th Street.
 
POSSIBLE MERGERS
Early Opposition to AT&T
Seeking to scuttle the largest corporate merger in history even before it is formally proposed, Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declared that merging AT&T with a regional Bell telephone company would be "unthinkable." AT&T responded tartly that the F.C.C. should judge a merger "when and if it is made." Although there has been no official confirmation of the talks, executives have said that AT&T, the largest long-distance company, has been discussing a $50 billion merger with SBC Communications, the largest of the regional Bell telephone companies, for several months. The F.C.C. has traditionally deferred to the Justice Department on antitrust matters, but now Mr. Hundt is seizing the initiative.
 
THE MIGHTY MARK
Germans Invest in Times Square
What could be more American than Times Square? Never mind. One Times Square, the skinny tower that has been home to the New Year's Eve ball drop for nearly a century, is being sold to German investors for nearly four times the $27.5 million paid for it by Lehman Brothers a little more than two years ago. Lehman has signed a contract to sell the property to the Jamestown group, a German investment firm, for about $110 million, according to people familiar with the negotiations. The building is vacant and is likely to remain mostly empty, serving basically as a gigantic billboard, although a theme restaurant may be added in its base. So, guten Appetit!
 
EUROPEAN UNION
Is the Euro Back on Track?
Turning back a French challenge, leaders of the European Union agreed to a stability pact that preserves tight government spending as the alliance's top priority and renewed its determination to create a common currency, the euro. Britain and Germany made clear that government spending was not an acceptable way to create new jobs for Europe's 18 million jobless people.

STEAMED
Federal Express vs. Federal Espresso
If a corporation is legally a person, what sort of person is it? In the case of Federal Express, let's say street fighter. Bully would sound rude. The Associated Press reported that the global company has sued Federal Espresso, a grocery store coffee cart in Beaverton, Ore., operated by 23-year-old Greg Judish, accusing him of violating its trademark. Mr. Judish said he saw nothing wrong with his name or winged coffee-cup logo, but would ask a lawyer friend to help him write a reply. On a good day he serves 100 cups of coffee, along with tea, biscotti and other snacks.
 
THE CAT'S MEOW
And the Backers Purr
"Cats" overtook "A Chorus Line" as the longest-running show in Broadway history, playing its 6,138th performance on Thursday. The musical, which opened at the Winter Garden theater on Oct. 7, 1982, has been seen by more than 50 million people worldwide. A financial juggernaut, with ticket sales totaling $329 million in New York alone, it was the first in a wave of megamusicals that reshaped Broadway in the 1980's, redirecting the Broadway market toward blockbuster hits and foreign tourism. It also made Andrew Lloyd Webber, the musical's composer, a global brand name. But not all has gone well lately for Sir Andrew. His production company has laid off two-thirds of its employees since losing $20 million on "Sunset Boulevard."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; Women's Health

LENGTH: 2190 words

HEADLINE: More Research, More Profits, More Conflict

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

 BODY:
NEVER before have women meant so much to so many. Recognized as the health care system's biggest customers, they are being treated as such: researched and marketed to, tracked and talked about.
Consider: Premarin, an estrogen replacement, is the most widely used prescription drug in the United States. From 1991 to 1992, the number of hospitals with a women's health center rose 19 percent, according to a survey by the American Hospital Association. In many cities, Atlanta and Dallas among them, hospitals are competing for pregnant Medicaid patients; among the lures are free Disney movies for the older children, infant car seats, baby showers, insulated beverage flasks and monogrammed blankets. 
 Even the women who coalesced 30 years ago into something loosely called the women's health movement are struck by the mix of responsive medicine and commercial grasping that the 1990's have delivered. It is both more and less than these mothers of intervention bargained for.
"As a lasting legacy of the women's movement, health care is one of our shining moments," said Dr. Susan Reverby, a professor of women's studies at Wellesley College, who recently served on an obstetrics and gynecology advisory panel for the Federal Food and Drug Administration.
While acknowledging that "the health care system is relentless in its ability to figure out where the next buck is coming from," Ms. Reverby said the medical profession had become more aware of women's concerns, especially those beyond the gynecologic. "There's much more consciousness about what women's issues are," she said. "We can now talk about heart disease and about AIDS."
But not all women applaud the results of that new consciousness.
Rachel Fruchter, an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn, said she was appalled that women were pursued so avidly as consumers, particularly by pharmaceutical companies whose advertisements picture radiant middle-aged women and counsel, "Ask your doctor."
"The pretense that that's what the women's health movement wanted is a bad joke," Ms. Fruchter said.
In the beginning, the women's health movement talked mostly about abortion and contraceptives. But as its baby boomer leaders have reached the age of influence -- and the age of menopause -- the health concerns of older generations have taken on new urgency. That urgency is also fueled by the fact that women are living longer -- on average, more than seven years longer than men -- and are thus suffering from the crippling diseases of old age, like arthritis and osteoporosis.
At the same time, women have not just been complaining about doctors but have been becoming doctors. The influx has made female patients happier and helped bring new emphasis to the doctor's role as interviewer, said Dr. Charlea Massion, a family doctor at the Santa Cruz Medical Center in California and a clinical faculty member at Stanford University.
"Women physicians do have, and linguistic studies show this, a different way of communicating," Dr. Massion said, adding: "I don't think women physicians are necessarily interested in women's health just by being women, and I don't think women physicians are more open-minded or have a more comprehensive approach just because they are women. But most of the innovative thinking that's being done in health care is being done by women."
That does not mean that women believe they are being well served.
Like many of the other early participants in the women's health movement. Ms. Fruchter views the issue as a matter of social justice. She noted that many women cannot afford the health care that is being urged upon them.
She said that she addressed Brooklyn community groups and churches on cancer screening but that many of the women she saw could not pay for it: they are the working poor, not insured by employers and not old enough to qualify for Medicare. And they have an array of health problems.
"They say breast cancer is important," Ms. Fruchter said, "but there are other things. What about their blood pressure, their diabetes, their disabled child?"
Much of the attention to women is undeniably genuine, even if it feeds advertising campaigns. Federal funds for breast cancer exceeded $600 billion in the current fiscal year, up from $90 billion in 1990. The National Institutes of Health, the source and overseer of money for most of the nation's biomedical research, established an Office of Research on Women's Health in 1990 and has undertaken two huge studies of heart disease and cancer among women.
A half-dozen new medical journals on women's health have sprung up in the same period. But even these cannot contain the academic attention: while a survey of Medline, a data base of medical journal articles, turned up 159 entries under the heading "women's health" from 1986 through 1991, it found 1,426 entries from 1992 through 1996.
Still, women's health remains a fractious business. Even some of the most commonplace decisions women make -- yearly mammograms for 40-somethings? hormones for 50-somethings? -- are subject to wild disagreement.
Many women say that focusing on disease and treatment misses the point. "It's easier to prescribe a pill than to address the precarious economic status of women," said Dr. Judith G. Gonyea, a professor of social work at Boston University who specializes in women and aging. "People's health is about their housing, their nutrition, about feeling socially connected, which all may have a much greater bearing on their physical health status than their level of estrogen does."
In research, especially, the line between science and politics has been tested in the debate over whether women have been shortchanged.
"There's a perception that women and their diseases have been studied less than men," said Dr. Curtis L. Meinert, an epidemiology professor at the Johns Hopkins University who specializes in clinical trials. "That's so totally dead wrong it's painful."
When they surveyed research published from 1980 to 1993, Dr. Meinert and two colleagues, both of them women, found that the number of projects studying just men and the number studying just women were virtually equal.
In public research dollars spent, it does not seem that women have been slighted. In 1996, the last year for which figures are available, 16 percent of National Institutes of Health funds went to study diseases exclusive to women, 5.7 percent to diseases exclusive to men and 78.3 percent to diseases afflicting both. A decade ago, when the first breakdown by sex was calculated, the figures were 13.5 percent, 6.5 percent and 80 percent. And on a per-fatality basis, the National Cancer Institute spends much more on cancers that afflict only women than it does on prostate cancer.
Some researchers say age is more important than sex in determining where the money goes. Compare, for example, the hundreds of millions of dollars spent on breast cancer, which strikes many women in the prime of life, with the much smaller sum spent on prostate cancer, a disease of elderly men.
But Dr. Vivian Pinn, the director of the N.I.H. Office of Research on Women's Health, said: "Budget figures can fool you. You have to figure out where you have gaps in knowledge, and we know there are great gaps of knowledge in women's health."
The sharpest contention centers on introducing a form of affirmative action in clinical trials of new drugs and treatments for both men and women. Though the N.I.H. prodded researchers to include women in more clinical trials in the 1980's, the General Accounting Office reported in 1990 that the policy was often ignored. Then in 1993, Congress mandated the inclusion of women in most trials in numbers sufficient to analyze sex differences in the way a disease and its treatment play themselves out.
Many researchers resented the intrusion -- the phrases "research by quota" and "politically correct trials" were invoked -- and argued that in many trials, including enough women to yield reliable comparisons would be prohibitively expensive.
Cardiovascular disease raises especially perplexing questions. Because its incidence during middle age is so much higher in men, any clinical trial requires many more female than male subjects to assess risk factors and treatments for women -- and more still to analyze the differences between men and women.
That is why, researchers say, they have focused on men. But when women reach their 70's, their risk of cardiovascular disease rises sharply. Yet a lack of data makes it unclear whether they respond to preventive measures and treatments in the same way that men do.
Some epidemiologists, like Dr. Meinert, maintain that in terms of most diseases and treatments, women do not differ significantly from men, so including women in most clinical trials is unlikely to produce useful information. Others respond that this issue is, at the least, woefully underinvestigated.
Some women contend that sex differences are important and complicated enough to warrant a new specialty -- women's medicine -- analogous to pediatrics or geriatrics. "We're not talking about lady doctors delivering medical care to lady patients," said Dr. Eileen Hoffman, a co-director of the women's health program at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York. "We're talking about an art and science that's focused on the female."
"Female," in Dr. Hoffman's view, is a distinction that applies at every physiological level, down to the cellular, and should not be the province of obstetrics and gynecology alone. Besides, she added, "medicine only takes something seriously when it occupies an official space in the academic hierarchy."
Dr. Hoffman and other doctors and researchers have formed the American College of Women's Health Physicians, which is working toward recognition as a new specialty. But not without opposition. Many women argue that anything labeled "women's medicine" is unnecessary and, worse, bound to be marginalized.
"My response," Dr. Hoffman said, "is that women's health has already been marginalized by ob-gyn. Many women in this country only see a gynecologist for care. But lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in women, and heart disease kills 10 times more women than breast cancer."
To some, the notion that women have been underserved by American medicine is amazing. In a 1995 article in The Atlantic Monthly, Dr. Andrew G. Kadar, an anesthesiologist on the clinical faculty of the University of California at Los Angeles, wrote that if either sex needs better health care, it is the men.
"There is no question that women seek out medical attention more," Dr. Kadar said in an interview. "Whether they are less healthy is another issue and much more difficult to sort out, especially since there are diseases that keep you from feeling your best but don't shorten your life expectancy."
A better measure of health, he said, is mortality rates, reflected in the 7.5-year gap between men's and women's life spans. "You can't get any sicker than dead," he said.
But the trends in women's health care are likely to be determined more by market imperatives than by medicine or politics. "We made people aware of how health care works," Ms. Reverby said. "We couldn't control the economics of it." Neither, to their dismay, could doctors.
The march of managed care, most public health experts say, is good news and bad news for women.
"Women want respect; they want choices; they want preventive care," said Sally Rynne, a health care consultant in Evanston, Ill. "That's what women have clamored for." And the intent today, Ms. Rynne said, is to get people to take care of themselves because it is cost-effective.
"The other side of that," she said, "is, Are women going to be denied certain procedures or treatments that they feel they really need? That's the dance we're in right now."
Managed care also means that patients spend less time with doctors, though surveys consistently show that women prize such time. Health care providers have tried to address the problem by offering women's centers, which join specialists under one roof and use nurses and physicians' assistants to help coordinate medical care.
"Right now, it's a big marketing attempt," Dr. Hoffman said. "Let's be clear about that."
But the centers are hugely popular. "Women love them," said Dr. Carol Weisman, a professor and health services researcher in the Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health who has surveyed women's health centers nationwide.
Whether the clinics provide better care, Dr. Weisman said, is a separate question, and an all-but-unexamined one. It is not clear that any attempts to make medicine more responsive to women have brought measurable results. Regarding of whether the big push in research will lead to big advances in treatment, no answers are expected in this century.
Plenty of people are working on it, though. So far this year, Medline lists more than 80 articles under "women's health." There is no heading for "men's health."
