SECTION: Section 14; Page 4; Column 3; Women's Health

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: Patients View H.M.O.'s With Hope and Suspicion

BYLINE: By WENDY MARSTON; Wendy Marston is a contributing editor at Health magazine.

 BODY:
WHICH is your picture of managed care for women: free annual mammograms or "drive through" mastectomies?
Managed care is inevitable, a juggernaut that is quickly becoming the norm for how Americans get their health care -- 70 percent of people employed by companies with more than 200 workers use managed care. 
 How are women faring in this confusing new world? In interviews, doctors and experts in health economics discussed managed care with a mixture of optimism and suspicion.
The good news is that managed care in theory lends itself to preventive measures that are especially important to women, who on average visit a doctor 25 percent more often than men. The bad news is that the cost-cutting pressures behind the system's expansion have also led to the types of limits on hospital stays that produced Federal legislation on drive-through deliveries (enacted) and mastectomies (pending).
For the most part, they agree that the situation will improve to keep customers satisfied.
Recent studies have found that screening measures like Pap smears and mammograms and other tests are offered more consistently by health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, than by doctors seeing women in traditional fee-for-service settings.
But some observers are skeptical about how deep the managed care commitment to preventive care, especially in its more costly forms, really runs. "Yes, managed care does a little better on preventive health and contraception, but it needs to be more than just unlimited access to an ob-gyn," said Dr. Eileen Hoffman, the associate director for education at the Mount Sinai Women's Health Program in New York.
Dr. Hoffman is more excited about the prospect of what an H.M.O. can offer, and learn from, customers, a group that a plan can treat as an instant medical data base, showing what works and what does not.
She explained: "If we can use managed care to look at women as a defined population, like we look at people with diabetes, for example, then we can work backwards figuring out the best way to deliver appropriate care that's cost-effective."
Her optimism is echoed by Ewe Reinhardt, an economics professor at Princeton University. "Women are probably better off in managed care since the positives of having protocols outweigh the negatives they encounter," he said.
Professor Reinhardt added that the horror stories about H.M.O.'s, like tests or treatments being refused because an H.M.O. executive -- not the doctor -- thought they were too expensive, are problems that will be ironed out eventually. "At the moment, it's kind of the O.K. Corral, a real shoot-out," he said. "It's very fresh and raw and new to patients, and there are some H.M.O.'s that just shouldn't be there at all."
Dr. Sidney Wolfe, the director of the Public Citizens Health Research Group in Washington, has a bleaker perspective. "The current dominant model, of for-profit H.M.O.'s, is destroying the doctor-patient relationship," Dr. Wolfe said. He added, "Doctors in H.M.O.'s earn more money by not doing a test and not sending a patient to the hospital."
On the flip side, Margaret O'Kane, the president of the National Committee for Quality Assurance, which accredits H.M.O.'s, points out that managed care providers are better able to rein in overtreatments like high rates of hysterectomies and Caesarean sections, which women's health advocates have long complained about.
But Dr. Wolfe's criticisms are all the more pointed since surveys show that women, more than men, tend to have difficulty in the doctor-patient relationship.
The worries about managed care are leading to proposals for broad new regulations, including a bipartisan Senate bill to require coverage of contraceptives. The General Assembly in Connecticut recently passed a bill creating a state appeals process for decisions to deny care, and many other states, including New York, are pushing for similar legislation.
Meanwhile, patients might have to redefine the role they play in their care, said Sue Berkman, the author of "Surviving Your H.M.O.," to be published by Villard in the fall.
Ms. Berkman said she doesn't believe that today's doctor-patient relationship works as a partnership. "I'll tell you, when the plumber comes to fix the sink, I may hand him a wrench, but he isn't my partner," she said. "It's the same with my doctor. I want the best care, and that means I need to know what the system is so that I know how to operate within it."
And that new system may call for a more aggressive attitude, especially among women, she said.
In this new world of H.M.O.'s, she suggested that everything be written down. "So you may be sitting there practically naked on the examining table," she said, "but no one says you can't have a pad of paper and a pen."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 15; Column 1; Women's Health

LENGTH: 1622 words

HEADLINE: Is There a Doctor in the House? Whatever Kind You Need

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS

 BODY:
SURE, there are magazines in the waiting room of the Columbia-Presbyterian Center for Women's Health: Metropolitan Home, Vanity Fair and the like. But the patients would rather yak -- strangers turned friends as they exchange remedies for hot flashes, brittle bones, depression or obesity in what is fast becoming the medical version of the kaffeeklatsch, Tupperware party or consciousness-raising group of old.
It is a typical day at the three-year-old center in an Upper East Side high-rise, a stone's throw from Bloomingdale's. A woman in her late 40's is here to see the obesity specialist and nutritionist to find out whether she is a candidate for the hot new appetite suppressants, although she has a heart condition. A woman in her 50's is here to see the cardiologist, osteoporosis expert and endocrinologist as she considers the pros and cons of hormone-replacement therapy. And a woman near 70, who has broken more bones than Humpty Dumpty, is here for the results of her latest bone-density test and to celebrate the startling regeneration she has experienced with a new drug. 
 "If you go to one doctor uptown and one doctor downtown, nobody knows what anybody else is prescribing," said Jacqueline Simenauer, an author and literary agent from Upper Montclair, N.J., and a patient in the waiting room. "They're too busy to call each other. Or they don't know each other. Here, they all confer. It's a medical mall."
One-stop shopping is the catch phrase for centers like Columbia-Presbyterian's, which are popping up throughout the metropolitan region and in other major urban markets, inspired by the demographics of the baby boomers, the surging interest in women's health and the fierce competition among hospitals for new customers in a restructured health-care economy.
Women's health centers, in one form or another, have existed for nearly 200 years. In the 1800's, there were maternity hospitals; in the early 1900's, family planning clinics. The legalization of abortion in 1973 was the catalyst for the modern women's health movement, which spawned birth control, abortion and birthing centers.
Then, in the 1980's, came breast centers, inspired by an increase in diagnosed cases of breast cancer -- including those of prominent women who went public with their disease -- and the political forcefulness of patients who imitated those active in the fight against AIDS. The restructuring of the health-care industry in the 1990's led to off-site clinical and educational programs aimed at lucrative markets.
All these trends intersect in the gracious quarters of Columbia-Presbyterian's women's health center, on 60th Street near Madison Avenue in New York, where fresh orchids and peonies grace the waiting room and botanical prints and Impressionist reproductions adorn the walls.
The clients here, about 4,000 in all, fit a narrow, privileged profile similar to that of the doctors: predominantly middle-aged and upper-middle-class women, employed and insured, white and well educated. As they meet and mingle in the waiting room, this could be a Radcliffe reunion or a week at Canyon Ranch.
The center's director, Dr. Elsa Giardina, a professor and cardiologist, hopes to open a center at the hospital's campus in Washington Heights for poor women, most of them black and Hispanic. But she knows why the concept will catch on more easily here.
"You have to have a motivated population," Dr. Giardina said. "It's hard to talk about estrogen to somebody who's never heard of estrogen and is struggling to put rice and beans on the table."
The patients on East 60th Street, in a building that is also the headquarters for the Ralph Lauren empire, came of age reading the feminist health-care bible "Our Bodies, Ourselves" and demanding information, not a pat on the head by a condescending male doctor. When these women were in their 20's and 30's, their primary-care doctor was generally a gynecologist, but their needs have changed as they have moved into middle age and beyond.
There is the hormonal turbulence that precedes actual menopause. There is the conflicting advice about estrogen replacement and the terror of breast cancer that dissuades women from treatment for afflictions more likely to kill them, like heart disease and bone loss. There are the diseases that come with menopause or disproportionately afflict women, among them osteoporosis, Alzheimer's, depression, lupus and irritable bowel syndrome.
There are new findings about how women differ from men in their manifestations of heart disease and responses to treatments. There is the knowledge that women live longer than men and need to work toward a healthier dotage. And there are the stresses that collapse upon midlife women: careers, children, aging parents, empty nests.
The Columbia center and others like it put under one roof specialists who coordinate their expertise in these interconnected physical, social and emotional problems. The centers also create an environment more like a spa than a hospital. Proponents of the concept say the team approach and focus on prevention and behavioral changes is a model that will also benefit men. Critics say this is bald marketing to a prosperous population, the gatekeepers of their family's health care, who will not only enrich the hospital with their business but will refer their husbands and children as well.
The doctors and patients on East 60th Street see nothing wrong with doing well by doing good. "This is driven both by good medicine and consumer demand," said Eva Anderson, the center's administrative director and a former investment banker with a specialty in nonprofit health systems.
Dr. Ellen Silverstein, a Columbia radiologist, agreed, noting: "That's what medicine has become -- marketing. But it has to be good medical practice, or it won't work."
An example, Dr. Silverstein said, is the one-stop shopping. Here, a woman can have a checkup and a mammogram in the same visit. If the mammogram is irregular, she can have a sonogram on the spot. "Busy professional women don't have a week," she said. "They want to fit everything in today."
That Filofax mentality is what the center's "A Day in Your Life" program is all about. For $725, women under 40 can have a full battery of tests and procedures in one day. A package for women over 40 is $1,400. Both are advertised in a brochure not unlike the one at the Georgette Klinger salon, which does not embarrass Ms. Anderson in the least. "The Columbia-Presbyterian Day Spa!" she said. "Boutique health care amid the boutiques of Madison Avenue!"
But the bells and whistles -- support groups for midlife women, smoking cessation classes, a quarterly newsletter and tony luncheons with guest speakers -- are add-ons. The mission here is coordinated, comprehensive care delivered mostly by female providers, all of them researchers and clinicians in the growing subspecialty of women's health. They also train residents and sit on a university task force that will revise the medical school curriculum.
So a woman with irritable bowel syndrome has a gastroenterologist as her primary doctor, but will also see a psychologist and a nutritionist. If she has a family history of heart disease, a cardiologist will be part of the team. If she is slightly built and postmenopausal, a bone-density expert will assist. If she is considering hormone replacement, an endocrinologist weighs in.
Missing from the lineup, but to be added, Ms. Anderson said, are a psychopharmacologist, who can monitor the alchemy of antidepressants and hormones, and a neurologist who is an expert in Alzheimer's disease.
No matter which doctor a patient sees, the notes are recorded on a single chart so there is a free flow of information. But that approach is, at times, superfluous because the doctors gather at lunchtime in the conference room for sandwiches and informal consultations. They pop into each other's offices throughout the day to discuss patients. And they pass someone along on the spot if a different expertise is in order.
The patients generally applaud the coordinated approach. But what many say they seek are doctors who will collaborate, not dictate, an attitude they think is more common in women. Lenore Schmidt, a lecturer for Weight Watchers and a regular patient, told a typical tale of being turned off by a male doctor. A sharp chest pain sent her to the same cardiologist who had performed her husband's open-heart surgery. With her husband, he had been respectful and eager to explain. With her, he was barking orders and deflecting questions.
"He was this big and had a Napoleon complex," Ms. Schmidt said, her hand held at shoulder height. Now, she sees a female cardiologist at the center.
Patients also report a difference in the diagnostic tests that female doctors order. For example, among postmenopausal women, bone-density screening is routine. Sonograms are performed in tandem with mammograms for women with particularly dense breast tissue, where early evidence of cancer is often missed. Abdominal ultrasound is recommended for women whose mothers had ovarian cancer, a silent killer. And everyone is urged to undergo a flexible sigmoidoscopy, which tests for colon cancer and is commonly ordered for middle-aged men but not women, although they are just as likely to contract the disease.
Dr. Steven Heymsfield, the lone man on the staff and the obesity expert, once had doubts about the concept of serving all of a woman's medical needs under one roof. "When I started working here, I wondered why you needed a women's center," Dr. Heymsfield said. "Why not go to a regular doctor? But the synergy created here is greater than the sum of its parts."

HEADLINE: The Sunny Side Of the Cascades

BYLINE: By JOHN ROSENTHAL; JOHN ROSENTHAL is a travel writer based in New York.

 BODY:
IT never rains in Bend. Any Oregonian will tell you that. The clouds and drizzle that envelop Portland, Salem and Eugene leave a snowy topping on the Cascades, some of the best skiing mountains in the West, then magically evaporate, leaving nothing but glorious blue skies over the eastern two-thirds of the state.
In the many trips my family and I have made to Oregon, I can remember it raining just long enough to remind us that we were in the Pacific Northwest. And once we crossed the Cascade range, which separates the three biggest cities from the rest of the state, we usually found an embarrassment of sunshine. 
 Bend is about a three-hour drive from Portland; the fastest route is over Mount Hood on Route 26, through towns with names like Zigzag and Rhododendron. I had been to Bend more than a half-dozen times as a child on family vacations. When I returned in May last year to show my wife, Lisa, the area where I had spent so many happy summers, the weather was just as I had promised: sunny and 65 degrees, with clouds as scarce as tourists.
Mount Bachelor, which overlooks the area from more than 9,000 feet, had several lifts and runs still open a week before Memorial Day, with temperatures about 32 degrees at the base lodge and fresh snow. I was reminded of the year I skied there in early July. On this trip, though, we chose hiking and fishing along the Deschutes River.
The Deschutes runs north to south along the eastern edge of the Cascades, surrounded on both sides by the towering ponderosa pine trees of the Deschutes National Forest. The river is as placid as bath water in some stretches, but churns like a whirlpool in others, making it a prime route for white-water rafting.
The hiking trail we chose ran right along the river, like an escape route for white-water rafters who stumble into a class of rapids they're not sure they can handle. But as we walked among the volcanic rocks upstream from Lava Island Falls to Benham Falls, just south of Bend, none of the rafters we saw seemed daunted. One group navigated a particularly fearsome stretch of white water, picked up the raft, carried it back up the trail and went through it again, as though it were some kind of giant water slide. Another group -- a guide and several neophyte paddlers -- stopped after each set of rapids to discuss things they did right and wrong and to prepare for the next, more challenging cascades.
Chipmunks and chocolate labrador retrievers shared the trail with us, the former darting in front of us from one side of the narrow dirt path to the other, the latter barreling straight ahead in front of their owners and announcing the presence of an imminent mountain biker or two. Across the river, huge cinnamon-colored wastelands of solidified lava surrounded the area leading to Lava Butte, the 6,000-year-old cinder cone and crater that was the source of much of the volcanic rock in the area.
Steelhead and trout populate the Deschutes and many of the surrounding lakes and rivers, and fly-fishing is the angling method of choice here. We stopped to fish for a few hours at a quiet spot on the trail below Dillon Falls. We didn't catch anything, nor did we see any other anglers, allowing us to conclude that it was our timing, not our technique, that was to blame.
But the serenity was reward enough. In the middle of the river, the reflections of the 50-foot-high auburn lava piles that line one bank met and mingled with those of the rich brown and green 250-foot pine trees that border the other shore.
We returned to the house we had borrowed from a friend in Sunriver, a resort community 15 miles south of Bend where my family used to stay. Part hotel, part weekend-home destination and part planned community, Sunriver was originally a training camp for the Army during World War II, but was developed as a vacation resort in the 1960's. Its uncrowded golf courses, abundant tennis courts, snug stables and manicured lawns surrounding the well-maintained pool initially attracted people for vacations, and many decided to buy weekend homes there. About 1,500 live there year-round.
The accommodations at Sunriver range from hotel rooms in the main lodge to two-bedroom condominiums to five-bedroom houses. The wood-shingled houses and condominiums, gently curving roads and cul-de-sacs and the trim outdoor village mall are neat and hospitable. But what I remembered best about Sunriver from my youth were the 35 miles of paved bike paths that meandered from the houses to the meadows, the stables and the river.
Most parts of Sunriver are easier to reach by bike than by car, so we borrowed our friend's bikes (bike rentals are available in Sunriver and Bend) and headed for the river. The flat, well-maintained macadam path wandered through pine forest and lava fields, over bridges that crossed tiny creeks and through tunnels under roads to a meadow and the river.
As we sat in the meadow, the fish that had ignored our lines earlier in the day came out to feed on the hovering flies, while Canada geese honked furiously as they passed on their way north. When the crescent of sun hanging over Mount Bachelor finally dipped behind the mountain, the temperature plummeted, sending us back to our bikes.
On the third day, it snowed. Like most summer snowfalls, which are not unusual in Bend, this one melted by the time it touched the ground, since it was about 50 degrees. But we decided against the horseback riding we had planned.
INSTEAD, we stopped at the eight-acre Sunriver Nature Center, with its modern wood and glass building, on River Road, out toward the stables. The center is filled with displays and information about the local flora and fauna, including a thick book of blank pages entitled "Rattlesnakes of Sunriver" (one of the naturalists explains that Sunriver's compact rocks and soil make a poor habitat for snakes). While we were there, a volunteer brought in a 3-week-old great horned owl that had been separated from its mother. Jay Bowerman, the center's director emeritus, tried to introduce the orphan to one of the resident female owls, hoping that she would literally take it under her wing. He succeeded in getting the baby owl to eat from his own hand, but could not persuade the adult owl to take over the feeding chores.
Jay did persuade us to visit the High Desert Museum, on Highway 97 between Sunriver and Bend. Built in 1982, the museum is one of the best of its kind in the country. Its indoor exhibits of the region's geological and political history include well-executed dioramas of the Native Americans who lived here and the Europeans who joined and displaced them: fur traders, miners, cowboys and, finally, permanent settlers.
When the sun finally came out, so did the museum's resident river otters, Bert and Ernie, to watch the tourists who streamed down the path to the museum's exceptional outdoor exhibits. In addition to the otter pond, the 20 acres of outdoor attractions include a porcupine habitat, a marsh-bird viewing deck, an exhibit on the changing forest and log cabins, covered wagons and a transplanted saw mill.
We continued into Bend and explored its small but diverse downtown scene. Like many areas of rapid population growth (it now has 30,000 inhabitants, compared with 20,000 in 1990), Bend is plagued by a strip of chain restaurants, hotels and mini-malls along 10 miles of Route 97 (also known as Third Street), the main artery. But it shows vestiges of its small-town roots along Bond and Wall Streets. Big bank buildings anchor several corners, and though many of them are no longer occupied by banks, they have been preserved or restored and contain stores, law offices and other businesses.
Stores are a mix of the old Bend and the new. J. T. Miller's Gentlemen's Traditional Clothing, which now sells more golf wear than Stetsons and dusters, looks across the street to Birkenstock of Bend and several art galleries. Masterson St. Clair Hardware, a frontier-era general store, proclaims itself as the place to buy sporting goods, hardware and guns, while Tri Mountain Sports attracts those in need of rock climbing shoes and carabiners.
The Pine Tavern has been a Bend institution since 1919, famous for the ponderosa pine growing through the main dining room, while Toomie's, a Thai restaurant, and several brew pubs are more recent additions.
It was dark when we headed back to Sunriver, and once we had passed the lights of the strip, thick stands of pines on either side turned the highway into a country-dark corridor. We passed few cars in either direction, and even the deer we had come to expect near the roads seemed to be resting for the sunny day presaged by the stars above us.
 
To play along the river
 
Getting There
Bend is 160 miles from Portland, where there is an international airport. The Redmond-Bend airport, 16 miles north of Bend, is served by United Express and Alaska/Horizon Airlines, with several flights daily from Portland and San Francisco.
March and April are mud season in most resorts, but skiing in this high desert area often lasts through June. Mount Bachelor is one of the latest-closing ski areas in the country. Summer days are often hot, but usually free of humidity, and almost always followed by an evening cool enough to prompt the sparking up of the fireplace.
 
Things to Do
The Sunriver Nature Center, 17620 River Road, Sunriver, (541) 593-4394, is open daily 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is $2, $1 for those 12 and younger.
The High Desert Museum is three and a half miles south of Bend on Highway 97, (541) 382-4754 It is open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily; admission, $6.25, $5.75 for those 65 and older and 13 to 18, and $3 for 5 to 12.
Every summer, the Bend area is home to two festivals of mostly classical music. Except for a pops concert in Bend, the Sunriver Music Festival will be in Great Hall in Sunriver, Aug. 15 to 23; tickets are $7 to $35 from (541) 593-9310. The Cascade Festival of Music, which will include a blues night, is in Drake Park in downtown Bend, Aug. 23 to 30; tickets are $12 to $20 from (541) 382-8381.
 
Dining and Lodging
Though we mostly ate in our condo, Bend has a surprisingly large number of restaurants, from fancy French to brew pubs. One we ate in is Toomie's, 119 Northwest Minnesota Avenue, downtown, (541) 388-5590, a casual contemporary Thai restaurant, offering good food, especially of the spicy variety. Dinner entrees average about $10.
Sunriver Resort, a nearly 4,000-acre planned community 15 miles south of Bend, has a variety of accommodations from a standard lodge room with fireplace for less than $100 a night to houses or condominiums for $300 or more.
The resort has more than a dozen restaurants in all price categories, from sandwich and chowder shops to formal establishments. There are 2 supermarkets, 27 tennis courts, 3 18-hole golf courses, 2 pools, stables, 35 miles of paved bike paths and convention facilities. Many services, including canoe, bike and ski rentals, are available whether you stay at the resort or not. For reservations, call (800) 547-3922.
The Riverhouse, in the heart of Bend, and the Inn of the Seventh Mountain, seven miles from Bend on Century Drive, the access road to Mount Bachelor, are smaller resorts. The Riverhouse, with 220 beds, has rooms from $65 to $86 a night, double occupancy, and suites, most with kitchens, $81 to $110. It has two swimming pools and an 18-hole golf course. Phone: (800) 547-3928.
The Inn of the Seventh Mountain, (800) 452-6810, has 238 beds, and charges $59 and up for hotel rooms, $99 to $115 for a studio with kitchenette, and $129 to $299 for one-to-three-bedroom condos. The inn has two restaurants, and offers bike rentals, tennis and swimming.
Bend's central artery, Route 97, is also home to at least one outpost of most chain motels, including Econo Lodge, Hampton Inn, Shilo Inn and Red Lion Inn, as well as the Bend Riverside Motel II (800) 228-4019, an attractive locally run operation with 82 units from $49 to $106. J. R.

An article on June 22 about Bend, Ore., misstated the flow direction of the Deschutes River. A reader's letter received July 28 points out that it flows south to north.

HEADLINE: For Elegant Watch Hill, New Faces on the Scene

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH ABBOTT

DATELINE: WESTERLY, R.I.

 BODY:
FOR more than a century, the elegant seaside community of Watch Hill beckoned a select group of wealthy families, who traveled by steamer and train to their Victorian-style cottages from New York, Philadelphia, Cincinnati and other bases of industry.
Life in Watch Hill revolved around golf and tennis at the Misquamicut Club, bathing and yachting at the Watch Hill Yacht Club and tea and cocktails at Ocean House and Watch Hill's other grand hotels. 
 "It was a closed community," said Nancy Richmond, whose family has summered in Watch Hill for five generations.
Watch Hill was a place where everyone knew everyone, a somewhat staid and family-oriented community compared to glittering Newport, Rhode Island's other, more famous summer colony.
But times are changing. Even in Watch Hill.
After hanging onto their homes for decades, several Watch Hill families have decided in recent years to sell their "cottages" -- spacious homes that range in price from $250,000 to $3.5 million and often have 10 bedrooms or more. At the same time, a buoyant stock market has financed a new class of buyers, who find Watch Hill affordable compared with the Hamptons.
The result has been a vibrant Watch Hill real estate market in the last two years. Last summer, more than 20 of the 300 or so spacious houses sold. This year, the market is just as strong, said Claus Rossin of Buffum & Rossin Realty, an affiliate of Sotheby's that specializes in Watch Hill listings.
These new buyers are changing the fabric of life in Watch Hill.
"It has opened up Watch Hill to a whole new crowd of people," observed Ms. Richmond, who has been selling real estate in the area for more than a decade. This new crowd is more cosmopolitan than the families of old and less dependent on the private clubs for their social scene, she said.
Perched on Rhode Island's southernmost tip, Watch Hill is one of a string of summer colonies that line the state's South County shore. Others include Weekapaug, a community similar in style and price to Watch Hill; Shelter Harbor, Misquamicut and Quonochontaug. (Fans of the "X Files" television series know Quonochontaug as the summer home of Agent Mulder's mother.)
About 50 miles south of Providence, 13 miles across Block Island Sound from Block Island and about 140 miles from New York City, Watch Hill is one of several distinct neighborhoods in the larger town of Westerly, an old mill village on the banks of the Pawcatuck River. But it is unquestionably Westerly's most famous neighborhood, a picturesque enclave of winding, hilly streets with notable landmarks like the 1916 Olympia Tea Room, famous for its lobster salad rolls, and the 1880's Flying Horse outdoor carousel.
Then there's the Ocean House, one of the last of several Victorian-style hotels built in Watch Hill after the Civil War. A massive yellow building with a sweeping oceanfront veranda, the Ocean House conjures up another age, when women wore white gloves to tea and golf was a newfangled pastime.
Mr. Rossin called Watch Hill "a yachtsman's paradise, a quaint village with a beautiful harbor and beautiful beaches."
IN many respects, the Ocean House illustrates the changes wafting over Watch Hill. After owning the seven-story hotel for 60 years, earlier this year the April family decided to put it on the market. The asking price is $7.5 million.
Asked to explain her family's decision, Carol April said merely, "It is time."
But, in fact, the April family found themselves in the same position many Watch Hill residents did in the 1980's. After summering in Watch Hill for decades, and sometimes paying little attention to the maintenance of their cottages, these families woke up one day to find themselves in houses that were too big for them and which, while charming, required a lot of work.
This is what happened to Ms. Richmond. She inherited her grandmother's home on the bluffs in the 80's. At that time, it was just her and her son and the 10 or so bedrooms were "a bit much for the two of us," she said. So in 1987, Ms. Richmond sold the house for $1.8 million, becoming not only one of the first of the old guard to sell, but also one of the first sellers in Watch Hill to see a startling appreciation in property value.
"I was thinking maybe I could get $500,000 for it," Ms. Richmond.
When she got more than three times that, "My teeth nearly fell out," she said.
And so it began, the gradual change of ownership of an historic seaside colony.
Since 1960, Wayne Cottage has been in the family of Toby Beavers, a Manhattan nightclub owner. Built in 1898 by J. Stark Wayne, a tobacco plantation owner, it was the perfect place to spend summers as a boy, said Mr. Beavers.
"It was fabulous," said Mr. Beavers, who owned the now defunct Surf Club on the Upper East Side. But the Beaverses, like several other Watch Hill families, have decided it's time to sell the summer cottage.
MR. BEAVERS and his family share the house with a brother and his family. Since they rent it out in the summer to help pay the bills, they are not getting enough use of the house to make ownership worthwhile.
The nine-bedroom Wayne Cottage is now on the market with an asking price $995,000.
Mr. Rossin said that, because of its uniqueness, the Watch Hill market is "never really dead." But he and other agents conceded that after the boom of the 80's went bust at the end of the decade, there were a few very flat years in Watch Hill. Then the economy improved and the market came back.
"It's really hot," said Paul Klotz, a developer who is building a cluster subdivision, New Bottom Pond, on 120 acres in Avondale, a neighborhood bordering Watch Hill. Two years ago, he said, there were more than 30 properties for sale in Watch Hill. Now they are almost all sold, he added.
The new buyers are different from the old owners in that many of them are winterizing their homes with plans to use them not only in the summertime, but also on weekends throughout the year, Mr. Rossin and other agents said. Although some people find Watch Hill isolated in the wintertime, others find the quiet peaceful.
"It's a big beautiful world that's all yours," said Mr. Klotz, who has lived year-round in Avondale for 29 years.
The broader community of Westerly is, itself, beginning to see some change. Insulated and moribund since the late 1940's, when the town's historic downtown lost much of its life to the suburbs, Westerly has recently shown more signs of life.
In the last year, a group of developers transformed the landmark old McCormick's department store into a mixed use residential/retail complex. Westerly's historic Spanish-style Amtrak station on the edge of the downtown is to get a $1.5 million restoration. And thanks to downtown Westerly's proximity to Foxwoods Resort Casino, which is only 10 miles away, the town's apartment market has rebounded.
"Before Foxwoods opened [in 1992], the rental market was about 50 percent vacant and now it's full," Mr. Klotz said.
The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe owns Foxwoods, one of the world's largest and most profitable casinos. Although some people in Westerly and southeastern Connecticut are wary, if not critical, of the tribe's growing economic clout in the region, Mr. Klotz is not among them.
"They got money circulating in the region again and we had no money circulating," he said, referring to the fact that the area was hit both by the recession and cutbacks in the nation's military budget.
But here the noise and glitz of the casino seem a million miles away. Which is, of course, one of the reasons a new set of buyers are flocking to this seaside community.
"A lot of new blood is coming into Watch Hill," said Ms. Richmond. "I think it's healthy."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Tinted Windows

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Sure, America's G-7 allies were grumbling a bit in Denver over what they considered excessive bragging by President Clinton about how "America's economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world." But I say let him brag a little. The fact is he deserves credit for a five-year program of deficit reduction and trade expansion that has lowered inflation and interest rates -- without a recession -- and left enough steam in the economy to finance America's transformation into a much more efficient global competitor.
America's economic strength today is real. The U.S. now excels in making everything that is light. That is critical because the more knowledge and information technology designed into a product, the less it tends to weigh, and the more it tends to sell for. As Alan Greenspan recently noted, there is less weight today in each dollar of U.S. G.D.P. than ever before: vacuum tubes are replaced by tiny transistors, heavy fabrics by feather-light ones and your 150-pound receptionist by a voice mail device. And whether it is software design, Internet marketing, banking, insurance, consulting, fast-food catering, higher education, package delivery, entertainment, media, computer chips or potato chips, the U.S. today is good at all the light stuff. 
 The only bad news is that at precisely such a moment of unprecedented prosperity, we should be addressing the very real problems still holding our economy back -- and we're not.
For instance, I'd feel better about America's economy if I knew we were prospering as one country, not as two. One way I'll know that is when my 11-year-old daughter, who goes to public school in Maryland, stops coming home sad because another one of her friends just quit the public school to go to private school. If I've learned anything traveling the world it's this: Never trust a country where the rich live behind high walls and tinted windows. That is a place that is not prospering as one country. That is a place where the rich not only say, "I don't want you to see how I live," but "I don't want to see how you live."
Without the cold war, the space program, the civil rights movement or army service to unite us, it's easy for this widening rich-poor gap to become institutionalized. This is particularly true when so many of the wealthy are dropping out of the last great homogenizing institution in America -- the public schools, even the best public schools. In the Cabinet of the recently defeated British Conservative Prime Minister, John Major, not a single minister had his children in the British public school system. The Clinton Administration can't be far behind that. President Clinton did propose $5 billion in seed money to repair and upgrade decrepit public schools, but Republicans cut it to zero. That is a travesty.
I'd feel better about America's economy if there were less tax cutting at this moment of prosperity and some serious reform of Medicare and Social Security. Without it, the deficit is sure to explode again when all the baby boomers start to retire. The longer you wait to do entitlement reform, the greater the pain.
I'd feel better about America's economy if this latest budget did a little more for young people and a little less for older ones. If we're going to take that lower slice of the population that is not ready for the information economy and give them skills to become tax payers instead of tax drainers, we need to invest more in the ages of birth to 5. If we can cut $85 billion in taxes over five years, we can spend a little more making sure every child has a minimum of Head Start, health care, nutrition and educational opportunities.
I'd feel better about America's economy if we weren't doing so many of our improvements with other people's money. We are still borrowing tens of billions each year from the rest of the world to finance our deficit. China alone holds $52 billion in U.S. T-bills, and Japan holds $291 billion. I'd feel a lot better if I didn't know that Japan had a savings rate of 31 percent of G.D.P. and an investment rate of 28 percent, while we have savings rate of 17 percent and an investment rate of 16 percent. Surely, it can't be good if they are planting the seeds for the future at double the rate we are.
In short, I'd feel a lot better about America's economy if there were just a little less "Today, for Me" in the new budget and a little more "Tomorrow, for Us."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Mexican Leaders Honor a Union Giant, and an Era

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 22

 BODY:
Government officials and labor leaders turned out today to pay their last respects to Fidel Velazquez Sanchez, the 97-year-old labor patriarch whose death on Saturday marked the end of six decades of unbending top-down control of the Mexican union movement.
But notably absent from the ceremonies was any outpouring of grief from rank-and-file workers. Local unions from around the country sent huge wreaths of white marigolds and scarlet roses. But the streets outside the Mexican Workers' Confederation, the scene of many labor demonstrations over the years, were empty except for the parked luxury cars of Government and labor officials. 
 President Ernesto Zedillo rendered his homage standing beside Mr. Velazquez's mahogany coffin during a wake in the atrium of the headquarters of the labor confederation. Mr. Velazquez ran the confederation for most of the last 60 years.
"He always encouraged negotiation, not confrontation," Mr. Zedillo said. "He always worked for stability, not uncertainty."
Inside, after President Zedillo's speech a few workers started to shout "Fidel! Fidel!" But their voices sounded thin as they echoed up toward the skylight, and the shouting quickly subsided.
Government officials were ready to show their gratitude to Don Fidel, as he was known in Mexico, after he used his grip on the mainstream labor movement to help them impose a harsh belt-tightening program on Mexican workers that has begun to pull the country out of a steep recession that began in 1994.
But dissident labor leaders and opposition politicians immediately criticized the legacy of low wages that Mr. Velazquez has left and predicted that his death would unleash a power struggle to produce a more decentralized and aggressive labor movement, and to break the decades-old bonds between the unions and the Government.
"The old labor system is passing away," said Kevin Middlebrook, an expert on Mexican labor at the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies in San Diego. "It is quite likely that no one can maintain the unity and discipline Fidel Velazquez achieved. That was his historic contribution."
Leaders of the labor confederation were shaken by the death of their leader, even though it was long expected, and moved to postpone the succession battle within their ranks.
Based on a pecking order established in the confederation's statutes, 78-year-old Leonardo Rodriguez Alcaine, the head of the electrician's union, will act as secretary general until a national assembly meets next February. Mr. Rodriguez got the interim job because he is the only one of the highest leaders of the confederation who is in good health.
But already there are murmurings among mid-level officials that the mainstream labor movement needs a younger leader who will be less identified with years of unquestioned support for Government policies.
As a sign of the confederation's lack of credibility with the public, the announcement of Mr. Velazquez's death Saturday morning prompted a storm of rumors that he had in fact died a day earlier, but that the Government delayed the announcement to allow for secret succession negotiations.
Mr. Velazquez's personal physician, Dr. Salomon Jasqui, later made another announcement confirming the date and time of death.
After Mr. Velazquez was first elected to head the labor group in 1941, he pioneered a system in which workers collaborated with the Government in exchange for privileged treatment from public institutions like the national petroleum company and the social security system.
But this pact was practically destroyed by the grinding economic crisis of the last two years. The buying power of the average Mexican worker today is less than it was in 1980.
In the last two months President Zedillo has been booed and taunted twice at labor gatherings, shows of disrespect that would have been unthinkable before the crisis.
"What Fidel Velazquez left workers was constantly declining living standards," said Agustin Rodriguez Fuentes, the head of a dissident labor coalition. "His death means that we can begin to rehabilitate the labor movement."
Mr. Velazquez's death is expected to cost Mr. Zedillo's political party, which has ruled Mexico for nearly 70 years, votes among workers in national legislative and local elections on July 6.
Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leftist candidate for Mayor of Mexico City, who polls indicate will be elected, said he lamented Mr. Velazquez's death as he would "that of any person," but he called him "the leader of a labor movement based on corruption and patronage."
Mr. Rodriguez, the interim head of the confederation, reacted by banning Mr. Cardenas from the wake. Analysts said that Mr. Cardenas, who has been fiercely critical of President Zedillo's economic policies, could attract many unions to his side if he gains control of the huge capital city.
Workers will almost certainly become more combative in their demands for wage increases now. But Government officials were quick to stress that a more vociferous labor movement is not likely to destabilize the country.
"Mexico is a country of institutions," said Manuel Bartlett, the influential Governor of the state of Puebla. "The passing of a great man does not mean the passing of stability."
A second wake for Mr. Velazquez was held today in the Mexican Senate, where he served two terms. His body was cremated and was to be buried tonight in a private ceremony at a cemetery in a prosperous neighborhood of Mexico City.

HEADLINE: Subsidies Hurt Environment, Critics Say Before Talks

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 20

 BODY:
As world leaders converge here starting on Monday to take stock of the global environment five years after the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, a growing number of experts say that government subsidies to industries not only squander money that could be spent cleaning up the Earth, but but also actually damage it.
Subsidies for energy suppliers, water services, road building, agriculture and fisheries and other activities often have side effects that cost from $500 billion to $900 billion in environmental damage, according to a surprisingly varied group of experts -- from the left and right, industrial countries and the third world. 
 Such payments can make some commodities too cheap, leading to profligacy, experts say. Other goods and services become artificially more expensive, in effect taxing consumers while bolstering inefficient industries that squander natural resources.
Thus, farmers in Asia, enjoying inexpensive water, electricity and fertilizer, are tempted to overirrigate and chemically pollute fields and streams. In the United States, automobile manufacturers build bigger, more gas-guzzling cars, and harmful emissions rise and public transportation atrophies. In Germany, according to one estimate, it costs the Government more than $70,000 a year to keep each coal miner at work extracting an uneconomical fuel that dirties the atmosphere.
"There's something unbelievable about the world spending hundreds of billions of dollars annually to subsidize its own destruction," says a new report from the independent Earth Council, based in Costa Rica, and the Institute for Research on Public Expenditure in the Netherlands. The report, "Subsidizing Unsustainable Development: Undermining the Earth with Public Funds," recommends re-examining all subsidies to sift out those that are damaging from those that still serve a social or economic purpose.
Subsidies do not appear to be on any nation's priority list for the summit meeting, known as Rio Plus 5. President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore are expected to attend, among leaders from more than 60 countries. The President is scheduled to speak on Thursday. American officials list as top issues the debates over global warming and how best to protect the world's forests. Many poor nations want to confront the richer nations with demands for more money and technology transfers, which they say they need to bring environmental protection up to date.
The issue of subsidies is a difficult one for any leader to tackle, even though it knows no ideological or national boundaries and is not related to levels of development. Governments of the left and right, in rich industrial nations and the poorer third world, use subsidies to win votes or mute dissent and they have become difficult to abolish.
"Many of these subsidies are kept in place through political pressure, campaign donations or even bribery," said Worldwatch Institute in Washington in a report, "Paying the Piper: Subsidies, Politics and the Environment."
The author of that report, David Malin Roodman, concluded that "more than $500 billion a year of consumers' and taxpayers' money is spent by governments to subsidize deforestation, overfishing and other environmentally destructive activities." Subsidies for fishing fleets have produced enough fishery boats and equipment to catch twice the available fish in the world's seas, Mr. Roodman said.
In India, a recent study for Finance Minister Palaniappan Chidambaram found that the national and state governments together were spending about $40 billion, or 14.4 percent of the country's gross domestic product, on subsidies. More than $5 billion of that goes to support prices for petroleum products, with agriculture subsidies close behind. Less than 4 percent of India's economy goes toward education.
The assault on subsidies is particularly noteworthy in the third world, where grass-roots groups are resisting years of demands by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund that such supports be eliminated or reduced. The local groups say that cutting subsidies hurts the poor, especially women and children.
The Indian Government and others in the third world now question those assumptions. Mr. Chidambaram's study, based on research by the National Institute of Public Finance and Policy in New Delhi, found that the rich, not the poor, more often benefited from subsidies, because the rich were in a position to buy and use subsidized commodities and services. Inexpensive electricity does not help the poorest, unelectrified villages, or the farmer unable to afford a subsidized bag of high-yield fertilizer.
"The poor generally don't benefit from subsidies as much as the middle class," said Anders Wijkman, director of the bureau for policy and program support at the United Nations Development Program, which recently published a report, "Energy After Rio." That report says that subsidies to conventional energy sources like coal, oil and nuclear power are "a significant impediment to sustainable energy futures."
"They make it more difficult for new, sustainable energy technologies to enter the market, while simultaneously reducing the economic efficiency and creating fiscal burdens for the government," the report said. "Energy price subsidies are often an ineffective and inefficient way of helping those living in poverty."
In Tanzania, the report noted, kerosene subsidies were found to be helping mostly the wealthier households that buy the bulk of the fuel.
At the Cato Institute in Washington, Jerry Taylor, director of natural resources studies, characterized many subsidies as "socialist" measures, and argued that the environment would be better left in the hands of an "unfettered" private sector, not dependent on Federal aid.
In an interview, Mr. Taylor said that subsidies to agriculture in rich and poor countries had contributed to excessive use of pesticides, fungicides and herbicides. Import quotas and price supports protecting the American sugar industry have raised sugar prices and led to destruction of parts of the Everglades, an example cited by American environmentalists.
In a speech earlier this year to the Environmental Grantmakers Association in Washington, Mr. Taylor said: "It makes no sense for the Federal Government to subsidize environmental destruction on one hand, while establishing laws, regulations and vast bureaucracies to mitigate it on the other."

HEADLINE: Jacor a Rising Star Among Radio Networks

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
In just over 18 months, Jacor Communications Inc. has gone from being a bit player in the radio business to one of its rising stars.
Thanks to deregulation and a Wall Street-financed buying binge, the company is now the nation's third-largest radio station group, as well as the third-largest radio network, featuring programs like Rush Limbaugh's conservative talk show. 
 Jacor is not the household name that Mr. Limbaugh is. But in more and more small and midsize cities, as well as in Los Angeles, the company's presence is growing. Starting with 26 stations in 1995, Jacor now owns 149 stations in 32 markets.
It trails the CBS Radio Network and the ABC Radio Network in advertising revenue. Moreover, in terms of overall radio revenue and station ownership, it has already eclipsed ABC and is closing in on CBS and the Chancellor Media Corporation, a big broadcasting group that produces little programming.
The company can take a decidedly hands-on approach. For example, during a Sunday drive near Jacor's suburban Cincinnati headquarters in Covington, Ky., Randy Michaels, the president and chief executive, was annoyed at the broadcast fidelity when tuning in WLAP-AM in Lexington. "I thought it sounded lousy," he said. So Mr. Michaels showed up at the station. "I'm the new engineer," Mr. Michaels assured the host of the station's horse-racing show while tuning the 5,000-watt transmitter. Now, Mr. Michaels said with satisfaction, "it sounds a lot better."
Since the industry's deregulation by the Federal Communications Commission in January 1996, more than 2,100 stations have changed hands in deals worth $15 billion. Jacor alone spent $1.6 billion on stations financed by a combination of debt and equity, more than any other company, according to Broadcasting and Cable magazine.
While the company entered a top market in acquiring KIIS AM and FM in Los Angeles, Jacor is an industry contrarian: its strengths are in secondary markets and AM formats.
But Mr. Michaels, 45, did not stop with stations. In an effort to control even more commercial broadcast time, this spring Jacor spent a combined $246 million to make itself into a network power by acquiring Mr. Limbaugh's syndicator, EFM Media Management Inc.; Premiere Radio Networks Inc. and NSN Network Services, which builds two-way data and audio transmission pipelines.
"Our business is so trivially simple," Mr. Michaels said. "It's all a matter of product. We believe in original programming that's mass appeal but difficult to duplicate."
Loosely adapting the airline industry's hub-and-spoke system, Jacor's post-deregulation strategy is to develop radio programs with regional appeal that can be syndicated and sold to stations in contiguous markets near a metropolitan area. Such a strategy allows it to spread programming costs across several stations and to sell advertising that is comparable in total audience size to a local newspaper or television station but typically at lower cost. Rules that limited station ownership had previously precluded such an approach, so it remains legally untested.
"It's a brilliant strategy that takes advantage of what the telecom bill allowed us to do," said Bill Clark, former chief executive of Shamrock Broadcasting. "It's a farm system for talent and a delivery system for syndicated programs."
Such a strategy also has its risks. In Cincinnati, the company's dominance led to the industry's most visible antitrust investigation by the Federal Trade Commission. Jacor was forced to sell WKRQ-FM and to abandon financing support for WGRR-FM.
The regional emphasis aims to amass the bigger audiences that advertisers prefer to a single station's listeners. It may allow Mr. Michaels to achieve what has become the holy grail of radio executives: pushing radio's share of total advertising dollars beyond 7 percent. That percentage amounted to $11.3 billion in revenue last year.
Since doubling its Cincinnati presence by acquiring its broadcast rival Citicasters Inc. in September, Jacor's seven Cincinnati-area radio stations and its No. 1-rated television station, the ABC affiliate WKRC, are heard or seen by 1.2 million people. By comparison, the leading newspaper, The Cincinnati Enquirer, has a daily circulation of about 202,000. Mr. Michaels contends that Jacor's heft has helped its radio stations snag $1 million in job-recruitment advertising, which had been the exclusive province of The Enquirer, a Gannett Company newspaper.
David J. Hunke, executive vice president of The Enquirer and The Cincinnati Post, a Scripps Howard paper -- the two have a joint operating agreement -- questioned such assertions, suggesting that a rising tide was lifting all boats. "Everybody has shown very strong growth," he said.
In addition to Cincinnati, Jacor plans to develop regional programming around Tampa, Fla.; Denver; Cleveland; Columbus, Ohio, and Los Angeles. Mr. Michaels recently told analysts that he expected this strategy to produce annual investment returns of 20 percent or more.
In Southern California, Jacor's foundation is an all-sports station modeled on the nation's No. 1 revenue producer, WFAN-AM in New York, which is owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the parent of CBS Radio. Jacor won radio broadcast rights for the Los Angeles Dodgers for KIIS-AM, beginning in 1998. Sports talk shows could be syndicated to stations in Santa Barbara, Palm Springs and Ventura, Calif.
Jacor's programming push means that both its cash flow margin and price-earnings multiple are typically lower than its competitors. "It's expensive bidding for sports rights," said Frank Bodenchak, a Morgan Stanley analyst. He thinks Jacor's strategy has merit, anyway, adding, "You can increase revenue over a longer leg of growth than the cost cutters."
Others on Wall Street have shown enthusiasm for Jacor. Its stock closed on Nasdaq Friday at $37 a share, compared with a 52-week low in December of $23.75.
Mr. Michaels' affinity for technology and content comes out of his experience as a chief engineer and programmer. He started his own station group in 1983, which later merged with Jacor. Debt and recession in the early 1990's forced Jacor to revamp with capital from the Zell/ Chilmark Fund of Chicago, which specializes in bailing out troubled businesses. Samuel Zell, Jacor's chairman, and his fund are Jacor's largest shareholders at 33 percent.
Jacor had $223 million in revenue and $5.1 million in profit last year. For the first quarter of this year, however, the company registered a loss of $8.1 million on revenue of $100 million, mainly because of higher interest expenses.
Much of Jacor's profit comes from AM stations, which over the last two decades have lost considerable ground to their FM rivals. "Competitors have abandoned programming attempts on the AM dial," Mr. Michaels said, because cash-flow margins for FM stations have been so rich, averaging 40 percent.
Most AM stations and small-market stations broadcast, simulcast or network programs in exchange for giving up commercial time. The high ratings generated by a syndicated personality -- and higher advertising revenue that go with it -- demonstrate to group owners that radio can be successful without local content, according to Ted Bolton, a radio research consultant in Philadelphia. "The national talent in a small market comes in and makes the local guys look ridiculous," he said.
Listeners now hear satellite-delivered programs with play lists and slogans as formulaic as a Big Mac. "Radio is so generic; local doesn't mean anything anymore," said Lee Abrams, a Dallas programming consultant. As a result, he thinks Jacor's plan to syndicate local programming with network polish has a good chance of success.
And Nicholas J. Verbitsky, president of United Stations Radio Networks Inc., a programming syndicator, adds: 'I think their strategy is flawless. They are breaking some new ground."

HEADLINE: To Growers, Deal Brings Uncertainty And Anger

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER

DATELINE: LUCAMA, N.C., June 21

 BODY:
The tobacco farmer lunged forward, his face red with anger at the latest provocation from Washington.
"Don't get me wrong," said Billy Bass, a gold tobacco leaf swinging from its chain around his neck. "Tobacco is bad. I wouldn't tell it any other way. But as long as it's legal, I'll grow it." 
 The tobacco farmers here have long felt scorned by outsiders. Each development in the anti-smoking wars is another blow, and in the wake of the wide-ranging settlement announced in Washington on Friday, the haze of freshly hurt pride was as palpable here in eastern North Carolina as the new summer's heat.
The deal left tobacco farmers here in Wilson County, the heart of eastern North Carolina's tobacco country, feeling like agriculture's pariahs. They do not know if the deal will mean fewer cigarette buyers, less money for their crop or even eventual ruin for themselves, but none of the half-dozen farmers interviewed today suggested quitting.
"It hurts my feelings, if you want to know the truth," said Donnie Boyette, who farms 113 acres near here.
The farmers' houses are surrounded by the plants, already robust and dark green. Their ancestors grew tobacco -- Mr. Bass said his family had grown tobacco on the same land since 1741. But they are ambivalent about this lucrative crop.
Most of the farmers volunteered that they did not smoke, did not want their children to smoke and did not want any teen-agers to smoke.
But they also insisted, vehemently, that they are good, hard-working citizens. In America's tobacco wars, they said, they are at least blameless. In their view, the crop is legal, so if there are ill effects from it, they are not responsible.
"Tobacco farmers are good people," said Thad P. Sharp Jr., 10 miles up Highway 581 in the hamlet of Sims. "They'd give you the shirt off their back if you had chill bumps."
"We don't need the abuse that Mike Moore imposes on us," Mr. Sharp said, referring to the Attorney General of Mississippi, Michael Moore, who has led the anti-tobacco fight.
"We're the people that's the salt of the earth, that's paying the taxes," said Mr. Sharp, whose 200 acres of tobacco provides 70 percent of his net profit, though he also grows soybeans, corn and tomatoes.
He was sitting in an air-conditioned office, saying he was grateful that tobacco had brought him all the way there from a Depression-era boyhood.
"I'm just as good a citizen as I was yesterday," Mr. Sharp said. "I have no problem with my conscience."
The officials' televised jubilation on Friday angered him. "It looked like a community soccer team, kids' stuff, running around slapping each other's hands," he said.
 The $368.5 billion deal notwithstanding, the short-term outlook for these farmers is not all gloomy, said Blake Brown, an agricultural economist.
They are producing more tobacco than 10 years ago, and the huge export market is helping to make up for drastic declines in domestic consumption, said Mr. Brown, who works at North Carolina State University. About 40 percent of flue-cured tobacco, the kind produced here, is exported. Still, Mr. Brown said, the farmers are earning less than in the 1970's, as is North Carolina as a whole. Tobacco was 46 percent of the state's farm income in 1964, but only 15 percent 30 years later.
The settlement evidently would not affect the Federal Government's subsidies for tobacco farming, which are relatively small anyway. Direct subsidies ended in the 1980's. Now the subsidies amount to a quota system in which the Government licenses the right to grow tobacco and has a Federal program to insure farmers against crop losses. The Department of Agriculture has budgeted $145 million for the insurance in the coming fiscal year; in years with no significant losses, it contributes little or nothing to the insurance pool.
Andrew J. Fisher, a spokesman for Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Senate's Committee on Agriculture, said today that the negotiators had not focused on Federal assistance for growers.
"Federal involvement is so minuscule that it wasn't seen as a major issue," Mr. Fisher said.
To the tobacco farmers, there is something unpatriotic about the tobacco deal.
Why, they ask, should the tobacco companies, and perhaps they, too, have to pay for something so fundamentally American as the exercise of free choice -- the decision to buy a pack of cigarettes?
"I think it's legalized extortion, but that's neither here nor there," Mr. Boyette said. "You've got a U.S. company marketing a legal product to a public that can buy or not buy it. You, as a free American, choose the pack of cigarettes -- that was your choice. Now, we've got to pay for your sickness?"
Mr. Bass said: "If I was growing marijuana out here, I could understand this. Tobacco put this country on its feet, used to have a lot of support. Now everybody's sold it out."
Mr. Boyette said: "It's become a whipping boy. You just get tired of it. Every day there's something. My grandfather worried about it, my father worried about it, and now I am. Will there ever be any end?"

HEADLINE: Effects of Pact's Costs on Industry and Smokers Are Unclear

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
For years, the tobacco industry and its critics have disagreed, in public at least, about why people smoke. Are they heavily swayed by marketing promotions and advertising? By where smoking is allowed? By the relatively low cost of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco in the United States, compared with other wealthy countries?
These and other questions of consumer behavior would be put to their most sweeping test ever, with smokers as guinea pigs, if Congress approves the settlement creating a new legal and regulatory framework for the $45 billion industry. 
 Many smokers feel trapped. "I'm hoping it would make me quit, but I doubt if it will," said Penny Calabrese, a school secretary and two-pack-a-day smoker from Carol Stream, Ill.
The settlement assumes that the tobacco companies will pass on most of the costs of the settlement to customers, but the 68-page agreement has little to say about how and when that will happen.
Analysts speculate that the industry would try to quickly raise prices by 50 cents to $1 a pack. The cost to someone who smokes a carton a week could be $400 to $500 a year.
There is nothing in the agreement, though, to insure that the pricing field stays level within the industry. Philip Morris gets two-thirds of its profits from overseas sales and enjoys the largest profit margins because of its size. Its financial strength would also allow it to borrow money to pay the initial costs of the settlement at lower interest rates.
Such advantages give Philip Morris more leeway than its rivals to delay price increases in the hope of keeping customers and attracting new ones. At one point in the negotiations, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco and other worried Philip Morris competitors discussed seeking a provision in the settlement that would, in effect, guarantee that all price increases would be simultaneous and across-the-board, but that approach raised serious antitrust issues and was dropped.
One way the companies may try to cope with the settlement is to encourage the trend toward stores selling only tobacco products, where high volume allows bargain prices. The companies may also quickly begin to phase out marginal brands.
It is possible though that some brands would be stripped of their premium image and sold at lower prices. And analysts say the limited black market in cigarettes could expand if prices rise enough.
In short, the financial impact of the settlement on individual smokers could vary widely depending on the brands they smoke and how they buy them.
"My husband travels out of state each week and I'll be more likely to have him buy cartons for me where it's cheaper," said Deborah Herdon of Belleville, Mich., a state where high taxes have pushed the cost of premium cigarettes to $2.50 a pack.
Regardless of what happens with prices, the settlement guarantees that smokers and nonsmokers alike would no longer be bombarded with familiar images that appeal to young people, like Joe Camel and the Marlboro Man. Tobacco sponsorship would disappear completely from some popular family venues, like sporting events.
Analysts assume that much of the $6 billion a year spent on marketing would be diverted to help pay for the settlement, at least initially. But substantial sums are sure to be redeployed to expand marketing programs that would still be legal and to invent new ones.
On the other hand, consumers would also be confronted with the impact of several billion dollars more being funneled into anti-smoking advertising and smoking-cessation programs.
Health advocates hope the broader bans on smoking in workplaces called for in the settlement would make smoking so inconvenient that more adults would be encouraged to quit. Under the settlement, most restaurants could continue to offer smoking sections, but fast-food restaurants would have to follow the example of industry leaders like McDonald's that have banned smoking.
Historically, the most effective way to reduce youth smoking has been to increase prices. Based on experience with price increases, analysts have projected that the number of legal smokers would fall anywhere from 10 percent to 30 percent and that the heaviest smokers would at least reduce the number of cigarettes they smoke or be more inclined to switch to cheaper brands.
But the greatest declines would be expected among teen-age smokers, who have less disposable income to pay for price increases. Researchers say teen-agers' smoking rates have dropped more than adult rates in response to past price increases in part because some teen-agers have been discouraged from beginning to smoke. Another factor is that teen-agers are image conscious -- they are much more likely than adults to smoke heavily advertised brands like Marlboro and Camel -- and, as a result, more likely than adults to quit or cut back rather than switch to budget brands when prices jump.
The catch is that much of that experience with both teen-age and adult behavior is based on more modest price jumps in the wake of new taxes, a situation in which the blame could be placed entirely on politicians and the industry's adversaries. And smokers have never been asked to swallow such a large price increase while such a sweeping effort is being made to undermine tobacco's appeal.

HEADLINE: Rocky Mountain Cram Session

 BODY:
President Clinton and the leaders of Russia, Japan and Western Europe emerged from their marathon meetings in Denver over the weekend like tired college students who had endured a grueling round of final exams. Their joint declarations covered such a bewildering array of subjects, from Bosnia to global warming to trade barriers, that it was hard to imagine that they did justice to any of them. The blurred focus obscured a couple of significant accomplishments, however. One was the further integration of Russia's President, Boris Yeltsin, into the West's concerns, and the other was a new economic agenda for the world's richest countries.
As host of the Denver summit, Mr. Clinton rankled feelings among some colleagues, especially Japan, by insisting that Mr. Yeltsin become a nearly full-fledged member of the exclusive club of nations known as the Group of Seven. In financial terms, Russia is clearly not in the same league as the other G-7 countries that have met annually since 1975 to discuss economic problems. But since the collapse of Communism, Russia has crept its way in. For the United States, inviting Russia this past weekend was a crucial payback for Russia's reluctant acceptance of NATO expansion, to be formalized in Madrid next month. 
 In return, Mr. Yeltsin gave welcome new promises to speed economic reform at home. Russia agreed just before the summit to write off most of its Soviet-era debt, and in Denver Mr. Yeltsin promised to push hard for improved tax collection, a step that economists consider crucial to restoring Russian solvency. American officials were impressed that Russia had floated its first 10-year bond issue since 1913. But it was far from clear that Russia will make sufficient progress toward a legal system and open markets to meet the criteria for joining the World Trade Organization next year.
A year ago Mr. Yeltsin was a physically ravaged man, struggling to survive politically and unable to attend the economic summit meeting in Lyons, France. This past weekend he seemed more fit than in years. He joined with his summit colleagues to call for the reconstruction of Bosnia and went along with a renewed threat of sanctions against Iraq. But there were disquieting signs that Mr. Yeltsin remains on the defensive at home because of the United States' ill-considered drive for NATO expansion. Russian officials offered little assurance, for example, that they would win parliamentary approval of the Start 2 nuclear arms treaty in the Russian Parliament any time soon.
Although Mr. Yeltsin's presence overshadowed the other work of the summit, the conferees nudged a few economic issues forward and papered over their differences in several areas. Europe continues to complain about lagging American aid for Africa, but there was at least an agreement to accelerate trade and investment for countries with open markets. The summit gave a welcome if vague push toward closer collaboration on global warming and the spread of infectious diseases. A pledge to make bribery by multinational companies a crime might eventually reduce corruption in the world economy.
Conspicuous by its absence in the final communique was much reference to Europe's painful struggle to meet the austere requirements of a new monetary union without deepening unemployment, especially in France and Germany. While bragging about America's recent economic success, Mr. Clinton wisely avoided lecturing his European colleagues about how to solve their problems. He seemed more intent on creating a diversion from their crises at home in the warm Rocky Mountain sunshine.
