HEADLINE: Canadians Surprised by Proposal to Extradite Pol Pot

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, June 23

 BODY:
Canadian officials said today that they were taken by surprise when the United States suggested that their country seek the extradition of the former Cambodian dictator, Pol Pot, and expressed doubt that their genocide law could be used as Washington requested.
A senior official at Canada's Ministry of Justice, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, noted that Canada has no extradition treaty with Cambodia. Under Section 7 of the Canadian criminal code, charges can be brought for war crimes and crimes against humanity that are committed outside Canada. The suspect, however, must be present in Canada in order for the law to be applied. 
 The United States has indicated it would be willing to take part militarily in bringing Pol Pot to Canada, although it is not clear under what legal basis such an operation would be carried out.
[In Washington, Clinton Administration officials said they were discussing using American aircraft and military forces, as well as those from other nations, in the event that Cambodian officials succeeded in working out a plan for the surrender of Pol Pot, possibly to an international tribunal.
[With conflicting intelligence reports about Pol Pot's whereabouts, United States legal experts began discussions with Denmark and the Netherlands to see if their laws would allow them to seek the extradition of the Khmer Rouge leader.]
Over the weekend, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright raised the possibility that Canada could extradite the 69-year old Khmer Rouge leader in a conversation with her Canadian counterpart, Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy, at the international economic summit meeting in Denver.
According to a Canadian official, they had been discussing the breakdown of talks between Canada and the United States over salmon fishing rights when Ms. Albright suggested that Canada play a leading role in an international attempt to bring Pol Pot to trial.
In 1987, Canada passed a law that provides for prosecution of anyone in Canada who has committed crimes against humanity in Canada or elsewhere. The law was part of Canada's attempt to prosecute suspected Nazi war criminals who had immigrated to Canada after World War II.
The law has been applied four times against suspected war criminals in Canada. None of the cases resulted in a successful prosecution, the justice official said. The most recent case was against Imre Finta, a suspected war criminal, in Ontario. In a 1994 appeal of that case, the Supreme Court of Canada upheld the constitutionality of the war crimes law.
"We presume it's applicable in this case," the official said, referring to the planned proceedings against Pol Pot. "We're actively reviewing it. It's just too early to give a considered opinion at this point."
Presumably, the former Cambodian dictator would have to be brought to Canada in order for Canada to be able to bring charges against him.
The United States has indicated that it would be willing to participate militarily in bringing Pol Pot to Canada, although it is not clear under what legal basis such an operation would be carried out, since there is no extradition agreement.
Then, according to the justice official, Pol Pot would have to be accused under the criminal code in Canada. For that to happen, Canada would have to be in possession of evidence collected by the Cambodian Government against Pol Pot.
"Really what it comes down to," said the justice official, "is that without the active participation of Cambodia, it will be impossible to prosecute. All the evidence and witnesses are on Cambodian soil. That country is best situated to bring these charges forward."
Catherine Lappe, a spokesman for Mr. Axworthy, said that just bringing Pol Pot to Canada would also raise immigration issues, depending on how that was done.
"We are consulting with other allies and working with the U.N. and the United States," Ms. Lappe said. "Canada is interested in assessing what it can do and what course makes the most sense in reaching a conviction."
It is possible, though unlikely, that Canada could put Pol Pot on trial in Canada, as it has done with the suspected Nazi war criminals.
"Our preference is to have a U.N. mandate approach," Ms. Lappe said.
However, there currently is no international tribunal with the jurisdiction to try Pol Pot. The United Nations has agreed to consider taking such actions, but it has not done so yet.
Ms. Lappe said it may be possible to increase the scope of the International War Crimes Tribunal for Bosnia, or to create a new one for Cambodia.
Ms. Lappe said the Canadians were surprised when Ms. Albright approached them with the idea. Because so many details are unknown, the Canadians have not been able to lay out a firm course of action, she said.

HEADLINE: Official Says Pol Pot's Foes, Fearing Trial, May Kill Him

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 23

 BODY:
The enemies of Pol Pot are likely to kill him rather than let him testify at a trial where he could implicate them, First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh said today.
"It appears to me that some Cambodians and maybe some countries are not really willing to see Pol Pot alive and to be brought to justice," he said, in an assessment endorsed by a number of political experts today. 
 "You see, maybe Pol Pot would say something not very nice to them. Pol Pot would say, 'Those people were involved,' or, 'Those countries were supporting me for years.' "
He did not name any countries or people, but China was once the patron of the Khmer Rouge Government, and various Thai interests continue to have close economic connections to the guerrillas, whose bases are along the Thai border.
There remains a widespread sense among foreign diplomats and political experts that the reports about Pol Pot are not what they seem.
The entire scenario that has been reported over recent days -- Pol Pot's split with his supporters, his flight into the jungle and his reported capture -- could be a drama orchestrated by the Cambodian Government, the Khmer Rouge or both, they say.
Prince Ranariddh's comments followed the news on Sunday that the United States and other nations had asked Canada to seek the extradition of Pol Pot under its law against genocide, pending the creation of an international tribunal that would conduct a trial.
On Saturday, both of Cambodia's Prime Ministers, Prince Ranariddh and Second Prime Minister Hun Sen, signed a request to the United Nations for help in setting up a tribunal.
The Prince's comments today echoed the suspicions of a number of foreign political experts here who said that, even in captivity, the man responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians from 1975 to 1979 remained a threat to the political interests of a variety of people.
A number of leading members of the current Government, as well as King Norodom Sihanouk himself, are former members of the Khmer Rouge or have had close ties to them.
A trial of Pol Pot, with all its emotional impact, might have unsettling effects on this already unstable country, where the two Prime Ministers are locked in an increasingly dangerous political rivalry.
If Pol Pot is now in some form of custody, a number of political experts say they agree with the Prince that the Khmer Rouge leader might not survive to face a tribunal.
"You get a feeling around here that there is still a real fear of this guy," a Western diplomat said. "I'm still skeptical that he is going to show up for trial."
The prospect that Pol Pot, 69, could die soon is one that has been suggested privately and publicly by a number of Government officials for whom his death would be more convenient than his trial.
"I don't think that they will give up Pol Pot to the Government or that they will accept Pol Pot testifying in the face of an international tribunal and explaining the way they all implemented the bureaucracy of death," said Raoul Jennar, an expert on Cambodian politics.
"So they will kill him, if he is not killed already," said Mr. Jennar, who is the director of the European Far Eastern Research Center in Belgium.
On Sunday, a top general in the Cambodian armed forces, Nhiek Bun Chhay, said he had seen Pol Pot alive in the rebel base of Anlong Veng, 300 miles north of here. If his report is true, this would be the first sighting of the Khmer Rouge leader by outsiders in 17 years.
The general is a senior adviser to Prince Ranariddh and he is the apparent source of most of his accounts about the Khmer Rouge split and the fate of Pol Pot.
The only corroboration of those accounts has come in broadcasts from the clandestine Khmer Rouge radio station, which Mr. Jennar and others said could be part of an elaborate charade.
General Nhiek Bun Chhay produced no photographs to prove his report that he had seen Pol Pot, and he said he had not spoken to the Khmer Rouge leader because he was kept away from him, a factor that raised questions about the general's report that he had seen him.
Foreign political analysts said Pol Pot's possible death could itself be the next act in a scenario that has played itself out for nearly two weeks in a series of unconfirmed reports.
"I would like to say that I'm very suspicious because the picture is too beautiful," said Mr. Jennar. "All the bad guys are killed or in the darkness."
He was referring to reports from Prince Ranariddh that Pol Pot had killed his former Defense Minister, Son Sen, and that there was no news about two of the most feared of the Khmer Rouge leaders, Ta Mok and Nuon Chea.
At the same time, the Prince's reports have cast in a positive light Khieu Samphan, the nominal leader of the Khmer Rouge, with whom the prince had been negotiating an arrangement that could lead to a political alliance.
The aim of those maneuvers, a number of diplomats and political analysts suggested, could be a grand alliance of Cambodian political interests aimed at squeezing out Mr. Hun Sen, who was the Cambodian leader for a decade after the ouster of the Khmer Rouge.
The Khmer Rouge radio broadcasts, including one this evening, have already plunged into mainstream politics, supporting Prince Ranariddh while attacking Mr. Hun Sen.
"The Khmer Rouge are already making themselves felt in mainstream politics," a Western political analyst said, "and their aim does not seem to be stability."

HEADLINE: Clinton, in Talk to Mayors, Sketches a Vision for Cities

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 23

 BODY:
As he hopscotched among California fund-raising events, President Clinton alighted today at an elementary school to promote his ideas for children's health care and at the annual gathering of the United States Conference of Mayors to unveil some modest initiatives -- and some grand dreams -- for cities.
At the Mar Vista Elementary School here, Mr. Clinton attended a ceremony where the medical services giant Kaiser Permanente announced that it would provide $100 million over five years to help pay for health coverage for as many as 50,000 California children from low-income families. 
 In his remarks, Mr. Clinton recalled his efforts to create a national health care system. "It's well known I failed, but I'm not ashamed that I tried," he said. After that misfire, he said, "we sort of rolled up our sleeves" and approached the problem of uninsured Americans incrementally.
He called on other companies to chip in for health insurance for the 10 million American children who lack it, but also declared that "government has to do its part, too," noting that the new budget agreement would help extend insurance to poor children.
But the President's major address of the day was to the mayors, meeting in San Francisco, where in 45 minutes and under the loose rubric of urban policy he corralled topics as diverse as his dreams for home ownership, his plans for the Federal budget, his desire for an AIDS cure and his hope to "rewrite the rules of human evolution, almost," by teaching people of different races to get along.
Mr. Clinton told the mayors that he among American Presidents was exceptionally equipped to address the needs of cities.
"I imagine I have been in more urban neighborhoods, meeting with more different kinds of people about more different kinds of issues, than any of my predecessors," he said.
The President stopped just short of promising the mayors that he would veto a budget bill that did not restore disability benefits to legal immigrants, money that he said was stipulated in the budget accord with the Republican leaders of Congress. "I will not sign the bill unless Congress keeps its commitment in the budget agreement to do that," he said.
The President announced three Administration initiatives for the cities.
To encourage police officers to live in the neighborhoods they patrol, he said, the Department of Housing and Urban Development will offer them a 50 percent discount to buy homes that it owns. "Just imagine what it will be like when more police make those neighborhoods their homes again," he said.
Mr. Clinton did not mention the number of officers who would be eligible to buy the homes, but the Administration said it hoped to reach about 1,000 with the program, which is to last a year. Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said that "if it works the way we think it's going to work, then we would continue it and the numbers would be larger."
In addition, Mr. Clinton said the Federal Housing Administration would reduce mortgage premiums, or loan points, to 1.50 percent from 1.75 percent for first-time home buyers in central cities. Administration officials said the reduction would cut closing costs by an average of $200 for qualifying buyers, whom they expect to number about 20,000.
Last, Mr. Clinton announced a plan for a demonstration program in which up to 2,000 families would purchase their own homes using rent subsidy money available under a Federal program known as Section 8.
Mr. Cuomo said the three initiatives together would cost $700 million a year.
Mr. Clinton was the star of three fund-raising events in the two cities he visited today.
At one, a lunch in San Francisco to raise money for Senator Barbara Boxer's re-election campaign, Ms. Boxer said critics had charged that "the poor people are left out of this event." But she told her guests that by donating to her campaign, they were helping to make sure that "poor people's concerns are inside the United States Senate."
Mr. Clinton praised Ms. Boxer for her sunny disposition, finding a contrast between her and others in Washington. "You listen to some of these people talk in the nation's capital," he said, "you'd think that they spent the whole morning sucking lemons."
In Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton appeared at an event to raise money not only for Ms. Boxer but also for other Democratic senators. Ms. Boxer's office said it expected Mr. Clinton to raise $1.5 million today.
And planners hoped that an event here tonight for the Democratic National Committee would raise about $80,000 for the President's debt-ridden party.
Mr. Clinton also used the mayors' gathering today to renew his call for national education standards, deriding as "a lot of bull" the notion that some poor children could not meet them.
And he implored the mayors to help encourage people of different races to get along.
"We have a chance here to do something that has never been done in all of human history," Mr. Clinton said, pointing to a time "before there was a written history" when tribes "identified people who looked different from them and lived different from them as their potential enemies."
He said the United States could now overcome the dictates of evolution to create "the world's first truly great multiracial, multiethnic democracy."

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: THE OVERVIEW;
Immunity From Suits Is Withheld For Guards in Privately Run Jails

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that employees of companies that run prisons under contract with a state or local government are not entitled to the immunity from prisoner lawsuits that shields prison guards who are on the public payroll.
The 5-to-4 decision, rejecting an immunity claim by two employees of the biggest private manager of correctional centers, could help shape the law and economics of the fast-growing move to the privatization of government services. 
 Writing for the majority, Justice Stephen G. Breyer said that "given a continual and conceded need for deterring constitutional violations," the traditional immunity doctrine that enables government employees to do their job without fear of lawsuits should not be extended to employees of private companies.
Competitive pressures of the marketplace, making errant behavior expensive to defend and leading to the loss of contracts for poor work, should be permitted to operate, Justice Breyer said.
In the dissenting opinion, Justice Antonin Scalia said the decision would make privatization more expensive for taxpayers and lead to windfalls for prisoners who bring suits and lawyers who represent them.
Workers who perform a public function should receive a public employee's immunity, Justice Scalia said.
The immunity doctrine in dispute shields state officials from liability for civil rights violations as long as their conduct does not violate "clearly established" rights that a "reasonable person" should have known.
In legal terms, this is called "qualified immunity," as distinguished from the absolute immunity accorded to judges, prosecutors and some other officials.
In practical terms, qualified immunity is a powerful shield that makes it extremely hard to win a suit against a protected official.
In the case today, an inmate of a prison in Tennessee that the Corrections Corporation of America of Nashville operated sued two guards for injuring him by keeping him in unduly tight physical restraints. The Federal District Court in Nashville and the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled that the privately employed guards were not entitled to qualified immunity and rejected their motion to dismiss the suit.
In upholding the lower court rulings, Justice Breyer's opinion surveyed the histories of the immunity doctrine and of the private operation of prisons, which he said was common in the 18th- and 19th-century United States and earlier in England. There was no corresponding tradition of immunity for the private jail operators, Justice Breyer said.
Concluding that there was no reason to extend immunity now, Justice Breyer said the most important function of the doctrine was to prevent government employees from being unduly fearful in carrying out their normal duties.
He said that "unwarranted timidity" was less likely to be a problem with a private operator, because "competitive pressures mean not only that a firm whose guards are too aggressive will face damages that raise costs, thereby threatening its replacement, but also that a firm whose guards are too timid will face threats of replacement by other firms with records that demonstrate their ability to do both a safer and a more effective job."
The majority opinion, Richardson v. McKnight, No. 96-318, was joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, David H. Souter, and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Justice Scalia's dissenting opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas.
"Function, not status" should determine the scope of immunity, Justice Scalia said. He said it was "fanciful to speak of the consequences of 'market' pressures in a regime where public officials are the only purchaser and other people's money the medium of payment."
The decision did not necessarily guarantee how the Court would rule on the status of employees of companies carrying out other privatized functions like determining welfare eligibility, for example, as is being discussed in some states, and where the competitive marketplace might operate differently. But the majority's rejection of Justice Scalia's emphasis on "function" as the determining principle means that it will be an uphill battle for any private worker to claim a public employee's immunity.
The case was closely watched, in part because privatization is becoming so popular. Twenty-two states have laws to authorize contracts with companies to run correction programs. New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut are not among that group. The Corrections Corporation of America operates 49 correctional centers in 11 states and in England.
There were also these other actions today as the Court began what it expects to be the final week of the 1996-97 term.
 
State Inmates
In an opinion by Justice Souter, the Court ruled, 5 to 4, that a 1996 law that placed sharp new restrictions on the ability of state prison inmates to receive hearings in Federal court did not apply retroactively to the petitions for writs of habeas corpus that were already pending in Federal court when the law took effect.
The decision, Lindh v. Murphy, No. 96-6298, overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, and will have the effect of keeping hundreds if not thousands of petitions that would otherwise have run aground on the new requirements.
The law, the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, took effect when President Clinton signed it on April 24. The law greatly circumscribes the traditional role of the Federal courts in reviewing prisoners' arguments, through habeas corpus petitions, that their convictions or sentences violate the Constitution.
Constitutional challenges to the substance of the law are pending in lower courts. In the case today, an appeal by a convicted murderer in Wisconsin based on his inability to cross-examine the state's expert psychiatric witness at his trial, the Supreme Court had agreed to decide only the retroactivity question. Congress was silent on whether the general provisions of the law applied to pending cases.
Justice Souter's opinion reasoned from what he called the "negative inference" that Congress did not intend the relevant sections of the law to apply retroactively, because a separate section that applies to death-row inmates, not at issue in the case today, was explicitly made applicable to all pending cases in the text of the statute.
Justice Souter acknowledged that the case was hard. "No answer leaps out at us," he said. "All we can say is that in a world of silk purses and pigs' ears, the act is not a silk purse of the art of statutory drafting."
His opinion was joined by Justices O'Connor, Stevens, Ginsburg and Breyer.
In a dissenting opinion, Chief Justice Rehnquist called the inference on which the majority relied weak and strained. Justices Scalia, Kennedy, and Thomas joined the dissent.
 
State Immunity
In a splintered ruling in the oldest case on its docket, the Court enlarged the dimensions of constitutional immunity for states from suits in Federal court but did not go as far in that direction as Justice Kennedy and Chief Justice Rehnquist evidently wanted to go.
The question in Idaho v. Coeur d'Alene Tribe, No. 94-1474, was whether the state could be sued in Federal court in a dispute over ownership to the bed of a lake, part of which is on an Indian reservation. The 11th Amendment generally bars suits against states in Federal court.
But under a Supreme Court decision in 1980 called Ex Parte Young, state officials may be sued to bar them from enforcing state laws that are said to be unconstitutional. The Ex Parte Young doctrine, in effect a legal fiction based on the theory that the suit is not really against the state, has been under attack from states and from their allies on the Court.
In this case, Idaho appealed a decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, that permitted the Indians' suit to proceed against state officials under the Ex Parte Young doctrine. In overturning that decision today, five Justices -- Justice Kennedy, the Chief Justice and Justices O'Connor, Scalia and Thomas -- agreed that the suit bore too directly and intrusively on Idaho's "sovereign interest in its lands and waters" to be permitted to proceed.
Justice Kennedy wrote the opinion. But only Chief Justice Rehnquist joined him in the sections that would have replaced the general outlines of Ex Parte Young with a case-by-case balancing test that would have greatly limited the doctrine's usefulness in suing states in Federal court at all. That result was blocked by Justice O'Connor's concurring opinion.
Justice Souter wrote a dissenting opinion, joined by Justices Stevens, Ginsburg and Breyer. Justice Souter expressed "great satisfaction" that Justice O'Connor's more limited view had prevailed over Justice Kennedy's view, but said the suit should have been permitted to proceed.
 
Native Alaskan Rights
The Court agreed to hear an appeal by Alaska from a ruling of the Ninth Circuit that a remote village of 350 Athabaskan Indians is sovereign "Indian country," with broad powers to impose taxes and control land use and resources over an area the size of Delaware.
Alaska told the Court that the Ninth Circuit decision, growing out of a minor tax dispute, called into question the status of 44 million acres of Indian-owned land, or 10 percent of the state, which had not previously been regarded as Indian territory, as that phrase is used to describe the sovereign rights of Indians who live on reservations in the lower 48 states.
A 1971 Federal law, the Alaskan Native Claims Settlement Act, extinguished historic Indian titles to land in exchange for a cash payment and new political arrangements. The case, Alaska v. Native Village of Venetie, No. 96-1577, will require the Court to examine that law and other facets of Alaskan history.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Budget Clears Committees

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A $16.8 billion state budget for the next fiscal year cleared the budget and appropriations committees of the State Senate and Assembly yesterday and is now expected to be voted on by both houses on Thursday. The spending plan, which Gov. Christine Todd Whitman must sign before July 1, would increase spending by more than half a billion dollars, an increase that is $260 million higher than the Governor proposed in January. Much of the extra money would go to urban schools, state social workers and higher education. 
 Lawmakers are able to spend more money without raising taxes, because revenues are up this year, thanks to the boom on Wall Street, a strong state economy and a pension bond sale that allows the state to skip $590 million in pension payments.

HEADLINE: House Votes to Overturn a Plan By Clinton to Save Military Jobs

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Defying a veto threat from President Clinton, the House voted tonight to overturn the Administration's plan to keep thousands of jobs at two large Air Force maintenance bases in Texas and California that were ordered closed two years ago.
The vote, 278 to 145, defeated an amendment to the $268 billion Pentagon budget bill, for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1, which would have kept the Administration plan intact. Mr. Clinton's aides say he will veto any bill that reverses the plan. 
 In 1995, with an eye on the electoral votes of two large states, Mr. Clinton sought to keep thousands of military jobs at Kelly Air Base in San Antonio and McClellan Air Force Base near Sacramento, Calif., from being shifted to military bases in other states by directing that private companies be allowed to assume some of the work there.
Many Republicans, led by lawmakers from Oklahoma, Georgia and Utah, whose Air Force maintenance centers would inherit the work from the two bases, led the charge tonight against what they said was Mr. Clinton's political meddling.
"He undercut the integrity of the B.R.A.C. process to achieve political gains," said Representative Tillie Fowler, a Florida Republican on the House National Security Committee, referring to the Base Realignment and Closure Commission.
But proponents of the amendment, including some fiscally conservative Republicans, said that provisions in the Pentagon bill would allow private companies to compete for work only when existing maintenance centers operate at 80 percent of capacity. Military experts say that is an unrealistic standard, given that the current capacity is about 50 percent.
"We should at least give the military the ability to compete at the best price," said Representative Terry Everett, an Alabama Republican who sponsored the amendment.
How much military work should remain at Government-run depots is one of the most contentious post-cold war military issues facing Congress. The depots, with thousands of civilian employees, are economic boons to their regions. But some experts say private companies can perform the jobs more efficiently.
Congress is so angry over the depot issue that the House and Senate military committees refused to include in their Pentagon budget bills the Defense Department's request to authorize new rounds of base closings in 1999 and 2001.
In another contentious vote tonight, the House narrowly approved a plan to buy nine B-2 radar-evading bombers that the military says it does not want and cannot afford.
The vote of 216 to 209 defeated an amendment that would have eliminated $331 million for components to begin expanding the B-2 fleet beyond the 21 planes paid for already.
The Senate, which until two years ago favored the B-2 more than the House did, is not inclined to include additional financing for the planes when it votes on the Pentagon budget next month. As a result, the fate of the B-2's will likely rest with a House-Senate conference committee.
When the House narrowly approved a down payment on 20 more B-2's two years ago, the Senate refused to go along and the plan died. Some military analysts predicted a similar fate for the aircraft this time.
But B-2 proponents resurrected the issue this year. "I'd rather be wrong in favor of too good a defense with too good an airplane saving too many Americans," said Speaker Newt Gingrich in a rare floor speech.
Opponents of the B-2 said the Congressional Budget Office estimated that buying nine more B-2's and operating them for 20 years would cost a total of $27 billion.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Atlanta Finds No Relief From Reed

BYLINE: By BUSTER OLNEY 

 BODY:
As pitchers go, Rick Reed is a sprinter. Runs to the mound, pitches quickly, runs off, does not take time to change his sweaty T-shirt between innings, usually does not last much longer than six innings.
But the Mets needed a marathon from the sprinter last night against first-place Atlanta. Four of their six relievers were sitting in the bullpen strictly as decoys, tired and unavailable, and the Mets needed at least eight innings from Reed. They got nine: Reed pitched a complete-game, 3-2 victory over the Braves, a raucous crowd of 22,193 goading him along at Shea Stadium. What Reed accomplished, pitching coach Bob Apodaca said, was "huge." 
 Carl Everett hit a two-run shot off the Cy Young Award winner John Smoltz in the sixth inning, the second consecutive day Everett mashed the game-winning homer.
The Mets (42-32) are the best fourth-place team in baseball. They have won five straight games since the Yankee series, and closed to within five games of the Braves, with Florida and Montreal sandwiched in between in the crowded National League East.
John Franco, the closer, had pitched four of the five games before last night, and he needed a night off. So did the set-up man Greg McMichael, who pitched in two games. Cory Lidle and Juan Acevedo threw at length Sunday. The Mets' primary reliever last night was the sore-kneed Armando Reynoso, who would have been used only in case of emergency.
Terrible thoughts permeated through the Mets dugout, then, when Reed needed a whopping 22 pitches to get through the first inning.
After the inning, in which Reed allowed one run, Apodaca reiterated the need for economy. Don't overthrow your curve, and relax, he told Reed. Reed threw 10 pitches in the second inning and 12 in the third, allowing another run; Atlanta led, 2-0.
Reed singled in the fifth inning and scored from second on Edgardo Alfonzo's double, breathing hard as he walked back to the dugout. After that, Reed decided to conserve as much energy as possible, coming back onto the field almost dragging his feet, climbing the third base side of the mound, stepping in the same holes each time out of superstition. "I didn't take all my warm-up pitches, either," Reed said after the game. Instead of 10, he threw five or six before each inning.
Todd Hundley singled off a shoelace-high pitch to lead off the sixth after a prolonged at-bat against Smoltz. Everett, next to hit, fought Smoltz to a full count, fouled off a pitch, and then drove an inside fastball over the right field wall, for a two-run homer.
"Nothing seems real hard to me right now," Everett said. "That didn't seem like a John Smoltz fastball."
When Everett returned to the dugout, Reed barely moved, wasting little energy. He held the lead through the seventh and eighth, striking out the .400-hitting Smoltz with a runner on third with what Apodaca said were the best fastballs and the best location he had ever seen from Reed. But there were signs of fatigue; balls hit hard. Reynoso and the left-hander Takashi Kashiwada started throwing in the bullpen, and Reed, his cap darkened by sweat, guessed he would be relieved before the start of the ninth.
"How do you feel?" Apodaca asked Reed, staring him in the eyes, the way a boxing referee reads a tired fighter.
"How would you feel after eight innings?" Reed replied. He assured Apodaca he had enough to continue, and the pitching coach asked Hundley, the catcher, what he thought. "This is the guy we want out there," Hundley said. Reed returned to the mound for the ninth.
Slow and deliberate, he struck out Andruw Jones, the crowd roaring. Javy Lopez flied out, to more cheers. Mark Lemke singled, and Apodaca visited the mound -- more than anything, he wanted to buy time for Reed to rest before he pitched to the pinch-hitter Keith Lockhart.
Reed coaxed Lockhart to hit a high popup toward the third base stands. Alfonzo and Luis Lopez botched the play, but Reed's expression never changed. He later admitted that, as the ball was descending, he was thinking, "C'mon Luis, catch it, c'mon."
Reed received another ball and waited before ascending the mound. Lockhart smacked the next pitch on the ground up the middle, Reed lunged and speared it and threw to first to end the ballgame.
"You could see it in his eyes," Apodaca said. "This young man always had one more hitter left in him. My God, he picked up this whole ballclub."
 
INSIDE PITCH
The Mets have discussed a possible four-player trade with Toronto, according to a member of the Mets' organization, that would send pitcher DAVE MLICKI and outfielder ALEX OCHOA to Toronto for the reliever MIKE TIMLIN and outfielder SHAWN GREEN. The Mets may have a glut of starters in a month, when PETE HARNISCH is ready to pitch again, making another starter -- such as Mlicki -- expendable in a deal. Timlin would bolster the Mets' bullpen, and Green is a talented left-handed hitter who has fallen out of favor with Blue Jays Manager CITO GASTON. Toronto has tried to land Mlicki in the past, always unsuccessfully. . . . Harnisch threw a five-inning simulated game yesterday, but Manager BOBBY VALENTINE believes Harnisch will need some more work before being assigned to a minor-league team for a few starts. . . . Mlicki was named N.L. Player of the Week after shutting out the Yankees, 6-0, and beating Pittsburgh, 3-2.

HEADLINE: Faring Well With Labor, Giuliani Gets Fire Union Nod

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The city's largest firefighters union plans to endorse the re-election of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who so far is faring better in the battle for union support than Republicans typically do in New York City.
Officials in the 8,900-member Uniformed Firefighters Association, which is expected to announce its support for the Mayor today, said that they were backing Mr. Giuliani because he had helped turn around the city's economy and finances and had done some favors for their union. 
 Specifically, the firefighters are pleased that Mr. Giuliani agreed to restore five-person fire trucks in 50 firehouses, after the city had fought for years to reduce the crews to four to save money. The union had long insisted that four-person crews were unsafe, and the change also means more overtime for firefighters.
Some Democratic Party officials are voicing concern that Mr. Giuliani's main challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, has received little labor support. Most New York unions -- the police and the firefighters are the most notable exceptions -- have traditionally been close to Democratic candidates.
Labor leaders say some unions are hesitant to support Ms. Messinger because her campaign has not caught fire and because they are reluctant to offend the favorite in the mayoral race, Mr. Giuliani.
In one unusual twist, a union that traditionally is close to Republicans, the 29,000-member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, has made some vehement statements against Mr. Giuliani, largely because of its long-standing contract dispute with him. At the same time, the city's largest union, traditionally Democratic District 37, which has 120,000 members, has had kind words for Mr. Giuliani, and some labor leaders say its executive director, Stanley Hill, might even push to endorse the Mayor.
Michael A. Carter, a vice president of the firefighters union and the director of its political activities, said, "There's going to be a respectable number of unions that will endorse the Mayor, and I think you'll probably see a higher number than usual will choose not to make an endorsement because he appears to be a likely winner."
The union representing 20,000 school crossing guards, lunchroom aides and other school paraprofessionals has already endorsed Mr. Giuliani and pledged to provide phone banks that can call thousands of voters an hour.
Some labor leaders and political experts predict that the 90,000-member United Federation of Teachers, which is often considered the city's most politically potent union, might sit out the election rather than endorse the winner of the Democratic primary in September. Besides Ms. Messinger, Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn and the Rev. Al Sharpton are seeking the Democratic nomination.
But several labor and political leaders said there was some good news ahead for Ms. Messinger. Within the next few weeks she is expected to receive endorsements from two of the city's most powerful unions: the Union of Needletrade, Industrial and Textile Employees and 1199, the National Hospital and Human Service Employees Union.
"It's still pretty early in the process," said Leland Jones, a spokesman for the Messinger campaign. "A lot of organizations have still not made a decision one way or the other."
Bill Lynch, who managed the campaign of former Mayor David N. Dinkins and is an unofficial political adviser to several unions, said, "I think some unions are waiting for a few major unions to make some endorsements, and I know that's going to happen."
So far the only two unions to endorse Ms. Messinger are small ones, the musicians and the lithographers.
Some liberal unions that might have been expected to back Ms. Messinger are supporting her Democratic primary opponents. Mr. Albanese has been endorsed by Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents 7,500 middle managers working for the city. And the union representing more than 10,000 workers at city-owned hospitals has endorsed Mr. Sharpton.
"Al Sharpton is a man who is concerned about the workers -- he's out in the street marching with us," said James Butler, president of the hospital workers local, who said his union would endorse Ms. Messinger if she wins the primary.
The leader of the 15,000-member Social Services Workers Union, another usually liberal local, was far harsher in his assessment of Ms. Messinger. "Unfortunately, the presumptive Democratic nominee is no friend of this local at all," said Charles Ensley, the union president. He criticized her for supporting the Dinkins administration's efforts to contract with private agencies to take over work from city employees.
"We will never endorse Ruth Messinger for Mayor, whether in the primary or after," he said.
Mr. Ensley was hardly more generous toward Mr. Giuliani, faulting him for creating a large workfare program and blaming social workers whenever there are highly publicized instances of child abuse.
The United Federation of Teachers rarely makes endorsements in primary campaigns, and Sandra Feldman, the union president, declined to tip her hand about whom the teachers would back after the primary. "The union's delegates will discuss all the issues, as to the winnability of the race and whether or not in terms of the issues, it's worth making an endorsement." she said.
Regarding Mr. Giuliani, she said teachers were pleased that he was spending more money on education this year after having cut school spending previously. "But," she said, "there's a lot of suspicion whether this is something being done for the election."
Gerry Hudson, a senior 1199 official who is on leave to work as political director of the State Democratic Party, said it was important for unions to insure that the Democrat make a strong showing in November.
"If Democrats expect to be victorious in 1998, then they need to prepare the ground in 1997," he said. "The highest concentration of Democratic voters in the state is in the city, and if unions and the Democratic Party don't organize them and pull them out to the polls, we might not lose just this year, but next year as well."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 25, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about labor union support for New York City mayoral candidates misidentified the unit of the Communications Workers of America that has endorsed Sal F. Albanese in the Democratic primary. While District 1 of the Communications Workers, representing more than 30,000 workers in the city, has endorsed Mr. Albanese, Local 1180, representing 7,500 middle managers working for New York City, has not yet made an endorsement.

HEADLINE: What Ever Happened To the Stars of the 80's?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
THE heady days of New York in the 1980's, when restaurants were theater and chefs achieved the celebrity status of movie stars, are gone, and with them some of the brightest lights at the stove.
Barry Wine. Len Allison and Karen Hubert Allison. Jonathan Waxman. Brendan Walsh. A decade ago, their names were on the cognoscenti's lips, their unlisted phone numbers eagerly sought by yuppies determined to sample $50 beggar's purses and $30 roast chicken. The excitement created by their restaurants -- the Quilted Giraffe, Huberts, Jams and Arizona 206 -- was even greater than the clamor at today's places to be seen -- Le Cirque 2000, Balthazar and Nobu. 
 Restaurant mania has again gripped New York, but this time it is more restrained: diners are more discriminating: they expect value for their money. And restaurants are now seen more as businesses, not just as opportunities for accomplished cooks to show off their skills or for some wealthy diners to invest their loose change.
Today the money comes from banks and others who expect to make a satisfactory return. But none of that seemed to matter in the 80's. Until Monday, Oct. 19, 1987, the day the stock market took a deep dive, sending New York's restaurant industry, along with the country's economy, into a tailspin.
Among the casualties were Mr. Allison and Ms. Hubert Allison, who owned Huberts, and Mr. Waxman, who made his name at Jams. And Mr. Walsh left Arizona 206 because he disagreed with new management policies, which he said changed the emphasis from food quality to making money. On the other hand, Mr. Wine and his wife, Susan, accepted a generous offer for their restaurant, the Quilted Giraffe, one they couldn't refuse.
In the intervening years, these restaurateurs have matured, and today, most of them willingly admit that they wouldn't mind being part of the new scene. But running a restaurant is much harder than it ever was. Only one is still at the stove, cooking in a bucolic Connecticut town. Another is writing; the latest book is an autobiographical novel about the restaurant business. One is a consultant still searching for a restaurant, and another, itching to get back into the business, has just found a niche, working for the restaurant impresario Warner LeRoy. Here's a closer look at where they are now.
 
Barry Wine
At the height of his career as a lawyer-turned-chef, Barry Wine and his wife, Susan, owned the Quilted Giraffe, the most expensive and arguably the best restaurant in New York. Their restaurant, as a temple of gastronomy and as a very profitable business, was what other chefs aspired to. When Mr. Wine introduced beggar's purses -- crepes filled with caviar and creme fraiche and tied with strings of green onion -- they were the talk of the town.
But then, when Sony bought the AT&T Building, where the Quilted Giraffe occupied a corner of the ground floor, it not only offered to buy out the lease for seven figures, but also offered Mr. Wine a job as a consultant. The restaurant, which traced its origins back to New Paltz, N.Y., in 1975, ceased to exist on New Year's Eve, 1992.
Shortly after that, Mr. Wine and his wife divorced. He went to work for Sony, where among other things he created a sushi bar for five with an artificial stream running through it. "When Sony discovered they had lost all that money in Hollywood, they became scared, and I was the symbol of that extravagance," Mr. Wine said. His contract was not renewed at the end of 1995. After Sony, he tried to create a culinary Web site, but it did not work out.
"When I see how busy people are and how exciting things are, I want to be part of the action," Mr. Wine, 54, said over lunch at Lutece recently. "But at the same time, I think it would be very difficult to compete, especially with people who are subsidized. Chefs have staff and support. When we were in it, it was Susan and me.
"I've played with the idea of doing a 30-seat counter and cooking what I want and calling it Barry's Counter, like the Empire Diner. I could get backing in a second, but I don't want to own a restaurant."
Two weeks ago, Mr. LeRoy, who owns Tavern on the Green, came to the rescue. Mr. LeRoy is already backing David Bouley and the culinary empire he is building at West Broadway and Duane Street. Mr. Wine is now director of planning for Mr. LeRoy, and it is no secret in restaurant circles that by hiring him, Mr. LeRoy is adding stature to his bid for the Rainbow Room lease, which is up for renewal in two years.
 
Jonathan Waxman
Jonathan Waxman, who was responsible for bringing the oh-so-trend-setting California cuisine to New York, is still searching. In 1984 he opened Jams on East 79th Street. It became a mecca for savory roast chicken and perfect french fries served from an open kitchen. A year later, there was a second restaurant, Bud's, and a year after that, Hulot's. By 1987, Jams had opened a branch in London. But by 1989, the original Jams had been renamed JW and had reduced its prices.
"People are tired of paying $80 each for dinner," Mr. Waxman said at the time. Less than a year later, JW was shuttered, along with Bud's. Hulot's was sold.
"We made a common business mistake," Mr. Waxman said. "We were undercapitalized. I bit off more than I could chew. I followed my fantasy life."
Sitting over a cup of coffee in a tiny Upper West Side cafe, Mr. Waxman discussed the demise of his restaurants, acknowledging that he did not always pay attention to his work. "If it was anything, it was going out to dinner too many times," he said. "I consulted on five other restaurants. I said yes to every charity. I was being indulgent rather than being a businessman. I walked away with nothing."
In 1990, Mr. Waxman sold his Ferrari for $65,000, went to California and lived on that money for a year. The next stop, in 1991, was Table 29, which he opened with others in Napa, Calif., to mixed reviews. By 1993, he was back in New York as a consultant to the Ark Restaurants Corporation, which owns several well-known places, including Lutece and Bryant Park Grill. Mr. Waxman had wanted, he said, to learn about business from a master, Michael Weinstein, the president of Ark.
He left last year, intending to open his own place, but those plans failed to materialize. He is still a consultant, currently for the owners of Nick & Tony's in East Hampton, N.Y., and Nick & Tony's Cafe on West 67th Street.
Now, Mr. Waxman, 46, has settled down. He married two years ago, and he and his wife, Sally, have an infant daughter. But professionally, he feels conflicted.
One moment he is indifferent to owning a restaurant: "It doesn't kill me not to be part of the restaurant scene." The next he admits to a hankering: "I'd do something if I'd found a space that was real special, but I need a really good business partner. Being a consultant isn't fun, but you can make a living. It's kind of like being a mercenary."
 
Brendan Walsh
What's a kid from the Bronx doing in the staid old Connecticut suburb of Ridgefield, running what was once the town's snootiest restaurant? Actually, Brendan Walsh's family moved to Ridgefield when he was 14.
He made a name for himself cooking Southwestern food at Arizona 206 in New York, but today he is back in Ridgefield, the local boy who made good, married his high school sweetheart and became the proprietor of the restaurant at the town's 200-year-old inn, the Elms.
As a boy in the Bronx, Mr. Walsh said, he was "used to sneaking under turnstiles, jumping between buildings and shimmying up the sides of them." By comparison, Ridgefield was a bore. But he had always been fascinated by the process of making bread, so he bought himself a copy of the "Beard on Bread" cookbook and started baking at 14 and went to work in a restaurant.
That was followed by the Culinary Institute of America, then work and travel in California, France and Italy. In 1985, at age 26, he was the chef at Arizona 206, where he made enticingly spicy Southwestern food, captivating New Yorkers with flavors they had never tasted before. But three and a half years later he had a falling out with some of the people in the corporation that ran Arizona 206.
"The new management was more concerned about percentages and numbers than about food and the quality of the service," Mr. Walsh said one recent afternoon at the inn.
When his plans to open another restaurant in Manhattan fell through, he moved to Long Island for four years, where he ran several restaurants.
"I didn't plan to be on Long Island as long as I was," he said. "The last few years were very difficult for me, but I learned a lot about suburban restaurants. You need quality food and a small, concise, very focused menu so it will work economically."
At the Elms, which he took over a year ago, he has two menus, one inexpensive and "user friendly" in the bar, and another more elaborate in the dining room for people who have made the Elms a destination.
"I'm not ashamed to say I make the best hamburger in town," Mr. Walsh said. "People like the fact that I'm here and tell me, 'It's so nice to have a restaurant of this caliber in this area.' I'm so happy I can do everything I want to do with food here and be appreciated."
The dishes are straightforward contemporary variations on American dishes like lobster shepherd's pie, crab cakes with corn, tender chicken with a morel stuffing. Nothing at all like Arizona 206: not a hint of chili. Mr. Walsh tried it once in a lamb and hominy dish. It didn't play well in Ridgefield.
And what about New York? His wife, Chris, who helps run the restaurant, answered for him. "We brought these three kids into the world, and you'd never see them," she said.
But he acknowledged that the idea is tempting. "When you get star status, you can get caught up," he said. "I know if I got back on that train -- I know my personality. I like to party." Instead, he has set his sights on more grown-up pursuits: an organic farm to supply the current restaurant. And because he can't get the chilies out of his system, a small Southwestern-Mexican place. And perhaps another for barbecue. And then maybe New York?
 
Karen Hubert Allison And Len Allison
Students of New York's restaurant history always cite the rags-to-riches story of Len Allison and Karen Hubert Allison, who started out by serving dinners in their Brooklyn home on weekends and ended up with an eclectic three-star restaurant, Huberts, at Park Avenue and 63d Street. From their home they graduated to an actual restaurant in Brooklyn in 1975, and by 1981 had found some backers and moved to 22d Street in Manhattan. Eight years later, it was time for another change.
"There's a lot of reinvention and freshening in the restaurant business," Ms. Hubert Allison said from her home on the Hawaiian island of Maui, where she has just returned from a tour promoting her new book, "How I Gave My Heart to the Restaurant Business" (Ecco Press). "When we reached three stars, it was time for another reinvention. Our customers wanted us to move uptown." And they did. To the high-rent district, after the stock market crash. By 1991, Huberts was no more.
"It's very hard to say that it was a mistake, that anything in your life is a mistake," Ms. Hubert Allison said.
And her husband had other interests. "I knew I wanted to go into food in a Chinese medical kind of way," he said. "I was interested in Chinese dietary therapy and had begun to study it."
In 1991, the couple moved back downtown, this time to SoHo, and opened Onda, where the menu was Asian and dinner cost $30 instead of $120, but it wasn't well received. By 1992, Onda closed, too. "At the time that's all we could think to do," Ms. Hubert Allsion said. "I think it would have been wiser to sit still and think."
After three years of teaching at the Culinary Institute of America, she and her husband moved to Hawaii to start over and to be closer to an older son who lives in China.
"We had to believe in ourselves as creative people and that we were capable of making another kind of living," said Ms. Hubert Allison, 48. But it wasn't easy making the transition. "Suddenly, we were out of business," she added, "and we had to reinvent ourselves personally."
"I was a writer who became a cook," Ms. Hubert Allison said. "So, very quickly I knew I wanted to go back to writing." And Mr. Allison, who is 63, is about to start practicing Chinese medicine and has become a licensed acupuncturist.
But the lure of New York remains. The couple maintain an apartment in Manhattan, and they travel back and forth frequently. She has not ruled out opening another place, though quite different from Huberts. "Now we are more interested in the health-giving properties of food," she said. "I don't think I would ever serve meat again unless it was organic."
A restaurant, Mr. Allison said, "is not high on my list."

HEADLINE: Nike's Asian Factories Pass Young's Muster

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Andrew Young, the civil rights leader called upon by Nike Inc. to look into its overseas labor practices, said yesterday that a months-long investigation had turned up no evidence of widespread or systematic mistreatment of workers.
Still, the sporting equipment company should do more to insure that its foreign subcontractors comply with its code of conduct, Mr. Young said at a news conference. 
 "We found Nike to be in the forefront of a global economy," Mr. Young, the former mayor of Atlanta and United Nations representative, said. "Factories we visited that produce Nike goods were clean, organized, adequately ventilated and well lit."
In fact, he said he had anticipated finding much worse conditions in factories in Asia where Nike shoes and apparel are produced.
Nike critics said they were disappointed by Mr. Young's report, adding that his remarks contained surprisingly few criticisms of the company and failed to address at all the issue of low wages paid to workers in many of the factories.
The company, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., hired Mr. Young's newly created consulting firm, Goodworks International of Atlanta, to review its recently updated international labor code. Since March, Mr. Young has toured Nike plants in China, Vietnam and Indonesia and has held several meetings with company executives and representatives of human rights organizations that have been critical of the company.
In remarks yesterday summarizing his findings, Mr. Young advised Nike to continue to "play a leadership role" in the White House Apparel Industry Partnership, which has produced a voluntary, global standard for international labor practices. Nike should also take more aggressive steps to explain and enforce its code of conduct, and it needs to promote the development of worker representation in factories, he said.
In addition, he said, Nike should support third-party monitoring of worker conditions and should endorse an independent grievance system for workers. And it should expand talks with human rights and labor groups in the countries where its products are produced, he said.
Mr. Young came closest to criticizing his client when he said that the factories he visited were "controlled by absentee owners, managed by expatriates who, in Vietnam in particular, do not speak the local language fluently and are overseen by a relatively small number of Nike technical supervisors focused largely on quality control."
The findings seemed to produce few surprises for the company but angered some of its critics.
"I think it was an extremely shallow report," said Medea Benjamin, director of Global Exchange, a human rights group in San Francisco. "I was just amazed that he even admitted that he spent three hours in factories using Nike interpreters and then could come out and say he did not find systematic abuse."
Several human rights groups have said that by hiring Mr. Young, Nike was simply trying to deflect accusations that its foreign subcontractors use child labor, pay abysmally low wages and subject workers to sweatshop conditions.
Nike has repeatedly denied that its goods are made in sweatshops or that factory owners subject workers to inadequate conditions or pay them low wages. The company says that Mr. Young's review provided a level of oversight to its commitment to setting the standard for global workplace standards, and it said that it intended to carry out all of Mr. Young's recommendations.
Philip H. Knight, Nike's founder and chief executive, said: "We will take action to improve in areas where he suggests we need to improve. For although his overall assessment is that we are doing a good job, good is not the standard Nike seeks in anything we do."
Throughout the investigation, Mr. Young maintained that he was working independently and was not a spokesman for the company. Yet Nike officials accompanied him on all his factory tours, and he presented his findings to the company's board and senior management a week before making them public.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Up for 4th Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Americans' confidence in the economy continued to climb this month, suggesting that consumer spending may rebound.
The Conference Board said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence rose in June for the fourth consecutive month, reaching a 28-year high of 129.6. That was up from May's revised index of 127.9, previously reported as 127.1. 
 Economists had expected the June report to show a decline in the index.
"Consumers continue to be bullish about the economy," said Lynn Franco, associate director of the Conference Board's consumer research center.
Rising incomes, low unemployment and low inflation are contributing to Americans' exuberance about the economy, analysts said. "Consumers are reloading for the third quarter," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio.
Strong consumer confidence has not translated into increased spending during the current quarter. But economists, investors and even policy makers at the Federal Reserve expect consumer purchasing to strengthen in coming months. Such spending accounts for about two-thirds of economic output.
Alice M. Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Fed, said in a recent interview that the sluggish retail sales that have hindered economic growth in the second quarter were "not likely to persist because all the signs that make consumers feel good are there." She predicted "good, healthy growth" ahead.
With consumers alternating between spending sprees and periods of unexpected austerity, the economy grew at the rapid annual pace of 5.8 percent in the first quarter and then slowed to an estimated 2 percent rate in the current quarter.
Those ups and downs in consumer spending are not unusual and, more important, help stretch the nation's seven-year expansion, said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston in New York. Americans "are positive, but they still wait for a bargain before they buy; they're not speculating like we saw in the 1970's and 1980's," he said.
That, in turn, means that consumers are less likely to send the economy into a growth spiral that would cause the Fed policy makers to tighten credit severely.
In yesterday's report, the Conference Board said the index gauging consumers' expectations for the next six months fell to 110.7 in June from 111.4 in May, while the index tracking their assessment of present conditions advanced to 157.8 from 152.6.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate for City Fell Slightly in May

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New York City inched down last month, falling to 9.6 percent, from 9.7 percent in April, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday. The statewide jobless rate was unchanged, at 6.3 percent, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations.
Both numbers remain far above the national average of 4.8 percent in May. Economists have attributed the city's high jobless rate -- up nearly a full percentage point in the last year -- to a surge in the numbers of people looking for work, rather than more people losing their jobs. 
 On the month-to-month snapshot basis, the unemployment rate for the eight-county metropolitan area -- New York City's five boroughs, plus Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties -- fell to 8.4 percent, not seasonally adjusted, from 8.6 percent in April, the state said.
 KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: Attorneys General Defend Landmark Tobacco Pact

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., June 24

 BODY:
With a landmark tobacco settlement coming under increasing criticism as too lenient on cigarette companies, state attorneys general today offered a spirited defense of the pact they reached after nearly three months of negotiations, describing it as an unprecedented leap forward on a vital public health issue.
"It isn't perfect, but it's the best anyone has put forward," said Christine Gregoire, Attorney General of Washington State. "To those who say 'wait,' I say when? To those who say 'not this,' I say what? To those who say that Congress could do something, I say, what in the history of Congress leads you to believe that?" 
 The attorneys general, attending the annual meeting here of their national association, said that critics had focused on minor imperfections, overlooking the enormous changes that a deal with tobacco companies would bring about. The pact, they noted, would force tobacco companies to give up a wide range of marketing tools, pay a substantial sum in damages and commit themselves to reducing youth smoking in return for protection against a range of litigation.
Although the attorneys general took no formal vote on the tobacco agreement, Ms. Gregoire and other members of the negotiating team received a standing ovation when they briefed their colleagues. Support ranged across party and geographic lines.
"It's a historic alliance of attorneys general that is unprecedented in American history," said Peter Verniero, Attorney General of New Jersey and a Republican.
"For all the critics, it's easy to do what they have done over the last 50 years, which is nothing," said Grant Woods, Arizona's Attorney General and a Republican. "Congress has had the ability to do something for the last 50 years, so go to it."
"You've got to keep this thing in perspective," continued Mr. Woods, a member of the negotiating team. "This is the biggest public health and corporate settlement in the history of this country."
Although the 68-page tobacco pact would impose restraints and penalties on the tobacco industry that would have been unimaginable only a year ago, critics have expressed concern about several provisions that they view as too favorable to the industry. One concern is that companies would be able to evade severe penalties that the agreement sets for failing to reduce youth smoking. Another concern is that the penalties would be tax deductible as a business expense, softening the blow felt by cigarette companies.
Still, attorneys general who negotiated the accord said, public response has been overwhelmingly positive.
"Parents dropping off their kids were hugging me," Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's Attorney General, said of a birthday party for his son Michael at their Greenwich house on Saturday. "It really astonished me. It has been beyond my wildest expectations."
"Only a year ago, completely responsible people were saying: 'This is a complete pie in the sky. Why are you wasting the state's resources on this completely frivolous lawsuit?' " Mr. Blumenthal recalled of reactions last year when Connecticut joined other states in suing tobacco companies to recover the public health costs stemming from cigarette smoking.
Among the strongest critics of the tobacco settlement has been Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former United States Surgeon General and longtime anti-tobacco crusader, who has described the pact as "deeply flawed." Dr. Koop has found particular fault with the system for penalizing companies that did not meet specified targets for cutting youth smoking, calculating that fines could never amount to more than "a nickel a pack."
But Jeffrey A. Modisett, Attorney General of Indiana, said the penalties would have their desired effect. "They say it's only a nickel a pack," he said. "We say we have removed the financial incentive to hook children."
"We have calculated what is the financial profit to a tobacco company to hook a child on smoking -- that is the penalty they will get if they miss the targets," he added.
Some anti-tobacco forces were disappointed that the accord did not place restrictions on the marketing of cigarettes overseas by American tobacco companies.
"Given our druthers we would have brought them to their knees all over the world, but there is a limit to our leverage," Mr. Blumenthal said. Referring to the accord's limits on promotion and sales, he added, "Our hope is that this model will be adopted in other countries."
Several critics of the tobacco pact have noted that the $368.5 billion cost of the settlement would be tax deductible as "ordinary and necessary business expenses."
Mr. Blumenthal said that was a matter that Congress should address in a broader context. "Our entire tax structure is a construct that allows business to do a lot of bad things and receive tax breaks," the Connecticut Attorney General said. "Maybe Congress will want to change that economic fact of our country."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise on Fed Governor's Comments

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Overcoming a strong consumer confidence report, Treasury securities rallied yesterday after Robert Parry, head of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said he foresaw the economy slowing to a moderate pace.
Mr. Parry is a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's policy-setting body, which is to meet on July 1 and 2. A robust economy might lead the committee to push up interest rates. A fairly successful Treasury auction yesterday also kept prices higher. 
 The 30-year bond rose 3/32, to a price of 99 5/32 to yield 6.69 percent, down from 6.70 percent on Monday.
James Padinha, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said he did not see anything telling in Mr. Parry's remarks, which were made at a Fed-sponsored conference in Oregon, "and that is exactly why the market was up."
Mr. Padinha added, "In this feel-good environment, participants will not buck unless they see an imposing piece of spending or inflation data, or until a Fed member tips his or her hand in terms of signaling a desire to fight for a tightening at either of the next two Fed meetings."
The central bank raised its Federal funds target rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- in March to 5.50 percent, and left it unchanged in May.
"Note too," Mr. Padinha said, "that Parry makes no specific mention of any upside future inflation risk like the unemployment rate."
The market opened higher yesterday after Japan's Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said his Government did not plan to sell United States Treasury securities. Stock and bond prices had plunged in New York on Monday after Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto made remarks that many market participants interpreted as a warning that Japan might be tempted to sell some of its Treasury holdings if the dollar/ yen exchange rate remained volatile.
Following that early rally, the Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index for June hit 129.6, another 28-year high, after being revised higher to 127.9 in May. That exceeded the market consensus, which had anticipated a slight retreat, and caused some investors to sell holdings, erasing early gains.
In theory, upbeat consumers are more likely to spend, which could quicken inflation and prompt the Fed to raise short-term lending rates soon. Still, some market analysts are not convinced high consumer confidence will lead to more spending and higher prices; indeed, the market managed to shrug off the report and resume its climb.
"Consumer spending numbers have been weak in the face of record high levels of consumer confidence in the last few months," said Jonathan Basile, an economist with HSBC Markets. "With retail sales declining for three consecutive months from March to May, it would seem that the strong confidence numbers would be inconsistent with a weak spending picture. And although we do expect retail sales to rise in June, consumers' buying plans for automobiles and major appliances over the next six months were at the lowest levels since last December."
At yesterday's Treasury auction of $15.5 billion in two-year notes, the high yield was awarded at 6.027 percent, in line with expectations, with the bid to cover ratio was a good 2.46 to 1.
Today the Treasury will auction $11.5 billion of new five-year notes. By late in the day in when-issued trading, the notes were offered at a price to yield 6.29 percent.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
City Confident of New Plan for Notorious Building

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
For exactly $1, Frank J. Sciame Jr. has bought one of Manhattan's oldest structures, a brick house at 273 Water Street that was built in the 1780's by a seafaring mahogany trader and then became an infamous tavern where bloody rat-and-dog fights were the chief diversion.
One dollar may sound like a bargain for a raffish landmark in the South Street Seaport Historic District. But Mr. Sciame, president of the F. J. Sciame Construction Company, believes he overpaid. 
 That is because 273 Water Street is a wreck. The property, between Peck Slip and Dover Street, was seized 20 years ago by New York City for failure to pay taxes. It has since defied three rescue efforts.
Sciame Development, an arm of Mr. Sciame's real estate business, plans to reconstruct the four-story brick pile as a small luxury apartment house with four units. Mr. Sciame would not disclose the cost of the project, which he hopes to complete by the fall of 1998.
Although no other attempt to salvage the property has succeeded, the latest undertaking has several advantages. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which owned the building, and the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which regulates the historic district, worked cooperatively to devise a feasible plan.
Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the landmarks commission, said it was more important to find an experienced builder with a track record in preservation than to realize a windfall in selling the property.
"The history of this project is that if it's sold to the highest bidder, it often winds up back in the city's hands," Ms. Raab said. "The goal was to make sure that didn't happen again."
And James F. Lima, assistant commissioner for land-use planning in the housing agency, said, "There was an emphasis in finding someone with the capacity for getting it done who had the passion for seeing it get done.
"While Frank Sciame wasn't making a cash offer like other buyers," Mr. Lima said, "we knew he could pull it off."
Mr. Sciame has been working in the South Street district for seven years. His company constructed the Seamen's Church Institute at 241 Water Street and then reconstructed a 150-year-old Greek Revival building at 247 Water Street that had been perilously close to collapse.
He has a personal stake in the area, too, since No. 247 is the headquarters of Sciame Construction, which has 75 to 100 employees and about $100 million in annual sales. Mr. Sciame is chairman of the Seaport North Community Business Association.
But what may finally insure the reconstruction of 273 Water Street are the property tax abatements and exemptions being offered for the residential conversion of commercial properties downtown.
"Enter the Giuliani administration," Mr. Sciame said. "What I thought would be a very long-term investment for my children, motivated by a desire to save the building, may become economically very viable."
While the authors of the tax program had office towers in mind -- not former grog shops -- city officials believe 273 Water Street would be eligible. "It's probably one of the more interesting uses of the tax-incentive provision," Mr. Lima said.
Mr. Sciame's project, designed by Oliver Lundquist of Manhattan, does not attempt to restore the house to its original condition. There is no evidence of what the building looked like when it was home to Capt. Joseph Rose, who kept his brig, Industry, moored at a wharf out the back door.
It is almost a misnomer to speak of 273 Water Street as an 18th-century building since little -- if any -- of its original fabric survives. Because the remaining facade is in such a precarious state, it will be dismantled and partially reassembled in front of a new masonry and steel structure.
The reconstruction is based on an illustration from the 1860's that shows the house with a pitched roof, dormer windows, splayed lintels and stone bands between the floors. At the time, No. 273 was Kit Burns's Sportsman's Hall, a tavern notorious enough to warrant its own chapter in "The Secrets of the Great City," by Edward Winslow Martin (1868).
Martin described the main room as a kind of amphitheater, with rough wooden benches and a fenced-in ring at the center. Rats would be placed in the ring to be dispatched by a dog "of the best ferret stock," as the "sportsmen" wagered on how long the killing would take. Alternately, two dogs would be set loose in combat.
"The scene is disgusting beyond description," Martin huffed, adding that the patrons were no better. "A more brutal, villainous-looking set it would be hard to find. They are more inhuman in appearance than the dogs."
Since Dog House would probably not attract upscale tenants, 273 Water Street will be marketed as the Captains House.
