HEADLINE: Stocks Dive In 3d Straight Volatile Day

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled yesterday in the third consecutive session of volatile trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average, after falling 50 points in the first hour of trading, soared 100 points higher by noon, only to plunge 180 points from its peak in an afternoon selloff. 
 In late trading, however, those losses were pared, so that by the time the volatile session was over, the Dow stood just 68.08 points below where it began the day, closing at 7,689.98.
But the damage, mostly to the psyches of everyday traders and investors, was evident.
"There is nothing subtle anymore in this market. Everything is volatile -- violent," said Joseph Yurman, a managing director at Robertson Stephens.
One reason is that the market has been dominated in recent days by heavy program trading, analysts said. Any rumor, they added, could touch off a wave of arbitrage-related activity, as traders attempt to capitalize on the huge price swings.
In fact, program trading activity has been heavier than usual, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. Yesterday, for instance, there was one program trade sale of more than 400 blue-chip securities worth over $225 million. The program trade began at 2:42 P.M. and lasted until 3:07.
Analysts said they had to go back to late February to find a program trade with such a large basket of securities. And during that sale, the Dow plunged more than 100 points.
"The program traders are alive and well," Mr. Yurman said from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. "This is the stuff they like: volatility. And when the programs start kicking in it's like a waterfall."
Much of the heaviest activity was tied to a slump in bond prices and rising oil prices. But several analysts said that the volatility of the last few days had less to do with the economy and more to do with technical activity.
"This is what happens with markets at fairly high valuations," said William Meehan, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "It just takes a little rumor and you get selling in the futures market. It's like a mini-panic."
On Monday, there was an even sharper selloff after word spread that the Japanese Prime Minister had threatened to sell American Treasury securities unless the United States Government acted to stabilize the yen-dollar exchange rate.
Such a move would have depressed bond prices and lifted yields, which compete with stocks. The Dow lost 192 points that day in its worst setback of the year.
But Japanese officials later said that the Prime Minister's remarks were misinterpreted and that there was no intention to sell their large holdings of Treasury issues. On Tuesday, prices bounced back, with the Dow soaring 153 points.
Such wild price swings have become a hallmark of this bull market, partly because investors have become uneasy about the rapid escalation of share prices, often symbolized by the Dow, which has risen about 20 percent since April.
But other analysts also note that with the Dow up at the 7,700-point level, a swing of 100 points -- while it seems large -- is only 1.3 percent. In fact, already this year, there have been 18 days of 100-point moves. Before this year, there were only 5 sessions with 100-point swings.
Yesterday's selloff was largely tied to large capitalization stocks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.35 points, to 888.99. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq composite index lost 6.19, to 1,446.24.
Volume was heavy on the Big Board, with more than 607 million shares trading.
And of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 23 lost ground yesterday. American Express led the drop, down 1 11/16, to 75 1/2. Philip Morris lost 1, to 43 3/16, and Procter & Gamble lost 1 1/2, to 136 1/8.
Exxon, also a Dow stock, fell 1 9/16, to 60 15/16, along with other slumping oil shares. Chevron lost 7/16, to 73 13/16 and Texaco fell 7/16, to 111 3/8.

SECTION: Section C; Page 13; Column 1; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1331 words

HEADLINE: Got the Gig, but Where's the Health Insurance?;
In the Arts, Benefits Are Often 'Catch as Catch Can'

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Carol Reynolds, a dancer, actress and teacher in a Manhattan acting studio, had to give up her health insurance six years ago, when Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield eliminated group rates for associations that almost anyone could join.
"They made it so expensive for individuals that I couldn't handle it," said Ms. Reynolds, who will be 56 next month. 
 Without insurance protection, she lived with constant pain from an old dance injury until last year, when X-rays showed that a bone in her hip was so full of holes that it could collapse at any time. Finally, on March 20, she had hip replacement surgery.
Although friends came up with $5,500 to pay the surgeon, she still owes $18,000 in hospital and doctor bills. The Actors' Fund of America also helped out with a check to cover her living expenses until she could return to work, and the fund helped her file an appeal seeking a one-time payment from Medicaid, which had turned her down.
Ms. Reynolds's problems with health insurance are familiar to hundreds of thousands of people who work in the visual and performing arts. With employment sporadic, and often poorly paid, a high proportion of workers in the arts have little or no insurance, even though the risks of injury can be severe. Singers strain vocal cords; musicians develop painful hand injuries; dancers hurt their knees and backs; painters and ceramicists work with toxic paints and powders that blacken their lungs.
People with AIDS or H.I.V. often have special problems because of the high cost of the many drugs they need. The Actors' Fund AIDS Initiative in New York helps several hundred people each year with money for co-payments on drug regimens and for necessities while they wait for insurance checks.
The Clinton Administration said last month that it would ask Congress to expand Medicaid financing for protease inhibitors, the potent but costly new drugs that can help some people with H.I.V. to keep working and avert AIDS. The drugs cost $8,000 to $16,000 a year. For people with AIDS, they are combined with AZT and other drugs that bring the cost up to $2,000 a month.
Last month, the Screen Actors Guild Foundation announced that it would pay for protease inhibitors for needy members who are uninsured.
Nearly one arts worker in five across the country did not have insurance in 1995, according to a recent analysis of the latest Census Bureau Current Population Survey by the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington.
The research institute said that even more self-employed people -- one in four -- were uninsured. That group includes many painters, freelance writers and graphic artists. It said 17.6 percent of all Americans were uninsured.
Even freelancers who have insurance are often poorly protected. "Half my income goes to medical stuff," said Kristine McKenna, a Los Angeles-based arts writer. She pays $3,000 a year to California Blue Cross, she said, but it does not cover her "sun-related skin problems."
"It's a huge problem," said Ted Berger, executive director of the New York Foundation for the Arts, which provides grants to support individual artists.
"Artists who have worked forever are just playing Russian roulette with their health," Mr. Berger said. "The whole issue of fringe benefits in the not-for-profit community, and the arts commmunity, specifically, is catch as catch can," he said.
To be sure, people who work regularly in movies and television and parts of the music industry typically have solid health benefits under union contracts. But even many members of the entertainment unions have spotty protection, although 77 percent of them were covered throughout the year by entertainment employers or unions, according to a recent survey by the Workplace Center at the Columbia University School of Social Work.
Television actors, for example, are covered for health care by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists only if they earn at least $7,500 during the year under Aftra contracts.
"From crafts people to photographers to fashion to ballet, circus and opera, it is a population very often not connected to a significant employer," said Barbara S. Davis, human services director in New York for the Actors' Fund, which helps 4,000 people a year with social problems, often involving health care.
Meyer Braiterman, a Brooklyn insurance broker, said that "many performers' union health plans have been decimated." In New York, for example, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians dropped hospital coverage for members, except for those in Broadway shows or pit orchestras of big opera and dance companies. The union still covers doctors' fees.
The American Guild of Musical Artists says it is seeking health coverage for singers and backstage workers who are not on permanent payrolls of opera and dance companies in current negotiations with the New York City Opera and a number of other companies.
A singer who insisted on anonymity said that under current restrictions he was not covered even though he had paid $500 to join the union and its dues were deducted from his paycheck during a recent four-week gig with a Philadelphia opera company.
"Health coverage is practically nonexistent for dancers and musicians in smaller dance companies," said Mark Jones, executive director of the 12-member Limon Dance Company, which spends about $40,000 annually for health benefits. As Government subsidies have dwindled, a number of small dance groups dropped coverage, he said.
"Health care is a tough issue for artists because so many are self-employed or underemployed," said Randall Bourscheidt, president of the Alliance for the Arts, a nonprofit research group. "It is not only an issue for those individuals," he added, "but it is a cultural issue for the country, because we allow this important part of our population to live in jeopardy."
Lenore Janacek, a health care consultant and broker in Chicago, said many arts organizations cover their staffs but not the dancers or musicians. She was able to arrange a group rate with Illinois Blue Cross and Blue Shield for expensive medical problems for an artists' coalition. "But for everyday care, they are on their own," she said.
After several years of discussing the problem, the National Endowment for the Arts recently asked the Actors' Fund to help create a national health care and insurance information center. Ms. Davis said that planners from arts groups across the country were laying the groundwork for an "800" telephone service and a Web site on the Internet that will tell callers, including members of the general public, about insurance opportunities for individuals with low incomes or in small groups.
"Many artists have no idea what is available," said Roy Assad, a New York insurance broker who has arranged reduced rates for arts and music groups with the Health Insurance Plan, the New York-based H.M.O.
In New York and Los Angeles, the entertainment capitals, there has been growing recognition of the economic importance of the arts and their attraction for tourists. "The culture sector has been one of the strongest growth industries in New York City in this economic recovery," said Rosemary Scanlon, an economist who is deputy state comptroller for New York City.
Ms. Scanlon estimated that "the impact of the arts in New York City now exceeds $10 billion," up from $9.2 billion in the 1992 survey by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Alliance for the Arts.
Although more than 1.5 million Americans had jobs in the arts in 1995, said Paul Frontsin, a researcher with the Employee Benefit Research Institute, they can be hard to pin down. The Census Bureau lumps together workers in "entertainment and recreation services." One recent New York job survey combined "culture and media," and another survey grouped writers, editors, artists, entertainers and, in what may have been a judgment call, athletes.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The Economy and Markets Frail, Thais Breed Skeptics

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

 BODY:
Thailand's new finance minister has moved to repair the country's troubled financial system, but analysts see little evidence so far that the Government has found the resolve to rejuvenate the faltering economy.
The Thai stock market reacted with initial relief to assurances by the new minister, Thanong Bidya, a 49-year-old economist and banker appointed last Thursday, that he would stick to his predecessor's economic recovery plan. 
 The main stock index surged 8.6 percent in a two-day rally on Friday and Monday before retreating 2.3 percent Tuesday on profit taking and continued concern about the country's trade deficit and weakening currency. Yesterday, it rose modestly despite new doubts raised about the Government's recovery program and new fears of a currency devaluation.
Mr. Thanong won Cabinet approval on Tuesday for two measures aimed at reviving the financial system -- one that would allow property loans to be repackaged and sold as securities and the other that would promote mergers among ailing finance companies.
But yesterday, analysts expressed skepticism about the initiatives, saying they were unlikely to have much impact. "They're something of a fudge," said Richard Henderson, research chief at Krungthai Thanakit P.L.C. "The real alternative is to let genuine bankruptcies happen."
The analysts said the Government had yet to overcome the political infighting that has held up meaningful economic change. Indeed, they said, the resignation last week of the previous Finance Minister, Amnuay Viravan, star of the Government's onetime economic "dream team," in a dispute over excise taxes underscored a paralysis in the country's political leadership.
Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyuth, taking a break from economic and political crisis, flew to Phnom Penh, Cambodia, over the weekend for an official visit. But when he returned to Bangkok, there was increasing disillusionment with his handling of the economy and doubt about the durability of his seven-month coalition Government.
"Party politics has prevailed and the economy is again the biggest loser," the English-language Bangkok Post said in an editorial.
The appointment in December of Mr. Amnuay as Finance Minister had aroused resentment from other members of the governing coalition because the new minister had not earned his spurs by running for Parliament. From the start, his policies faced challenges from political opponents in the six-party coalition.
When Moody's Investors Service lowered Thailand's long-term credit rating in April, it said that although economic fundamentals were sound, the nation's unstable, personality-based coalition governments were prone to exactly the sort of pressures and infighting that in time brought down Mr. Amnuay.
Although Thailand's economy is humming along nicely by American standards, this country has been one of Asia's "tigers," where growth that would be considered extraordinary in much of the rest of the world is almost expectable here.
Last year, the Thai growth rate fell to 6.7 percent from an average of more than 8 percent in previous years, and last week the central bank lowered its projection for 1997 growth to 5.9 percent from 6.8 percent. If the economy continues on its present course, analysts say, Thailand could end the year with both an unaccustomed trade deficit and its first budget deficit in 10 years.
Yesterday, there was more bad news as economists estimated that Thailand had spent $5 billion in May shoring up its currency, the baht, and analysts questioned how long the Government could head off a devaluation. And the political climate heated up, with opposition members of Parliament demanding during a budget debate that Prime Minister Chavalit account for $2.1 billion they said was missing from the treasury.
The country's economic woes and political tensions have been painfully reflected in the Thai stock market, East Asia's weakest in the last year and a half. In 1996, what had been a booming market lost nearly 39 percent of its value, and so far this year, the main stock index is down nearly 40 percent beyond that.
The financial system is increasingly vulnerable. Thailand's rapid economic growth had been fueled in part by a construction boom that produced a glut in office and apartment buildings, golf courses, shopping centers and entertainment complexes. And the banks and other lenders that financed the expansion are left holding a lot of bad loans, dragging down the broad economy.
Thailand's slowdown has raised fears among some of its fast-developing neighbors that they might be heading toward the same sorts of financial strains. The Philippines, in particular, has experienced a construction boom that has some people fretting it might become the "next Thailand."
Mr. Amnuay's recovery package included a multibillion-dollar government cost-cutting program, tighter controls on lending, forced mergers of troubled finance companies and a $2 billion property rescue.
But as the economy continued to falter, he became the target of growing criticism. The last straw was the decision by the Cabinet, under pressure from affected industries, to overturn an excise tax increase levied weeks before on motorcycles, batteries and granite. When that happened, he quit in protest.
Almost from the moment that Mr. Thanong was appointed as Mr. Amnuay's successor, he came under criticism as too inexperienced and politically weak to deal as finance minister with the country's economic problems.
But Prime Minister Chavalit said that he already had plenty of economic policies and that what he needed was "someone to do the job." He said he would take charge of economic policy himself, although he has said in the past that he knows little about the field.
"The basic problem," a Western financial analyst remarked, "is that Thailand has no central leadership -- an unstable, inefficient leadership. The country as a whole is stable, but its coalition governments are tremendously unstable. People who have bet their fortunes on continued growth are suffering."
Still, he said, "it's hard to cry too much over economic growth rates that are still 5 or 6 percent."

HEADLINE: A Lakeside Villa in Berlin Tells Its Long, Bittersweet Story

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 25

 BODY:
If buildings could tell stories, the 40-room lakeside villa at Sandwerder 17-19 on Berlin's Wannsee would have a tale to recount.
Once the home of a prominent Jewish banking family, it became the wartime home of Walther Funk, Hitler's economic guru who built a bunker where the Fuhrer was said to have spent some time. 
 Then, in 1945, the occupying Red Army made a shambles of the villa before the Americans took it over as a military recreation center. Thousands of United States soldiers and civilians in West Berlin took time out from the cold war to enjoy tennis and swimming and sailing.
Now the imposing structure is about to enter its newest incarnation, that of an academic institution that is billed as an emblem of American interest in Germany at a time when some Germans feel the United States has lost interest in its erstwhile ally.
At a ceremony here today, a more human tale emerged. The people who are donating the $3 million founding grant for the American Academy to open next year are a German-born, American Jewish couple who met at the Sandwerder villa in the 1930's before they fled the Nazis.
"Time is a funny thing," said Anna-Maria Kellen, now a New York philanthropist, whose father, Hans Arnhold, once owned the villa. "I never expected that the house in which I grew up, where I learned my first words and took my first steps, where I met my dearest friend, my husband, would some day re-enter my life."
Indeed, when the donation was announced today at a ceremony attended by German and American officials as well as Mrs. Kellen and her husband, Stephen, a New York banker, the twist of destiny seemed to beg a question: why would people dispossessed by Nazi Germany return with gifts, particularly now when, across Europe, a broad debate has emerged on the moral and financial debt owed to survivors of the Holocaust?
The answer, possibly, lies not so much in Germany as in Berlin, which both husband and wife remember as a special place where the hatreds of Nazism did not spread so quickly as elsewhere in Germany. "I became a good New Yorker, but I always remained a good Berliner," Mr. Kellen said at the ceremony.
And to listen to the benefactors as well as others involved in creating the American Academy for visiting scholars in Berlin -- similar to the American Academy in Rome -- the institution will stand as a display of United States commitment to turn cold war swords into scholarships.
The academy responds to "a perception that the U.S. does not care about Germany," said Richard C. Holbrooke, now the academy's chairman and once the American Ambassador to Bonn.
Mr. Holbrooke said the Kellens' gift was the bulk of $5 million donated so far -- half the $10 million the Academy is seeking to start up and operate for the first two years.
As of next year, the American Academy is to begin offering fellowships and scholarships to academics and professionals to visit and study in Berlin. The villa on the Wannsee will be named the Hans Arnhold Center for Mrs. Kellen's father. Its history, though, will be hard to forget. The Wannsee is better known as the location of a nearby villa where Nazi leaders formulated what they called the "final solution" in January 1942.
As early as 1927, Mrs. Kellen said, her father sensed that Jews would be forced to leave Germany. "I think I was a little too young to understand," she said.

HEADLINE: Blair Offers New Ulster Deal; Key Is Disarming Both Sides

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 25

 BODY:
Prime Minister Tony Blair disclosed a new plan today for all-party peace talks on Northern Ireland coupled with simultaneous negotiations on disarming Catholic and Protestant gunmen. He challenged Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, to make an "absolute commitment" to nonviolence so it could take part in the talks.
The issue of how to arrange a weapons handover has been cited by Sinn Fein as a reason not to enter multi-party negotiations, with the Government of John Major rejecting parallel talks and Sinn Fein demanding them as a condition for considering a cease-fire. 
 Today's detailed initiative, a joint proposal of the Governments of Britain and Ireland, sets a timetable for the process beginning in September and ending in May.
Citing "revulsion and outrage right across the world" over the I.R.A. killings of two policemen in the town of Lurgan 10 days ago, Mr. Blair said that patience with the organization's refusal to abandon violence was running out. "Whatever Sinn Fein now say or do, I am determined to move on," he told a packed and solemn House of Commons. "Sinn Fein know what they have to do. There is no shred of justification for carrying on as they are now."
The leader of Sinn Fein, Gerry Adams, acknowledging that the Blair Government had taken positions "in advance of those of the last Government." said from Belfast that he would give the proposal his "fullest attention and consideration."
Mr. Blair has moved vigorously in his first weeks in office to take up the search for an accord in Northern Ireland, where sectarian violence has claimed more than 3,200 lives since 1969. His Government was deeply dismayed by the Lurgan murders since they came at a time when it had restored the first contact with Sinn Fein in the 15 months since the I.R.A. ended its cease-fire; the Government and Sinn Fein had held two meetings, with a third scheduled. In addition, Mr. Blair's Secretary for Northern Ireland, Mo Mowlam, has pursued contacts with all sides in the conflict more aggressively than her predecessors did, and a new government and new prime minister, Bertie Ahern, are coming to office in Dublin this week.
Mr. Blair noted today that the killings had had repercussions for Sinn Fein's credibility in the United States, where he had just spent three days at economic summit talks. President Clinton, he noted, condemned them "in exactly the same terms as I did." While in the United States, Mr. Blair appealed to Americans to stop giving aid to the I.R.A., echoing a longtime complaint by British governments that Americans are unknowingly funding violence.
He told the Commons today that three days before the killings of the two constables in Lurgan, he had sent a note to Sinn Fein setting out the terms of what was needed to gain re-entry to the talks and the period of time, six weeks, that the Government would need to conclude that the cease-fire declaration was a "sincere" one.
"I have dealt straight with them," the Prime Minister said of Sinn Fein today. "I expect straight dealing in return. We and the other parties will not be waiting around for them." He repeated an earlier warning that "the settlement train is leaving, with or without them."
While there is no longer any doubting the British Government's commitment to pressing ahead with peace talks even without the participation of representatives of Sinn Fein, it is hard to assess whether any meaningful accord could be reached without them.
Mr. Blair is trying to take the heat out of the coming season of Protestant marches, which ended in violence last year. The staging of the attacks in Lurgan, a County Armagh town in the very area where the marches are due to start early next month, was seen as an effort by the I.R.A. to provoke retaliation by Loyalist paramilitaries, plunging Northern Ireland back into the tit-for-tat violence that has largely abated in recent years.
The Royal Ulster Constabulary said today that it had arrested a 29-year-old man and charged him with the murders of Constable Roland John Graham and Reserve Constable David Andrew Johnston, the two men shot as they were on patrol in Lurgan on June 16. The man was identified only as Colin Francis Duffy, with no occupation or involvement in any political group.
The police in Belfast said today that they had foiled an I.R.A. ambush in a house off a street that is often used by British Army and police vehicles. A man was arrested and two loaded AK-47 rifles were seized. "There is no time to waste," Mr. Blair told the Commons. "The situation on the ground in Northern Ireland is fragile."
Before presenting his plan to the Commons, Mr. Blair met at 10 Downing Street with David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, to seek his cooperation. Mr. Blair paid tribute to Mr. Trimble's acceptance of the plan, even though he knew it was not all entirely to his liking and would cause him "difficulties."
The leaders of the two principal opposition parties, William Hague of the Conservatives, and Paddy Ashdown of the Liberal Democrats, expressed support for the initiative, in keeping with the tradition of non-partisanship on British policy in Northern Ireland.
John Hume, head of the moderate Social Democratic and Labor Party in Northern Ireland and the man who helped engineer the initial I.R.A. cease-fire with Mr. Adams, also rose to praise the approach. But the Rev. Ian Paisley, head of the hard-line Democratic Unionist Party, complained that Sinn Fein was being offered a chance to rejoin the talks without relinquishing "one weapon," or, in a reference to a plastic high-explosive, "one ounce of Semtex."
The principal new element in today's proposal is an agreement to set up simultaneous talks on disarmament and peace, a step called "parallel decommissioning." The term means that the I.R.A. and rival Protestant paramilitary groups would give up their arms in closely monitored stages while the main talks on a lasting settlement continued.
When this was proposed in January 1996 by George J. Mitchell, the former United States Senator who is the chairman of the year-old peace talks, Mr. Major said it was unacceptable and called instead on the I.R.A. to give up its arms as a condition for entering the talks. Sinn Fein has argued that arms should be turned in only when a final political settlement is reached.
As outlined in a 12-page document from Ms. Mowlam's office, the plan would set up an independent commission to make proposals for disarming the guerrilla forces and then assess how to carry them out. Another committee would be charged with coming up with "confidence-building measures," and a full meeting would be convened every two months to review progress. Any overall agreement would be put to a referendum in Northern Ireland and to a vote in Parliament.
The I.R.A. violence of recent weeks is evidence that at least some elements of the underground organization want to sabotage any moves toward new talks. The political talks do not hold out the prospect of a united Ireland for which activists have fought, but a government in Northern Ireland that would enjoy a degree of autonomy like that being proposed for Scotland and Wales, while still remaining a part of Britain.

HEADLINE: Bond Issue In New Jersey Brings In $2.8 Billion

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 25

 BODY:
Investors from around the world took part in the biggest debt offering in New Jersey's history, buying more than $2.8 billion in bonds issued by the state today.
The sale, which was preceded by months of political bickering and debate, marked a victory for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who is using the proceeds to shore up the state pension fund and to avoid using $590 million of this year's budget to cover a scheduled contribution to the fund. 
 Enthusiasm for the bonds was strong enough that the offerings were sold at an average interest rate of 7.64 percent, significantly lower than the originally projected rate of 7.78 percent.
Also, the debt service -- the total amount the state will repay over the life of the bonds -- was reduced, because the bonds were scheduled to be repaid in the year 2029, instead of 2033, as had been earlier projected. In a statement, Ms. Whitman called the bond issue an "overwhelming success" and a "big win" for taxpayers.
The individual and institutional investors who bought the bonds apparently were not deterred by critics of Ms. Whitman's plan, who have argued that it would place the state in a precarious fiscal position, and have also tried to stop the sale through court challenges.
Officials at Merrill Lynch & Company, the firm that managed the bond sale, said the response from investors exceeded expectations. Noting the lower than anticipated interest rate, David Andersen, managing director and co-head of municipal trading and underwriting at Merrill Lynch, credited state officials for spending "several days educating the market on the deal."
And as Samuel B. Corliss Jr., managing director of Merrill Lynch's public finance group, pointed out, "the current bullish market environment for new issues" also allowed the firm to price the offering below expectations.
Institutions that took part in the sale included United States and international pension funds, banks, insurance companies and mutual funds, state officials said. There were about 15,000 retail buyers, and the average spent by each buyer was $25,000, according to Merrill Lynch.
The total transaction was the largest municipal bond issue ever for Merrill Lynch, which will split a fee of $23 million with a group of firms that jointly managed the sale.
The total transaction included three separate offerings, one for zero coupon bonds totaling $1.14 billion, another for $1.3 billion in current coupon bonds sold to institutional investors and a third for current coupon bonds totaling $375 million that were sold to institutional investors.
While investors were gearing up for the bond purchase this week, critics of the Republican Governor's financing plan -- most of whom are Democrats -- were trying to stop the sale from going forward.
A state appeals panel on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit filed by Democratic politicians who were seeking to stop the bond sale on the basis that it was unconstitutional to issue the debt without voter approval. (Earlier this month, the State Legislature approved the plan.)
The three-judge panel rejected a request by the Democrats to halt the sale. Also earlier this month, a judge in Superior Court ruled that the bond sale did not require voter approval, and on Monday that same judge refused a final motion to freeze the sale pending appeal.
Alan Karcher, the lawyer representing the plaintiffs and a former county Democratic Party chairman, said he planned to file an appeal with the State Supreme Court.
Despite the robust sales of the bonds, Mrs. Whitman's fiscal maneuvers have caused concern on Wall Street among investors who wonder what effect the huge debt will have on the state's long-term stability. On Friday, Moody's Investor Service, a New York-based bond ratings agency, issued a report in which it warned that the state's aggressive budget strategies in recent years and its increasing debt "will leave it less well prepared to deal with the next economic downturn."
Moody's gave an A1 rating to the $2.75 billion pension financing issuebut also warned that the agency was taking a "negative outlook" on the state's general obligation debt, which is rated Aa1, a few notches above the pension bonds.
The negative outlook means that the rating on those pre-existing bonds could be lowered over the next one to three years.
But neither the threat of ongoing litigation nor the potential for future tough economic times in the state could create much trepidation among the bulls on Wall Street today. As Mr. Corliss of Merrill Lynch asserted: "Given the overwhelming response from the market, I would conjecture there was no concern."

HEADLINE: Carnival Starts Bidding War For Celebrity Cruise Lines

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 25

 BODY:
The Carnival Corporation opened a bidding war today when it offered $525 million in cash or stock for Celebrity Cruise Lines.
The offer comes on the heels of an offer last week by Royal Caribbean International for $230 million in cash and $270 million in stock for Celebrity. 
 Both offers include assumption of $800 million in Celebrity debt.
Tim Gallagher, Carnival's vice president, said last night that the Miami-based company would provide more details Thursday.
There was no answer tonight at Royal Caribbean's Miami headquarters.
Money-losing Celebrity, a well-regarded upscale line with four modern ships and another scheduled for delivery in October, appeals to older customers and has many from New England. But it is considered too small to compete on its own, as the industry expands internationally.
Under the Carnival offer, Celebrity's shareholders could choose how much of the purchase price would be paid in cash, or a combination of cash and Carnival Class A common stock in the same proportion as the Royal Caribbean offer.
Carnival said it might consider increasing the purchase price if it found Celebrity worth it.
The Carnival Corporation owns Carnival Cruise Lines, Holland America Line, Windstar Cruises and has interests in Seabourn Cruise Line and Costa Cruise Lines, which combined operate 33 ships in the Caribbean, Alaska, Europe and other destinations.
The merger of Royal Caribbean and Celebrity would have ranked the combined companies second largest in the industry behind Carnival and ahead of London-based P&O Cruises, the parent of Princess.
Royal Caribbean, which sails to more than 150 destinations worldwide, changed its name last year after almost 30 years as the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line. The company, based in Miami, wanted a name that better reflected its growing fleet and greater reach.
Richard D. Fain, Royal Caribbean's chairman and chief executive, said last week that "Together, the two brands will enable us to deploy vessels and attract customers on an increasingly global basis, as well as provide opportunities to achieve greater economies of scale."
Celebrity is jointly owned by the Chandris Group, a Greek shipping company with headquarters in London, and the Overseas Shipholding Group Inc., one of the world's biggest bulk shipping companies. Chandris also owns hotels in Greece, as well as commercial ships.
Cruise Week, an industry newsletter, reported last week that Overseas Shipholding Group was disappointed with the financial results of its relationship with Celebrity and wanted to sell its interest in the line.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Tokyo Economic Data Send Dollar Down vs. the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most key currencies yesterday, hurt by unexpectedly strong Japanese economic data that suggested Japan's record-low interest rates could start to rise.
New indications of a possible delay in Europe's single currency also pressured the dollar indirectly by helping to strengthen the mark, which would remain the predominant European currency if the January 1999 timetable for introducing the euro was postponed. 
 The dollar ended higher against the pound on a broad selloff in the British currency, its second straight decline, on British trade data that suggested the pound's strength was hurting Britain's exports. But the pound's weakness largely benefited the mark and yen, further contributing to the dollar's weakness against those currencies.
The dollar fell to an intraday low of 113.30 yen before settling in New York at 113.80 yen, down from 114.82 yen Tuesday and the lowest closing level in a week. The dollar cost 1.7235 marks, down from 1.7245 marks. The pound fell to $1.6636 from $1.6675.
The main event in currency trading came early in the day when the Bank of Japan released its quarterly survey of business sentiment known as the Tankan, viewed as a barometer of Japanese economic and interest-rate trends.
Instead of showing weakness as had been widely forecast, the results showed a surge in confidence among big Japanese manufacturers.
The unexpectedly positive reading suggested that the Bank of Japan could soon start raising interest rates, which have languished at record lows since September 1995 because of prolonged Japanese economic weakness. Higher rates would enhance the yen's value.
"I think the Tankan report surprised the financial markets and the purchases of yen overnight were quite significant," said John Nelson, head of foreign-exchange trading at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. in Chicago.
The dollar later recovered a bit as the foreign-exchange market reassessed the Tankan results and concluded a rise in Japanese interest rates was unlikely for a while. Despite the rising confidence among big manufacturers, smaller companies and nonmanufacturing businesses were more pessimistic about the economy than three months earlier.

HEADLINE: Decisive Days for Congo

 BODY:
The coming days will show what kind of ruler Congo's new President, Laurent Kabila, is likely to be. A United Nations team has arrived in the country, formerly called Zaire, to investigate reported massacres by Mr. Kabila's troops earlier this year. If Congolese officials cooperate with the investigation, as Mr. Kabila has assured the Clinton Administration they will, Washington can put some faith in the new leader's other promises. These include an end to corruption, respect for human rights and eventual democratic elections.
If Mr. Kabila lets his lieutenants obstruct the investigation by denying the U.N. independent access to people and places, Washington should suspend the tentative support and promises of assistance it has offered the new Government. 
 Mr. Kabila initially stirred high hopes by promising clean and law-abiding government after decades of corruption and brutality under his predecessor, Mobutu Sese Seko. But since he took full charge of Congo last month, disturbing reports of arbitrary rule and military brutality have emerged. These include credible accounts that Mr. Kabila's troops massacred thousands of Hutu refugees.
Earlier this month, President Clinton offered Mr. Kabila assistance in improving health and education and American advice on planning a market economy and democratic elections. But Mr. Clinton's emissary, Bill Richardson, who is also Washington's United Nations delegate, made clear that American help depended on whether Mr. Kabila addressed human rights and refugee concerns and how quickly he moved toward democracy.
Last weekend a United Nations advance team arrived in Congo to establish ground rules for the investigation into the reported refugee massacres. The tone of its first meetings with Congolese officials has been cooperative. But specific details remain to be worked out.
Mr. Kabila must make sure that when a full U.N. team starts work it is free to interview people and conduct forensic tests in the areas where massacres may have taken place. Any soldiers found to have participated in massacres must be promptly prosecuted. Mr. Kabila must also see that United Nations refugee workers and the Red Cross are allowed access to all remaining refugees. He needs to start delivering on the humanitarian agenda raised by Mr. Richardson if he wants continued American support.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Divided Over Mexican Governor Who's Reportedly Linked to Drug Trade

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN and JULIA PRESTON 

 BODY:
United States diplomats in Mexico City have rejected a proposal to revoke the visa of a powerful state governor in Mexico, despite what officials described as a widespread judgment among law enforcement and intelligence analysts in Washington that he is linked to major drug traffickers.
Differences over the issue have opened an unusual rift between American officials responsible for anti-drug efforts and the departing United States Ambassador to Mexico, James R. Jones, who has grown close to Mexico's governing elite. 
 American officials said the dispute also underscored the difficulties they face in trying to take action against Mexican politicians and businessmen who are implicated in the drug trade on the basis of information that law-enforcement and intelligence agents piece together from informants and secret investigations.
The State Department typically defers to its ambassadors and consuls general on visa cases abroad. But officials in Washington said divisions over the Mexican governor had been so deep that the embassy's decision might yet be reviewed by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
In recent years, the United States has revoked the visas of scores of Colombians linked to the drug trade, President Ernesto Samper among them. But applying the same strategy has proven considerably more complicated in Mexico, a country with which the United States has a far more important economic and political relationship.
Officials in Washington said Ambassador Jones had objected repeatedly to efforts by State Department drug-policy officials to withdraw the visa of Manlio Fabio Beltrones, the Governor of the Mexican state of Sonora, which borders Arizona.
Mr. Jones voiced considerable skepticism about the intelligence data on Mr. Beltrones, calling it inconclusive. He also told State Department officials that he did not want to preside over "a witch hunt" in which Mr. Beltrones's rights might be trampled.
The Ambassador is leaving his post this week to head the international division of Warnaco Group Inc., a large multinational apparel company that has extensive operations in Mexico, including a brassiere manufacturing plant in Sonora.
Mr. Jones said in an interview in Mexico City that he was unaware during the visa dispute that Warnaco operated a plant in Mr. Beltrones's state. He said it was "off the wall" to suppose his judgment was influenced by the possibility that Mr. Beltrones might be able to harm the business of his new employer.
"If you don't even know, I don't see how you could have a conflict," Mr. Jones said.
Officials of Warnaco said its Sonora plant, in the border city of San Luis Rio Colorado, has operated for 12 years and employs about 800 workers in the assembly of Olga brand brassieres. They said it was one of five plants the company runs in Mexico.
Mr. Jones said senior embassy officials, including law-enforcement and intelligence officers, had voted unanimously against revoking the visa on June 13 while he was out of town.
However, a senior official of the Drug Enforcement Administration directly contradicted Mr. Jones' claim. The official, who spoke on the condition he not be named, said drug-enforcement officials at the embassy had participated in discussions, but never in a vote.
In Washington, half a dozen other officials interviewed about the case also challenged the Ambassador's position, suggesting that it was at least inconsistent.
Almost three years ago, some of the officials noted, Mr. Beltrones had been included on a secret list of 18 serving and former Mexican officials who were believed by embassy officials to have protected drug traffickers or were implicated in other serious corruption.
The officials said Mr. Jones had the list drawn up and then delivered to the incoming Mexican President, Ernesto Zedillo, in an effort to keep the 18 men out of Mr. Zedillo's Government.
Before Mr. Beltrones, 44, was implicated in a series of scandals, he had been widely seen as a rising star in Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, and he remains popular in Sonora.
In an interview in Mexico City, Mr. Jones denied that he had shown any favoritism to Mr. Beltrones because of the Governor's influential place in Mexican politics.
Officials said Mr. Beltrones's visa began to come under serious scrutiny in February, around the time The New York Times reported that numerous United States drug-intelligence reports linked the Governor to major drug smugglers.
Then, as now, Mr. Beltrones denied being anything but an implacable foe of the traffickers, who have made his state one of the most important bases of drug operations in Mexico.
"I am extremely upset and indignant about these reports, which are entirely false," he said in a telephone interview yesterday from his office in the city of Hermosillo. Mr. Beltrones said he had received no information from American officials about the status of his visa.
Since the February article appeared, both Mr. Beltrones and Jorge Carrillo Olea, the Governor of Morelos, who was also mentioned in the article, have asked the Mexican Attorney General's office to bring criminal charges of libel in the matter.
Mr. Carrillo Olea has also denied any involvement with drug traffickers. American officials said they are continuing to review whether to cancel Mr. Carrillo Olea's visa.
United States immigration laws say American consular officials can revoke a visa if they have a "reason to believe" the foreigner has aided or colluded with drug traffickers. That criterion can be met where officials have "several reliable and corroborative reports" of such involvement.
In late February, the State Department's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs, then run by Robert S. Gelbard, began to circulate a memorandum calling for the revocation of Mr. Beltrones's visa.
The State Department's Office of the Under Secretary for Global Affairs endorsed the proposal, officials said, as did its Bureau of Consular Affairs. The Department's Latin America bureau opposed the idea, however, echoing Mr. Jones's concerns.
After a sometimes heated struggle within the State Department, the issue was referred to the United States Embassy in Mexico City. Officials also sent the embassy about a dozen pages summarizing intelligence reports on Mr. Beltrones.
Officials said the documents showed that American agencies had received frequent reports of contacts between Mr. Beltrones and the powerful syndicates that move cocaine and other drugs through Sonora and across the border into the United States.
One American official who read the documents said they contained "no smoking gun"; other officials described them as unusually voluminous and specific.
The most concrete and frequently mentioned charge in the documents was that Mr. Beltrones was present at a meeting at a ranch in northern Mexico where Raul Salinas de Gortari, the elder brother of the former President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, received a payoff from Mexican traffickers, one official said.
At a meeting at the United States Embassy, an official said, Mr. Jones underscored the political sensitivity of Mr. Beltrones's case once more.
The Ambassador argued that in deciding whether to cancel the visas of prominent Mexicans, the embassy should, in effect, consider a higher standard of evidence than that stipulated in consular regulations, the official said. He urged that American diplomats act only on evidence that would be strong enough to put before a grand jury in the United States.
Later, at Mr. Beltrones' request, Mr. Jones also invited the Governor to the Ambassador's residence in Mexico City so that he might defend himself against the allegations. Mr. Beltrones said he argued strongly that he had been slandered by the reports.
At the Ambassador's suggestion, he said, he will file a request under the Freedom of Information Act for any drug intelligence reports that mention him.
In the interview, Mr. Jones repeatedly took issue with accounts of the debate given by officials in Washington. He denied having contravened consular rules. But he also called the reason-to-believe standard "a great nebulous thing."
"If I need to convince a group of people that what I'm suggesting is right," he added, "I want to have the minimum amount of credibility of what I present to them. And the lowest test of credibility is generally what you would present to a grand jury."
Mr. Jones contended that the initiative to review Mr. Beltrones's visa had come from him. As far as he was concerned, he said, the case was closed.
"There was a discussion and it was decided that based upon the information, there wasn't enough information to do it," he said. "That's the decision that the embassy unanimously agrees upon. If it is going to be overruled, it is going to be overruled in Washington."

HEADLINE: Harvest of Shares;
One Farm's Stock Plan Gives Its Migrant Workers a Stake

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: WATERLOO, Wis.

 BODY:
Like most farms reliant on seasonal field workers, the McKay Nursery Company long ago gave up the notion that it could afford wages high enough to make such dirty, wearying labor attractive to unemployed Americans.
"We haven't had a local market for entry-level farm labor since the 1960's," said Griff Mason, McKay's president, recalling how the company turned to migrant Mexican workers to sustain its nursery here in southeastern Wisconsin. "People here just didn't see it as a place to start a career." 
 Since then, though, McKay has veered far from the norm in agriculture. It has quietly evolved into an employee-owned enterprise where many migrant workers not only play an increasingly influential role, but annually receive chunks of stock in the company. Mr. Mason projects that the stock distributions and related bonuses will compound into a nest egg of at least $100,000 in 30 years for even the most lowly paid.
"I don't feel like an owner," said Guillermo Castillo, a 28-year-old native of Zacatecas, Mexico, who freely admits he is confused about the details of the company's ownership structure and his accumulating holdings. "But I do feel like a partner," he added, noting that some peers had kidded him in his early days about the amount of unpaid work he performed caring for young plants.
Such attitudes -- and the opportunities that created them -- are so rare in the world of migrant labor that McKay caught the attention of the Business Enterprise Trust, a California foundation created by the television producer Norman Lear to honor businesses that combine financial success with social vision.
In February, Mr. Mason, along with Richard Knoke, the company's nursery superintendent, and Reuben Almanza, a migrant worker who has been coming north annually from Texas to work McKay's fields for 35 years, were lauded by business leaders and President Clinton at the foundation's annual awards ceremony in New York.
McKay's award was a public reminder that many Americans are angered or embarrassed every time they are confronted with agribusiness's reliance on impoverished migrants -- and with the way many companies treat them.
Conditions have improved for the nation's one million farm workers since Edward R. Murrow's shocking 1960 CBS documentary "Harvest of Shame." Most now get unemployment insurance, Social Security, and workers' compensation coverage, clean water and access to toilets.
After adjusting for inflation, though, wages have been declining for 20 years, as illegal immigrants continue to flood the labor market. The most recent Department of Labor surveys estimate that the number of illegal aliens working on farms jumped from less than 10 percent in the 1988-89 crop year to 37 percent in 1994-95. Labor leaders say the actual figures are higher.
Meanwhile, many seasonal workers have seen their cost of living soar. Employers have avoided charges that they provide substandard housing by simply shifting to the workers the burden of finding housing and transportation to work.
Nor have the most flagrant abuses entirely disappeared. Just last month, three men pleaded guilty in South Carolina to enslaving migrant workers who had illegally entered the country from Mexico.
"There's rampant violations of the minimum wage laws," Bruce Goldstein, director of the Farmworker Justice Fund in Washington, said.
Debate about migrants is an annual event in Congress. This year, growers support a Senate bill to make it easier to import more "guest workers" -- foreign nationals who are allowed to enter the United States temporarily for specific employers. Farm employers say there are not enough natives and legal immigrants to meet their needs.
But critics say that the growers are simply trying to avoid paying higher wages and that unemployment remains high among farm workers. The Labor Department estimated in its most recent study that 190,000, or 12 percent, were unemployed in 1994. Hearings have not yet been scheduled on the Senate bill.
At McKay, wages are legal but meager by any measure. New migrants start at $6 an hour, far less than the $7.50-an-hour average for farm workers in the Great Lakes region. Just 30 hours a week of work is guaranteed, though migrants can count on the typical spring workload being almost double that. After 35 years, Mr. Almanza's base wage has risen to just $9.50 an hour.
In California, which has half the nation's farm workers, the union wages paid at Dole Fresh Foods, start at almost $7.50 an hour plus piecework bonuses that lift the average to more than $9. And migrant workers can easily find jobs paying $12 an hour or more in meatpacking operations here in the upper Midwest.
But McKay's other benefits and advancement opportunities keep far more than 90 percent of its migrant workers returning year after year. Ten of McKay's 60 year-round employees, including several key managers, are former migrants whose early stints on its payroll lasted only through the 10 weeks of spring when the company is busiest shipping trees and shrubs. About 60 migrants have moved into jobs that keep them on the payroll eight months annually, long enough to work the minimum 1,000 hours needed to receive bonus payments in company stock along with the year-round staff.
Eligible migrant workers receive bonuses equal to 20 percent to 25 percent of their wages in stock or cash; the mix depends on how much stock is available to distribute in a given year. It comes to at least $2,000 worth of stock or cash each year for even the lowest-paid worker, Mr. Mason said.
The stock, which is not traded publicly, is revalued each August by an outside accounting firm. Mr. Mason said it had been steadily appreciating but declined to disclose the most recent price. McKay does not release financial performance data, but filings with industry associations and statements about the breakdown of sales suggest that annual revenue is about $15 million.
The beneficiaries of the McKay stock plan include Monsies Gomez, who has risen to second-in-command of daily operations, and his wife, Juanita, who became a full-time worker in 1974. Mrs. Gomez, who plans to retire this August at age 55, figured she would not have to work again, thanks to the money the couple expect to receive from selling her stock back to the company.
"I never expected to see this when I started," said Mrs. Gomez, who declined to say how much the sale should bring. McKay has set up a financial counseling program to arm its migrant employees against bad advice from investment advisers.
Employees are required to sell their stock to the company when they retire, which limits its value. Mr. Mason worries about outsiders trying to convince employees to eliminate that restriction in the stock plan, risking loss of control of the company in return for a short-term gain in the value of the shares.
McKay is uneasy about being cast as a model of progressive migrant labor policy. Indeed, in horticultural terms, the century-old company might be seen as a "sport," a freak of nature that pops up unexpectedly through a combination of heritage and circumstances that may not be easily duplicated. Senior executives stress that McKay's employment policies for migrant workers are just one part of a unique and sometimes stressful corporate culture.
By all accounts, the pivotal figure was Karl Junginger, who succeeded the founder, W. G. McKay, at the company's helm in 1959. Part autocrat, part father figure, Mr. Junginger used a combination of low base pay and substantial bonuses to create a strong team feeling.
The search for a tax-friendly way to pay off the small group of private investors who owned the company, make sure it remained independent and prepare for Mr. Junginger eventual retirement led to the sale of all of the company's stock in 1984 to an employee stock ownership plan, or ESOP.
"The ESOP is the current embodiment of the feeling Karl created," said Mr. Mason, who had been a grocery clerk and life insurance salesman before joining the company as a 20-year-old apprentice. He was 43 when he became president in 1988, three years before Mr. Junginger's death.
Migrants and former migrants make up about half the ESOP membership (though they own considerably less than half the shares) but that is not the only thing unusual about McKay's stock plan. Most such plans own less than a majority of a company. McKay's plan owns 100 percent.
Mr. Mason has always envisioned the stock plan as a tool to goad all his employees to feel more responsibility for improving operations throughout the company. "It's an excuse for changing the culture to get more bottom-up participation," Mr. Mason said.
But other managers, whom he encouraged a visitor to interview, say that process went too far in the early years and may still need reining in.
"This is the greatest company in the country to work for, but people have way too intense discussions about small things," said Jerry Draeger, the executive vice president. "The ESOP concept is beautiful, but it had gone to the extreme where you couldn't make a decision without a committee of 12."
At the same time, he and others said, some lower-level employees made costly mistakes by assuming they had the authority to do what they wanted without direction from upper management.
One positive outcome, however, is that immigrant shareholders, while generally more reticent than their American-born counterparts, have still had a remarkably open window on how the business operates and have begun to take more responsibility.
The employee stock plan is not the only peculiarity shaping McKay's award-winning employment policies; indeed, they might not be possible were it not for the economics of the nursery business. The trees and shrubs produced by the nation's 5,000 nurseries are a high-priced crop. Total receipts of $10.4 billion last year were higher than those for crops like cotton and wheat that involve many more farms and millions of acres.
Nurseries are also labor-intensive. For McKay, the value of each plant and the company's investment in labor -- 50 cents for every $1 in revenue -- create an unusually strong need compared with other farmers to reduce turnover and training costs.
Farm labor leaders also note that nurseries can attract the cream of the migrant work force because they offer jobs that last longer than picking a season's produce or fruit. McKay's location may also have figured in its evolving employment policies: The farther employers of seasonal workers are from Texas or California -- the main marketplaces for hirings of migrants -- the more benefits they must offer to recruit workers.
Could McKay's deal for migrants get sweeter still? Mr. Almanza, for one, said that the company ought to offer medical insurance. Indeed, in California, unionized farm workers with the best contracts enjoy not just medical coverage, but dental and vision benefits and paid vacations.
Matching those standards would be a challenge for McKay, because the company needs to control labor costs to stay competitive with other nurseries, especially as it expands from its primary markets in Minneapolis, lower Wisconsin and Chicago.
Still, even union members see plenty to envy in McKay's approach. "I've never heard of giving stock to migrants," said Doug Blaylock, an administrator of the United Farm Workers Union pension plan in Keene, Calif. "I think it's fantastic."

HEADLINE: CLINTON SHARPLY TIGHTENS AIR POLLUTION REGULATIONS DESPITE CONCERN OVER COSTS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
President Clinton today approved significantly tighter pollution limits on deadly soot and choking smog, while offering states and cities substantial flexibility in deciding how to reach the new goals over the next 10 years and beyond.
The action, one of the most important environmental decisions of the decade, ended a fierce behind-the-scenes battle. Mr. Clinton sided with the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol M. Browner, against the concerns of his economic advisers, who had balked in the face of industry complaints that the rules would cost far more than they were worth. 
 The White House put aside many of those economic concerns once Vice President Al Gore jumped into the fray last week, after lobbying by environmental groups, Administration officials said today.
And in the end, Ms. Browner made relatively modest changes to the rule her agency proposed last November.
Announcing his decision in a speech in Tennessee, the President cast it as an initiative to protect children, a favorite theme for the Administration. In this case, he cited especially the asthmatics who are most at risk from exposure to ozone and small particles of soot, two common pollutants caused by burning fossil fuels.
"I approved some very strong new regulations today that will be somewhat controversial, but I think kids ought to be healthy," Mr. Clinton said at a conference on families at which Mr. Gore was the host.
The rules are expected to have wide-ranging practical effects. For example, old power plants in the Midwest may have to install the kind of expensive pollution-control equipment that is already commonly used in much of the Northeast, where the air is dirtier. Also, states will probably have to put more money into mass transit and other measures to reduce pollution from automobiles.
In addition, some factories like steel plants that burn lots of coal may be required to adapt their equipment to cleaner-burning fuels to avoid emissions of soot. And even the United States Forest Service may have to change the way it sets controlled fires on public lands to avoid sending too much smoke into the air.
The air pollution regulation is one of two major environmental issues on the President's agenda this week, both of them intensely debated and each of them dividing one of the Administration's core constituencies, environmentalists, from business groups that the Administration does not want to alienate. On Thursday, he is to outline the Administration's policies on global warming to a United Nations conference in New York, where the United States has been criticized by European states for not moving swiftly enough to control emissions of carbon dioxide.
Although the pollutants are different and the problems they cause are not directly related, both global warming and the soot and smog issues addressed today stem largely from the combustion of fossil fuels.
Like the efforts to negotiate a binding treaty to limit emissions of gases that cause global warming, the Administration's decision on air quality rules faced an enormous campaign of opposition by industry and equally determined efforts by environmentalists who supported it.
"The final product, I am delighted to say, is a major step forward for protecting the public health of the people of this country," said Ms. Browner, whose adamant defense of the proposals was described by her backers as courageous and principled, but by her detractors as stubborn and close-minded. "These new standards will provide new health protections to 125 million Americans, including 35 million children."
She spoke at a White House briefing that included officials who for weeks have argued over the rules.
Those millions of people, E.P.A. officials said, live in hundreds of counties that will eventually have to impose new pollution control measures to meet the new standards.
The agency has claimed, based on epidemiological studies, that 15,000 people die every year from exposure to these pollutants, especially the fine sooty particles. And the agency expects that hundreds of thousands of acute asthma attacks can be avoided each year, since smog often triggers breathing difficulties in children with that disease.
By putting the new controls into place, states with relatively clean air will also be helping to clean the air in New York and other downwind states where the air is generally dirtier. Across most of the Northeast, a significant fraction of the chronic air pollution blows in from the Midwest.
Under the Clean Air Act, the E.P.A. must set health-based standards for air quality without regard to the potential expense. States where the air violates these standards must then impose pollution controls that can cost industries billions of dollars and inconvenience motorists. The drive to tighten the standards touched off a huge lobbying campaign over the past two years, led by auto makers, electric utilities, fuel suppliers and manufacturers.
Although the final rules are not quite as aggressive as the version that was first proposed, they are nonetheless a significant milestone in the long struggle against unhealthy air. The last time the ozone standard was changed, nearly 20 years ago, it was weakened. The tiniest particles of sooty chemicals, so small that they lodge deep in the lungs, have never been controlled before under the Clean Air Act.
Some of the expected health benefits from the new regulations will not be felt until at least 2003 in the case of smog and 2008 in the case of soot, officials said. In the meantime, steps that are already under way to control pollution should continue to provide more modest gains.
A coalition of powerful industry groups denounced the decision as "crushing blow" to the economy, and urged Congress to overturn it.
"The Administration lacked the courage to do what is right," said Charles J. DiBona of the American Petroleum Institute, a leader of the coalition. "Those who worked hard to bring reason to the debate, including some 250 members of Congress, 27 governors and more than a thousand mayors and other state, county and local officials, were simply ignored."
Environmental groups highly praised the new standards and raised no objections to the flexible approach the Administration is offering to put the rules in place.
"They really stood up to the worst that industry could throw at them," said Philip Clapp, the head of the Environmental Information Center, who had lobbied hard on the issue and criticized Mr. Gore last week for not intervening strongly enough.
Mr. Clapp and other environmentalists said they believed that when Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore focused on the rule in the past week or so, they acted decisively to favor the Administration's green faction. "They were extremely mindful of the fact that they had campaigned extensively on the environment, and the leaders of the Administration made their decision based on the promises they had made," Mr. Clapp said.
At the White House today, Mr. Clinton's advisers sought to describe the intense interagency fight over the rules as a normal process in writing regulations, and said all sides agreed that protecting the public health was a top priority all along.
But privately, Administration officials said there was a definite dispute between economic agencies and health agencies. The Treasury Department, for example, fought Ms. Browner's proposals, while the Department of Health and Human Services supported her.
Although the fight within the Administration over the proposals is now over, the new standards continue to face opposition in Congress and in the courts.
Industry opponents are making several claims. They contend that the scientific evidence linking air pollution to illness and death is not solid enough, and the predicted health benefits not great enough, to justify such large expenditures. And they maintain that the E.P.A. failed to adequately assess the economic effects of tighter controls on small businesses, as required by a new law that gives Congress 60 days to overturn any major Federal regulation. The new rules on air quality are expected to be published in mid-July.
The new standards for ozone, a compound of oxygen in a form that corrodes tissues, call for concentrations in the air not to exceed 80 parts per billion over an eight-hour period. Places where smog exceeds that standard more than four times a year averaged over three years would have to adopt corrective measures. The existing standard is 120 parts per billion over a one-hour peak period, a measure that the agency considers flawed because brief spikes of smog show up as violations, while persistent smog at lower but still damaging levels go unprevented.
The new rules for fine particles of 2.5 microns in diameter call for daily averages not to exceed 65 micrograms per cubic meter of air, and for annual averages not to exceed 15 micrograms per cubic meter.
To provide more flexibility as states try to comply with the fine particle rule, the E.P.A. loosened its earlier proposal for the daily standard, which was to have been 50 micrograms per cubic meter. But it maintained its initial proposal for the annual standard, which is a better indicator of chronic air pollution.
The E.P.A. agreed to allow five years for constructing monitors to detect the fine particles, since they have not been regulated before, and a few years more will pass before states must actually control emissions. During that time, more scientific studies of the health effects will be conducted.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The strict new air quality require-ments are a victory for Carol M. Browner, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator. (Amy Thompson for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The New Restrictions"
Highlights of the air quality standards that President Clinton approved yesterday:
 
LIMITS ON POLLUTANTS
The rules tighten limits on smog-causing ozone to 80 parts per billion over an eight-hour period from the current 120 parts per billion and limit microscopic sooty particles for the first time.
 
WHOM IT AFFECTS
Industries and households in hundreds of counties, especially in heavily industrial states.
 
HEALTH BENEFITS
The Administration says that the sooty particles kill 15,000 people a year and that children with asthma should especially benefit from the restrictions.
 
THE OPPOSITION
Industry groups contend that the rules will cost far more than they are worth and are not supported by sound science.
 
NEXT STEPS
Congress has 60 days to review the rules once they are published next month. Court challenges are likely.

HEADLINE: Surprise Fall For Durables During May

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Orders to factories for durable goods fell unexpectedly in May, easing concern that inflationary bottlenecks might develop in the manufacturing sector. Home resales during the month also confounded analysts' expectations by increasing.
The Commerce Department said today that factory orders for the big-ticket goods, which are meant to last at least three years, decreased six-tenths of 1 percent in May, in contrast with analysts' expectations of a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent. But April's increase was revised upward, to 1.8 percent from the 1.3 percent reported originally. In March, orders fell 2.8 percent. 
 The report provided further evidence that growth had slowed sharply in the second quarter. The economy expanded at an annual rate of 5.8 percent in the first quarter -- the fastest pace in nearly a decade.
The data also helped dissipate earlier fears that factories would become swamped with orders, leading to delayed deliveries and shortages that would push up prices.
The lull suggested that the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee was unlikely to raise interest rates again soon. It meets next Tuesday and Wednesday.
Fearing the economy was overheating, the committee raised short-term interest rates in March. It left rates unchanged at its most recent meeting, on May 20.
Orders for durable goods tend to be volatile from month to month because of the erratic pattern of orders for commercial jets and military weapons. Excluding transportation equipment, durable goods orders rose two-tenths of 1 percent during May after having increased 1.6 percent in April. Excluding military hardware, orders decreased one-tenth of 1 percent after rising 1.1 percent in April.
In line with the easing pressure in manufacturing, the backlog of unfilled orders for durable goods was unchanged in May after having fallen in April and March.
May's drop in new orders was widespread, except for a strong 10.4 percent increase in orders for electronic equipment, led by demand for electronic parts and communications equipment. That helped raise orders for nonmilitary capital goods -- a barometer of business investment in modernization -- by seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Transportation orders fell 3.3 percent, with orders for vehicles and aircraft decreasing. Orders for primary metals like steel decreased 2.4 percent, and those for industrial machinery fell 1 percent. Orders for military goods plunged 12.8 percent.
Shipments, a measure of current production, fell 1.2 percent in May after an April gain of 1.3 percent and eight-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Separately, the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes jumped 4.4 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.24 million. That was the highest level since the record 4.28 million sales rate of May 1996.
Sales had fallen in April and March, and analysts had expected a decline in the latest month as well.
The association's president, Russell Booth, said May's sales reflected pent-up demand among some homeowners who were trading up to bigger houses. Sales were helped by the highest level of consumer confidence in 28 years and the lowest jobless rate in nearly 24 years.
"We expect fairly stable sales for the balance of the year," Mr. Booth said. That would bring sales in at about the 18-year high of 4.09 million reached last year.
The median price of an existing home was $123,900 in May, up 4.8 percent from a year ago. Sales rose 8.2 percent in the South, to a rate of 1.46 million, and 5.9 percent in the Midwest, to 1.07 million. Sales in the West were unchanged at a rate of 930,000. They fell 1.5 percent in the Northeast, to 660,000.

INTERNATIONAL A3-16
 
Space Station Loses Power After Collision With Ship
An unmanned cargo vessel smashed into Russia's Mir space station during a practice docking, puncturing part of the space station and knocking out much of its power supply. The collision was the most serious in space history but none of the astronauts on board were injured. A1 

Britain Offers Wider Terms
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain unveiled a new plan for all-party peace talks on Northern Ireland and offered British acceptance of simultaneous negotiations on disarming sectarian guerrillas. He challenged Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, to make an "absolute" commitment to non-violence so it could take part. A1
 
Patten a Hong Kong Favorite
Outgoing colonial Governor Christopher Patten won the approval of 79 percent of Hong Kong's citizens, a recent poll found; Tung Chee-hwa, the shipping tycoon chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong after it returns to Chinese control next Tuesday, won the support of only 57 percent. Mr. Patten was the first Governor to grant Hong Kong's people the right to elect members of their legislature. The move prompted Beijing, which will abolish the legislative council, to call Mr. Patten "a sinner for a thousand generations." A3
 
Mexican Governor to Keep Visa
United States diplomats in Mexico City have rejected a proposal to revoke the American visa of Manlio Fabio Beltrones, the powerful governor of the state of Sonora, which borders Arizona. The decision irked law enforcement officials and intelligence analysts who suspect Mr. Beltrones is linked to major drug traffickers. Mr. Beltrones has vehemently denied any such links. A16
 
Albright Scraps Cambodia Visit
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright canceled plans to visit Cambodia this Friday due to security concerns, her spokesman said. Ms. Albright had planned to press the country's co-premiers to stop factional violence that led to clashes last week, and to work toward holding elections next year. (Agence France-Presse)
 
U.N. Releases Drug Report
The World Drug Report, commissioned by the United Nations, estimated that about 140 million people -- nearly 2.5 percent of the world's population -- smoke marijuana and its derivative, hashish. The report said that the international business of illicit drugs generates as much as $400 billion a year in revenues, equal to 8 percent of all international trade.

Egyptian Court Reverses Ban
An Egyptian court has outlawed a year-old ban on the ritual cutting of female genitals. The decision, which outraged human rights advocates but was celebrated by Islamic leaders, allows the traditional practice in all state and private clinics but prohibited the operation by those untrained in medical practices. Clinton Backs E.P.A. Plan For Tighter Pollution Limits

Browner, against the concerns of his economic advisers, who had been sympathetic to industry complaints that the rules will cost far more than they are worth. A1
 
Court Voids Law on Religion
The Supreme Court said that Congress exceeded its authority when it passed a law four years ago to give the practice of religion more protection than the Court itself has found to be constitutionally required. The 6-to-3 decision to strike down the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, was a forceful reminder of judicial power and a warning to the other branches of Government not to trespass into the Court's domain.
