HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Power of Unity

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In every struggle for human rights, the time comes when governments that rule by repression can no longer block penalties by the democracies.
They lose that power when people of free countries who differ on other important matters decide to use their combined political weight against religious and political persecution in the dictatorships. 
 Movement toward that unity of purpose is beginning between many American conservatives and liberals. Some are motivated by longtime revulsion against China's system of rule by oppression and U.S. appeasement of Beijing during the Bush and Clinton Administrations.
Other Americans have awakened to the persecution of Christians in China and about a dozen other Communist and Muslim countries. They add a critical new engine against religious oppression, and so for all human rights. Name a country that has wiped out either political or religious freedom, and permits the other to flourish.
Americans fighting the Chinese repression and the strengthening of Beijing by American business took an expected loss on Tuesday. The House of Representatives defeated another attempt to make China pay the price of increased tariffs for its persecutions. The bill gained 30 more votes than last year but went down because of the political pressure of the Clinton Administration, whose betrayal of human rights in China has made it Beijing's prisoner, and the money power of the U.S.-China business lobby. It was a sorrowful defeat for the Chinese and Tibetans in slave-labor camps.
But in Washington and across the country Americans long in the human rights struggle and those new to it are just beginning to fight.
Beginning this summer, a hopper full of bills will be presented, aimed at Chinese political and religious oppression. Among them will be a package from Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, a strong fighter for human rights.
One bill would increase tariffs for the hundreds of companies owned by the Chinese Army, which uses profits to make itself bigger and better. Another would tighten the ban on slave labor goods, or try to. Others would cut off American contributions to loans to China from international organizations like the World Bank and mandate annual U.S. reports on Chinese manipulation of American politics with money or espionage.
Another goal: to hamper Chinese sale of nuclear, chemical and cruise-missile material and technology. To be believable, the legislation should include Congressional investigation and disclosure of all the cases the Clinton Administration knew about, but would not act on.
No proposed legislation will be as effective a human rights message to China and the world as taking away Beijing's tariff privileges -- an effort that will go on in Congress.
But the bills will speak for America against tyranny. They will also test the good faith of Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Congressmen. They opposed ending China's tariff privileges across the board. But they promised to support other action to fight rule by terror in China.
Then in the fall, as part of a campaign against religious persecution leading up to an International Day of Prayer, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Representative Frank Wolf of Virginia, both Republicans, will present another bill. It is a call for action against all countries persecuting Christians, Buddhists and members of the Bahai faith -- as in Iran. It will include a variety of sanctions against persecuting countries, such as withholding international loans; make immigration to the U.S. easier for victims of religious oppression, and set up a special office in the White House to monitor and report on religious persecution.
Congressional action would then have two spearheads -- against Chinese repression of all human rights, and against religious persecution internationally. The combination would be logical -- and doable if American unity for human rights holds.
After World War II, much of the Western left edged off from the fight for human rights in Communist countries. Conservatives looked away almost everywhere else. The losers were the people in the cells.
So if the still-developing and largely untested unity can be preserved it will be of historic importance in the fight for human rights, and the revival of America's role in it.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Apple Computer is seeking to burnish its results by finding a new agency for its domestic account.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THEY say the apple doesn't fall far from the tree, but a big bite of the Apple Computer Inc. account has finally fallen from its longtime perch.
Apple, struggling to reverse a severe slump in sales and profits, said yesterday that it would begin a review on the largest portion of its worldwide account: the domestic duties, with billings estimated at $80 million to $90 million, handled since 1986 by BBDO West. 
 But BBDO West abruptly resigned those duties, effective on Sept. 30 -- thereby cutting the longest ties between a major computer company and its agency -- by refusing a request to take part in the review.
"We've been a very loyal and committed partner," said David Lubars, chief executive and chief creative officer at BBDO West in Los Angeles. "But like a relationship, you just know when it's over."
The review on the American portion of the Apple account caused some confusion as to whether BBDO Worldwide, the global agency to which BBDO West reports, would retain its international Apple accounts, with billings estimated at $50 million to $60 million. Mr. Lubars and Apple executives said, however, that the review involved only the domestic duties, though they differed on the billings; Mr. Lubars estimated them at $45 million.
The sudden coming change in Apple's American sales pitches is indicative of the substantive shifts that are roiling Madison Avenue as more giant consumer product marketers, in categories from automobiles to fast food to computers, reassess their agency ties in the face of increasing competition. Accounts with billings of more than $1 billion have been placed in review so far this year by blue-chip advertisers such as BankAmerica, Black & Decker, GTE, Saab, Samsonite, Sun Microsystems and Taco Bell.
"BBDO has made a great contribution to Apple," said David Roman, vice president for advertising and brand communications at Apple in Cupertino, Calif. "We have had many, many successful campaigns."
"This is not driven specifically by BBDO's performance," he added. "We're just making sure we have the best advertising we can get."
Speculation that Apple was unhappy with BBDO West has persisted for several years, intensifying in the wake of the serious, sustained slide in Apple's financial results as computer users spurned Macintosh computers for those that use Microsoft and Intel products. Apple reported a loss of $708 million in its second quarter ending March 28, more than analysts expected, as sales declined 27 percent, to $1.6 billion.
The speculation about worms gnawing at the core of the relationship between Apple and BBDO West -- which has created campaigns with themes such as "The power to be your best" -- gained strength as Apple frequently changed marketing and operating executives.
"The reason for doing this is not so much to take some dramatic action to save the company," Mr. Roman said. "It's part of a process of refocusing our marketing efforts to support the business better."
Allen Rosenshine, chairman and chief executive at BBDO Worldwide in New York, owned by Omnicom Group, took issue with that.
"Apple executives are looking to do something dramatic, and as part of the drama they're looking for a new agency," he said in a telephone interview from London.
"I do understand why they're doing it," he added, "but that doesn't make it right."
Computer industry analysts expressed doubts about the ability of an agency change to improve Apple's faltering performance.
"It is very late in the day, and advertising alone will not solve Apple's problems," said Gary Stibel, a principal at the New England Consulting Group in Westport, Conn., who specializes in technology marketing. "Apple has got to figure out a way to break out of the box."
Only "great advertising in concert with product news has the potential to significantly improve the current situation," he added, "which is not very positive."
James Poyner, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company in New York, was equally pointed.
"I wish Apple's only problem was advertising," he said in an interview with Bloomberg News, adding that Apple executives "are trying to hold body and soul together until they can get their next-generation technology out." That reference was to new operating system software, code-named Rhapsody, to be released next year.
Mr. Lubars at BBDO West said that Mr. Roman had notified him of the review on Tuesday, adding that he spoke with Mr. Rosenshine on Wednesday and then informed Mr. Roman that BBDO West would reject the invitation to participate.
"I have a lot of mixed feelings," Mr. Lubars said. "Obviously there were tensions between us, but that goes on with all clients."
"I still believe it's the superior technology, the way the world should've gone," he added, referring to Macintosh, which has steadily lost ground to Microsoft's Windows.
Mr. Roman said that he and other Apple executives had hoped BBDO would take part in the review.
But "there's always that chance," he added, that an incumbent will decline to participate.
Indeed, big agencies have become more willing to quit than fight, walking away from large accounts after surprise reviews are called. Since January, agencies such as Grey Advertising Inc. and two units of the Interpublic Group of Companies, Ammirati Puris Lintas and Lowe & Partners/SMS, resigned rather than undergo reviews for accounts such as Domino's Pizza, Mastercard and Nabisco Foods.
"We're not petulant," Mr. Rosenshine said. "It's not a BBDO policy to refuse to participate in a review. You look at it case by case."
"But with Apple," he added, "I couldn't ask our people, considering what they've gone through in the last three or four years, to go through it and lose -- which is what I think would have happened."
Mr. Roman said that Apple would seek an agency to create ads to burnish Apple's brand image for the mass media and peddle products to current customers in specialized media. The goal is to hire one shop, he added, but duties may be divided.
Mr. Roman declined to identify the agencies in the review because, he said, they are only now being contacted. The trade publication Advertising Age suggested contenders with computer experience like the Bates USA unit of Bates Worldwide, owned by Cordiant P.L.C.; the CKS Partners unit of CKS Group in Cupertino; Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, and Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco.
Advertising Age also mentioned the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom in Venice, Calif. That shop is the successor to Chiat/Day, which created the spectacular, successful spot for Apple titled "1984" but stumbled the next year with a dour commercial called "Lemmings" and lost Apple to BBDO West in 1986.
"But the question is how desirable Apple is as an account," said Bradley Johnson, the national technology editor for Advertising Age in Los Angeles. "If you are a hot agency, do you want to lock yourself into a troubled and apparently declining company in an industry that's the fastest-growing part of the economy?"
That question echoes for BBDO Worldwide, too, because that agency was invited by I.B.M. in 1994 to take part in a closed review for its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $400 million to $500 million. BBDO executives said they would rather stick with Apple.
"We believed in Apple, and that's how I still feel," Mr. Lubars said.
Asked whether BBDO West would now get rid of all of its many Macintoshes, he replied, laughing: "No. Not anytime soon, anyway."
As for layoffs at BBDO West after Apple's departure, Mr. Lubars said they would be minimal because of recent account gains. About 40 to 50 members of the staff of fewer than 200 people work on Apple, he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Falter; The Dow Ends 35.73 Lower

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stock prices closed lower yesterday as Wall Street's nerves were again rattled by another rise in long-term bond interest rates ahead of next week's meeting of the policy-setting Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee.
Worries about the quality of second-quarter corporate profits also cut into stocks, analysts said. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended 35.73 points lower at 7,654.25.
In the broader market, declining issues narrowly outpaced advancers, 1,460 to 1,339, on heavy New York Stock Exchange volume of 503.8 million shares. The Nasdaq composite index lost 9.86 points, to 1,436.38. And the Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 5.31 points, to 883.68.
It was the fourth day this week that stocks were subject to sharp swings. On Monday, the Dow had its second-biggest point loss ever as it dropped 192.25 points, followed by Tuesday's recovery of 153.80 points and Wednesday's 68.08-point fall.
Since the beginning of May, the blue-chip Dow index has risen nearly 700 points, or 9.7 percent, fostering doubts about whether the run-up still had staying power.
"People are nervous as cats out there and they are doing some selling to nail down profits," said Marshall Acuff, the chief investment strategist for Smith Barney.
Analysts said stocks were jarred by the steady rise in long-term interest rates, which have advanced for four straight days.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32 , raising its yield to 6.78 percent, from 6.73 percent on Wednesday. The price and yield move in opposite directions.
More warnings of lower second-quarter profits from the technology company Komag Inc. also helped to cool investors' ardor for stocks, analysts said.
"For the past three quarters, there has been a sense of hesitancy and nervousness in the month before earnings get reported when profit warnings come out," Mr. Acuff said. "We are heading into the reporting period, and this quarter shouldn't be any different."
Wall Street was also on edge ahead of the meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee, though most economists do not expect a credit tightening until the panel's August meeting at the earliest.
The stocks of computer disk drive companies slumped after Komag, of San Jose, Calif., said that its profits for the second quarter and the rest of the year would fall short of analyst expectations.
The stock, the most heavily traded on Nasdaq, fell 6 7/8 a share, to 16 11/16 . Shares of rival disk drive makers also fell: Seagate Technology was off 1/8 at 33 1/2 and the Read-Rite Corporation lost 2 1/8, to 20 1/16 .
Technology and drug stocks, which have led the market higher recently, lost ground. Pharmacia & Upjohn shed 13/16 a share, to 34 1/16 ; Johnson & Johnson fell 1 5/16 , to 63 7/8, and Warner-Lambert was off 2 3/4 at 119.
Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. surged 11 9/16 , to 91, after its French parent company, Rhone-Poulenc S.A., said it was considering a $4.3 billion bid to buy the stake of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer it does not already own.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
TriBeCa Lofts Are Growing, and Growing Larger

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Manhattan's heated housing market continues to fuel the conversion of old manufacturing buildings into loft condominiums in TriBeCa, where developers are trying to meet a demand they say still outstrips the supply.
"Throughout lower Manhattan, there is a virtual explosion of housing, and TriBeCa is part of it," said Paul Goldstein, district manager of Community Board 1, which tries to guide the area's growth. He said there are more conversions in TriBeCa now than during the heyday of the mid- to late 1980's. 
 Estimates from the community board are that in the last two years 250 loft apartments have been completed or are under way, and some 300 more are planned. That, along with rising prices, has bolstered the neighborhood's transformation, which began in the 1980's but was stalled by the recession.
Mr. Goldstein said the conversion activity is also "working its way northward" from Duane Street, the neighborhood's core, and bringing in "other types of developments," like restaurants and theaters.
Three projects illustrate the current activity. Work started early this month at a 56-unit project on North Moore. A 30-unit project on Duane is winding down its sales campaign. Construction also will start soon on a conversion of up to 42 units, which includes a six-screen movie theater, also on North Moore.
The conversion boom has been aided by zoning changes adopted by the City Council in 1995 affecting a 45-block area in TriBeCa. The regulations permit new construction and conversions south of North Moore to residential, business and art uses. Such conversions still require special permits from the City Planning Commission north of North Moore and Walker Streets.
The new projects are different in several ways from those of the 1980's, brokers said. Most offer larger apartments, averaging 2,400 square feet. They are also condominiums, reflecting consumer preference toward that more flexible form of ownership over the restrictiveness of co-ops.
Many of the larger new developments also come with more services than those of the last decade. Among them are 24-hour doormen, concierges and live-in superintendents.
"The new product has broadened the base of buyers," said Pamela Liebman, managing partner at the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan brokerage. In addition to artists and entertainers, today's buyers also include professionals in the finance and media industries, empty nesters and families, including some from the Upper East and West sides.
Sales are steady, prices are rising and "there are no signs that demand is waning," added Jeffrey Tabak, who runs Tabak Real Estate in TriBeCa. He said prices for existing lofts, which fell by as much as 30 percent since the market's downturn in 1990, have rebounded and surpassed their 1987 peak.
In its midyear survey, the Corcoran Group reports that existing loft apartments, with 2,250 square feet, sold on average for $322 a square foot, or $724,500. The firm puts the average sales price for new lofts at $400 a square foot, with some going as high as $500.
"I would not say prices have peaked," Ms. Liebman said. But she added, "It will be difficult to achieve prices too far beyond the $500 a square foot level in the near future."
Sales began four months ago at the 12-story Duane Park building, at 166 Duane, which Hudu Development of Manhattan turned into 30 lofts, at sizes from 2,700 square feet to nearly 6,000. Contracts have been signed or are pending on 23 units at the building, which will offer a concierge. Prices range from $695,000 to $3.7 million with monthly maintenance fees, including taxes, from $1,259 to $4,834
"The demand is being driven by young Wall Street families," said Mark S. Blau, Hudu's president. Initial occupancy will start this fall and be completed by year's end, he said.
Work started three weeks ago on the conversion to 56 lofts of the former John Ericsson Ice House, a 10-story, 1905 Renaissance Revival structure at 27 North Moore. It is being done by Jack Lefkowitz and Joseph Pell Lombardi, who is also the project's architect.
The design calls for restoring the building's exterior, installing windows in its now mostly windowless facade and carving a courtyard from its core. The last will allow more light to the building and provide each loft, ranging from 1,600 to 4,700 square feet with exposures on the street and on the courtyard. The cut-away space will be relocated as two and a half floors for penthouses, said Mr. Lombardi.
Prices for the lofts will be $425 a square foot and monthly common charges, including taxes, will be $1,600 to $4,700. Amenities will include an exercise room and a concierge.
Next month, work is to begin on the conversion of the 16-story Atalanta Building at 25 North Moore into up to 42 lofts and a movie theater on the first five floors. Most of the apartments will have 1,035 to 2,500 square feet, and the penthouses will have 5,000 square feet, but all will be offered as unfinished space and can be combined, said George L. Olsen. Mr. Olsen and Martin Shaw are general managing partners of 25 North Moore Associates, which is developing the project. Mr. Olsen said prices will be competitive.
The intent is to provide buyers with smaller units that are not now available and with flexibility to design their own space, he said, noting, "We do not see demand abating."

HEADLINE: Rules Alone Won't Clean the Air

BYLINE: By Richard M. Daley; Richard M. Daley is the Mayor of Chicago.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
This week's announcement that the Environmental Protection Agency will move forward with recommendations for significantly tighter limits on air pollution is both encouraging and disappointing.
I am encouraged by President Clinton's assurances that the new regulations will be flexible and sensible and not single out large metropolitan areas for punishment. 
 But unfortunately, the new E.P.A. regulations include no new ideas. Everyone wants less soot and smog -- especially residents of large cities, where pollution is the biggest problem. But setting tougher pollution standards will not give us cleaner air.
Indeed, good standards, if carried out badly, can adversely affect public health and the environment. The major cause of smog and soot in cities is no longer industry, which has cleaned up its act, but automobile emissions. Yet the new clean air regulations could encourage suburban sprawl (and thus more cars), while hurting the development of industrial jobs in the cities.
That's what happened with the Government's Superfund program, which was supposed to speed the cleanup of polluted sites. But because of liability problems associated with the Superfund, contaminated property is almost certain to be abandoned. Industry won't invest in this property; neither will lenders.
This has happened thousands of times in cities across the country: jobs and capital are encouraged to flee to the suburbs and beyond. The result is more people in cars driving to and from work, and more air pollution.
The new clean air regulations could have an equally devastating effect. For instance, if a city is having trouble meeting the new standards, a moratorium could be placed on industrial development. Industry moves out, promoting more traffic and suburban sprawl.
Cities need real programs to clean up the air. For example, Chicago has a new program, Brownfields, aimed at correcting the failures of the Superfund. The city is reclaiming abandoned, polluted inner-city industrial property. This reclamation cleans the environment and brings jobs into the city. Congress is considering several bills that would help cities rebuild their industrial sites.
But the Government must do a better job of planning how cleaner air will be achieved. For instance, highway construction still takes first priority, while urban mass transit receives less and less Federal money. It is left to the cities and states to give mass transit more money in order to meet the new clean air standards.
This week at a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors, many mayors, from Susan Savage of Tulsa, Okla., to Dennis Archer of Detroit, expressed concerns about the new E.P.A. standards. Together under the leadership of Mayor Paul Helmke of Fort Wayne, Ind., the conference will work toward a more flexible approach to this problem.
But serious questions have been raised about whether the E.P.A. has the legal authority to be flexible. Congress should act to insure that the new standards will be carried out with the common sense that has been promised. This may require rewriting the Clean Air Act to make it fairer to cities by making it less reliant on punitive sanctions and enforcement.
Action must match rhetoric. Without a real Federal plan to meet the new standards, taxpayers won't be getting the cleaner air they deserve.

HEADLINE: CLINTON AT THE U.N.;
Clinton on the Global Environment: Some Progress but Much More Still to Be Done

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's address to the United Nations environmental conference yesterday, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:
Five years ago in Rio, the nations of the world joined together around a simple but revolutionary proposition: that today's progress must not come at tomorrow's expense. 
 In our era, the environment has moved to the top of the international agenda because how well a nation honors it will have an impact, for good or ill, not only on the people of that nation, but all across the globe. Preserving the resources we share is crucial not only for the quality of our individual environments and health, but also to maintain stability and peace within nations and among them.
As the father of conservation in our nation, John Muir, said, "When we try to pick anything out by itself, we find it hitched to everything else in the universe."
In the years since Rio there has been real progress in some areas. Nations have banned the dumping of radioactive wastes in the ocean and reduced marine pollution from sources on land. We're working to protect the precious coral reefs, to conserve threatened fish, to stop the advance of deserts. At the Cairo Conference on Population and Development, we reaffirmed the crucial importance of cooperative family planning efforts to long-term sustainable development.
Here in America, we have worked to clean up a record number of our toxic dumps, and we intend to clean 500 more over the next four years. We've passed new laws to better protect our water, created new national parks and monuments, and worked to harmonize our efforts for environmental protection, economic growth, and social improvement, aided by a distinguished Council on Sustainable Development.
Yesterday I announced the most far-reaching efforts to improve air quality in our nation in 20 years, cutting smog levels dramatically and, for the first time ever, setting standards to lower the levels of the fine particles in the atmosphere that form soot. In America, the incidence of childhood asthma has been increasing rapidly. It is now the single biggest reason our children are hospitalized. These measures will help to change that, to improve health of people of all ages, and to prevent as many as 15,000 premature deaths a year.
Still, we here have much more to do, especially in reducing America's contribution to global climate change. The science is clear and compelling: We humans are changing the global climate.
Concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are at their highest levels in more than 200,000 years and climbing sharply. If the trend does not change, scientists expect the seas to rise two feet or more over the next century. In America, that means 9,000 square miles of Florida, Louisiana and other coastal areas will be flooded; in Asia, 17 percent of Bangladesh, land on which six million people now live, will be lost; island chains such as the Maldives will disappear from the map unless we reverse the predictions.
Climate changes will disrupt agriculture, cause severe droughts and floods and the spread of infectious diseases, which will be a big enough problem for us under the best of circumstances in the 21st century. There could be 50 million or more cases of malaria a year. We can expect more deaths from heat stress. Just two years ago here in the United States in the city of Chicago, we saw the tragedy of more than 400 of our citizens dying during a severe heat wave.
No nation can escape this danger. None can evade its responsibility to confront it, and we must all do our part, industrial nations that emit the largest quantities of greenhouse gases today, and developing nations whose greenhouse gas emissions are growing rapidly.
I applaud the European Union for its strong focus on this issue and the World Bank for setting environmental standards for projects it will finance in the developing world.
Here in the United States, we must do better. With 4 percent of the world's population, we already produce more than 20 percent of its greenhouse gases.
Frankly, our record since Rio is not sufficient. We have been blessed with high rates of growth and millions of new jobs over the last few years, but that has led to an increase in greenhouse-gas emissions in spite of the adoption of new conservation practices. So we must do better, and we will.
The air-quality action I took on yesterday is a positive first step, but many more must follow. In order to reduce greenhouse gases and grow the economy, we must invest more in the technologies of the future. I am directing my Cabinet to work to develop them. Government, universities, business and labor must work together. All these efforts must be sustained over years, indeed, over decades. As Vice President Gore said Monday, "Sustainable development requires sustained commitment." With that commitment, we can succeed.
We must create new technologies and develop new strategies like emissions trading that will both curtail pollution and support continued economic growth. We owe that in the developed world to ourselves, and equally to those in the developing nations. Many of the technologies that will help us to meet the new air quality standards in America can also help address climate change. This is a challenge we must undertake immediately, and one in which I personally plan to play a critical role.
In the United States, in order to do our part, we have to first convince the American people and the Congress that the climate change problem is real and imminent. I will convene a White House Conference on Climate Change later this year to lay the scientific facts before our people to understand that we must act, and to lay the economic facts there so that they will understand the benefits and the costs. With the best ideas and strategies, and new technologies and increased productivity and energy efficiency, we can turn the challenge to our advantage.
We will work with our people, and we will bring to the Kyoto conference a strong American commitment to realistic and binding limits that will significantly reduce our emissions of greenhouse gases.
I want to mention three other initiatives briefly that we are taking to deal with climate change and to advance sustainable development here and beyond our borders.
First, to help developing nations reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the United States will provide a billion dollars in assistance over the next five years to support energy efficiency, develop alternative energy sources, and improve resource management to promote growth that does not have an adverse effect on the climate.
Second, we will do more to encourage private investment to meet environmental standards. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation will now require that its projects adhere to new and strengthened environmental guidelines, just as our Export-Import Bank already does, and as I hope our allies and friends soon will. Common guidelines for responsible investment clearly would lead to more sustainable growth in developing nations.
Third, we must increase our use of new technologies even as we move to develop more new technologies. Already we are working with our auto industry to produce cars by early in the next century that are three times as fuel efficient as today's vehicles. Now we will work with businesses and communities to use the sun's energy to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels by installing solar panels on one million more roofs around our nation by 2010. Capturing the sun's warmth can help us to turn down the Earth's temperature.
Distinguished leaders, in all our cultures we have been taught from time immemorial that, as scripture says, "One generation passes away and another comes, but the Earth abides forever." We must strengthen our stewardship of the environment to make that true, and to insure that when this generation passes, the young man who just spoke before me, and all of those of his generation, will inherit a rich and abundant Earth.

HEADLINE: CLINTON AT THE U.N.: AN ASSESSMENT;
Pollution Politics: Clinton's Choice

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 26

 BODY:
President Clinton this week confronted the two most important environmental questions of the year, how to slow global warming and how to tighten the Clean Air Act. He satisfied the environmentalists in his constituency on the issue of smog and soot, but deeply disappointed many of them today on the question of climate change. It was a striking disparity, given that the two environmental problems have some important common roots. Soot and smog, like greenhouse gases, come mainly from burning fossil fuels. Imaginative new approaches to controlling both kinds of pollution are likely to involve plans for trading emissions credits and perfecting new technologies.
But there are important differences, and these illustrate why the President found himself seeming so torn on the overall question of what to do about air pollution. 
 For one thing, many ordinary people have immediate concerns about the smog they breathe and the way it and particles in the air can worsen the illnesses of their young children and aging parents. Not so many are worried about rising sea levels caused by melting glaciers, or about the scientific subtleties of global warming.
For another thing, President Clinton faced a pressing deadline for deciding on the new air pollution rules, which under a court order had to be issued by July. His ultimate decisions about how fast to move on global warming are not due until December, when international negotiations sponsored by the United Nations culminate in Kyoto, Japan.
And above all, fixing the global warming problem requires not just more powerful medicine, but a lot more of it, than controlling local smokestacks and tailpipes.
To satisfy the critics demanding swift and decisive action from the United States to head off global warming, Mr. Clinton would have to pledge that a nation in the midst of an energy binge was about to break its addiction to cheap fossil fuels.
And that implies an act of extraordinary political will.
At the United Nations today, Mr. Clinton promised to mobilize his own country in such an effort, but he disappointed anybody who wanted a precise plan. In the President's own crucial word, any goals he will eventually accept must be "realistic."
The industry giants who lambasted the Administration for its decision on air quality on Wednesday praised Mr. Clinton's caution on global warming today.
"We are encouraged by the fact that President Clinton seems to be taking a slightly more cautious approach to climate issues than he appeared to be taking several months ago," said Gail McDonald, president of the Global Climate Coalition, an industry group. "There are many vested interests pushing very hard for an agreement that would have dire consequences for the economy."
Several policies favored by many environmentalists are seen by the Administration as unrealistic.
Energy taxes as a way to lower fuel consumption are pretty well ruled out in Washington's current political climate. Regulations to enforce fuel-efficiency on automakers are equally out of favor.
Federico Pena, Mr. Clinton's Energy Secretary, said in an interview today that the most important thing in the President's speech was his commitment to proselytizing the public on the urgency of the problem and then to persuading the country that the solution will not be unduly painful.
"We have not done a good job of educating the American people, first about the challenges we face on global warming, and secondly about the value of making the long-term investments that actually pay back in your pocketbook," he said.
It is impossible to say, of course, whether technology breakthroughs of the kind Mr. Clinton vowed to pursue are the most realistic way of weaning America from coal and oil. Despite the progress toward wider use of photovoltaic solar cells, electric cars, fuel cells that run on hydrogen, and so on, the technical hurdles are still formidable.
"Solar energy is an important part of the long-term solution, but it is no substitute for binding targets and timetables for reducing emissions soon," said Michael Oppenheimer, chief scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund.
America is, after all, a nation where energy waste is common enough that many readily available conservation measures could pay for themselves by reducing the energy costs of businesses and households. Still, market mechanisms do not yet exist to drive investments in those directions, at least not at the speed needed to dramatically slow emissions of carbon dioxide, the principal greenhouse gas.
The Administration is working hard to develop an approach toward holding down emissions that will create pollution permits that companies can buy and sell to each other. Known as the "cap and trade" approach, it is intended to steer investments in pollution control toward the cheapest possible solutions. It pleases some environmental groups, but others view it with the suspicion of a grandmother confronted with a newfangled gadget.
But the White House appears to be persuaded by its own economists that the economic pain of abruptly taking new paths on energy consumption might be too great to bear, and that a more moderate approach is called for. Such conclusions are amplified in dire warnings from powerful industries about the dangers of moving too quickly.
Fed by an economic boom that has overwhelmed steady improvements in industrial energy efficiency, its gas-guzzling vehicles slaked by affordable gasoline, the United States appears likely to increase emissions of carbon dioxide by 13 percent in this decade. This is just the reverse of what it promised to do five years ago in Rio de Janeiro, where the industrial countries aimed to reduce greenhouse gas output to the level of 1990 by the year 2000.
As Mr. Clinton said in his speech, only 1 out of every 25 people on the planet is an American, but the fuel they burn produces one out of every five tons of the carbon dioxide that is steadily building up in the atmosphere, threatening to seriously disrupt the climate 100 or 200 years from now.
To be sure, some countries have met their targets and others are willing to promise to obey a new, binding treaty that would actually reduce greenhouse gases further. The target the European Union proposes is to cut emissions by 15 percent from the 1990 level, achieving that goal by the year 2010.
The British cut emissions when they ended subsidies for an inefficient coal industry. The Germans, after unification, tore down the obsolete state-run factories of the east. Russia met the target of reducing emissions, but only because its economy collapsed along with Communism. And as a whole, Europe does not have the aversion to energy taxes -- or taxes in general -- that has been displayed in the United States, where the Clinton Administration's first big economic policy defeat was on the BTU tax, and where just last year Congress, egged on by Bob Dole, was busily trying to roll back gas taxes because of a blip in prices at the pump.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Drop For a 2d Day; Job Data Cited

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities, with the exception of the shorter maturities, fell yesterday for a second day.
The market was hurt by a report that the number of Americans applying for unemployment dropped significantly in the latest week, hinting at possibly inflationary conditions in the labor market, and by a large supply of new corporate debt. The short end was helped by portfolio managers buying to provide window dressing for their portfolios at the end of the quarter. 
 Still, moves were limited, and analysts expect that to continue to be the case ahead of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meeting next week, as market participants anticipate that the Fed will keep interest rates at current levels.
The 30-year bond fell 17/32 , to a price of 98 2/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.78 percent, from 6.73 percent on Wednesday. In just the last two days the long bond is down 1 3/32 , or about $11 for $1,000 invested.
The Labor Department said that the number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits for the first time fell by 14,000, to 332,000, last week. Analysts had expected a drop of 5,000 jobs. Traders said the bigger-than-expected drop fueled concerns that the Fed might raise rates in an effort to slow the economy, despite the fact that other recent reports have indicated the economy is already experiencing a slowdown.
Adding to the picture of moderating growth was a report yesterday by the Conference Board that its index of help-wanted advertising in newspapers for May fell six points, to 81, the lowest level since last August.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said he believed that the drop in the index was consistent with the relatively small increase in payrolls in the Government's last monthly employment report, for May. Mr. Harris is also predicting that the June payroll number will be slightly less than the one a year earlier.
Still, the unemployment rate in the United States is now at a 23-year low of 4.8 percent, which has left many market participants concerned that employers will have to compete for workers by raising wages, passing the extra costs on to consumers.
Joel Marver, chief technical analyst with Technical Data of Boston, said that the decline in bonds yesterday was caused by the amount of new debt issued this week, from the Treasury's auction of new two- and five-year notes and new corporate debt.
"The gains scored this month have been eroded, but not completely eliminated," Mr. Marver said. "Traders note that as the market is examined from a longer-term time frame, there is still positive momentum present despite the losses of the past several days."
Contributing to the new supply on the market, Poland sold $400 million of debt yesterday in two parts through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities.
For $300 million of notes due 2004, the yield after pricing was 7.129 percent, or about 75-hundredths of a percentage point more than a comparable United States Treasury security, while $100 million of notes due 2017 was priced to yield 7.82 percent, a full point above a comparable Treasury. Both parts are noncallable and rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Study Finds Cutting Clothing Tax Costly

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
A new study concludes that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to do away with the sales tax on clothing items under $500 in New York City would have a relatively small impact on the local economy and would depress overall tax revenues more than Mr. Giuliani has estimated.
The study, released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office, found that if the 8.25 percent clothing tax were eliminated, the municipal government would lose $300 million annually in tax revenues. 
 Elimination of the tax would lead to some increase in economic activity and municipal taxes, the study said, because shoppers would buy more clothing in the city instead of going to New Jersey or other places that do not have sales taxes. For example, clothing stores might hire more people to handle the additional sales, causing an upturn in revenues from the city's income tax.
By 2001, the study said, the additional spending would raise annual revenues from the range of city taxes by at least $35 million, or 12 percent of the $300 million annual cost of the cut.
Mr. Giuliani disputed the conclusions of the Independent Budget Office, which is independent of the Mayor and the City Council. He said eliminating the clothing sales tax would generate an "enormous economic boom and opportunity in the city."
The Giuliani administration's own analysis has found that the additional tax revenues would initially cover nearly 40 percent of the cost of the cut, while also providing many indirect benefits.
 CLIFFORD J. LEVY

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1289 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON AT THE U.N.: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Defers Curbs on Gases Heating Globe

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 26

 BODY:
President Clinton told a special session of the United Nations tonight that if countries ignore the "real and imminent" problem of global warming, the earth risks severe drought, floods and the spread of infectious disease.
But, speaking a day after he sharply tightened pollution limits on soot and smog, Mr. Clinton stopped well short of the commitment to cutting greenhouse gases that allies have been urging. He deferred announcing any such restrictions -- which are opposed by automobile and oil companies and other heavy industries -- until an international meeting in December in Kyoto, Japan. 
 Mr. Clinton went further tonight than he has before in endorsing scientific findings establishing the dangers of pollution.
"The science is clear and compelling: We humans are changing the global climate," he said. "Concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are at their highest levels in more than 200,000 years and climbing sharply." [Transcript, page A11.]
Mr. Clinton's speech fit the tone of the conference, which has been attended this week by the heads of state of about 70 nations. The debate over the environment here has been marked by talk of crisis, bitter criticism of international foot-dragging and apocalyptic visions of a stricken planet.
Warning that unless changes are made, scientists expect the seas to rise by two feet or more in the next century, Mr. Clinton envisioned an America in which "9,000 square miles of Florida, Louisiana, and other coastal areas will be flooded." He spoke of an increase of 50 million or more malaria cases worldwide each year.
"No nation can escape this danger," he said. "None can evade its responsibility to confront it." Mr. Clinton noted that with 4 percent of the world's population, the United States emits 20 percent of its greenhouse gases, which are defined as carbon dioxide emissions generated by anything that burns fossil fuels like oil and coal. "Here in the United States, we must do better," he said.
But just last weekend at an annual summit meeting of industrialized nations held in Denver, Mr. Clinton fended off demands from the French and Germans that he move immediately to restrict greenhouse emissions.
Privately, his aides said the Europeans were more interested in posturing for their voters back home than in setting immediate and strict goals that could also prove difficult for them to meet.
Further, Mr. Clinton faces less pressure domestically on the issue of greenhouse gases than he did over soot and smog. While heat waves, like the one in Chicago that was blamed for more than 400 deaths two years ago, have periodically drawn public attention to the issue of global warming, on a daily basis, parents ferrying their children to baseball practice are more likely to fret about the smog.
Today, the President said he would take action on greenhouse gases later this year. He said he would "work with our people and we will bring to the Kyoto conference a strong American commitment to realistic and binding limits that will significantly reduce our emissions of greenhouse gases."
Within the Administration, Vice President Al Gore has been the house goad over the dangers of greenhouse gases. He is fond of unveiling a chart whose right side unfolds repeatedly upward to display a dramatic red spike depicting the recent global increase in carbon dioxide.
Support from environmentalists -- who were delighted by the Administration's moves against pollution on Wednesday but disappointed tonight -- is considered a key to Mr. Gore's probable Presidential bid. But it is an open question how far the Administration can afford to push energy and auto companies, and the union workers who depend on them.
Fred Krupp, head of the Environmental Defense Fund, said President Clinton's failure to set specific timetables for reduction of greenhouse gases made "instant Pablum" out of his speech, despite the promises of foreign aid and advanced research aimed at controlling climate change.
But Richard Mott, vice president of the World Wildlife Fund, called the speech "the strongest statement on climate change by any sitting U.S. President, by a wide margin." He said it was very significant that Mr. Clinton had endorsed the scientific consensus that the problem is serious, and had pledged to educate the public and persuade the Congress to address it.
Mr. Clinton promised some modest steps tonight to begin tackling the problem of climate change -- two of them intended to modify the practices of foreign countries, rather than of the United States. He promised $1 billion in assistance, already proposed in his budget plan, to help third-world nations manage their resources and develop alternative energy sources.
He also said the United States would require that certain projects it helps finance overseas meet new environmental standards.
Lastly, he said the United States would try to increase its own use of more environmentally friendly technologies, including solar energy.
In keeping with rules at the conference, most speeches have lasted about seven minutes. Mr. Clinton spoke for 12 minutes. He wrestled with the wording of his remarks all afternoon after attending the burial of a great-uncle in Hope, Ark.
Bill Richardson, United States representative to the United Nations, said Mr. Clinton's decision on Wednesday to tighten pollution restrictions had helped allay other nations' doubts about the Administration, proving it was "serious about the environment."
Asked why the President decided not to move immediately on the issue of greenhouse gases as well, Mr. Richardson said, "We've got to build support with the Congress and the American people first," adding, "I think there'll be a good basis to move aggressively in Kyoto."
Mr. Clinton said he needed to generate more support before trying to cut greenhouse emissions. To do so, he said, he will hold a White House conference on climate change later this year, "to lay the scientific facts before our people, to understand that we must act, and to lay the economic facts there so that they understand the benefits and the costs."
Mr. Clinton intended his appearance at the United Nations tonight to raise his profile on environmental issuesdramatically.
He had announced his intention to attend during a speech in a Costa Rican rain forest on May 9. In that speech, he issued a more hedged warning about the dangers of climate change.
"There is some doubt about what increased greenhouse gas emissions are doing to the climate," Mr. Clinton said then, "but no one doubts that they're changing the climate, and no one doubts that the potential consequences can be very profound and severe."
The special session of the General Assembly was called to assess what progress has been made toward solving global environmental problems since the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro five years ago. When the conference ends on Friday night, representatives of 199 countries and international organizations will have spoken, including 42 heads of state or government, a couple of princes and dozens of ministers.
There was little expectation that the conference would break any new ground or reach any new agreements.
The highlight of the week was the unexpectedly strong language used by Europeans in urging the United States to take a leadership role in solving environmental problems.
Britain's Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, said on Monday that this meant the American people as well as the Clinton Administration.
Nations from the third world wanted promises of more aid to help alleviate pollution and other problems. Except for offers of some assistance from Japan and the United States, no such pledges materialized.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Earnings Increase 12% at Lehman Brothers

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that its earnings had risen 12 percent in its second quarter as gains in investment banking offset a decline in trading.
Lehman, the fourth-largest United States securities firm, said earnings for the quarter, which ended on May 31, rose to $121 million, or 95 cents a share, from $108 million, or 89 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
 The results exceeded the average forecast of 82 cents a share made by four analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Lehman's shares rose 75 cents, to $43.50, yesterday.
The firm's focus on high-margin businesses such as mergers and acquisitions helped it overcome "an extremely difficult trading and underwriting environment in March and April," Richard Fuld Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said.
Lehman's results contrasted with those of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Goldman, Sachs Group. Both reported declines in their securities businesses from the quarter a year earlier, which was particularly strong for Wall Street.
Lehman's revenue, excluding interest income and expenses, rose 2.5 percent in the second quarter, to $854 million. Investment banking revenue had the biggest gains, rising 23 percent, to $274 million. Trading revenue -- including interest costs -- fell 6 percent, to $473 million, amid the slump in stock and bond markets in March and April.
Lehman, one of Wall Street's biggest bond traders and underwriters, is trying to expand its merger, stock and high-yield bond businesses to improve shareholder returns. These areas have higher profit margins than the firm's debt businesses.
The firm was the second-biggest bond underwriter during the quarter ended in May, arranging $25.6 billion of sales, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks the securities industry.
Lehman ranked eighth among Wall Street's stock underwriters, putting together sales worth $783.9 million. It was also the eighth-biggest merger and acquisition adviser, completing $16.2 billion of corporate combinations.
Though underwriting of stocks and bonds by Lehman and other firms slowed after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in March, lower rates and rising stocks spurred a recovery later in the quarter.
"Since the second week of May, we've seen an acceleration in underwriting across the board," said Jeffrey Vanderbeek, head of debt capital markets at Lehman.

HEADLINE: Albert L. Latter, 76, Physicist And Expert on Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Albert L. Latter, a nuclear physicist and expert on nuclear weapons systems' abilities and vulnerabilities, died on June 8 at his home in the Pacific Palisades section of Los Angeles. He was 76.
His death was announced on Wednesday by the Rand Corporation, the research concern based in Santa Monica, Calif., where Dr. Latter worked from 1951 to 1971. Rand's public information director, Jess Cook, said Dr. Latter had had a long illness. 
 While Dr. Latter was at Rand, he was the co-author, with the physicist Edward Teller, of a widely noted 1958 book, "Our Nuclear Future: Facts, Dangers and Opportunities." The two men had worked together on the Air Force's Scientific Advisory Board.
Reviewing the work in The New York Times Book Review, Leonard Engel, a science writer, said the authors presented "a strong, carefully reasoned plea" for the Atomic Energy Commission's nuclear bomb-testing program "and the necessity of continuing it, at least for the near future."
In their book, Dr. Latter and Dr. Teller contended that past nuclear weapons tests had caused at most a very minor increase in the world's exposure to radioactivity without detectably having an impact on human life and that further testing at the current rate for several years would not alter that. The authors also argued that trying to ban bomb tests would fail because they could be hidden and because the Soviet Union could not be relied on to obey a ban.
"It is almost certain," they wrote, "that in the competition between prohibition and bootlegging, the bootlegger will win."
In 1960, Dr. Latter became head of the physics department at Rand, where the aspects of nuclear weapons he dealt with ranged from their design and efficiency to defensive steps against them. He also played a significant role in developing certain advanced missile warheads and in devising ways to detect underground nuclear tests.
Among the honors he received was an Atomic Energy Commission award in 1964 for his contributions to the design of nuclear weapons and to the detection of nuclear explosions. He also did important work in contriving measures to strengthen United States missile silos to make them less vulnerable to nuclear attack.
Dr. Latter left Rand in 1971 and founded R & D Associates, a defense company based in Marina del Rey, Calif. In 1983, when the company was acquired by Logicon Inc., it was providing high-technology electronic systems and professional services, mainly to the Defense Department. Dr. Latter was the president until he retired from that post in 1985.
Dr. Latter was born in Kokomo, Ind., and received a bachelor's degree in mathematics and physics in 1941 and a doctorate in physics in 1951, both from the University of California at Los Angeles.
He is survived by his wife, Barbara; two daughters, Christina Kelton of Cincinnati and Jacqueline Latter of Los Angeles; a brother, Richard of McLean, Va., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: HOUSE BACKS BILL FOR BIG TAX CUTS IN A 253-179 VOTE

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The House passed the first big Federal tax cut in 16 years today, brushing aside Democratic complaints that the plan favored the wealthy to approve a package of reductions that Republicans said would give the middle class much-needed relief.
The bill, which contains a credit of $500 per child for many families, tax breaks for college expenses, and reductions in capital gains and inheritance taxes, must still be reconciled with a somewhat different version making its way through the Senate. 
 The House bill passed 253 to 179. Just 27 Democrats joined 226 Republicans to approve the legislation, which was largely unchanged from the version passed by the Ways and Means Committee earlier this month without any Democratic support.
The House bill contains provisions that President Clinton has said are unacceptable to him, including an allowance for investors to exclude inflation in calculating capital gains, on stocks, real estate and other investments.
Mr. Clinton has also contended that the costs of the tax cut could spiral out of control in coming decades, risking a return of big budget deficits, and he is pressing for changes on a number of specific provisions, like making the child credit available to more low- and moderate-income families and providing more money for college tuition tax breaks.
Because he can veto the tax bill, Mr. Clinton will have a say in reshaping it when House and Senate negotiators meet next month to work out differences between their versions, including a provision in the Senate bill to raise the Federal tax on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack from its current level of 24 cents. The Senate is expected to vote on its bill on Friday.
Along with spending bills passed by the House and Senate on Wednesday, the tax bills provide the framework for implementing the agreement between Congress and the Administration to balance the Federal budget by 2002.
"I can give you my word that we're going to do everything we can to get the two bills signed by the President," Speaker Newt Gingrich said after the House vote. "We have no intention of playing games and I don't think the President has any intention of playing games."
Gene Sperling, the chairman of the White House's National Economic Council, said that although the House bill fell short of Mr. Clinton's demands in a number of areas, the Administration hoped "to work in good faith toward getting a bill the President can sign."
The Administration plans to unveil its own comprehensive tax-cutting proposals on Monday to make clear how it would want to see the House and Senate bills changed.
The House bill would provide about $135 billion in tax cuts over the next five years, partly offset by $50 billion in new or extended taxes, primarily on airline tickets.
Its main provisions are a $500-per-child credit for couples filing jointly with incomes up to $110,000, a reduction in the top rate on capital gains to 20 percent from the current 28 percent, a credit of up to $1,500 a year per student for the first two years of college, creation of a new type of retirement savings accounts, cuts in the minimum tax on corporations and cuts in the Federal estate tax.
The Senate version is likely to resemble the House bill in broad outline, containing a $500 child credit, cuts in the capital gains and estate taxes, expansion of the retirement savings account and tax incentives for college education.
But the two bills will differ in many other ways, some small, some big, including the Senate bill's reliance on the increased cigarette tax to raise $15 billion over the next five years, in part to pay for expanding medical coverage to uninsured children. The Senate bill also calls for the proceeds of the child credit for children ages 13 to 16 to be placed in a special education savings account, a requirement not included in the House bill.
The attempt to raise cigarette taxes is shaping up as a major battle. The Administration said tonight that it would support an effort by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to raise the tax by 43 cents a pack in order to cover additional uninsured children. But tobacco-state lawmakers are fighting hard to have even the 20-cents-a-pack increase stripped out of the Senate bill or deleted from the final legislation during the conference to work out the differences between the House and Senate versions.
While small relative to overall tax revenues, the reductions contained in both the House and Senate bills are substantial by the standards of an era in which bringing the Federal budget deficit under control has become an overriding priority for both parties.
But the debate on the House floor today highlighted the deep philosophical and political differences between the parties on how the tax cuts should be apportioned and more generally on taxes as a barometer for the scope of the Federal Government.
Republicans argued that tax cuts should go to those who pay the most in Federal income taxes and who help the overall economy by investing and saving. Democrats took the position that cutting taxes is an opportunity to help working people at the bottom of the income scale who are struggling to become secure members of the middle class.
The bill's chief author, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, said the vote was an opportunity for Republicans to reverse years of tax increases and begin reining in Washington's influence on economic and social issues.
"For too many years taxes went up, spending went up and the size and power of Washington Government went up," Mr. Archer said. "It's time for Washington to tax less so the American people can do more."
Mr. Archer said 76 percent of the bill's benefits would go to people making $75,000 a year or less. Saying tax relief should go to those who shoulder most of the tax burden, Mr. Archer said, "This plan is dedicated to America's forgotten middle-income taxpayers."
Of the Democrats arguing against his bill, Mr. Archer said, "Their fingers remain stuck deep in the wallets of middle-income Americans, trying to take from one citizen in order to give to another."
Democrats pressed their case that the bill was written primarily to benefit those people who already have wealth or savings, and not those who are working just to make ends meet. They said reductions in capital gains taxes, the expansion of the Individual Retirement Account and other provisions of the bill would do little to help families making $30,000 or less.
"Everyone is for tax cuts," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader.
"The question is, who gets the cuts?" Mr. Gephardt said, citing an analysis by the Treasury Department saying that 67.9 percent of the benefits of the House bill would go to the wealthiest 20 percent of taxpayers and that 19.3 percent of the benefits would go to the top one percent.
"The lion's share should go to hard-working middle-income families," Mr. Gephardt said.
In particular, Democrats said, the bill unfairly excludes from eligibility for the child credit many working families whose Federal income tax bills are already reduced by the earned income tax credit. They said the burden of other payroll taxes on those families is so heavy that they need and deserve the $500 per child credit at least as much as families who make more and have bigger Federal income-tax liabilities.
"The people on the other side think people who work for low incomes are asking for welfare," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Speaker Newt Gingrich at a rally of the House Ways and Means Committee that was held yesterday to support tax cuts. The House voted 253 to 179 for a bill that includes a $500 per child credit for many families. (Amy Toensing for The New York Times)(pg. A22)
 
Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: Major Provisions of House Tax-Cut Bill"
Here are the major provisions of the bill passed by the House yesterday providing about $85 billion in tax breaks. The Senate was still debating the proposed legislation and hoped to vote today on its version of the bill, which is similar to the House measure in the major elements. The Senate has included a 20-cent per pack increase in the Federal cigarette tax that is not in the House version. And the House would allow capital gains to be reduced to reflect increases caused by inflation.
 
TAX CREDITS FOR CHILDREN
Would provide a credit of up to $500 per child up to age 17, phased out for couples filing jointly with incomes above $110,000. The credit would be $400 next year, rising to $500 the next year. Many lower- and middle-income families who already claim the earned income tax credit or the dependent-care credit would not receive the full child credit.
 
COLLEGE EDUCATION
For the first two years of college, a tax credit of up to 50 percent of $3,000 in tuition and book costs would be offered, after accounting for financial aid. Would provide deductions of up to $10,000 a year for college costs when money is saved through several varieties of savings plans. Would allow penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s for college and graduate school.
 
CAPITAL GAINS
Would reduce the top rate to 20 percent from 28 percent for individuals making more than $24,650 and couples making more than $41,200, and set a bottom rate of 10 percent. Would allow investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating gains starting in 2001. Would allow profits on sale of a primary home to be exempted up to $500,000 for couples filing jointly, $250,000 for single filers. Would reduce the top corporate rate to 30 percent from 35 percent.
 
RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS
Would create a new form of I.R.A. open to taxpayers, regardless of income level. Contributions would not be tax deductible, but would accrue interest tax free and could be withdrawn tax free after retirement or for purchase of a first home.
 
INHERITANCE TAXES
Would increase the exemption from Federal estate taxes to $1 million from $600,000 by 2007. (pg. A22)

HEADLINE: Whitman Gets Auto Plan in Final Session

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 26

 BODY:
The State Legislature sent an auto insurance bill to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's desk today that would eliminate the automatic rate increases scheduled to cost the average New Jersey driver at least $30 a year more and would end the surcharges some drivers are forced to pay after minor accidents or traffic tickets.
But because the bill would do little to reduce the actual cost of insuring New Jersey's 4.5 million drivers, most motorists would probably see little or no relief from the nation's highest premiums, which now average $1,013 a driver. In fact, the bill would do much less than the Governor first proposed last January. 
 The latest annual automatic rate increase, of at least 3 percent, was scheduled to go into effect on July 1. But insurance company executives expect dozens of companies to apply for increases by year-end. Insurers would still be allowed to ask state regulators for permission to raise rates each year to account for inflation and earn a profit.
Tens of thousands of drivers in the state now pay surcharges on their premiums for traffic tickets and accidents when they are at least partly at fault.
Those surcharges would be dropped in the next year. But they would be replaced by a new tiered system that rates drivers by their driving records. And insurers say some good drivers could end up paying more than they do now.
The bill prevents insurance companies from dropping drivers without cause.
The Legislature, in its final session before the summer recess, also took action on several other major bills.
Legislators voted along party lines to give final approval to a $16.8 billion budget for the new fiscal year, starting July 1, that includes more money than Governor Whitman originally proposed for state colleges, child protective workers and school construction projects.
New Jersey's Senate, by an overwhelming margin, passed bills that would cut the tax rate on sales of electricity and gas by 45 percent over six years but assure that the state's 567 communities dependent on that tax would not be hurt.
Auto insurance dominated much of the debate during the voting sessions of both the Assembly and the Senate, which went well into the night.
Insurance companies said today that they could not provide specific estimates of how auto rates would change since state regulators must still write regulations to enact the bill, which Governor Whitman is expected to sign.
This afternoon, Mrs. Whitman said the bill would result in a system that was fairer to motorists, with good drivers paying less and bad drivers paying more.
The Governor said she would continue to press for the more aggressive changes that she had proposed earlier this year but could not get enough support for in the two houses, even though both are controlled by her own party.
"More certainly needs to be done," she said. "I do not think the will is there at the present time. Just because we are all Republicans does not mean that we all think alike. The Legislature determined that this needs a lot more discussion."
Democrats, who called a news conference before the votes, charged today that Mrs. Whitman should have fought harder for more aggressive changes.
"The Governor's idea of reform is a charade," said State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor. "It will do absolutely nothing to lower rates."
Mr. McGreevey and other Democrats introduced a bill today that would roll back rates by 10 percent on July 1, stop insurance companies from passing the cost of fraud onto their customers and create a special state prosecutor to handle fraud cases.
The Democrats called on the Legislature to reconvene this summer to consider their bill, but Republicans showed little interest in bringing the issue back during July or August, months when vacationing lawmakers rarely meet.
The bill also helps state justice officials prosecute people who insure their cars in New Jersey but live in New York City or Philadelphia, where high theft and accident rates have pushed premiums even higher than the average premium in New Jersey.
The bill would also give insurers incentives to sell more insurance policies in urban areas, which most companies now avoid, saying that they cannot charge high enough premiums to cover the losses there.
The legislation would crack down on fraud, which state regulators now believe accounts for as much as 20 percent of the cost of premiums.
 
Energy Tax
The Legislature also took action on energy tax legislation, which passed the Senate by a 37-to-1 vote. It would cut the tax rate on electricity and natural gas sales, now one of the nation's highest, to 7 percent, from 13 percent, by 2003. State officials say residents and businesses will receive a monthly savings in 2003 of 6 cents on each dollar spent on electricity and natural gas.
Governor Whitman proposed the change because New Jersey plans to deregulate energy sales by 2000 and open the state to out-of-state suppliers. The current energy tax, known as the Gross Receipts and Franchise Tax, cannot legally be applied against out-of-state suppliers. The new tax, starting next Jan. 1, would consist of a 6 percent sales tax, a 1 percent tax on corporate net income and a transitional tax that starts at 6 percent next year and then is phased out by 2003.
Under the new system, revenues from energy sales are to decline from $1.1 billion this year to $798 million in 2003.
Governor Whitman also wants to use the lower tax as a lure to new industry and business. The municipal aid in the bill eased fears that local budgets and taxpayers would suffer from the changes.
After local governments grumbled recently about the state's initial offer of $730 million a year from the revised tax, legislative leaders and the Whitman administration increased the aid from $730 million this year to $740 million in 1998. The aid will increase by $5 million a year until it is capped at $755 million in 2001. The distribution formula passed on a vote of 38 to 1.
The aid is critical to the state's municipalities because it is their second-biggest single source of revenue, after local property taxes.
It comes from taxes that electrical, gas and other utility companies pay to the state for their wires, pipes, poles, transformer stations and other equipment around the state.
 
Abortion Procedure Ban
 The day was also notable for what votes were not cast. It was widely expected that both the Assembly and Senate would vote to override Governor Whitman's conditional veto of legislation that would ban an abortion procedure known to its opponents as "partial birth" abortion.
But while there were enough votes in the Assembly to override the Governor's veto easily, the Senate was one vote short.
Lawmakers have until Jan. 13, 1998, to act on the Governor's conditional veto, which she issued on Monday.

The New Jersey Legislature has passed bills that would cut the tax rate on the sale of electricity and natural gas by 45 percent over six years. Graph shows how the cuts would affect future revenues from energy and telecommunications taxes. (Source: N.J. Board of Public Utilities)

HEADLINE: Observer;
Acute Outrage Failure

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
My outrage generator is out of order. Hard as I try to work up a full head of outrage about the tobacco industry, I cannot. It is alarming. Being outraged about big tobacco is the duty of every decent American just now. I cannot manage it.
On the other hand, I become purple with outrage when someone writes a sentence that begins, "On the other hand . . ." 
 You see what I mean: malfunctioning outrage generator. Not a drop of steam sizzling off the top of the skull about those vile tobacconists, but red-hot pedantic rage about flabby diction.
And what is my response to matters every decent American has a duty to smile upon? Outrage. Inappropriate outrage. The rich-voter-friendly tax cut now being planned by President Clinton and the Congress, for instance, produces only a sullen outrage.
It brings to mind H. L. Mencken, who, while listening to Chopin, was reminded of "two embalmers at work on a minor poet." The minor poet on whom the morticianly Clinton and Congress are at work is the American body politic.
"The body politic is dead?" you ask. You have to be dead, at least between the ears, to believe cutting taxes will balance a budget. Well, Americans have believed it again and again ever since Ronald Reagan's great tax cut of 1981 was followed by the most astounding deficit in history.
Being outraged about this subject embarrasses me. Nobody else is outraged. Everybody is delighted to hear that the trick to paying the nation's overdue bills is to have less income.
My outrage problem may be grave. The generator seems to work only when it detects an onset of serious silliness.
Look at the case of the vile tobacconists, for whom I feel no outrage whatever. They were just another group of consumer-goods peddlers who used modern salesmanship methods to get people hooked on their product. We are asked to find them uniquely hateful because they used their wiles on children.
Struggling to achieve outrage, I end up asking why we should confine our anger to the tobacco set. Shouldn't we despise with equal fervor all consumer-goods salesmen who use modern advertising guile to make children crave their goods?
Dozens of different businesses are conditioning toddlers to lust for junk food, junk toys and just plain junk. Why is no one outraged by the Pied TV Pipers of Christmas and Saturday morning?
Unhealthy though tobacco is, common sense harnessed to a little will power can break its grip. Addiction to a life spent acquiring unnecessary consumer goods, however, may be just as destructive as a cigarette habit, and even harder to shake. Who has not recoiled from appalling scenes of tertiary acquisition fever played each day in the shopping malls of America?
See the problem? I am outraged because nobody is outraged about something I think should outrage everybody as thoroughly as tobacco outrages them.
So back to Washington's cockamamie tax cut: I am outraged because nobody else is outraged about politicians for thinking us dumb enough to believe we can pay overdue bills by earning less money.
Outrage oozes from every pore when these duplicitous embalmers say tax cuts for the champagne classes are needed to encourage investment and spark business activity. I have to fight a childish impulse to ask hasn't anybody heard about Wall Street's big bull market deluging people with money.
I am foolishly outraged about a government, which having just refined the welfare law to deny paupers' tots a pot of beans, now plans to give boxcar-lots of money to the well heeled in the form of tax cuts. Considering the rate at which Wall Street is pumping money to them, wouldn't it make more sense -- if we really think a balanced budget important -- to raise their taxes instead of cutting?
This is foolish of me. Childish nonsense. Economic ignorance. Liberal elitist idiocy. Outdated humanitarianism. I am ashamed to have an antique, broken-down, malfunctioning, dysfunctional outrage generator that cranks up such pap, twaddle, piffle, drivel, poppycock, balderdash and malarkey.
I shall have it replaced. Then I shall enjoy fuming with righteous anger about the truly serious outrages that every decent American has a duty to be outraged about, if only to divert his attention from matters of genuine gravity.
