HEADLINE: Mario G. Salvadori, Engineer And Inner-City Teacher, 90

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
Mario G. Salvadori, an engineer whose passion for structures was equaled only by his devotion to teaching about them, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 90 and lived in Manhattan.
At his death, Dr. Salvadori was honorary chairman of the engineering firm of Weidlinger Associates and the James Renwick Professor Emeritus of Engineering and a Professor Emeritus of Architecture at Columbia University. He was best known in his last years, however, for his determination to use the principles of architecture and engineering as a way of teaching science and math to inner-city students. 
 Responding to a call for volunteers in the New York City public schools in 1975, Dr. Salvadori, then 68, taught a junior high school class in Harlem. His success at explaining complex structural concepts through such real-world examples as how bridges and skyscrapers are built led him to develop his ideas into a formal curriculum, which ultimately became the basis of the Salvadori Educational Center on the Built Environment, now based at City College. The nonprofit center trains teachers and supervises the use of Dr. Salvadori's curriculum in more than 25 schools in the South Bronx, Harlem and elsewhere.
Dr. Salvadori, a lifelong pacifist, had a gentle, patient manner that belied his stature as one of the world's leading structural engineers. He took particular delight in encouraging inner-city students to build models of buildings and bridges out of ordinary materials like toothpicks and string, and would even encourage them in class to set up economies in play money to teach them about the economics of structure as well as the physics of it. He showed the students how to make arches out of folded paper, startling them by revealing that the paper could be strong enough to support several bricks.
"I teach them why buildings stand up -- that is, the basic principles of architectural structures, which is also the subject of my first-year course in architecture at Columbia," Dr. Salvadori wrote in 1981. "To my surprise, the children seem to absorb the ideas better and quicker than do my university students. Their enthusiasm is unbounded and their questions come like bullets from a machine gun."
In a speech in 1990 at the International Design Conference in Aspen, Colo., he asked: "Are children capable of influencing the environment? I believe the answer to this question to be a resounding yes, on one condition: that they be empowered to understand, appreciate and wish to modify that environment."
In 1993, when Dr. Salvadori received the Hoover Medal, given jointly by the nation's engineering societies, Jonathan F. Fanton, president of the New School, said of him: "He is shattering myths about how science and math must be taught, how inner-city children learn and what they are capable of learning." Dr. Fanton concluded: "He has made the teaching of engineering a humanitarian art in itself."
Unlike many engineers who think in purely mathematical terms, Dr. Salvadori was a scientist who constantly sought ways to connect his craft to art and society. He designed the concrete structural system for Eero Saarinen's CBS Building in Manhattan, among many other celebrated buildings.
"His main concern was that great architecture be achieved," the architect Eugene Kohn said of Dr. Salvadori in 1995. "Some engineers say you can't do this or that, but Mario never did. In my view, he's on a par with Louis Kahn or Paul Rudolph."
Mr. Salvadori was born on March 19, 1907, in Rome and was reared in Genoa and in Spain. His father was an engineer, but Mario hoped to become a concert conductor, and in 1925, at 18, he established what he later said was Italy's first student jazz band.
Dissuaded by his parents from a musical career, he received two doctorates from the University of Rome, one in civil engineering and the other in mathematics. An outspoken critic of Mussolini's Fascist regime -- he later said that his exposure to Fascism helped inspire him to seek more creative and open teaching methods with children -- he left Italy in 1939 for the United States. Through a contact established by his parents, he first worked as a time-and-motion engineer at Lionel Trains in New Jersey.
His interest in teaching was already apparent, however, and by 1940 he joined Columbia as a temporary faculty member, the beginning of a 50-year association with the university. He was appointed a full professor in 1959.
For three years he worked as a consultant to the Manhattan Project, unaware, he said later, that his research was connected to the atomic bomb. In 1945, Dr. Salvadori joined with Paul Weidlinger, who had recently established an engineering firm in New York. While his name was never on the door, for many years he was the firm's most prominent presence, serving as a consultant until 1960, as a partner from 1960 to 1991, and then as honorary chairman.
At Weidlinger he established a particular expertise in the analysis of structural failure. While he helped design numerous new buildings, Dr. Salvadori was often called in as a forensic engineer, investigating building failures in situations ranging from design and construction errors to earthquakes.
Dr. Salvadori is survived by his wife, Carol; a son, Vieri; a stepson, Michael Kazan, and three grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Early '97 Growth Is Lifted a Bit, to 5.9%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
The economy grew in the first quarter at a slightly faster pace than previously estimated, and inflation remained in check, the Commerce Department said today.
Growth in corporate profits was revised downward. 
 Gross domestic product, the nation's output of goods and services excluding foreign income, rose at a 5.9 percent annual rate in the quarter, faster than the 5.8 pace reported earlier. The expansion was the fastest in nearly a decade. The economy grew at a 3.8 percent rate in the fourth quarter of 1996.
Today's revision, which matched analysts' expectations, "mainly reflects an upward revision to net exports that offsets a downward revision to inventory investment," said Steve Landefeld, director of the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. The improvement in net exports came as imports turned out to be lower than initially estimated, Mr. Landefeld said.
Business inventories grew by $48.6 billion in the quarter, down from the previously estimated $51.4 billion. Real final sales, which exclude the effects of inventory changes, rose 4.1 percent; the rise had been previously put at 3.8 percent.
After-tax corporate profits rose 3.5 percent, slower than the 4.5 percent gain reported earlier. Profits from current production, meantime, rose 6.3 percent, the largest gain since an 8.5 percent rise in the third quarter of 1985.
Growth in inflation-adjusted earnings was revised upward, to a 4.1 percent rate from 3.8 percent.
The G.D.P. price deflator, a measure of price increases followed by Wall Street, showed prices accelerated at a 2.2 percent annual pace in the first quarter, unchanged from the previous report.
In the current quarter, which ends Monday, growth probably slowed to an annual rate of 2 percent or less as consumer spending wound down and unsold goods piled up in stores and warehouses, analysts have said.
The slowdown and the subuded inflation suggest Federal Reserve policy makers will refrain from raising interest rates at their two-day meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Uncertainties For Dollar: Trade, Euro, U.S. Growth

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The combined weight of a strong economy, low inflation and comparatively high interest rates in the United States buttressed the dollar for much of the first half of the year, helping it continue a rally in which it climbed back from historic lows.
Yet after reaching a four-and-a-half-year high against the Japanese yen in early May, the dollar has reversed course, falling about 10 percent, and it has stumbled in its ascent against European currencies. 
 Although many of the positive fundamentals remain in place, three big uncertainties -- the trade deficit with Japan, the outlook for European currency union and the United States economy -- have weighed on the dollar after its rebound, and currency traders and analysts expect these factors to continue to play critical roles for the rest of the year.
"Six months ago I was very bullish on the dollar," said Russell LaScala, chief spot dealer for Citibank in New York. "And I thought the trend would continue. But the follow-through has been disappointing."
In part, it is the dollar's strength, notwithstanding the recent gyrations, that is responsible for the questions. Yesterday, though there was little economic news, the dollar rose strongly. It continued its uneven gains against the mark, rising to 1.7387 marks, from 1.7256 on Thursday. Its last close that high came in February 1994. The dollar traded at 114.55 yen, up from 113.15 yen.
Through yesterday, an index compiled by J. P. Morgan shows that on a trade-weighted basis the dollar has appreciated by more than 4 percent against the currencies of 12 major industrial countries. A broader measure, which covers about 30 currencies, shows that the dollar has risen by just under 4 percent.
After those gains, it is perhaps not surprising that the dollar has stumbled a bit, particularly given the rise in the closely watched United States trade deficit with Japan. It has been widening as Japanese goods have become less expensive here, possibly causing a resurgence of trade tensions.
Uncertainty about the prospects for European monetary union, which buffeted the dollar in the first half, could continue to send it higher or lower depending on the market's perceptions of the strength or weakness of the planned currency, the euro.
Finally, the outlook at home is clouded, too, as the economy shows signs of slowing from a pace at which it has clearly outpaced its main trading partners and fueled the demand for dollars.
"Over all, the main thing underlying the dollar's performance is that the United States economy has been outperforming economies in the rest of the world, in terms of growth and employment generation, most notably compared with Germany and Japan," said Ron Leven, global currency strategist at J. P. Morgan.
"Also, interest rates have been rising in this country, and have remained very low elsewhere," making dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
Mr. Leven predicted that the dollar would strengthen in the second half, particularly against the yen, largely because he believes that the economy, which has slowed in the second quarter, will expand at a 4 percent rate on average in the third and fourth quarters. That sort of growth will prompt the Federal Reserve Board to raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point by the end of the year, he predicted.
A number of other analysts said they, too, were expecting further tightening moves from the Fed, though perhaps not as soon as at next week's meeting of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee.
"It seems to us that the Fed will not move until August," said Jim O'Neill, chief currency economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "And unless we see some strength in upcoming employment numbers, they might wait until the fourth quarter."
Unlike Mr. Leven at J. P. Morgan, Mr. O'Neill said he expected the dollar to fall further, particularly against the yen.
"The single most important determinant of a currency's value is the balance of payments, and the United States balance-of-payments deficit is still 2 percent of gross domestic product," he said. "If it were not for that factor, the dollar would be stronger than it is."
Unlike other analysts, who said they saw the recent widening in Japan's trade surplus with the United States as temporary, Mr. O'Neill and others said they did not expect it to narrow. Over the next 12 months, Mr. O'Neill said he expected the yen to appreciate 5 to 6 percent against the dollar.
"Trade and exports are the only source of strength in the Japanese economy at the moment," he said. "Japan is trying to export its way out of trouble, as it has in the past."
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research organization, also views America's trade deficit as a major impediment to sustained strength in the dollar.
"There is a direct conflict between short-term fundamentals, which are bullish for the dollar, and the longer-term ones, which are bearish," he said. "I think there is a shift going on, and that this is likely to be a bearish period for the dollar."
The subject of Japan's widening trade surplus prompted some political sniping at the recent Group of Seven economic meeting in Denver, and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan provoked a mini-meltdown in the stock market last Monday when he suggested that Tokyo might sell its holdings of United States Treasury securities unless Washington moved to stabilize the dollar-yen exchange rate.
A spokesman for the Prime Minister subsequently said Mr. Hashimoto's remarks had been misinterpreted. But Mr. Leven of J. P. Morgan said the rhetoric on both sides masked an underlying fact: For the foreseeable future, against a backdrop of relative prosperity, the dollar is not likely to be an important political topic in the United States.
"This is not an issue for the United States," he said. "For that to happen unemployment would have to be a lot higher than it is." In addition, he said, a relatively strong dollar is one more argument against an increase in interest rates, because it helps dampen inflation. "And the public is happy when interest rates are lower than they might otherwise be," Mr. Leven said.
By contrast, political concerns will likely be a dominant theme in Europe as it struggles with the plan to adopt the single currency.
And while currency market participants seem to believe that members of the European Union remain on track to achieving monetary union on schedule beginning in 1999, the recent Socialist Party victory in France, coupled with political developments in Germany, has shaken confidence a bit. The Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, a main proponent of the single currency, has found it difficult to reconcile its own worsening budget situation with the strict fiscal criteria of the currency plan.
Some analysts said that uncertainty about monetary union could benefit the dollar, as investors turned to it as a haven. But setbacks for the currency plan could also lead to a strengthening of the German mark, traditionally the strongest European currency.

HEADLINE: Late Selling Curbs a Rally; Dow Up 33.47

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market ended a jittery week the way it began: erratically.
The market rallied strongly in the morning, with the help of falling interest rates. In the late afternoon, however, a sharp selloff erased most of those gains. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, up nearly 117 points at 2:13 P.M., ended the day with a gain of just 33.47 points, at 7,687.72. For the week, the Dow lost 108.79 points, or 1.4 percent.
"It was almost as if someone flipped off a switch at 2 P.M.," said Art Hogan, an equity trader at Morgan Stanley, referring to the late afternoon selloff. "We gave it a run, but there were just no players in the last couple of hours."
Broader indexes also held onto slim gains. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.62 points, to 887.30, and the Nasdaq composite gained 1.77 points, to 1,438.15.
Considering how the week began, though, the market finished with just minimal losses. On Monday, the Dow fell 192 points in its worst loss of the year after reports that the Bank of Japan was considering large sales of American Treasury securities.
A day later, when such reports were discounted by Japanese officials, the markets shot back up, with the Dow climbing 153 points.
The remainder of the week was not much different. In fact, each session saw a 100-point swing in the Dow, the first week that has ever happened.
Much of the volatility was related to worries about a soaring market. Since its low on April 11, the Dow has risen nearly 1,300 points, or 20.3 percent. But analysts also said that increased volatility might be related to heavy trading as the end of the second quarter approaches on Monday.
"This has been an odd week because you have end-of-the-quarter window dressing and a lot of program trading," said Hildegard Zagorski, an analyst at Prudential Securities.
In "window dressing," portfolio managers sell their losers and buy winners to create the impression of a more successful portfolio.
And with a large majority of portfolio managers underperforming the S.& P. 500 index, it is not surprising that activity was heavy this week, analysts said. Yesterday, however, volume on the New York Stock Exchange was lighter than it has been recently, at 472.5 million shares.
Issues with gains edged out those with losses by nearly 2 to 1.
Although many analysts express fears that the market is pricey, many also say stocks will trend higher, partly because of the heavy cash inflows into mutual funds.
That has led some strategists to revise their year-end forecasts. For instance, William LeFevre, an analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, is now projecting 8,250 on the Dow at year-end, up from his earlier forecast of 7,000.
Part of the reason is that inflation jitters have subsided, and few analysts believe Federal Reserve officials will raise short-term interest rates when they meet next week.
"The absence of a Fed tightening and fresh money flowing into the market is going to keep this thing going," Mr. LeFevre said.
The Dow was led yesterday by Procter & Gamble, up 2 13/16, to 139 5/16, and Caterpillar, up 2 3/8, to 108. Allied Signal gained 1 1/2, to 84.
Shares of Mercantile Stores Inc. soared yesterday, up 7 3/16, to 63 15/16, a 52-week high, after Business Week reported that the retailer had rejected a takeover bid from Federated Department Stores. Federated was said to have offered $75 a share.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Gold at 4-Year Low
 (Bloomberg News) -- Gold prices fell to a four-year low yesterday. The futures contract for August delivery was down $3.90, to $335.90 an ounce, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest since March 29, 1993.
On other markets, wheat and corn fell. Wheat was at its lowest price in almost three years amid signs of a bumper crop.
Soft red winter wheat for July delivery fell 7.25 cents, to $3.2575 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade, the lowest for a contract closest to delivery since July 1994.
Corn for December delivery, representing the fall harvest, lost 3 cents, to $2.355 a bushel. July corn tumbled 4 cents, to $2.4625 a bushel, the lowest for a contract closest to delivery since March 1995.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The Opium War's Secret History

BYLINE: By KARL E. MEYER 

 BODY:
Losers rarely name wars, an exception being the conflict between Britain and China from 1839 to 1842, known bluntly ever since as the Opium War. To most Chinese, a century of humiliation began with this war, in which Westerners sought to force a deadly drug on an Asian people, and then imposed an unequal treaty that pried open their country and annexed the island that became Hong Kong.
In embarrassing truth, that is essentially what happened. As Hong Kong reverts to China at month's end, many of us for the first time may see a bit of history from a different end of the telescope. Yet a further point needs making. Even the authors of the Opium War were ashamed of it, and Western protests against it marked the beginning of a concern with international human rights that in a fresh turn embarrasses today's leaders in Beijing. 
 Along with the slave trade, the traffic in opium was the dirty underside of an evolving global trading economy. In America as in Europe, pretty much everything was deemed fair in the pursuit of profits. Such was the outlook at Russell & Company, a Boston concern whose clipper ships made it the leader in the lucrative American trade in Chinese tea and silk.
In 1823 a 24-year-old Yankee, Warren Delano, sailed to Canton, where he did so well that within seven years he was a senior partner in Russell & Company. Delano's problem, as with all traders, European and American, was that China had much to sell but declined to buy. The Manchu emperors believed that the Middle Kingdom already possessed everything worth having, and hence needed no barbarian manufactures.
The British struck upon an ingenious way to reduce a huge trade deficit. Their merchants bribed Chinese officials to allow entry of chests of opium from British-ruled India, though its importation had long been banned by imperial decree. Imports soared, and nearly every American company followed suit, acquiring "black dirt" in Turkey or as agents for Indian producers.
Writing home, Delano said he could not pretend to justify the opium trade on moral grounds, "but as a merchant I insist it has been . . . fair, honorable and legitimate," and no more objectionable than the importation of wines and spirits to the U.S. Yet as addiction became epidemic, and as the Chinese began paying with precious silver for the drug, their Emperor finally in 1839 named an Imperial Commissioner to end the trade.
Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu proceeded to Canton, seized vast stocks of opium and dumped the chests in the sea. This, plus a melee in which drunken sailors killed a Chinese villager, furnished the spark for the Opium War, initiated by Lord Palmerston, the British Prime Minister, and waged with determination to obtain full compensation for the opium. The Celestial Empire was humbled, forced to open five ports to foreign traders and to permit a British colony at Hong Kong.
But as noteworthy, the war was denounced in Parliament as "unjust and iniquitous" by 30-year-old William Ewart Gladstone, who accused Palmerston of hoisting the British flag "to protect an infamous contraband traffic." The same outrage was expressed in the pulpit and the press, in America and England, thereby encouraging Russell & Company and most other American businesses to pull out of the opium trade.
Warren Delano returned to America rich, and in 1851 settled in Newburgh, N.Y. There he eventually gave his daughter Sara in marriage to a well-born neighbor, James Roosevelt, the father of Franklin Roosevelt. The old China trader was close-mouthed about opium, as were his partners in Russell & Company. It is not clear how much F.D.R. knew about this source of his grandfather's wealth. But the President's recent biographer Geoffrey Ward rejects efforts by the Delano family to minimize Warren's involvement.
The family's discomfort is understandable. We no longer believe that anything goes in the global marketplace, regardless of social consequences. It is precisely this conviction that underlies efforts to attach human rights conditions to trading relations -- to temper the amorality of the market -- a point that, alas, seems to elude the Socialist soon-to-be masters of Hong Kong. KARL E. MEYER

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Climb as a Fed Move Is Doubted

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose yesterday for the first time in three days amid optimism that Federal Reserve policy makers would refrain from raising interest rates at their meeting next week.
Traders also awaited a number of economic reports -- including the June employment report, to be released on Thursday -- for more clues about the strength of the economy and prospects for a rate increase in the months ahead. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 98 14/32, or $5 for a $1,000 bond. Its yield fell 4 basis points, to 6.74 percent.
Bond prices were aided by a Federal Reserve move to buy $1.405 billion of securities to add reserves to the banking system in a so-called coupon pass. The Fed bought Treasuries maturing between Aug. 15, 2002, and Jan. 15, 2027 -- a broader range of maturities than had been expected by analysts and traders.
"The coupon pass was more aggressive than most people expected," and that helped bolster bond prices, said Will Jarosak, a trader at Fuji Securities Inc.
Another factor in yesterday's gains was the rise in the dollar's value that came after Japan forecast that industrial production would decline in coming months, damping expectations that interest rates there would rise anytime soon.
A stronger dollar increases the returns that foreign investors receive on Treasury securities when the proceeds are converted into other currencies.
Yesterday's gains snapped a two-day decline for Treasury bonds. They had fallen as the dollar weakened and a number of corporations, municipalities and other borrowers sold more than $9 billion of new debt. Issuance subsided yesterday, with only three borrowers, led by Bear, Stearns & Company, selling $700 million of debt.
Bonds also rose as some traders reversed short sales, or bets that prices would keep falling, Mr. Jarosak said. In a short sale, a trader borrows bonds and sells them, speculating that the bonds can be replaced later at a lower price, with the trader pocketing the difference. If bond prices rise, short-sellers usually start buying bonds immediately to stem their mounting losses.
Some traders said yesterday that they remained reluctant to enter the market ahead of next week's Fed meeting and the release of several important economic reports.
"Trying to set any rules with this many variables ahead could be detrimental," said Jim Somers, who manages $2.5 billion at Martindale Andres & Company in West Conshohocken, Pa.

HEADLINE: Health Panel Set to Attack Tobacco Deal

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration begins an intensive review of the proposed tobacco settlement, a panel of public-health experts is preparing to send the White House a detailed critique of the deal, demanding several significant changes in the terms of the agreement.
The panel, representing 23 public-health groups, is insisting that the deal be strengthened in seven areas, including Food and Drug Administration jurisdiction over tobacco products, disclosure of industry documents and the right to sue cigarette makers for punitive damages. 
 President Clinton appeared to agree that the proposed settlement would take away too much of the F.D.A.'s authority over tobacco.
"It was a terrific achievement," Mr. Clinton said of the agreement reached last week. "But my preliminary take is that we do not want to paralyze the capacity of the F.D.A. to protect the American people."
Under the agreement, if the F.D.A. wanted to require that cigarettes have less nicotine, it would have to prove that they would be safer and would not lead to a black market for high-nicotine cigarettes.
The pre-emptive strike by the health experts, led by Dr. David A. Kessler, a former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, and Dr. C. Everett Koop, a former Surgeon General, is a sign of the pressure that Administration officials will be under as they struggle to meet a 30-day deadline imposed by President Clinton to review the terms of the tobacco deal thoroughly and recommend changes.
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Bruce Reed, the President's chief domestic policy adviser, are directing the Administration review. At least 50 officials from 10 Government agencies will participate.
Today, at a White House briefing, they outlined the approach they intend to follow to scrutinize the complex tobacco proposal. Though they insisted that every aspect of the deal would be studied, it appeared clear that their mandate is to find a way to make the proposal acceptable to the President -- and not to kill it.
Ms. Shalala and Mr. Reed have created four task forces to look at what they consider the key elements of the deal: provisions affecting Federal regulation, industry payments, legal issues and the future of the cigarette companies.
Ms. Shalala called the proposal "a chance of a lifetime" to make dramatic strides in public health. She indicated a number of preliminary concerns with the plan, including a possible weakening of F.D.A. authority to regulate nicotine and a lack of clear enforcement mechanisms.
She said the goal of the review was to answer two fundamental questions: Does this proposal improve the public health? And at what cost?
But the White House is unlikely to endorse any settlement that is not approved by the the Koop-Kessler panel, which was appointed by Congress. And the group has already concluded that the costs extracted by the tobacco industry in 12 weeks of negotiations are too high.
In a draft of a letter to be sent to the White House next week, the group identified what it considered weaknesses in the proposed settlement. Two of the problems are potential "deal-breakers," an aide to the panel said today.
In addition to its concerns about F.D.A. power, the group will tell the White House that penalties that would be imposed on cigarette makers for failing to meet targets to reduce teen-age smoking should be two to three times higher than those in the agreement.
The deal calls for tobacco makers to pay a maximum of $2 billion a year if smoking by teen-agers fails to decline by prescribed amounts: 30 percent after five years, 50 percent after seven years and 60 percent after 10 years.
Unless the penalties and F.D.A. power are strengthened, the public-health groups will recommend that the deal be scrapped, said the aide, who insisted on anonymity.
The group also objected to the deal's level of financing for public-health initiatives and programs for quitting smoking, its lack of measures to curtail tobacco companies' overseas sales, its limits on disclosure of tobacco industry documents and its ban on class-action lawsuits against cigarette manufacturers.
"The letter will say that the panel has reviewed the settlement and in these areas has grave concerns," the aide said. "These are core principles and there is unanimity on them."

HEADLINE: In Vietnam, 'Hanoi Hilton' Brick Links Past and Future

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, June 27

 BODY:
Pete Peterson, the first American Ambassador to Vietnam since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, gave the visiting Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, a precious gift today: a brick.
The brick, mounted on wood, is from the "Hanoi Hilton," where he spent more than six years as a prisoner of war, and which is now being turned into a luxury block of apartments and stores by a Singapore company. 
 "This brick is a symbol of a more brutal time," said Mr. Peterson, who arrived in Vietnam less than two months ago. "But it is also a stepping stone to a better future." Ms. Albright, visibly moved, said she would keep it in her office "as a sign of what we've been through and also of where we're going."
Standing alongside the former prisoner of war also gave Ms. Albright something else -- political cover.
Mr. Peterson, who was celebrating his 62nd birthday, is not only a highly decorated veteran and onetime P.O.W., but he is a Democrat, a former Representative from Florida, and his record of valor and endurance made it difficult for the Republican Party to block full normalization of relations with Vietnam and the exchange of ambassadors -- 22 years after the previous American Ambassador, Graham Martin, left the rooftop helipad of the previous American Embassy, in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon.
For Ms. Albright -- the first Secretary of State since then to visit Ho Chi Minh City, where on Saturday she will lay the cornerstone of an American consulate -- this is a trip about the future. Like former Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who came to Hanoi in August 1995 to raise the American flag over the new embassy, she is trying to solidify a political and economic relationship with a Vietnam that has shed its Chinese and Russian allies and now joined the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, originally set up by Washington as a bulwark against Communism.
But given President Clinton's youthful opposition to the Vietnam War, in which he did not fight, any high-level visit to Vietnam has to address the problem of American servicemen -- 1,584 at last count -- who are still unaccounted for.
So Ms. Albright has spent as much time on the issues of Vietnamese cooperation in the $10 million a year American effort to achieve "the fullest possible accounting" of the missing as she has meeting senior Vietnamese officials to press for faster economic reform, a better climate for investment and more respect for dissent and religious freedom.
She had a long briefing this morning by the Joint Task Force that searches crash sites, along with the Vietnamese, to try to resolve the fate of the missing -- now centered on the remaining 48 of 196 priority cases listed in 1992, men who were reported to have been seen alive after their capture. The operation could go on for years, said Lieut. Col. Jonathan Chase, and ultimately a political decision would have to be made about what constitutes "the fullest possible accounting."
In her meetings today with Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet, Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam and the Communist Party leader, Do Muoi, all expressed sympathy for the American search and promised full assistance.
Ms. Albright then pressed ahead with the message the Vietnamese are happier to hear: "We have been able to normalize our political relations with Vietnam and exchange ambassadors and we now want to lay greater stress on normalizing and moving forward in our economic relationship."
To do that, she said, Vietnam has to reinvigorate its economic reforms, or "doi moi," which have lagged because of conservatism in the party, a divided leadership, corrupt bureaucrats and remaining central controls. These criticisms echo those of the leadership itself. "What is needed now is doi moi II," she said, just after signing a copyright agreement with Mr. Cam.
But Vietnamese leaders were less convinced by her argument that "economic and political openness are two sides of the same coin," and that they should relax curbs on political dissent and religious practice.
They did listen closely, however, American officials said, as she raised three specific cases of prisoners, two jailed for political dissent and one for religious practice, and asked for their speedy release and the possibility of family visits.
She said that for Washington to provide loans and loan guarantees to American companies, Washington had first to waive a Jackson-Vanik provision, requiring fair emigration. To do that, Vietnam has to live up to its promise to speed up exit permits for boat people seeking interviews with American officials in an effort to immigrate to the United States. While Vietnam had promised 1,500 exit permits a month from April on, so far only 359 permits have been processed this year, officials said.
More timely exit permits for about 7,000 cases left pending would likely produce the waiver, American officials said.
But to receive the normal trading status Vietnam seeks -- called "most favored nation status" -- Vietnam and Washington first have to negotiate a complicated trade agreement, which is far from ready. Washington submitted a draft to Hanoi three months ago; Hanoi has not yet responded.
Vietnam is having National Assembly elections next month, and the top leadership -- the conservative President, Le Duc Anh, 76, and the relatively more liberal Mr. Muoi, 80, and Mr. Kiet, 74 -- will not run. They will retain influential party posts, but the transition in the Government is not helping a speedy negotiation, a Vietnamese official said.
But as Ms. Albright made her own first visit to Vietnam, she basked in the symbolism of a new era, and in the presence of Mr. Peterson. For the future, she said, "there is no better guide as our journey unfolds than Ambassador Peterson, whose own journey from airman to P.O.W. to legislator to diplomat is an inspiration for Americans and Vietnamese alike."
For his part, Mr. Peterson said that the Vietnamese treat him like an old friend. "They approach me in the street like they know me really well, like they knew me in another life -- and maybe they did." As a prisoner, he said, he saw the worst of the Vietnamese and they saw the worst of him. Now it is time to see the best of one another.
"We're not talking 1975 anymore. We're talking 1997," he said. "I think it would be really helpful if Americans could see Vietnam as a country, and not a war, if in the American psyche, in the mindset, we could get to '97 and not '75."

HEADLINE: A Movement Is Born;
New Britain Puerto Ricans React to Report Revealing Bias

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn.

 BODY:
For 28 years, Monserrate Rosado worked two jobs, making door hinges in a hardware factory in the morning and cleaning the floors of a hospital in the evening. In the whirlwind of his busy middle years, he also managed to learn English, graduate from high school at 40 and buy a modest house in this small city, 20 minutes from Hartford.
In four decades here, Mr. Rosado, who was born in Puerto Rico, never participated in politics. He simply voted and hoped for the best. 
 But two months ago, on a rainy afternoon, he and hundreds of others created an organization called Proud (Puerto Rican Organization for Unity and Dignity) to combat prejudice in New Britain.
The inspiration for the group was a report in which some New Britain business leaders blamed Puerto Ricans for the city's lack of economic progress. "The Hispanic population has poor language skills," the report said. "They have bad work habits. They're always late for jobs. They take off from work when they feel like it, and, as a consequence are very undependable." It also said Puerto Ricans "had poor family values and even poorer language skills."
The only solution for New Britain, the business leaders said, was to get rid of the Puerto Ricans who clog the city's public housing and strain its financial resources.
The report caused such a stir that three business leaders apologized for their comments, and two of them no longer hold leadership positions. Not content with the public acts of contrition, Puerto Ricans in New Britain sought outside help, calling the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, a national advocacy group based in New York, which has asked the Federal Government to investigate the handling of public money in New Britain.
Leaders of national advocacy and civil rights groups say that what is happening in New Britain reflects the current mood of Hispanic groups across the country. The quick and angry response, they said, is a common reaction when Hispanic immigrants, even those who are not immigrants, like Puerto Ricans, feel threatened by anti-immigrant and antiwelfare sentiments, and the laws that articulate them.
"The rhetoric that comes out of Congress filters down and this is what happens," said Juan Figueroa, president and general counsel of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund. "People are tired of the rhetoric, they feel blamed for everything that's wrong with America and they are saying, 'Stop.' They want to set the record straight."
Many local political and business leaders were taken aback by the reaction to the report. Not because they thought the comments did not merit a strong response, they said, but because they did not know that their neighbors had such ability to turn anger into action so quickly.
"The strength of the reaction surprised me," said William W. Weber, a lawyer who used to lead the Downtown District Council. Mr. Weber was quoted in the report stressing that Puerto Ricans needed to learn English, a remark for which he has apologized. "That the report and the reaction created such unity in the community also surprised me. But sometimes, a lot of things come together and things happen, and I guess this is that time for them."
Mr. Rosado's anger is simpler to explain. New Britain, he said, is home. "Where am I going to go? Where are my children going to go? They were born here. Am I a financial strain to this city? I've done nothing but work."
Assigning blame is an old story in New Britain, a city of immigrants where the last ones to arrive have always been held responsible for shortcomings. It happened to the Irish, the Germans, the Italians and the Poles. It is now happening to Puerto Ricans.
The difference this time is that, with the continuing loss of jobs in the hardware industry, the city's decline has never been as stark.
Despite the efforts of the Chamber of Commerce, the Downtown District Council and the city's economic development arm, the downtown area remains deserted. Boarded-up storefronts hide turn-of-the century architectural jewels, and dilapidated buildings dot the once bustling streets. One day last month, the busiest spot was the sidewalk in front of a store where used work shirts were on sale for 50 cents apiece. Two men browsed through the merchandise.
Members of Proud said something else is different today. Because anti-immigrant sentiment is so prevalent, they said, some New Britain business leaders felt emboldened to vent private feelings that previously had been whispered among friends or communicated subtly, with a dismissive wave of the hand.
"You know what really hurts," said Jenny Correa, a school counselor born in New Britain 42 years ago who raised her three children here. "That those people would think that we are so unimportant, that we don't count, that they could just sit there and tell a researcher their most intimate, racist thoughts. We are all prejudiced, to a certain extent, but I can tell you that in my house we don't even allow any Polish jokes."
The report that so rattled this city was commissioned by Citizens for Action in New Britain, a local group seeking to discover the obstacles to New Britain's economic development. With that information, the group was hoping to rally residents to redevelop Arch Street, a particularly troubled downtown block.
A local researcher, William W. Hansen, was hired for the task by the Trinity Center for Neighborhoods, which is associated with Trinity College. Mr. Hansen identified many of the sources in the report, but left out the names of those he thought had made the most caustic comments. Later, when asked by a reporter from a local paper who had made the comments, Mr. Hansen revealed the names of all his sources, because, he said, they were never promised nor had they requested anonymity.
When the names became public, Hispanic people were irate. Demonstrations were staged throughout the city, heated meetings were held, doors were shut on both sides, and hastily, Proud was created.
Two months later, the anger has subsided somewhat, but not the issue. Beyond the apologies and the calls for respect, the Puerto Ricans say they want power. In a searing open letter to town leaders, members of Proud made 10 demands. They want to serve on public-financed boards and city commissions, and they want a voice in economic planning. They have already met twice with the Chamber of Commerce.
There is sense in this city that the report was a blessing in disguise. It brought Hispanic people together and forced the business community to take notice. Hispanic people, mainly Puerto Ricans, were 16 percent of the city's population in the 1990 Census, and local officials estimate that has since climbed to 25 percent.
Now, a committee of the Chamber of Commerce is studying how to attract Hispanic business owners to the chamber. Some business owners are starting to plan ways to attract Hispanic clients, said Kevin McCabe, the longtime chamber director.
"They have shown us that there is a strong purchasing power there," Mr. McCabe said. "And, given what they have done lately, I think, they ought to be a big voting bloc."
The increasing political sophistication of Puerto Ricans here, moving from anger to specific demands and, later, to active participation, is similar to what advocates are seeing among other Hispanic groups.
"It's like someone lit a keg and it is ready to go," said Lisa Navarrete, public information director of the National Council of La Raza, the nation's largest Hispanic civil rights organization. "I'm reminded of the movie 'Network,' when people opened their windows and shouted into the night, 'I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore.' "
Ms. Navarrete pointed to last year's voting records (5.2 million Hispanic votes were cast in the Presidential election nationwide, a jump of more than a million from 1992) as an example of how eager Hispanic citizens are to have a voice in the political process.
In New Britain, at least two members of Proud have political aspirations beyond the city. William C. Rivera, a lawyer and the City Council's majority leader, has his sights set on Congress and plans to run for state senator next year. Edgardo Saavedra, a City Councilman, wants to run for state representative. Both are counting on support from the Puerto Rican community.
"It's like waking up a sleeping giant," said Mr. Saavedra, 33, an engineer, who has lived in New Britain since he was 7. "We have been taken for granted for too long. There is an awareness now of the size, potential and power of the Hispanic community."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-5
 
Serb War Crimes Suspect Is Arrested in Slavonia
A Serb charged in the 1991 massacre of 261 patients in a Croatian hospital in Vukovar was arrested and taken to The Hague by investigators with the international tribunal for war crimes in the former Yugoslavia. The arrest took place in Eastern Slavonia, a part of Croatia now administered by the United Nations, and was the first made by the tribunal's own investigators. 5 

Bosnian General Expelled
A Bosnian general was expelled from an elite United States Army training course after Administration officials heard unconfirmed accusations that he was a war criminal. Brig. Gen. Selmo Cikotic served as a field commander during the war in the Balkans until December 1994, when he went to Washington as the military attache at his country's embassy. 5
 
Political Leader Freed in Congo
Congo's leading opposition politician, Etienne Tshisekedi, was released after a night of detention that set off scattered disturbances throughout Kinshasa. Senior Government officials declined to comment on the reason for his arrest, but troops poured into the area when his supporters started to set fire to parked cars. 3
 
Glum End to U.N. Conference
The United Nations conference on the global environment ground to a close without concrete agreements on any of the critical issues of cutting emissions, protecting forests or increasing aid to poor nations. Razali Ismail, the Malaysian president of the General Assembly, lamented that the spirit of the conference in Rio in 1992 was gone. He said neither rich nor poor nations had shown real political will. 3
 
Albright Visits Hanoi
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright began her visit to Vietnam by meeting with Vietnamese and American officials in charge of achieving "the fullest possible accounting" of American servicemen missing since the war. She also pressed senior Vietnamese officials to allow fair emigration and speed up economic reforms, both necessary for increased United States trade and investment.
 4
 
Troops Readied for Hong Kong
Ships, helicopters and armored personnel carriers will rumble into Hong Kong on Tuesday morning, carrying 4,000 troops in a display of China's renewed sovereignty over the British colony, Beijing-appointed officials announced. Outgoing Governor Chris Patten condemned the planned show of military strength as an "appalling signal." 4
 
Formal End to War in Tajikistan
Tajikistan's President and a rebel leader signed a pact in Moscow formally ending the five years of civil war that ravaged the newly independent country. President Boris N. Yeltsin presided over the signing by President Emomali Rakhmonov and the rebel leader, Said Abdullo Nuri, at a Kremlin ceremony. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 6-10, 22
 
Supreme Court Rejects Key Provision of Brady Law
A bitterly divided Supreme Court ruled that the Brady gun control law violated "the very principle of separate state sovereignty" by requiring state officials to conduct background checks of prospective handgun buyers. The decision provided the strongest evidence yet of the ascension of state power at the Court, and was the third time in as many days that the Court overturned a major Federal statute. 1
 
Lawmakers in Congress who support gun control called the Court's decision a minor setback and said they would consider drafting legislation to require gun dealers to request criminal background checks on buyers. 1
 
Despite the Court's decision law enforcement officials in a majority of states will use local laws to continue to perform background checks on handgun buyers. 8
 
The Court ended its current term by laying the groundwork for a major debate over affirmative action when its next meets in October. The Justices agreed to decide whether a school district in Piscataway Township, N.J., violated the civil rights of a white high school teacher when it dismissed her to preserve the job of a black teacher with equal seniority. 9
 
Senate Passes Tax Bill
The Senate voted overwhelmingly to cut Federal taxes for the first time since 1981. A substantial number of Democrats supported the bill, and President Clinton expressed optimism about reaching a bipartisan compromise on the final legislation. 1
 
Accused Soldier Was Taped
The Army, which is holding hearings on sexual misconduct allegations against its top enlisted soldier, played a tape of a telephone conversation it had recorded earlier in which the soldier tried to tell one of his four female accusers what she should say to investigators. 1
 
NASA Reviews Mir's Status
NASA began an investigation into the collision between Mir and an unmanned cargo ship, and prepared to send more staff members to Russia's Mission Control outside Moscow to help oversee a risky repair spacewalk planned for next month. The steering also broke down on the battered space station, leaving the Russian craft adrift in orbit for up to three hours before the exhausted crewmen could regain control. 7
 
First Pictures of Asteroid
A spacecraft racing past an asteroid named Mathilde millions of miles from Earth captured spectacular views of a deep crater punched into the battered, coal-black surface. 7
 
Monitor Radio Pulls Plug
Monitor Radio, the public radio programming service of the Christian Science Church, said it would go off the air, its news reports and features submerged under mounting financial losses and the difficulty of competing in a public radio radio environment increasingly dominated by big foundations and business sponsorships. 6

New York State education officials are drawing up plans to abolish the system of lifetime licenses for public school teachers and to crack down on university training programs in which a large percentage of prospective teachers are failing state certification exams. But critics say any recertification requirement would worsen the shortage of qualified teachers. 1

Federal prosecutors have charged a second New York Blood Center supervisor with tampering with tests intended to screen blood for H.I.V. and other infectious diseases. 25

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Major Tax Cut By Big Margin

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to cut Federal taxes substantially for the first time since 1981, as many Democrats supported the bill and President Clinton expressed optimism about reaching a bipartisan compromise on the final legislation.
The legislation is similar in its broad outlines to a version passed by the House on Thursday on a largely party-line vote after a bitter debate. But the Senate bill contained enough compromises and specific provisions to woo Democrats and passed by 80 to 18, with 29 Democrats joining 51 Republicans voting in favor of it. Among those supporting the bill was the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota. 
 After Congress returns next month from a one-week recess, House and Senate negotiators will meet, with Administration officials looking over their shoulders, to work out the differences between their bills and draft a final version to send to Mr. Clinton. The Administration has raised objections to the details of the main provisions in both bills, but Mr. Clinton suggested today that solutions were in reach on all of them.
"I'm frankly quite optimistic," Mr. Clinton said. "You would expect that all the parties would advance their views in the most vigorous way possible."
Although he has managed to set some limits on the scope of the cuts, Mr. Clinton has long since given in to the fundamental Republican demand for reductions in taxes for investors and middle-class families. Like the House, the Senate voted to give many families a $500-per-child tax credit and to reduce inheritance and capital gains taxes, all centerpieces of the Republican agenda since the party took control of Congress after the 1994 elections.
So Mr. Clinton is pressing Republicans to use the bill to address his priorities as well. He wants more generous tax breaks for college expenses than the House or Senate bill contains, and he wants to make more low-income families eligible for the child credit.
Saying that the full package of Republican cuts could lead to a resurgence of the Federal budget deficit in the long run, Mr. Clinton is demanding the removal of provisions whose costs mount rapidly in later years. Among them is a measure in the House bill that would allow taxpayers to subtract the effects of inflation in calculating capital gains on stocks, real estate and other investments.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has already begun discussions with Republicans, including Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chief author of the House tax bill, in an effort to narrow the differences between the two sides.
The tax cuts in both bills would total about $135 billion over five years. In both cases, the reductions would be paid for in part by new or extended taxes -- $50 billion worth in the House bill and about $55 billion worth in the Senate bill -- including levies on airline tickets and, in the case of the Senate bill, an increase in the Federal tax on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack, to 44 cents.
Although passage of the tax bills in the Republican-controlled Congress was a foregone conclusion, their approval this week, along with passage by both chambers of bills setting spending levels, marked a big step toward enactment of the balanced budget agreement reached last month by Congress and the Administration.
And despite the political and philosophical differences between the parties over both taxes and spending, the votes on the measures this week were the most practical manifestations yet of the uneasy bipartisanship maintained this year in an effort by both sides to put aside their bitter battles of the past few years.
"This is truly a celebration of a bipartisan effort," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader. "We kept our word to each other, and we kept our word to the American people."
Amid the self-congratulation after the vote, there were a few dissenting voices. Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas, who was one of 14 Democrats who voted against the tax bill, said he was on the Senate floor in 1981 when the sweeping tax cut bill advocated by President Ronald Reagan was approved with only 11 dissenting votes.
Noting that the Reagan tax cuts had contributed to a huge surge in Federal budget deficits over the next decade, Mr. Bumpers said that those who voted against the tax bill today would be proved prudent, and that the money going to tax cuts would be better used to reduce the deficit.
"When the year 2002 rolls around, we will not have a balanced budget or anything close to it," Mr. Bumpers said.
Some of the four Republicans who voted against the bill, including Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, did so in opposition to the tobacco tax increase.
The tobacco tax included in the Senate bill is one of the biggest and most politically sensitive of the differences between the House and Senate bills. The $15 billion that the tax would raise over five years would help finance one of the provisions in the bill that attracted Democratic support, a commitment to spend an additional $8 billion, beyond the $16 billion provided for in other legislation, to offer medical coverage to uninsured children.
The House bill has no cigarette tax provision, and tobacco state lawmakers are certain to make an all-out push to keep the tax out of the final bill. The Administration not only supports the tax, but said this week that it would support efforts by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to increase the tax by 43 cents instead of the 20 cents in the Senate bill.
The details of the child credit are also certain to be hotly debated.
The Administration is insisting that the credit be made available to low-income working families that have to pay no Federal income tax after claiming the earned-income tax credit, which is intended to reduce the tax burden on the working poor.
House Republicans, who said that giving the credit to people who do not have to pay income taxes would be a form of welfare, are adamant in resisting the Administration.
Senate Republicans have already taken a step toward compromise by using a formula that would make more low-income families at least partially eligible for the child credit, although Administration officials said they would demand a more generous formula in the bill that emerges from the House-Senate conference.
Another provision of the child credit also seems certain to lead to a battle. The Senate bill, at the behest of several Democrats, requires that the proceeds of the credit for children age 13 to 16 be deposited in an educational savings account.
The House bill contains no such provision, and the requirement is strongly opposed by some of the most influential Republican constituencies, the religious right and other social conservatives.
"Our country is headed in the wrong direction when its leaders dictate exactly how each family must spend their money," said Gary L. Bauer, the president of the Family Research Council, a conservative research and lobbying organization.
As it moved toward a final vote today, the Senate approved several amendments to the tax bill.
It passed a measure sponsored by Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, to increase the deductibility of health insurance for the self-employed.
Senator Paul Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, won approval for a provision that would allow penalty-free withdrawals from individual retirement accounts for private school tuition.
The Senate also approved an amendment sponsored by Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, that would create a tax credit of as much as 50 percent on as much as $150,000 of an employer's expenses to increase the supply of child care.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Tax Bills: How They Measure Up"
A comparison of the tax bill passed on Thursday by the House and the bill passed yesterday by the Senate. Negotiators from the two chambers will meet to work out the differences between the bills next month. They will work closely with the White House in an effort to insure that President Clinton will sign the final legislation, which would provide the first substantial Federal tax cut since 1981.
 
TAX CREDITS FOR CHILDREN
 
HOUSE: A credit of up to $500 per child up to age 17, phased out for couples filing jointly with incomes above $110,000 ($75,000 for single filers). The credit would be $400 next year, rising to $500 the following year. Many lower- and middle- income families who already claim the earned- income tax credit would not receive the full child credit. Cost: $71 billion over five years.
 
SENATE: A credit of up to $500 per child up to age 17 through 2002 starting next year, and then up to age 18, subject to the same income limits as the House bill. For children aged 13 to 16, the proceeds of the credit would have to be placed in an educa 2/3tional savings account modeled on an I.R.A. A $250 credit for the current tax year for children under 13. Would limit the credit for families claiming the earned-income tax credit, but would be less restrictive than the House bill. Cost: $84 billion over five years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Supports a $500 credit, but wants more low- and moderate-income families to be eligible. Strongly opposes the language in the House bill. More supportive of Senate bill, but still insists on changes.
 
COLLEGE EDUCATION
 
HOUSE: Starting next year, for the first two years of college, a tax credit of up to 50 percent of $3,000 in tuition and book costs, after account 2/3ing for financial aid, phasing out for joint filers with incomes above $80,000 and for single filers with incomes above $40,000. Deductions of up to $10,000 a year for four years for college costs when money is saved through several varieties of savings plans. Would allow penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s for college and graduate school. Would extend through the end of this year the tax break for employer-provided educa 2/3tion payments, but would phase out the tax break for college employees who receive free or reduced tuition. Cost: $31 billion over five years.
 
SENATE: Starting next year, for first two years of college, a tax credit of up to 50 percent of $3,000 in tuition and book costs, after accounting for financial aid, or up to 75 percent of $2,000 for costs of community or technical colleges. Would make up to $2,500 a year in student loan interest payments deductible for five years. Would create educational savings accounts and allow penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s for college and graduate school. Would make permanent the tax break for employer-provided educational payments. Cost: $32.4 billion over five years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Strongly urges a more generous version of the tax credit for the first two years of college. Wants the credit to be $1,500 per year and opposes Republican language that would allow the credit to be claimed only against tuition and book expenses after accounting for financial aid and student loans.
 
CAPITAL GAINS
 
HOUSE: Would reduce the top rate for individuals to 20 percent from 28 percent and set a bottom rate of 10 percent for people currently in the 15 percent income tax bracket (joint filers with incomes below about $41,000 or single filers with incomes below about $24,000). The reduced rates would be applied to all transactions on or after May 7. Would allow investors to subtract the effects of inflation in calculating gains starting in 2001. Would allow profits on sale of a primary home to be exempted up to $500,000 for couples filing jointly, $250,000 for single filers. Would reduce the top corporate rate gradually to 30 percent from 35 percent. Revenue gain of $2.7 billion through 2002, but then would cost $35 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE: Would reduce the rates for individuals in the same way as the House bill, but would not allow indexing for inflation and would not reduce the corporate rate. The reduced rates would be applied to all transactions on or after May 7. Would include the same provisions as the House bill for sale of a home. Would also provide special capital gains reductions for small businesses and venture capital. Cost: $2.7 billion through 2002, rising rapidly to $25 billion over 10 years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Strongly opposes the provision in the House bill that allows investors to subtract the effects of inflation. Has generally supported only limited capital gains tax reductions like the exemption on the sale of homes, but is unlikely to fight the rate reductions in the House and Senate bills.
 
RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS
 
HOUSE: Would create a new form of I.R.A. next year open to taxpayers regardless of income level. Contributions, limited to $2,000 a year plus an annual upward adjustment for inflation, would not be tax deductible, but would accrue interest tax free and could be withdrawn tax free after age 59 and a half or for buying of a first home. Cost: $33 million over 5 years, $13 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE: Starting next year, would gradually double the current income limits on eligibility for traditional I.R.A.'s, to $100,000 for joint filers and $60,000 for single filers. Would allow penalty-free withdrawals of up to $10,000 for first-time home purchases or in the event of long-term unemployment. Would create new form of I.R.A. similar to those in the House bill. Cost: $3.3 billion over five years, $24 billion over 10 years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Supports expansion of I.R.A. program but worries that the Republican proposals will be too costly in coming years.
 
INHERITANCE TAX
 
HOUSE: Would increase the exemption from Federal estate taxes to $1 million from $600,000 over 10 years, starting next year. Cost: $7.5 billion over five years, $27 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE: Starting next year, would increase the exemption gradually to $1 million by 2006, and would provide an additional $1 million exemption for many family-owned businesses and farms. Cost: $6.1 billion over five years, $36 billion over 10 years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Supports a more limited reduction in estate taxes, but is unlikely to fight for a significant scaling back of the House or Senate bill.
 
TOBACCO TAX
 
HOUSE: Contains no provision.
 
SENATE: Would increase the tax on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack, effective Oct.1, to 44 cents. About $8 billion of total revenues earmarked over five years to increase medical coverage for uninsured children. Revenue raised: $15 billion over five years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Supports proposal by Senator Edward M. Kennedy to raise the tax by 43 cents a pack to provide further coverage for uninsured children.
 
AIRLINE TICKET TAX
 
HOUSE: Effective Oct.1, would reduce the current 10 percent tax on domestic flights to 7.5 percent, but would add a fee for every flight segment, starting at $2 and rising to $3 in 2002. The tax on international round trips would rise to $31 from $6. Revenue raised: $34 billion over five years and $82 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE: Extends the current 10 percent domestic-flight tax, which would otherwise expire on Oct.1, and raises the tax on international round trips to $16 from $6. Revenue raised: $34 billion over five years and $78 billion over 10 years.
 
ADMINISTRATION POSITION: Extends the current 10 percent domestic-flight tax, which would otherwise expire on Oct.1, and raises the tax on international round trips to $16 from $6. Revenue raised: $34 billion over five years and $78 billion over 10 years.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: LAW ENFORCEMENT;
Period of Confusion Expected After Ruling on Brady Law

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court's decision overturning a crucial provision of the Brady law is expected to have the greatest effect in the 23 states that perform background checks on prospective gun buyers only because the law requires them to do so. And many of those states recently have been identified by law-enforcement officials as major sources for the guns used in crimes in other states.
Law-enforcement officials and crime experts interviewed yesterday said the ruling would create a period of much confusion in those states, where the decision whether to continue checking gun buyers will now be up to thousands of local police chiefs or sheriffs, or in some cases, to state police. 
 Some crime experts said they were particularly concerned about states with weak gun-control laws like South Carolina, Mississippi and Texas, which are among the major suppliers of guns to areas with stricter laws like the Northeast.
"We will now start to see economic competition between states whereby states that see selling guns as an attractive opportunity and provide a haven for traffickers will export more guns to other states," said Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University.
Another fear is that some people barred by the Brady law from purchasing handguns will now be able to do so in the states without restrictive laws of their own. These include convicted felons, fugitives and people with mental illness. More than 250,000 people in these categories were stopped from buying guns since the law went into effect, according to Attorney General Janet Reno.
"This is really a shame," said Philip Cook, a professor of public policy at Duke University and an expert on illegal gun markets. "I think it is credible that putting this extra barrier to buying guns has helped reduce the homicide rate," he said, as violent crime has fallen sharply during the past five years.
In interviews, many sheriffs and police chiefs left no doubt that they support the key principles of the Brady gun-control law.
Despite the Court decision, law enforcement officials in 27 states will continue to perform background checks on handgun purchasers because of their state laws. And even many police chiefs in states without gun-control regulations say they will also continue making the checks.
"We're real committed to continuing with the background checks," said Ellen Hanson, the police chief of Lenexa in Kansas, which has no law requiring the checks. "To be real honest, it takes a lot less time to do a gun check than to do a homicide investigation."
Police support for Brady checks represents a dramatic change in attitudes from even a decade ago, when law-enforcement officers were often closely allied with the National Rifle Association. But the sharp rise in gun violence in the late 1980's and the N.R.A.'s opposition to any gun-control measures have made many police officers champions of restrictions on handgun sales.
"All of us have seen the devastation caused by guns and realized that some rational law should apply to gun ownership," said Gil Kerlikowske, the police commissioner of Buffalo and the president of Police Executive Research Forum.
But other law enforcement officers regard the background checks as too time consuming or an infringement on state's rights. They said they would now happily stop performing them.
"We can get back to our essential job, instead of shuffling Brady paper work," said Sheriff Jay Printz of Ravalli County, Mont., one of the two sheriffs who challenged the Brady law leading to yesterday's Court decision. "I think there will be no more gun checks in Montana, because Montana law prohibits local governments from regulating the purchase of firearms," said Sheriff Printz, a longtime member of the N.R.A.
In some states, where the Brady background checks have been performed by a statewide law enforcement agency rather than by local police, they may now be stopped altogether. In Ohio, for example, where the Brady checks have been done by the Ohio Bureau of Criminal Investigations and where there is no state law requiring background checks, Mark R. Weaver, a deputy attorney general, said the agency would stop doing the checks immediately.
State police officials in Arkansas and Kentucky, where there are also no state laws equivalent to the Brady law and the checks have been performed by the state police, said they had received no information yet on how to respond to the ruling, though a spokesman for the South Carolina State Law Enforcement Division said it would continue doing checks.
Despite the ruling, David Kennedy, a senior researcher at the Kennedy School at Harvard University, said he was optimistic that the decision would not have a far-reaching impact because of the variety of recent efforts to stop the flow of illegal guns. Among the most important of these is the increased tracing of guns seized in crimes by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
The Supreme Court's decision will also have no effect on another important policy, Mr. Kennedy noted, a move by the firearms agency to reduce the number of Federally licensed gun dealers to 110,272 today from 286,531 in 1993. Many of the dealers who have been closed down were so-called "kitchen dealers" selling small numbers of guns to buyers who would not have been able to obtain them legally.
The whole dispute over Brady checks is scheduled to become moot in November 1998 when the Federal Government is supposed to have in operation new technology to give gun dealers the means to instantly check any prospective buyer. The Court's decision did not affect that part of the Brady law.
But whether the technology will be effective, if people use false identification, for example, is uncertain.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "STATE BY STATE: To Check or Not to Check"
The Brady law's requirement, overturned yesterday by the Supreme Court, that state or local authorities check handgun buyers' backgrounds was intended as an interim measure. A national database, allowing gun dealers to perform instant background checks, is scheduled to go into operation in November 1998. And many states have their own systems for checking, so they are not subject to the law. Map/Chart shows states that were subject to the Federal requirement, states not subject to the Federal requirement because of existing state laws: background checks, permits or other system of approval and states that have adopted background checks or other systems since the passage of the Brady law in February 1994. (Source: U.S. Department of Justice)

HEADLINE: Big Increase In Spending Is Signed By Whitman

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 26

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today signed into law a $16.8 billion state budget that increases spending by $800 million over this year's, with most of the new money earmarked for public schools and dozens of modest programs aimed at appealing to a wide range of voters in this election year.
The budget for the new fiscal year, starting July 1, raises spending for almost every state agency and does not include new tax cuts, a departure from Governor Whitman's previous spending plans. Nor are layoffs of state workers planned. 
 The Governor used her power to veto individual items, striking out about $8 million, mostly for projects for which money had been allocated elsewhere in the budget. She left untouched most of the $40 million in pet projects of state legislators, with the exception of two items inserted by State Senator Robert E. Littell, the Sussex County Republican who heads the Budget and Appropriations Committee.
She took out two items for High Point State Park, in Mr. Littell's district: $16,000 for a trailer to carry forest fire equipment and $13,000 for a brush chipper. She also cut $1.8 million that Mr. Littell had placed in the budget to cover the costs of charity cases at Northwest Covenant Health Systems in Denville. Northwest Covenant runs three hospitals in his district.
Although Michael P. Torpey, chief counsel for the Governor, said politics had not played a role in the decision to cut the items, Mr. Littell was highly critical of Governor Whitman's plan to borrow for the state pension system. He at one point called it a "wacko idea."
Mr. Torpey today described the Governor's actions as "merit based." Mr. Littell declined to comment on whether he believed that the Governor was punishing him for not supporting her bond issue for closing a deficit in the state pension system.
The Legislature, which voted for the new budget along party lines after hours of debate on Thursday night, added almost $400 million to Governor Whitman's original proposal, mostly for public schools, state colleges and child-protection workers. More than half the additional money, $246 million, will go to the public schools. It was included after the State Supreme Court ordered the state last month to increase spending to help end the disparity between the richest and poorest school districts.
Governor Whitman's budget also increased spending in areas that are certain to appeal to Democratic and swing voters as she seeks a second term. After making cuts for three years at the State Department of Environmental Protection, she increased spending for some of its programs. She also added money for expanding tax-free zones in urban areas to help lure new businesses.
The budget also provides a $100 million increase in the property tax deduction from the state income tax next year, to 75 percent from 50 percent. The property tax deduction, which was part of the current budget, is being gradually phased in.
Surrounded by Republican legislative leaders and members of her Cabinet at a State House press conference today, Mrs. Whitman summed up the themes of her upcoming campaign as she signed the budget into law. "This is a promise-keeping, job-creating, crime-fighting, school-improving, environment-protecting budget," she said. "This keeps New Jersey on the right road."
The new spending is fueled by the boom on Wall Street and a strong state economy that increased tax revenues by at least $600 million more than had been expected in January.
The budget also relies on borrowing $2.75 billion to help close a deficit in the state pension system. The borrowing allowed the state to reduce scheduled pension payments to $220 million from $810 million, freeing $590 million.
Democrats were quick to attack the budget, asserting that it relied on borrowed money to increase spending, sticking future taxpayers with the bill.
"The Governor's budget is the culmination of four years of borrowing that will leave New Jersey's taxpayers in debt," said State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democrat from Woodbridge who is challenging Mrs. Whitman this fall.
