HEADLINE: The Paper Tiger Theory

BYLINE: By Benjamin Schwarz; Benjamin Schwarz is the executive editor of World Policy Journal.

 BODY:

THE GREAT WALL AND THE EMPTY FORTRESS
China's Search for Security.
By Andrew J. Nathan and Robert S. Ross.
268 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50. 

 When the cold war ended, the American foreign policy community cast about for a new threat. Perhaps a "rogue state," like Iraq, or ethnic conflicts or even "instability" would now be the enemy. But none of these contenders had the geopolitical gravity of a superpower adversary, nor did they require the sort of global strategizing that the cold war demanded. Quite suddenly, though, a World Bank report that remains controversial today seemed to point to a new hegemon on the horizon. The Chinese economy, the bank announced in 1992, was far larger than previously thought. The analysts quickly grabbed their calculators. Present economic and technological trends were extrapolated; China's military purchasing power was assessed; war games were played. The result: Many strategists concluded that China could emerge as the dominant power in Asia, seriously challenging America's interests.
The debate over the "China threat" closely resembles the disagreements over United States policy toward the Soviet Union during the cold war. Hard-liners and moderates disagree about Beijing's capabilities and about whether American aims would best be served by containing or engaging China. Earlier this year the journalists Richard Bernstein and Ross H. Munro comprehensively argued the hard-line position for a general audience in their aptly titled book "The Coming Conflict With China." Now another team, Andrew J. Nathan, a Columbia University political scientist, and Robert S. Ross, a Boston College political scientist, have delivered a detailed argument for the other side with "The Great Wall and the Empty Fortress."
Hard-liners see a China mounting a challenge to America's position in East Asia. Nathan and Ross, on the other hand, see a defensively minded state, vulnerable to internal unrest, obsessed with maintaining its territorial integrity and burdened by a military that is technologically and organizationally far behind not only the United States but Taiwan, Japan and South Korea as well.
Nathan and Ross issue a needed corrective to some of the more outlandish claims of those who stress the "China threat." They convincingly argue, for instance, that China's ambitions regarding the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea fail to constitute the geostrategic danger that many discern. Hard-liners warn that China's possession of the islands, which it has claimed uninterruptedly for centuries, would allow it to project its naval and air power, disrupting the sea lanes carrying trade between Europe and the Middle East and East Asia, and intimidating Malaysia, Singapore and the Philippines. But military geography is more complicated than playing a game of Risk: Nathan and Ross point out that the Spratlys are too small to support the military facilities that would make them strategically significant and that, anyhow, many of the islands are under water for most of the year.
Nathan and Ross also cut through the arcane debate over the actual size of the Chinese military budget to demonstrate just how severely limited Beijing's current capabilities are. China's cumbersome armed forces have traditionally been oriented toward the defense of home territory. If China were to make a bid for the mastery of East Asia, it would have to project huge naval and air power far from home. But most of its airplanes, as the authors observe, are based on 1950's and 60's technology -- and even its few new-generation fighter planes have been called "the most highly perfected obsolete aircraft in the world." Forget fighting Japan or the United States. The Chinese Navy would lose a battle against Singapore, Malaysia or Indonesia.
More important, Nathan and Ross emphasize factors other than hardware that constrain China's military influence, pointing to the current "revolution" in technology. The demands placed on the command, control, communications and intelligence capabilities that are required to integrate air, land and naval forces are enormous today and, with the continual advances in information technology, are growing nearly exponentially. The upshot is that the United States has such a jump on China in its ability to conduct modern warfare that America's military preponderance in East Asia will increase, not diminish, in the coming years.
Although Nathan and Ross demolish the most absurd claims of those who see an immediate China threat, by focusing on these extreme arguments they are, in a way, setting up straw men. The more sophisticated hard-line position holds that given its economic dynamism, China could in the long term threaten what Nathan and Ross call East Asia's "balance of power." The authors are surely right that China cannot mount a real challenge to American naval supremacy within anything less than 25 years, but what about after that? Nathan and Ross fail to address this long-range concern.
Actually, the most interesting feature of their argument is not their differences with the hard-liners but their similarities to them. Throughout their book Nathan and Ross assert, echoing the hard-liners and nearly everyone else in the American foreign policy community, that the United States must maintain the so-called balance of power in East Asia. But this begs a question: What balance? As Nathan and Ross make abundantly clear, "the United States possesses strategic superiority throughout Asia." This superiority, they argue, must be sustained, lest the states in the region begin to jockey for power and advantage among themselves, thereby "destabilizing . . . the regional balance of power." But the idea that balance can be achieved through dominance is the contradiction at the heart of American policy.
To Nathan and Ross, as much as to the hard-liners, United States dominance in Asia should continue indefinitely. Yet what America sees as balance can easily be seen by another state as hegemony. While one can agree or disagree with the authors' position, it should not really be surprising if China -- which, like any state, must be concerned more with a competing power's capabilities than with its intentions -- were to use its growing wealth to try to end American dominance in Asia. That Washington would regard as a threat the efforts of the largest and potentially most powerful state in a region to remedy its weak position reveals more about America's ambitions than about China's.

HEADLINE: Endless Trails To Open Water

BYLINE: By BRENDA FOWLER; BRENDA FOWLER contributes to The Times from Chicago.

 BODY:
THE Upper Peninsula of Michigan might as well be an island. Bounded by the broad and chilly waters of Lakes Superior, Huron and Michigan, this isolated arch of peninsula is anchored in the hinterlands of northern Wisconsin on the hem of the United States.
Two bridges lead to its eastern tip; one comes from Canada and the other across the straits of Mackinac from Michigan's lower peninsula. But the stream of traffic they carry seems effortlessly absorbed by vast forests and dispersed by ample swamps, rivers and lakes. The U.P., as people here call it, is as large as Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut and Delaware combined, yet has a population of just over 300,000. 
 Last June, I spent a week with friends at their well-equipped cabin on the shore of Lake Superior several miles east Marquette. During the day, we combed the beach, or hiked in a state park, or visited the little towns and museums along the more than 100 miles of shore between Marquette and Whitefish Bay. I was amazed by the unburdened roads, the beautiful, lonesome sandy beaches and boundless wilderness. My friends, who have spent part of each summer here for decades, told me that tourism increases later in the season, when the lake water warms up to just bearable, but you never see a crowd.
Many people come here for what I think of as hard-core wilderness activities like hunting and fishing. They stay in cabins in the woods, and catch and cook their own food. I noticed many older couples in luxury sedans, usually with two men riding in the front, and two women in the back. The young people I saw were couples with children who drove pickups or mini-vans. There are few night spots apart from bars, and most restaurants serve ordinary food like steak and potatoes for dinner and B.L.T.'s for lunch.
Marquette, an immaculate town of about 22,000 on Lake Superior, is the largest urban center in the U.P. At the turn of the century, the vast iron ranges of the Upper Peninsula were producing much of the iron ore for the nation, and most of it arrived in Marquette by rail and was shipped out through its harbors. Those who got rich off the iron-mining boom of the 19th century built homes out of the local sandstone on the bluff overlooking the docks. The Marquette County Historical Society sells a walking tour guide of these homes in the Arch and Ridge Streets Historic District.
Iron ore remains part of the region's economy. A friendly reference librarian at the Peter White Public Library in Marquette told me that people here joke that watching the loading of the 1,000-foot ore boats at the dock from Presque Isle Park is the best entertainment in town. The park, about a 20-minute walk north of downtown on a pleasant shoreline path shared by bikers and skaters, is an ideal city oasis.
The massive timber ore dock, under which you must pass to reach the park, forms an odd industrial gateway for the serenity of Presque Isle, a small peninsula whose name means "almost an island." Above the dock runs a rail line carrying cars laden with iron ore pellets from the nearby mine at Tilden. The pellets are released into chutes, and when an ore boat arrives, they are then poured down the chute into openings in the top of the tanker. I couldn't see them running down the chute, but I liked the dramatic rumble. The arrival of the ore boats is irregular, but the men in the small house beneath the dock may know when the next one is coming in.
Iron's importance in the development of the U.P. is engagingly explained at the Michigan Iron Industry Museum near Negaunee, eight miles west of Marquette. In the the 19th century, life in this remote and frigid clime did not hold much appeal, and mine work was a job for struggling newcomers. In 1892, an astounding 92 percent of the miners were foreign born; many came from the two poles of Europe, Italy and Finland.
A Finnish contribution to U.P. culture is the sauna, which is still a common fixture in the locals' camps, as they call their weekend cabins. The Italian heritage survives in the thin, tasty sausage known as the cudighi, (pronounced COO-duh-ghee), often eaten like a hamburger, on a bun with ketchup and pickles.
Another local specialty is the pastie (rhymes with nasty), a baked pocket of bread filled with meat or vegetables or both; it was introduced to the region by Cornish miners. They are advertised as if they were national treasures, but two local residents quietly told me they eat the rather bland pasties just once or twice a year, usually in connection with some family ritual.
Fortunately, if you camp or stay at a place with a kitchen, you can easily find good, fresh ingredients. Lake Superior's whitefish and trout are succulent and inexpensive. In Marquette, the best market for fish is Thill's Fish House, downtown right on the bay. One night, we grilled whitefish basted with olive oil, lemon juice and rosemary (I had brought the rosemary from home since fresh herbs were not generally available in the local supermarkets).
Two other native delicacies are blueberries, which ripen in August, and wild mushrooms -- chanterelles and morels -- available from July through the fall. Though these are not usually available in local stores, people who know which mushrooms are safe to eat can hunt them.
The edible thimbleberry, or black raspberry, grows in many clearings, including in Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore, a 35-mile wedge of Superior coastline between Munising and Grand Marais. The area gets its name from variably hued sandstone cliffs that rise several hundred feet out of the blue water. The brown, golden and pink streaks on the rocks come from minerals in the water that have seeped from the ground and stained the cliffs.
Endless trails, including one along the entire reach of Twelvemile Beach, cut through the wilderness, and several lead past waterfalls, like Sable Falls, the 19th-century romantic's paradigm of the waterfall, with a series of winding drops under a canopy of trees. Ten minutes by foot are the Grand Sable Dunes, an undulating landscape of high dunes, which, the informational tablet says, are creeping slowly along the beach, devouring forests as they move.
One day, I went walking in Pictured Rocks with a geologist friend who has been exploring this area since childhood. We had intended to follow a path north of Miners Castle through the piney forest atop the rock cliffs, but somehow we ended up on a barely discernible path along the shore. After 15 minutes of fighting back branches and traversing muddy pools, we emerged on a brilliantly lighted sandstone shelf that ran along the cliffs about 20 feet above the glistening blue water.
The shelf, which at points tilted precariously toward the water, dipped and rose, following the curve of the shore around a bend. We eagerly set out to see how far it would take us. Because the sandstone was so soft, the water had eroded it smoothly, revealing layer after layer of gold- and cream-colored sediments. At points, wading was possible on an inviting shelf a half-foot underwater, and we also found several beautiful spots from which it would have been possible -- if foolhardy -- to dive, Acapulco-style, from natural platforms.
After perhaps a half-mile, the shelf dwindled and the cliff became too steep to continue on. But from there we could hear, from just around a corner in the cliff, the sucking gurgle of a cave or hollow at water level. Until this point, we had seen no one else on the shore or water, but now, from the west, came a pair of kayakers who paddled silently past us and waved. I called to them to check out the cave ahead and they smiled and headed for it.
 THE pictured rocks, as well as the curvy sandstone formations with the inevitable anthropomorphic appellations (like Indian Head Rock), are best seen from the lake. Kayaks can be rented at a few locations on the southern shore, and at one, Northern Waters Adventures, Carl Hansen said that although they can be taken freely into the rivers and smaller lakes, his company requires four hours' training before venturing onto Lake Superior, which can turn stormy in minutes. A less strenuous way to see the cliffs from the water is a two-and-a-half-hour cruise out of Munising. I did not take it, but it was universally praised by passengers I asked.
Superior's moodiness is legendary. The Great Lakes Shipwreck Museum in Whitefish Point documents 300 shipwrecks that claimed 320 lives. The most recent -- and, thanks to the ballad by Gordon Lightfoot, the most famous -- was of the ore-carrying Edmund Fitzgerald, whose crew of 19 perished off Whitefish Point in 1975 in the worst storm anyone in the U.P. can remember. The exact cause of the wreck is not known; a video the museum shows keeps the story mysterious.
For me, the uncelebrated centerpiece of the museum is a nine-foot-wide, lozenge-shaped Fresnel lens. Made in Paris of leaded crystal prisms, it came from one of the lighthouses that still measure this dangerously rocky coastline. The Fresnel lens could modify and amplify a modest light into a life-saving signal visible for more than 28 miles.
I was reminded of the lens late that evening on the beach behind the cabin, where we picked up the rhythmic blink of light from the beacon in Marquette. Then we lit an enormous bonfire, settled into the sand and lay back to watch the stars.
 
Along a rugged coast
 
Places to Stay
Welker's Budget Host, Canal Street, Grand Marais, is on the beach two miles east of Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. Standard rooms are $35 to $55. Through Labor Day, one- and two-bedroom cottages are rented by the week only, for $235 and $310. There is a restaurant, gift shop, indoor pool and sauna; (906) 494-2361.
Big Bay Point Lighthouse Bed and Breakfast, 3 Lighthouse Road, Big Bay, is part of a functioning lighthouse northwest of Marquette, and guests can climb to the top, 120 feet above the water. All seven rooms are nonsmoking and have antique furnishings and spectacular views. Not recommended for children. May through October, $115 to $155 a night; November through April, $85 to $125; (906) 345-9957.
Dandelion Cottage, 440 East Arch Street, Marquette, (906) 228-3322, is in the historic district near the lake. Named after a children's book written in 1904 about the cottage when it was a private residence, the five-room house has been beautifully restored, with each room done in the sugary pastel color specified by the book. The cottage sleeps four and costs $75 on Friday and Saturday, $65 Sunday through Thursday, and $55 a night on a weekly basis.
Marquette Tourist Park, on Sugarloaf Avenue, is an immaculate campground with showers. It has hookups for recreational vehicles for $15 and $17 a night, and tent campsites for $8 a night; (906) 228-0465.
The Helmer House Inn, County Road 417, McMillan, (906) 586-3204, has five quiet, pleasant rooms with shared bath near Manistique Lake, southeast of the Pictured Rocks. Doubles are $50 to $55. A restaurant serves dinner, about $25 for two.
 
Where to Eat
New York Deli and Italian Place, Harlow Block (Front and Washington Streets) in downtown Marquette, (906) 226-3032, has some of the tastiest food in the Upper Peninsula. Picnic lunches are $8.25. The sole main supper selection in the informal dining area with a view of the lake is different each evening. One recent dish was glazed orange chicken with pistachio rice. Supper for two is under $20; no alcoholic beverages.
The Brownstone Inn, on Highway M-28 about two miles west of Au Train, between Munising and Marquette, (906) 892-8332, is a rustic and friendly place. Open for lunch and dinner, with entrees like fresh lake fish or pork chops. Dinner for two with beer is about $25.
Sweet Water Cafe, 517 North Third Street, Marquette, (906) 226-7009, is a large, skylighted room decorated with local artists' works. It has a wide selection of vegetarian dishes, and meat and fish dishes. Dinner for two without wine is about $20.
A good place to try a cudighi ($3.50) is Buck's, 218 Main Street, Ishpeming, west of Marquette; (906) 485-4534. A hearty breakfast for two is not more than $12.
Timber Charlie's, 110 North Newberry Avenue, Newberry, east of McMillan, has great sandwiches. It also serves dinners and has a bar and a homey atmosphere. Lunch for two is about $15; (906) 293-3363.
The Dunes Saloon, at Lake and Grand Marais Streets, in Grand Marais, serves excellent beer brewed on the site by the Lake Superior Brewing Company. Lunch and dinner is served, featuring pizza, whitefish, pasties and ribs. The bar, which doubles as a restaurant, is not smoky in the late afternoon, and even children seem welcome. A sampler of six five-ounce beers is $4.50 and a pitcher is $8. Dinner for two is about $20; (906) 494-2337.
For fresh fish to cook, try Thill's Fish House, at 250 East Main Street, Marquette; (906) 226-9851.
 
Sightseeing
Marquette County Historical Society and Museum, 213 North Front Street, (906) 226-3571, has exhibits on the area, including Indian artifacts. It is open Monday to Friday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and the third Thursday of each month until 9 P.M. Admission is $3, students $1.
Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore has a visitor information center in Munising that is open daily 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., except Sundays in winter; (906) 387-3700.
Pictured Rocks Boat Cruises leave from the city pier in Munising. Fare: $21; ages 6 to 12, $7. For a schedule, call (906) 387-2379.
Great Lakes Shipwreck Museum, 110 Whitefish Point Road, Paradise, (906) 635-1742, is open daily May 15 to Oct. 15, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; admission $6.
Michigan Iron Industry Museum, 73 Forge Road, Negaunee, (906) 475-7857; May through October, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., free.
Kayaks can be rented at Northern Waters Adventures, Bayview Street, off Highway M-28 just west of Munising, (906) 387-2323. Kayaking on Lake Superior requires a four-hour class for $45, after which kayak rental is $35 the first day and $30 for additional days. Wet suits are $8 the first day, $6 thereafter. B. F.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 976 words

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
The Good Buy

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis 

 BODY:
It is difficult to explain the joy to be had from paying too much. I learned about this subtle pleasure a few years ago, when I became surely the first man in America to pay the full sticker price for a new car. The dealer who benefited from this extraordinary act did not exploit me. He is incapable of the aggressive salesmanship for which car dealers are justly notorious. He is maybe the only car dealer in history who forgets to return phone calls from customers who say they are ready to buy. By the ordinary standards of car dealing, he is a flop, a disgrace to the science of manipulating his fellow man.
But this natural reticence is, at least in part, what provoked me to forgo any haggling. In this market-drenched world there are precious few opportunities for sedition. Buying from salesmen who don't know how to sell is one of them. My car dealer may be grotesquely unambitious, but he is nice to his employees, whom he encourages to be as laid-back and happy as he is. Plus, he never tries to fool anyone about anything. I first realized that I didn't want to bargain him down when he asked, "You sure you don't want to negotiate, like everyone else?" 
This man should be encouraged, I thought. The pleasure to be had knowing someone like him exists would far exceed the cost of helping to keep him alive. And it has. Each time I drive by his quiet lot I experience the same satisfaction as a man who has helped to preserve an endangered species. I used what little power I have as a buyer to reward qualities other than those typically rewarded in car dealers; e.g., slickness and efficiency. I am no longer a mere customer. I am a patron.
I am also a fool -- or at least that is how most of the world views people who pay the full sticker price for an automobile. This is just one of many things that is wrong with the world.
Walk into any bookstore and you find walls of texts on salesmanship. The modern world is obsessed with the subject. Three days into almost any job and some wizened character will take you aside and say, "Whatever they tell you, it all comes down to sales." No attention at all is paid to the art of buying. There's Consumer Reports, of course, and other similar references that detail the price and the quality of goods. But there is nothing to suggest the variety of attitudes available to the buyer. Rather, it is simply assumed that the best way to shop is to get the most for the least. That is why I would like to suggest a few tips for the New Enlightened Buyer.
* The New Enlightened Buyer understands that shopping is not a competitive sport. Often you hear people boasting about how they cut the best deal, as if they kicked the winning field goal in the Super Bowl. Enlightened Buyers understand that shopping contains a spiritual, counterintuitive dimension; sometimes you have to lose in order to win. In the same way that a college might admit a student with poor grades and low SAT's because of some special character trait, you might do business with retailers who are a bit more expensive or a tad inefficient out of deference to other qualities -- the appearance of the shop, the spirit of the enterprise, etc. Occasionally, when we are feeling political, we boycott companies we despise. Why not make smaller, less overtly political gestures and reward sellers we approve of?
* The New Enlightened Buyer takes pleasure in making the salesman happy. There is real satisfaction in subverting conventional market behavior. We pretty much assume that the customer enjoys a God-given right to make the salesman miserable, or at least to demand that he thoroughly kowtow to him. ("I paid good money for this fertilizer, and the grass still won't grow and I wanna know what you're going to do about it ... blah, blah, blah.") This retrograde attitude is the cause of no end of unhappiness in the world today. It is the main reason, for instance, that many sales jobs lack dignity. When New Enlightened Buyers see a customer at war with a salesman, they know that the ugliness is probably the customer's fault. Have you ever noticed that the same people forever encounter stupid or dishonest salespeople? Buyers create their own problems.
*Occasionally, New Enlightened Buyers leave themselves open to be taken advantage of. They understand that they'll sometimes stumble upon the genuinely malicious salesman. But more often than not, they will be rewarded for their benevolence and find themselves upgraded on domestic flights and offered free drinks after dinner. And even when they feel maltreated in the marketplace, they can take real pride in improving its standards, in the same way a good driver improves the safety of the road.
*The New Enlightened Buyer ultimately works toward a private system of self-evaluation. Once you become enlightened yourself, you may wish to sit down at the end of the day and ask yourself, "Did I buy well?" The nature of this exercise depends on the circumstances of the buyer. If you are rich, you deserve less credit for paying too much but more credit for putting up with terrible delays. If you are unemployed, you should reward yourself fewer points for waiting around but more credit for overpaying. Special Brownie points go to those who resist the urge to insult especially inept sellers.
Until I codified my new philosophy, I spent a lot of time thinking of devastating remarks to bring the employees of phone companies to their knees. Remarks like, "Are you always this charming, or is this just an especially nice day for you?" or, "We're thinking of switching to tin cans and string." Now I believe that their ineptitude presents me with an opportunity to score points on my self-evaluation sheets. The truly admirable transaction, I now think, is one in which the seller behaved terribly but the buyer somehow made him happy.

HEADLINE: When the Dutch Moved In and the Pequots Managed Trade

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
THE story of Connecticut's settlement is usually told in terms British Colonists versus Indians. Yet well before the British traveled from what is now Massachusetts to the Connecticut River valley, Dutch traders had made their way upriver from Long Island Sound and had established extensive trade, especially with the Pequot tribe.
This chapter in the state's history is the focus of the exhibition "Before New England: The Dutch and Native Americans in the Connecticut River Valley, 1609-1650" at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex. 
 "The concept of the show is the narrow span of time when two cultures met and established a trade relationship that was mutually beneficial and very successful," said Bruce Yenawine, director of the museum. "The denouement came when the governor of the Massachusetts Bay colony decided the relationship was too successful and it was time to move in."
Mr. Yenawine believes that the Dutch have been all but ignored in history books is the pro-British bias of most Colonial historians. The exhibition, organized in cooperation with Emily Stearns, the Museum's curator, is meant to offset some of that.
Displays -- 17th-century maps, ship models, paintings, Dutch and native American artifacts, a full-scale wigwam and a model of the Dutch Fort of Good Hope -- are centered around two life-size color transparencies housed in oversized light boxes, representing a Dutchman and a native American, both in elaborate costumes.
Plymouth Plantation, a living history museum, lent the costumes and provided assistance in research and photography.It also lent the furnishings for the recreation of a room inside a fort -- a table, a three-legged chair, a foot warmer, some swords and muskets -- all original period pieces from the Netherlands.
Early Colonial records describe the Fort of Good Hope as sited on land "extending one league down along the river and one-third of a league in width to the high land" -- the area of Hartford now known as Dutch Point. It was bought in 1633 from the chief sachem of the Pequots, Tatobem, for "one piece of duffels 27 ells long, 6 axes, 6 kettles, 18 knives, 1 sword blade, 1 shears and some toys." In modern terminology, the piece of duffels, or woolen cloth, was 41 feet long.
Because no description of the fort itself was ever found, the exhibit was based on what is known of Fort Orange, the 1624 Dutch fort on the Hudson River at Albany, where earthen and timber battlements enclosed a trading post and other structures. Outside the stockade, the land was farmed and used for grazing livestock and for an orchard.
Dutch explorations in the New World began in 1609, when Henry Hudson -- an English captain recruited by the merchants of Amsterdam -- sailed through New York Bay and up the river that now bears his name. He was followed in 1611 by Adriaen Block, an adventurer and cartographer who made three voyages in as many years, ascending the stream we call the Connecticut -- he named it Versche, or Fresh, river -- as far as today's Hartford and, perhaps, the falls at Enfield.
"In the year 1614," Block later wrote, "our traders had not only traded at the Fresh River but had also ascended it before any English had ever dreamed of going there . . . all the islands, bays, havens, rivers, kills and places . . . have Dutch names, which our Dutch ship-masters and traders gave to them."
It was the fur trade, and especially beaver pelts, that drew the merchants of the Dutch West India Company. Beaver hats became fashionable among Dutchmen of all social classes, along with fur capes, boots, mufflers and trimming for coats.
"Portrait of Rembrandt's Mother," by Gerard Dou (1613-1675), depicts a woman wearing a fur hat and collar as well as fur trimming on the cuffs of her coat.
As for the Pequots -- who conquered other river tribes in the early 1620's -- they were most interested in metal goods. A display features Dutch kettles, buckles, hooks and scissors, which would then be cut up to make points for arrows and spears. Knives, blades, ax heads and other tools were valued for practical uses; pendants, rings and buttons were worn for ceremonial uses or as amulets.
Another exhibit highlights the essential role of wampum in native American life. In its final form, wampum was white or purple beads, cut, shaped and drilled from quahog and whelk shells. The beads had decorative and ceremonial value, and could be used as a means of exchange, with each bead assigned a monetary value.
The market for wampum set up a triangular network: Dutch trade goods exchanged for wampum produced by Connecticut coastal tribes was traded for pelts harvested by Indians in the interior -- the entire transaction managed by the Pequots as middlemen.
"The English wanted the story to be that the Pequots were violent invaders ultimately chased out by other Connecticut River tribes and English settlers," said Mr. Yenawine. "The truth is that the Pequots were very successful partners of the Dutch and managed a trading operation that allowed for important economic development in this region of America."
According to Mr. Yenawine, it was only after the English learned the process of wampum trade from the Dutch -- and after the Pequots were annihilated in 1637 -- that English settlement of the Connecticut Valley became possible. "It was an economic war," Mr. Yenawine said.
In time, the English population grew to such proportions that it posed a constant threat to the small Dutch garrison at the Fort of Good Hope. Finally, at a meeting held in Hartford in 1650, Dutch officials agreed to forfeit their claim to Connecticut.
One of the few remains of four decades of Dutch presence along the river is on display: a small yellow brick, typically used in building chimneys, thought to be from the Fort of Good Hope.
"Before New England" will be on view at the Connecticut River Museum, 67 Main Street, Essex, through November. The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $4, with discounts for children and elderly people.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Before the British, the Dutch were on the scene, trading with the Indians, learning about wigwams and wampum. "Before New England" at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex, left, celebrates that chapter in history. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 290 words

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 1.5 Million Square Feet Downtown Back on Office Market;
2 Broadway to Get A Major Makeover

 BODY:
A nearly vacant building that stood as a symbol of Manhattan's struggling downtown office scene has come back on the rental market, with its owner saying it is confident the time is right to fill it up again.
The 1.6 million-square-foot building at 2 Broadway, at Bowling Green, is to undergo a $100 million makeover designed by Skidmore Owings & Merrill that includes new heating and air-conditioning, an electrical upgrade and renovations of the facade, the lobby and the elevators. 
 The owner, ZAR Realty, which purchased the building in September 1995 for about $21 million, said that about 1.5 million square feet of space was available at rents ranging from the upper $20's to the low $30's a square foot a year.
Several other large vacant or nearly vacant downtown buildings are being converted to residential use, but Frederick J. Contini, ZAR's executive vice president, said that "our feeling ever since we purchased it was that it would be fully commercial."
"We have large blocks of space, and we think the time is right based on the pent-up demand in the marketplace for large amounts of space," Mr. Contini said. "That, plus Mayor Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan, which gives tax breaks to encourage development, should attract tenants."
The building, which once housed back-office operations for large Wall Street brokerage firms, was put up by the Uris family in 1958 during an economic rebirth of Wall Street.
It was later owned by Olympia & York, which sold it as part of its bankruptcy.
Mr. Contini said that about 100,000 square feet of the building was occupied. The Williams Real Estate Company has been retained as the exclusive leasing agent.
"We can do immediate deals," Mr. Contini said.
